Title: Preamble
Original_Description:
WE, THE PEOPLE OF INDIA, having solemnly resolved to constitute India into a SOVEREIGN SOCIALIST SECULAR DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC and to secure to all its citizens: JUSTICE, social, economic and political; LIBERTY of thought, expression, belief, faith and worship;
EQUALITY of status and of opportunity; and to promote among them all FRATERNITY assuring the dignity of the individual and the unity and integrity of the Nation; IN OUR CONSTITUENT ASSEMBLY this twenty-sixth day of November, 1949, do HEREBY ADOPT, ENACT AND GIVE TO OURSELVES THIS CONSTITUTION
Simplified_Description: The Constitution of India was passed on November 26, 1949. It was the first constitution of the Indian National Congress party.
Subject: Preamble
Key_Points: Declares India as a Sovereign, Socialist, Secular, Democratic Republic.
Aims to secure Justice, Liberty, Equality for all citizens.
Promotes Fraternity to ensure the dignity of the individual and the unity and integrity of the nation.
Identifies the source of authority of the Constitution as 'WE, THE PEOPLE OF INDIA'.
Specifies the date of adoption as November 26, 1949.
Historical_Context: The Preamble is based on the 'Objectives Resolution', drafted and moved by Jawaharlal Nehru on December 13, 1946, and adopted by the Constituent Assembly. It was amended once by the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976, which added three new words—Socialist, Secular, and Integrity.
Landmark_Cases: Berubari Union case (1960): The Supreme Court held that the Preamble is not a part of the Constitution and thus not enforceable in a court of law.

Kesavananda Bharati vs State of Kerala (1973): The Supreme Court overturned its earlier decision and held that the Preamble is a part of the Constitution and can be amended, but its 'basic features' cannot be altered.
LIC of India case (1995): The Supreme Court again held that the Preamble is an integral part of the Constitution.
Related_Articles: Part IV (Directive Principles of State Policy)

Title: Name and territory of the Union
Original_Description:
(1) India, that is Bharat, shall be a Union of States.

 

(2) The States and the territories thereof shall be as specified in the First Schedule.

 

(3) The territory of India shall comprise —

(a) the territories of the States;

(b) the Union territories specified in the First Schedule; and

(c) such other territories as may be acquired.
Simplified_Description: India is a Union of States. The territory of India shall comprise the territories of the States.
Subject: Union & Its Territory
Key_Points: Declares the official names of the country: India and Bharat.
Describes India as a 'Union of States', not a 'Federation of States', indicating that states do not have the right to secede.
Defines the territory of India, which includes States, Union Territories, and any territories that may be acquired in the future.
The names of the States and Union Territories and their territorial extent are mentioned in the First Schedule of the Constitution.
Historical_Context: The term 'Union of States' was deliberately chosen by the framers of the Constitution to emphasize the indivisibility of the country. This was crucial in the context of the integration of more than 500 princely states into India after independence.
Landmark_Cases: The article itself has not been a major subject of judicial interpretation, but cases related to Article 3 (Formation of new States) often refer back to the concept of India as a 'Union of States'.
Related_Articles: Article 2 (Admission or establishment of new States)
Article 3 (Formation of new States and alteration of areas, boundaries or names of existing States)
First Schedule (Lists the States and Union Territories of India)

Title: Admission or establishment of new States
Original_Description: Parliament may by law admit into the Union, or establish, new States on such terms and conditions as it thinks fit.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may by law admit into the Union, or establish, new States on such terms and conditions as it thinks fit.
Subject: Union & Its Territory
Key_Points: Grants power to the Parliament to admit new states into the Union of India.
Grants power to the Parliament to establish new states.
This power relates to the admission or establishment of states that are not currently part of the Indian territory.
Parliament can determine the terms and conditions for such admission or establishment.
Historical_Context: This article was used to integrate territories that were not part of India at the time of independence. For example, the former French and Portuguese colonies like Pondicherry and Goa were integrated. Sikkim was admitted as a state in 1975 through the 36th Constitutional Amendment Act.
Landmark_Cases: In re Berubari Union (1960): The case dealt with the power of Parliament to cede territory to another country and discussed the scope of acquiring foreign territories.
Related_Articles: Article 3 (Formation of new States and alteration of areas...)

Title: Formation of new States and alteration of areas, boundaries or names of existing States
Simplified_Description: Parliament may by law form a new State by separation of territory from any State or by uniting two or more States or parts of States. Parliament may also increase the area of any State; diminish the area; alter the boundaries; and alter the name of any state. No Bill for the purpose shall be introduced in either House of Parliament except on recommendation of the President.
Subject: Union & Its Territory
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to reorganize the states internally.
Parliament can form new states, alter boundaries, change names of existing states by a simple majority.
A bill for such changes can only be introduced on the President's recommendation.
The President must refer the bill to the concerned state legislature for its views, but Parliament is not bound by these views.
Highlights the flexible and unitary nature of the Indian federation, famously described as 'an indestructible union of destructible states'.
Historical_Context: This article is one of the most widely used articles. It was instrumental in the linguistic reorganisation of states in 1956 based on the recommendations of the States Reorganisation Commission. It has since been used for the creation of numerous new states, including Gujarat (1960), Nagaland (1962), Haryana (1966), and more recently, Chhattisgarh, Uttarakhand, Jharkhand (2000), and Telangana (2014). It was also used in 2019 to reorganize Jammu & Kashmir into two Union Territories.
Landmark_Cases: Babulal Parate vs State of Bombay (1960): The Supreme Court clarified that Parliament is not bound by the views of the state legislatures and can proceed with the reorganization even if the state opposes it.
Related_Articles: Article 1 (Name and territory of the Union)
Article 2 (Admission or establishment of new States)

Title: Laws made under articles 2 and 3 to provide for the amendment of the First and the Fourth Schedules and supplemental, incidental and consequential matters
Original_Description:
(1) Any law referred to in article 2 or article 3 shall contain such provisions for the amendment of the First Schedule and the Fourth Schedule as may be necessary to give effect to the provisions of the law and may also contain such supplemental, incidental and consequential provisions (including provisions as to representation in Parliament and in the Legislature or Legislatures of the State or States affected by such law) as Parliament may deem necessary.

 

(2) No such law as aforesaid shall be deemed to be an amendment of this Constitution for the purposes of article 368.
Simplified_Description: The law may also contain such supplemental, incidental and consequential provisions (including provisions as to representation in Parliament and in the Legislature or Legislatures of the State or States affected by such law) as Parliament may deem necessary.
Subject: Union & Its Territory
Key_Points: Clarifies the procedure for laws made under Articles 2 and 3.
States that any law altering state boundaries or creating new states must also amend the First Schedule (list of states and UTs) and the Fourth Schedule (allocation of seats in Rajya Sabha).
Crucially, it declares that such laws are not to be considered constitutional amendments under Article 368.
This means state reorganization can be done through a simple majority in Parliament, rather than the special majority required for constitutional amendments.
Historical_Context: This article was designed to provide flexibility to the Union Parliament to reorganize the country's internal political map without having to go through the rigid process of a constitutional amendment. This has enabled the relatively smooth creation and alteration of states over the past 70 years.
Landmark_Cases: While Article 4 itself is procedural, its interpretation has been discussed in cases concerning Article 3, such as the Berubari Union case, where the court distinguished between altering boundaries (under Art 3) and ceding territory (requiring an amendment under Art 368).
Related_Articles: Article 2 (Admission or establishment of new States)
Article 3 (Formation of new States and alteration of areas...)
Article 368 (Power of Parliament to amend the Constitution)

Title: Citizenship at the commencement of the Constitution
Original_Description:
At the commencement of this Constitution, every person who has his domicile in the territory of India and —

       

        (a) who was born in the territory of India; or

        (b) either of whose parents was born in the territory of India; or

        (c) who has been ordinarily resident in the territory of India for not less than five years immediately preceding such commencement,

 

shall be a citizen of India.
Simplified_Description: At the commencement of this Constitution, every person who has his domicile in the territory of India and who was born in India shall be a citizen of India.
Subject: Citizenship
Key_Points: Defines who was considered a citizen of India on January 26, 1950.
It lays down three conditions, any one of which must be met, along with having domicile in India.
The conditions are: birth in India, either parent born in India, or being ordinarily resident in India for five years before commencement.
This article only deals with citizenship at the commencement and does not cover acquisition or loss of citizenship thereafter.
Historical_Context: This article, along with Articles 6, 7, and 8, was framed in the immediate aftermath of the Partition of India, which caused large-scale migration. These articles were designed to settle the question of citizenship for people who were living in India at the time of its independence and the commencement of the constitution.
Landmark_Cases: Pradeep Jain vs Union of India (1984): The Supreme Court discussed the concept of 'domicile' in India, clarifying that India has only a single domicile.
D.P. Joshi vs State of Madhya Bharat (1955): Explored the meaning of 'domicile' and its relevance for constitutional provisions.
Related_Articles: The Citizenship Act, 1955 (governs citizenship after the commencement of the Constitution)

Title: Rights of citizenship of certain persons who have migrated to India from Pakistan
Original_Description:
Notwithstanding anything in article 5, a person who has migrated to the territory of India from the territory now included in Pakistan shall be deemed to be a citizen of India at the commencement of this Constitution if —

 

      (a) he or either of his parents or any of his grandparents was born in India as defined in the Government of India Act, 1935 (as originally enacted); and

   

      (b)  (i) in the case where such person has so migrated before the nineteenth day of July, 1948, he has been ordinarily resident in the territory of India since the date of his migration, or

         

            (ii) in the case where such person has so migrated on or after the nineteenth day of July, 1948, he has been registered as a citizen of India by an officer appointed in that behalf by the Government      of the Dominion of India on an application made by him therefor to such officer before the commencement of this Constitution in the form and manner prescribed by that Government:

 

Provided that no person shall be so registered unless he has been resident in the territory of India for at least six months immediately preceding the date of his application.
Simplified_Description: A person who has migrated to the territory of India from the territory now included in Pakistan shall be deemed to be a citizen of India at the commencement of this Constitution. A person is a citizen if he or either of his parents or any of his grandparents was born in India.
Subject: Citizenship
Key_Points: Deals with the citizenship of persons who migrated from Pakistan to India.
Sets a cut-off date: July 19, 1948, the date when the permit system for migration was introduced.
Those who migrated before this date became citizens if they were ordinarily resident in India since their migration.
Those who migrated on or after this date had to register as citizens after residing in India for at least six months.
Historical_Context: This is a specific provision created to address the massive influx of population from Pakistan to India due to the Partition in 1947. It provided a clear legal framework for granting citizenship to these migrants.
Landmark_Cases: Shanno Devi vs Mangal Sain (1961): The Supreme Court interpreted the term 'migration' in this article not merely as moving from one place to another but as moving with the intention of permanently residing in the new location.

Title: Rights of citizenship of certain migrants to Pakistan
Original_Description:
Notwithstanding anything in articles 5 and 6, a person who has after the first day of March, 1947, migrated from the territory of India to the territory now included in Pakistan shall not be deemed to be a citizen of India:

 

Provided that nothing in this article shall apply to a person who, after having so migrated to the territory now included in Pakistan, has returned to the territory of India under a permit for resettlement or permanent return issued by or under the authority of any law and every such person shall for the purposes of clause (b) of article 6 be deemed to have migrated to the territory of India after the nineteenth day of July, 1948.
Simplified_Description: A person who has after the first day of March, 1947, migrated from the territory of India to the territory now included in Pakistan shall not be deemed to be a citizen of India. A person who returned to India under a permit for resettlement or permanent return issued by or under the authority of any law is deemed to have migrated after July 1948.
Subject: Citizenship
Key_Points: Deals with persons who migrated from India to Pakistan after March 1, 1947.
States that such persons shall not be considered citizens of India.
Provides an exception for those who returned to India under a permit for resettlement or permanent return.
Such returning persons were subject to the same conditions as those who migrated after July 19, 1948, under Article 6.
Historical_Context: This article addressed the complex situation of people who left India for Pakistan during Partition but later wished to return. It prevented automatic loss of citizenship for those who came back under an official permit, recognizing the chaotic circumstances of the time.
Landmark_Cases: State of Bihar vs Kumar Amar Singh (1955): This case dealt with a woman who had gone to Pakistan after March 1, 1947. The court held that her migration led to the loss of her Indian citizenship under Article 7.

Title: Rights of citizenship of certain persons of Indian origin residing outside India
Original_Description: Notwithstanding anything in article 5, any person who or either of whose parents or any of whose grandparents was born in India as defined in the Government of India Act, 1935 (as originally enacted), and who is ordinarily residing in any country outside India as so defined shall be deemed to be a citizen of India if he has been registered as a citizen of India by the diplomatic or consular representative of India in the country where he is for the time being residing on an application made by him therefor to such diplomatic or consular representative, whether before or after the commencement of this Constitution, in the form and manner prescribed by the Government of the Dominion of India or the Government of India
Simplified_Description: Any person who or either of his parents or any of his grandparents was born in India as defined in the Government of India Act, 1935 (as originally enacted), and who is ordinarily residing in any country outside India as so defined shall be deemed to be a citizen of India.
Subject: Citizenship
Key_Points: Confers citizenship rights on Persons of Indian Origin (PIOs) residing outside undivided India.
A person is eligible if they, their parents, or their grandparents were born in undivided India.
Such a person could become an Indian citizen by registering with the Indian diplomatic mission in their country of residence.
This provision applied to those living abroad at the time of the Constitution's commencement.
Historical_Context: This article was included to acknowledge the large Indian diaspora and provide them with a path to Indian citizenship, recognizing their ties to the motherland. It was a way of including those who were outside the territory of India but had strong ancestral connections.
Landmark_Cases: This article is relatively straightforward and has not been the subject of major constitutional litigation.
Related_Articles: Provisions of the Citizenship Act, 1955 related to Overseas Citizenship of India (OCI).

Title: Persons voluntarily acquiring citizenship of a foreign State not to be citizens
Original_Description: No person shall be a citizen of India by virtue of article 5, or be deemed to be a citizen of India by virtue of article 6 or article 8, if he has voluntarily acquired the citizenship of any foreign State.
Simplified_Description: No person shall be a citizen of India by virtue of article 5, if he has voluntarily acquired the citizenship of any foreign State.
Subject: Citizenship
Key_Points: Establishes the principle that India does not permit dual citizenship.
A person automatically ceases to be an Indian citizen if they voluntarily acquire the citizenship of another country.
This provision overrides the citizenship granted under Articles 5, 6, and 8.
The determination of whether citizenship was acquired voluntarily is made by the Central Government.
Historical_Context: The framers of the Constitution made a conscious decision to disallow dual citizenship to ensure undivided allegiance to India. This principle has been consistently upheld and is a fundamental aspect of Indian citizenship law.
Landmark_Cases: Izhar Ahmad Khan vs Union of India (1962): The Supreme Court upheld the power of the Central Government under the Citizenship Act, 1955, to determine if a person has voluntarily acquired foreign citizenship.

Title: Continuance of the rights of citizenship
Original_Description: Every person who is or is deemed to be a citizen of India under any of the foregoing provisions of this Part shall, subject to the provisions of any law that may be made by Parliament, continue to be such citizen.
Simplified_Description: Every person who is deemed to be a citizen of India under any of the foregoing provisions of this Part shall, subject to the provisions of any law that may be made by Parliament, continue to be such citizen.
Subject: Citizenship
Key_Points: Guarantees the continuance of citizenship for those who were citizens at the commencement of the Constitution.
This continuance is subject to laws made by the Parliament.
It links the constitutional provisions of citizenship with future parliamentary legislation on the matter.
Historical_Context: This article acts as a bridge, ensuring that the citizenship status established by Articles 5-8 is not temporary and will continue, while simultaneously empowering the future Parliament to legislate on all matters relating to citizenship, including its termination.
Landmark_Cases: This article is typically read along with Article 11 and the Citizenship Act, 1955, in cases concerning the termination of citizenship.
Related_Articles: Article 11 (Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship by law)

Title: Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship by law
Original_Description: Nothing in the foregoing provisions of this Part shall derogate from the power of Parliament to make any provision with respect to the acquisition and termination of citizenship and all other matters relating to citizenship
Simplified_Description: Nothing in the foregoing provisions of this Part shall derogate from the power of Parliament to make any provision with respect to the acquisition and termination of citizenship.
Subject: Citizenship
Key_Points: Grants exclusive power to the Parliament to make laws regarding citizenship.
This power covers acquisition, termination, and all other matters related to citizenship.
The provisions in Articles 5 to 10 are not exhaustive and do not limit Parliament's legislative power.
Parliament has enacted the Citizenship Act, 1955, under the authority of this article.
Historical_Context: The Constituent Assembly recognized that citizenship laws would need to evolve over time. Instead of embedding detailed and rigid citizenship rules into the Constitution, they provided a framework for citizenship at the commencement and gave the future Parliament the full authority to legislate on this dynamic subject.
Landmark_Cases: This article serves as the constitutional basis for the Citizenship Act, 1955, and its subsequent amendments, which have been the subject of numerous legal challenges and public debates.

Title: Definitions
Original_Description: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, “the State’’ includes the Government and Parliament of India and the Government and the Legislature of each of the States and all local or other authorities within the territory of India or under the control of the Government of India
Simplified_Description: “The State’’ includes the Government and Parliament of India and the Government of each of the States and all local or other authorities within the territory.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Defines the term 'State' for the purpose of Part III (Fundamental Rights) and Part IV (Directive Principles).
The definition is inclusive and very broad.
It includes the executive and legislative branches of the Union and State governments.
It also includes all local authorities (municipalities, panchayats) and 'other authorities'.
Fundamental Rights are enforceable against these bodies.
Historical_Context: The broad definition of 'State' was intended to ensure that the fundamental rights of individuals are protected not just against the actions of the central and state governments, but also against a wide range of public bodies and authorities that exercise governmental or quasi-governmental functions.
Landmark_Cases: R.D. Shetty vs International Airport Authority (1979): The Supreme Court laid down tests to determine whether a body is an 'agency or instrumentality' of the state and thus falls under 'other authorities'.

Ajay Hasia vs Khalid Mujib (1981): Further refined the tests, confirming that bodies like government companies and registered societies that are functionally, financially and administratively dominated by the government are 'State'.
Related_Articles: Article 226 (Power of High Courts to issue certain writs)
Article 36 (Definition of State for Part IV)

Title: Laws inconsistent with or in derogation of the fundamental rights
Original_Description:
(1) All laws in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, in so far as they are inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall, to the extent of such inconsistency, be void.

 

(2) The State shall not make any law which takes away or abridges the rights conferred by this Part and any law made in contravention of this clause shall, to the extent of the contravention, be void.

 

(3) In this article, unless the context otherwise requires,—

       (a) “law” includes any Ordinance, order, bye-law, rule, regulation, notification, custom or usage having in the territory of India the force of law;

       (b) “laws in force” includes laws passed or made by a Legislature or other competent authority in the territory of India before the commencement of this Constitution and not previously repealed, notwithstanding that any such law or any part thereof may not be then in operation either at all or in particular areas. 

 

(4) Nothing in this article shall apply to any amendment of this Constitution made under article 368
Simplified_Description: All laws in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, in so far as they are inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall be void. The State shall not make any law which takes away or abridges the rights conferred by this Part.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Establishes the supremacy of Fundamental Rights over all laws.
Declares that any pre-constitutional law inconsistent with Fundamental Rights is void.
Prohibits the State from making any law that takes away or abridges Fundamental Rights.
Gives teeth to the Fundamental Rights and is the basis for the power of judicial review.
Defines 'law' broadly to include ordinances, orders, bye-laws, rules, regulations, notifications, and even customs or usages having the force of law.
Historical_Context: This article is the cornerstone of judicial review in India. It establishes a check on the legislative and executive powers of the government. The question of whether 'law' under Article 13(2) includes constitutional amendments led to a long-standing tussle between the Parliament and the judiciary, culminating in the Kesavananda Bharati case.
Landmark_Cases: A.K. Gopalan vs State of Madras (1950): First major case interpreting fundamental rights.

Kesavananda Bharati vs State of Kerala (1973): Established the 'basic structure doctrine', holding that while Parliament can amend any part of the Constitution (including Fundamental Rights), it cannot alter its basic structure. This case resolved the conflict over the scope of Article 13 and Article 368.
Related_Articles: Article 226 (Power of High Courts to issue writs)
Article 368 (Power of Parliament to amend the Constitution)

Title: Equality before law
Original_Description: The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.
Simplified_Description: The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Guarantees two concepts: 'equality before the law' (a negative concept from English law) and 'equal protection of the laws' (a positive concept from the US Constitution).
This right is available to all persons, citizens and non-citizens alike.
It prohibits unreasonable discrimination but allows for 'reasonable classification' based on intelligible differentia with a rational nexus to the object sought to be achieved.
Modern interpretation holds that arbitrariness is the antithesis of equality.
Historical_Context: This fundamental right is the bedrock of the Indian constitutional framework, aimed at establishing a society free from arbitrary discrimination. Its interpretation has evolved from a narrow, formal view to a more substantive one that strikes at arbitrariness in state action.
Landmark_Cases: E.P. Royappa vs State of Tamil Nadu (1974): The Supreme Court held that 'Equality is a dynamic concept with many aspects and dimensions and it cannot be cribbed, cabined and confined within traditional and doctrinaire limits.' It introduced the doctrine that arbitrariness violates Article 14.
Maneka Gandhi vs Union of India (1978): The principle of reasonableness was held to be an essential element of equality.
National Legal Services Authority (NALSA) vs Union of India (2014): Affirmed the rights of transgender persons, recognizing them as a third gender and ensuring their equal protection under the law.
Related_Articles: Article 16 (Equality of opportunity in public employment)
Article 21 (Protection of life and personal liberty)

Title: Prohibition of discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth
Original_Description:
(1) The State shall not discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them.

 

(2) No citizen shall, on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them, be subject to any disability, liability, restriction or condition with regard to—

     (a) access to shops, public restaurants, hotels and places of public entertainment; or

     (b) the use of wells, tanks, bathing ghats, roads and places of public resort maintained wholly or partly out of State funds or dedicated to the use of the general public.

 

(3) Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from making any special provision for women and children.

 

(4) Nothing in this article or in clause (2) of article 29 shall prevent the State from making any special provision for the advancement of any socially and educationally backward classes of citizens or for the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes.

 

(5) Nothing in this article or in sub-clause (g) of clause (1) of article 19 shall prevent the State from making any special provision, by law, for the advancement of any socially and educationally backward classes of citizens or for the Scheduled Castes or the Scheduled Tribes in so far as such special provisions relate to their admission to educational institutions including private educational institutions, whether aided or unaided by the State, other than the minority educational institutions referred to in clause (1) of article 30.

 

(6) Nothing in this article or sub-clause (g) of clause (1) of article 19 or clause (2) of article 29 shall prevent the State from making,—

     (a) any special provision for the advancement of any economically weaker sections of citizens other than the classes mentioned in clauses (4) and (5); and

     (b) any special provision for the advancement of any economically weaker sections of citizens other than the classes mentioned in clauses (4) and (5) in so far as such special provisions relate to their admission to educational institutions including private educational institutions, whether aided or unaided by the State, other than the minority educational institutions referred to in clause (1) of article 30, which in the case of reservation would be in addition to the existing reservations and subject to a maximum of ten per cent. of the total seats in each category.

     Explanation.—For the purposes of this article and article 16, "economically weaker sections" shall be such as may be notified by the State from time to time on the basis of family income and other indicators of economic disadvantage.
Simplified_Description: The State shall not discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them. No citizen shall be subject to any disability, liability, restriction or condition with regard to shops, public restaurants, hotels and places of public entertainment.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Prohibits the State from discriminating against citizens on grounds ONLY of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth.
Also prohibits private individuals from discriminating in access to public places like shops, restaurants, wells, and roads.
Allows the state to make special provisions for women and children (affirmative action).
Allows the state to make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes of citizens, Scheduled Castes, and Scheduled Tribes.
Subsequent amendments have added provisions for reservation in educational institutions and for economically weaker sections (EWS).
Historical_Context: This article was drafted to combat the deeply entrenched social discrimination prevalent in Indian society, particularly the caste system. The exceptions for affirmative action were included to enable the state to take positive steps to uplift historically disadvantaged groups. The article has been amended multiple times (1st, 93rd, 103rd Amendments) to expand the scope of these special provisions.
Landmark_Cases: State of Madras vs Champakam Dorairajan (1951): This case led to the First Amendment, which added clause (4) to Article 15 to allow for special provisions for backward classes.
Indra Sawhney vs Union of India (1992): While primarily about Article 16, it extensively discussed the scope of special provisions for backward classes.
Ashok Kumar Thakur vs Union of India (2008): Upheld the 93rd Amendment Act, which allowed the government to make reservations for OBCs in educational institutions.
Related_Articles: Article 16 (Equality of opportunity in public employment)
Article 29(2) (Prohibition of denial of admission to educational institutions on certain grounds)
Article 46 (Promotion of educational and economic interests of weaker sections)

Title: Equality of opportunity in matters of public employment
Original_Description:
(1) There shall be equality of opportunity for all citizens in matters relating to employment or appointment to any office under the State.

 

(2) No citizen shall, on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, residence or any of them, be ineligible for, or discriminated against in respect of, any employment or office under the State.

 

(3) Nothing in this article shall prevent Parliament from making any law prescribing, in regard to a class or classes of employment or appointment to an office under the Government of, or any local or other authority within, a State or Union territory, any requirement as to residence within that State or Union territory] prior to such employment or appointment.

 

(4) Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from making any provision for the reservation of appointments or posts in favour of any backward class of citizens which, in the opinion of the State, is not adequately represented in the services under the State.

 

(4A) Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from making any provision for reservation in matters of promotion, with consequential seniority, to any class] or classes of posts in the services under the State in favour of the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes which, in the opinion of the State, are not adequately represented in the services under the State.

 

(4B) Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from considering any unfilled vacancies of a year which are reserved for being filled up in that year in accordance with any provision for reservation made under clause (4) or clause (4A) as a separate class of vacancies to be filled up in any succeeding year or years and such class of vacancies shall not be considered together with the vacancies of the year in which they are being filled up for determining the ceiling of fifty per cent. reservation on total number of vacancies of that year.

 

(5) Nothing in this article shall affect the operation of any law which provides that the incumbent of an office in connection with the affairs of any religious or denominational institution or any member of the governing body thereof shall be a person professing a particular religion or belonging to a particular denomination.

 

(6) Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from making any provision for the reservation of appointments or posts in favour of any economically weaker sections of citizens other than the classes mentioned in clause (4), in addition to the existing reservation and subject to a maximum of ten per cent. of the posts in each category.
Simplified_Description: There shall be equality of opportunity for all citizens in matters relating to employment or appointment to any office under the State. No citizen shall, on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, residence or any of them, be ineligible for, or discriminated against.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Guarantees equality of opportunity for all citizens in public employment.
Prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, or residence.
Allows Parliament to prescribe residence as a condition for certain employment (exception to the general rule).
Permits the state to provide for the reservation of appointments or posts in favour of any backward class of citizens not adequately represented in state services.
Includes provisions for reservation in promotions and for economically weaker sections (EWS).
Historical_Context: This article aims to create a level playing field in public employment, a key area of opportunity in India. The provision for reservations has been a subject of intense debate and judicial scrutiny since the Constitution's inception. It has been amended several times (e.g., 77th, 81st, 85th, 103rd Amendments) to clarify and expand the scope of reservations in promotions, carry-forward rules for vacancies, and EWS quotas.
Landmark_Cases: Indra Sawhney vs Union of India (1992) ('Mandal Commission Case'): The Supreme Court upheld reservations for OBCs but laid down several conditions, including the 'creamy layer' concept and a 50% ceiling on total reservations.
M. Nagaraj vs Union of India (2006): Upheld the constitutional validity of amendments providing for reservation in promotions but imposed stringent conditions for its implementation by the state.
Related_Articles: Article 335 (Claims of SCs and STs to services and posts)

Title: Abolition of Untouchability
Original_Description: “Untouchability” is abolished and its practice in any form is forbidden. The enforcement of any disability arising out of “Untouchability” shall be an offence punishable in accordance with law.
Simplified_Description: “Untouchability” is abolished and its practice in any form is forbidden. The enforcement of any disability arising out of ‘Untouchable’ shall be an
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Abolishes 'Untouchability' in all its forms.
Makes the practice of untouchability a punishable offense.
It is one of the few Fundamental Rights that is also available against private individuals, not just the state.
The term 'untouchability' is not defined in the Constitution but is understood in its historical context of social disabilities imposed on certain classes of people.
Historical_Context: This article was a revolutionary step to eradicate the deeply inhuman and discriminatory social practice of untouchability, which was a blight on Indian society for centuries. To enforce this article, Parliament has enacted laws like the Protection of Civil Rights Act, 1955, and the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989.
Landmark_Cases: People’s Union for Democratic Rights vs Union of India (1982): The court held that the rights under Article 17 are enforceable against private individuals and it is the constitutional duty of the State to take necessary steps to ensure that these rights are not violated.
Related_Articles: Article 23 (Prohibition of traffic in human beings and forced labour)

Title: Abolition of titles
Original_Description:
(1) No title, not being a military or academic distinction, shall be conferred by the State.

 

(2) No citizen of India shall accept any title from any foreign State.

 

(3) No person who is not a citizen of India shall, while he holds any office of profit or trust under the State, accept without the consent of the President any title from any foreign State.

 

(4) No person holding any office of profit or trust under the State shall, without the consent of the President, accept any present, emolument, or office of any kind from or under any foreign State.
Simplified_Description: No title, not being a military or academic distinction, shall be conferred by the State. No citizen of India shall accept any title from any foreign State.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Prohibits the State from conferring any titles, except military and academic distinctions.
Prohibits Indian citizens from accepting titles from any foreign state.
Restricts non-citizens holding an office of profit under the state from accepting titles from a foreign state without the President's consent.
Prevents any person holding an office of profit from accepting presents, emoluments, or offices from a foreign state without the President's consent.
Historical_Context: This article was included to promote social equality and prevent the creation of a formal aristocracy, which was a feature of the British colonial regime (e.g., titles like 'Rai Bahadur', 'Khan Bahadur'). It aims to ensure that merit and achievement (academic/military) are the only grounds for distinction, not hereditary or granted status.
Landmark_Cases: Balaji Raghavan vs Union of India (1996): The Supreme Court upheld the validity of National Awards like Bharat Ratna, Padma Vibhushan, etc., holding that they are not 'titles' within the meaning of Article 18. However, it directed that they should not be used as prefixes or suffixes to the awardees' names.

Title: Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech, etc
Simplified_Description: All citizens shall have the right to freedom of speech and expression. Nothing in sub-clause (a) of clause (1) shall affect the operation of any existing law, or prevent the State from making any law.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Guarantees six fundamental freedoms to all citizens: speech and expression, assembly, association, movement, residence, and profession.
These rights are not absolute and can be subjected to 'reasonable restrictions' by the state.
The grounds for restrictions are specified in clauses (2) to (6) of Article 19, such as sovereignty and integrity of India, security of the State, public order, decency, morality, etc.
Freedom of the press is implicitly included under the freedom of speech and expression.
Historical_Context: Article 19 is the heart of the fundamental rights, guaranteeing the basic freedoms that are essential for a functioning democracy. The balance between individual liberty and the need for social control is managed through the concept of 'reasonable restrictions', which has been a frequent subject of judicial interpretation.
Landmark_Cases: Romesh Thappar vs State of Madras (1950): Emphasized the importance of freedom of the press for a democratic society.
Shreya Singhal vs Union of India (2015): Struck down Section 66A of the Information Technology Act, 2000, as it violated the freedom of speech and expression.
Related_Articles: Article 21 (Protection of life and personal liberty)

Title: Protection in respect of conviction for offences
Original_Description:
(1) No person shall be convicted of any offence except for violation of a law in force at the time of the commission of the Act charged as an offence, nor be subjected to a penalty greater than that which might have been inflicted under the law in force at the time of the commission of the offence.

 

(2) No person shall be prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once.

 

(3) No person accused of any offence shall be compelled to be a witness against himself.
Simplified_Description: No person shall be prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once. No person accused of any offence shall be compelled to be a witness against himself.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Provides three types of protection for individuals accused of crimes:
1. Protection against ex-post-facto laws: A person cannot be convicted or given a higher penalty for an act that was not an offense at the time of its commission.
2. Protection against double jeopardy: A person cannot be prosecuted and punished for the same offense more than once.
3. Protection against self-incrimination: An accused person cannot be forced to be a witness against themselves.
Historical_Context: This article embodies fundamental principles of criminal jurisprudence that are recognized in many democratic legal systems. It ensures that criminal law is not applied retrospectively and protects individuals from state coercion during criminal investigations and trials. These protections are absolute and cannot be suspended even during an emergency.
Landmark_Cases: Nandini Satpathy vs P.L. Dani (1978): The Supreme Court expanded the scope of the right against self-incrimination, holding that it applies not only during trial but also during the investigation stage.
Selvi vs State of Karnataka (2010): The court held that involuntary administration of narco-analysis, polygraph tests, and brain mapping violates the right against self-incrimination.
Related_Articles: Article 21 (Protection of life and personal liberty)

Title: Protection of life and personal liberty
Original_Description: No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.
Simplified_Description: No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Guarantees the right to life and personal liberty to all persons (citizens and non-citizens).
Deprivation of these rights is only possible through a 'procedure established by law'.
The Supreme Court has interpreted this to mean the procedure must be fair, just, and reasonable (Due Process of Law).
It has been interpreted expansively to include the right to live with human dignity, right to privacy, right to education, right to a clean environment, and many other unenumerated rights.
Historical_Context: Initially, in the A.K. Gopalan case, the Supreme Court took a narrow view, stating that 'procedure established by law' only meant that a validly enacted law was sufficient to deprive a person of their liberty. However, this was completely overturned in the Maneka Gandhi case, which imported the American concept of 'due process' into Article 21, making it the most potent and dynamic fundamental right in the Constitution.
Landmark_Cases: A.K. Gopalan vs State of Madras (1950): Adopted a narrow interpretation of Article 21.
Maneka Gandhi vs Union of India (1978): Revolutionized the interpretation of Article 21, holding that the procedure must be 'right, just and fair' and not arbitrary, fanciful or oppressive.
K.S. Puttaswamy vs Union of India (2017): The Supreme Court declared the Right to Privacy as a fundamental right intrinsic to life and personal liberty under Article 21.
Related_Articles: Article 19 (Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech, etc)

Title: Right to education
Original_Description: The State shall provide free and compulsory education to all children of the age of six to fourteen years in such manner as the State may, by law, determine.
Simplified_Description: The State shall provide free and compulsory education to all children of the age of six to 14 years. The State may, by law, determine.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Makes free and compulsory education a Fundamental Right for all children between the ages of 6 and 14.
Mandates the State to provide this education.
The manner of provision is to be determined by law made by the State.
This right is a result of a constitutional amendment, not part of the original constitution.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 86th Constitutional Amendment Act, 2002. It was a landmark step to make education a fundamental right. Before this amendment, the right to education was a Directive Principle under Article 45. The Parliament enacted the Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education (RTE) Act, 2009 to give effect to this article.
Landmark_Cases: Mohini Jain vs State of Karnataka (1992) and Unni Krishnan, J.P. vs State of Andhra Pradesh (1993): In these cases, even before the 86th Amendment, the Supreme Court had held that the right to education is a fundamental right that flows from the Right to Life under Article 21.
Related_Articles: Article 21 (Protection of life and personal liberty)
Article 45 (Provision for early childhood care and education to children below the age of six years)
Article 51A(k) (Fundamental duty of parents/guardians to provide education)

Title: Protection against arrest and detention in certain cases
Original_Description:
(1) No person who is arrested shall be detained in custody without being informed, as soon as may be, of the grounds for such arrest nor shall he be denied the right to consult, and to be defended by, a legal practitioner of his choice.

 

(2) Every person who is arrested and detained in custody shall be produced before the nearest magistrate within a period of twenty-four hours of such arrest excluding the time necessary for the journey from the place of arrest to the court of the magistrate and no such person shall be detained in custody beyond the said period without the authority of a magistrate.

 

(3) Nothing in clauses (1) and (2) shall apply—

 

(a) to any person who for the time being is an enemy alien; or

(b) to any person who is arrested or detained under any law providing for preventive detention.

 

(4) No law providing for preventive detention shall authorise the detention of a person for a longer period than three months unless—

 

(a) an Advisory Board consisting of persons who are, or have been, or are qualified to be appointed as, Judges of a High Court has reported before the expiration of the said period of three months that there is in its opinion sufficient cause for such detention:

Provided that nothing in this sub-clause shall authorise the detention of any person beyond the maximum period prescribed by any law made by Parliament under sub-clause (b) of clause (7); or

(b) such person is detained in accordance with the provisions of any law made by Parliament under subclauses (a) and (b) of clause (7).

 

(5) When any person is detained in pursuance of an order made under any law providing for preventive detention, the authority making the order shall, as soon as may be, communicate to such person the grounds on which the order has been made and shall afford him the earliest opportunity of making a representation against the order.

 

(6) Nothing in clause (5) shall require the authority making any such order as is referred to in that clause to disclose facts which such authority considers to be against the public interest to disclose.

 

(7) Parliament may by law prescribe—


(a) the circumstances under which, and the class or classes of cases in which, a person may be detained for a period longer than three months under any law providing for preventive detention without obtaining the opinion of an Advisory Board in accordance with the provisions of sub-clause (a) of clause (4);

(b) the maximum period for which any person may in any class or classes of cases be detained under any law providing for preventive detention; and

(c) the procedure to be followed by an Advisory Board in an inquiry under sub-clause (a) of clause (4).
Simplified_Description: No person who is arrested shall be detained in custody without being informed of the grounds for such arrest nor shall he be denied the right to consult, and to be defended by, a legal practitioner of his choice. Nothing in clauses (1) and (2) shall apply to any person who for the time being is an enemy alien.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Provides procedural safeguards for persons arrested under ordinary law (punitive detention).
These include the right to be informed of the grounds of arrest, the right to consult a lawyer, and the right to be produced before a magistrate within 24 hours.
Also deals with preventive detention (detention without trial).
Specifies that preventive detention cannot exceed three months unless an Advisory Board finds sufficient cause.
These protections are not available to enemy aliens or persons arrested under preventive detention laws.
Historical_Context: This article was a subject of considerable debate in the Constituent Assembly. While recognizing the need for procedural safeguards against arbitrary arrest, the framers also included provisions for preventive detention, viewing it as a necessary evil to deal with threats to national security and public order. This dual nature makes Article 22 unique.
Landmark_Cases: D.K. Basu vs State of West Bengal (1997): The Supreme Court laid down detailed guidelines to be followed by police during arrest and detention to prevent custodial violence and protect the rights of the arrested person.
Related_Articles: Article 20 (Protection in respect of conviction for offences)
Article 21 (Protection of life and personal liberty)

Title: Prohibition of traffic in human beings and forced labour
Original_Description:
(1) Traffic in human beings and begar and other similar forms of forced labour are prohibited and any contravention of this provision shall be an offence punishable in accordance with law.

 

(2) Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from imposing compulsory service for public purposes, and in imposing such service the State shall not make any discrimination on grounds only of religion, race, caste or class or any of them
Simplified_Description: Traffic in human beings and begar and other similar forms of forced labour are prohibited. Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from imposing compulsory service for public purposes.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Prohibits trafficking in human beings, 'begar' (forced labour without payment), and other forms of forced labour.
Makes these practices a punishable offense.
This right is available against both the State and private individuals.
Allows the state to impose compulsory service for public purposes (e.g., military service or social service), provided it does not discriminate on grounds of religion, race, caste, or class.
Historical_Context: This article was enacted to combat feudal practices like 'begar' and social evils like devadasi system and slavery, which were prevalent in many parts of India. It represents a commitment to uphold human dignity and protect the vulnerable from exploitation.
Landmark_Cases: People’s Union for Democratic Rights vs Union of India (1982) (Asiad Workers' Case): The Supreme Court gave a wide interpretation to the term 'forced labour'. It held that paying less than the minimum wage also amounts to forced labour.
Sanjit Roy vs State of Rajasthan (1983): Held that the state cannot pay less than minimum wage even for work done during a famine or drought, as it would violate Article 23.
Related_Articles: Article 24 (Prohibition of employment of children in factories, etc.)
Article 39 (Certain principles of policy to be followed by the State)

Title: Prohibition of employment of children in factories, etc
Original_Description: No child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment
Simplified_Description: No child below the age of 14 years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Prohibits the employment of children below the age of 14 years.
This prohibition applies to factories, mines, and any other hazardous employment.
This is an absolute prohibition, with no exceptions.
It is a right against exploitation.
Historical_Context: This article was framed to tackle the widespread problem of child labour in India and to ensure that children are protected from hazardous work and have the opportunity to grow and receive an education. It complements other laws like the Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act, 1986, and the Right to Education Act, 2009.
Landmark_Cases: M.C. Mehta vs State of Tamil Nadu (1996): The Supreme Court issued extensive directions to eradicate child labour, including the creation of a Child Labour Rehabilitation Welfare Fund.
Related_Articles: Article 39(e) and (f) (Directive Principles concerning the health of children and protection from exploitation)

Title: Freedom of conscience and free profession, practice and propagation of religion
Original_Description:
(1) Subject to public order, morality and health and to the other provisions of this Part, all persons are equally entitled to freedom of conscience and the right freely to profess, practise and propagate religion.

 

(2) Nothing in this article shall affect the operation of any existing law or prevent the State from making any law—

(a) regulating or restricting any economic, financial, political or other secular activity which may be associated with religious practice;

(b) providing for social welfare and reform or the throwing open of Hindu religious institutions of a public character to all classes and sections of Hindus.

 

Explanation I.—The wearing and carrying of kirpans shall be deemed to be included in the profession of the Sikh religion.

 

Explanation II.—In sub-clause (b) of clause (2), the reference to Hindus shall be construed as including a reference to persons professing the Sikh, Jaina or Buddhist religion, and the reference to Hindu religious institutions shall be construed accordingly.
Simplified_Description: All persons are equally entitled to freedom of conscience and the right freely to profess, practise and propagate religion. Nothing in this article shall affect the operation of any existing law or prevent the State from making any law.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Guarantees to all persons the freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate religion.
This right is subject to public order, morality, and health.
The State is permitted to regulate or restrict secular activities (economic, financial, political) associated with religious practice.
The State can make laws for social welfare and reform, including throwing open Hindu religious institutions to all sections of Hindus.
The right to propagate does not include the right to forcibly convert.
Historical_Context: In a multi-religious country like India, guaranteeing freedom of religion was essential. This article establishes the secular character of the Indian state, ensuring that individuals are free to follow their faith while also allowing the state to intervene for social reform and to regulate non-religious activities associated with religion.
Landmark_Cases: Rev. Stanislaus vs State of Madhya Pradesh (1977): The Supreme Court held that the right to propagate religion does not include the right to convert another person, as that would impinge on the other person's 'freedom of conscience'.

Indian Young Lawyers Association vs State of Kerala (2018) (Sabarimala Case): The court held that the exclusion of women of a certain age group from the Sabarimala temple was unconstitutional, as it violated the principles of equality and religious freedom.
Related_Articles: Article 27 (Freedom as to payment of taxes for promotion of any particular religion)
Article 28 (Freedom as to attendance at religious instruction)

Title: Freedom to manage religious affairs
Simplified_Description: Every religious denomination or any section thereof shall have the right to establish and maintain institutions for religious and charitable purposes.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Grants rights to religious denominations (groups), as opposed to Article 25 which grants rights to individuals.
Every religious denomination has the right to establish and maintain religious institutions, manage its own religious affairs, own and acquire property, and administer such property by law.
This right is also subject to public order, morality, and health.
The state can regulate the administration of property but not the 'matters of religion'.
Historical_Context: This article protects the collective autonomy of religious groups, allowing them to manage their institutions and affairs without undue state interference. It balances the individual's freedom of religion (Art 25) with the group's right to manage its affairs.
Landmark_Cases: The Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras vs Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt (1954) (Shirur Mutt case): The Supreme Court defined what constitutes a 'religious denomination' and distinguished between essential 'matters of religion' (which the state cannot interfere with) and secular administration of property (which the state can regulate).
Related_Articles: Article 25 (Freedom of conscience and free profession...)
Article 30 (Right of minorities to establish and administer educational institutions)

Title: Freedom as to payment of taxes for promotion of any particular religion
Original_Description: No person shall be compelled to pay any taxes, the proceeds of which are specifically appropriated in payment of expenses for the promotion or maintenance of any particular religion or religious denomination
Simplified_Description: No person shall be compelled to pay any taxes, the proceeds of which are specifically appropriated in payment of expenses for the promotion or maintenance of any particular religion or religious denomination.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Prohibits the state from compelling any person to pay taxes for the promotion of a particular religion.
This means that public funds collected through taxes cannot be used to support any specific religion.
It upholds the secular nature of the state by ensuring financial neutrality towards all religions.
The article prohibits taxes, but not fees. Fees can be levied to cover the administrative costs of regulating religious institutions.
Historical_Context: This provision is a cornerstone of Indian secularism, preventing the establishment of a state-sponsored religion funded by taxpayers' money. It ensures that the state remains separate from the financial promotion of any particular faith.
Landmark_Cases: Shirur Mutt case (1954): The Supreme Court distinguished between a 'tax' and a 'fee'. It held that if the state collects a fee for providing a service (like regulating religious endowments), it is not a tax and is permissible under Article 27.
Related_Articles: Article 25 (Freedom of conscience and free profession...)
Article 28 (Freedom as to attendance at religious instruction)

Title: Freedom as to attendance at religious instruction or religious worship in certain educational institutions
Original_Description:
(1) No religious instruction shall be provided in any educational institution wholly maintained out of State funds.

 

(2) Nothing in clause (1) shall apply to an educational institution which is administered by the State but has been established under any endowment or trust which requires that religious instruction shall be imparted in such institution.

 

(3) No person attending any educational institution recognised by the State or receiving aid out of State funds shall be required to take part in any religious instruction that may be imparted in such institution or to attend any religious worship that may be conducted in such institution or in any premises attached thereto unless such person or, if such person is a minor, his guardian has given his consent thereto.
Simplified_Description: No religious instruction shall be provided in any educational institution wholly maintained out of State funds. Nothing in clause (1) shall apply to an educational institution which is administered by the State but is established under any endowment or trust.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Prohibits religious instruction in educational institutions wholly maintained by state funds.
Allows religious instruction in institutions established under a trust or endowment, even if administered by the State.
In institutions recognized by the state or receiving state aid, attendance at religious instruction is voluntary; consent is required.
For minors, the consent of their guardian is necessary.
This article seeks to maintain the secular character of state-funded education.
Historical_Context: This article reflects the framers' intent to keep state-run education secular, while respecting the autonomy of institutions established for religious purposes. It balances the state's secular duties with the rights of religious communities and individuals.
Landmark_Cases: D.A.V. College vs State of Punjab (1971): The court dealt with the question of what constitutes 'religious instruction' and the extent to which academic study of religion or philosophy could be part of the curriculum.
Related_Articles: Article 25 (Freedom of conscience and free profession...)
Article 30 (Right of minorities to establish and administer educational institutions)

Title: Protection of interests of minorities
Original_Description:
(1) Any section of the citizens residing in the territory of India or any part thereof having a distinct language, script or culture of its own shall have the right to conserve the same.

 

(2) No citizen shall be denied admission into any educational institution maintained by the State or receiving aid out of State funds on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language or any of them.
Simplified_Description: No citizen shall be denied admission into any educational institution maintained by the State on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language or any of them.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Protects the cultural and educational rights of minorities.
Guarantees the right of any section of citizens with a distinct language, script, or culture to conserve it.
Prohibits discrimination in admission to state-maintained or state-aided educational institutions on grounds of religion, race, caste, or language.
Clause (1) applies to both minorities and majorities, as 'any section of citizens' is used.
Historical_Context: In a diverse country like India, protecting the unique identity of various cultural and linguistic groups was a priority. This article ensures that minorities can preserve their heritage and that access to state-funded education is open to all, without discrimination.
Landmark_Cases: St. Xaviers College vs State of Gujarat (1974): The Supreme Court interpreted the scope of this article along with Article 30, emphasizing the importance of preserving the distinct identity of minorities.
Related_Articles: Article 30 (Right of minorities to establish and administer educational institutions)

Title: Right of minorities to establish and administer educational institutions
Original_Description:
(1) All minorities, whether based on religion or language, shall have the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice.

 

(1A) In making any law providing for the compulsory acquisition of any property of an educational institution established and administered by a minority referred to in clause (1), the State shall ensure that the amount fixed by or determined under such law for the acquisition of such property is such as would not restrict or abrogate the right guaranteed under that clause.

 

(2) The State shall not, in granting aid to educational institutions, discriminate against any educational institution on the ground that it is under the management of a minority, whether based on religion or language.
Simplified_Description: All minorities, whether based on religion or language, shall have the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Grants all religious and linguistic minorities the right to establish and administer their own educational institutions.
The choice of the institution is left to the minority group.
Prohibits the state from discriminating against minority-managed institutions when granting aid.
This right ensures that minorities can preserve their culture and language through education.
Historical_Context: This article was specifically designed to give minorities a sense of security and confidence. It empowers them to run their own educational institutions, which is crucial for the preservation and promotion of their distinct culture, language, and script.
Landmark_Cases: T.M.A. Pai Foundation vs State of Karnataka (2002): A landmark 11-judge bench judgment that extensively clarified the scope of the rights of minorities under Article 30, dealing with issues of admission, fees, and government regulation in minority institutions.

Title: Compulsory acquisition of property
Original_Description: [Compulsory acquisition of property.] Rep. by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978, s. 6 (w.e.f. 20-6-1979).
Simplified_Description: The Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978, s. 6 (w.e.f.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: This article, which originally guaranteed the Right to Property, has been repealed.
It is no longer a Fundamental Right.
The Right to Property now exists as a constitutional/legal right under Article 300A.

The repeal means the state can acquire private property for public purpose by authority of law, and it is no longer a fundamental right violation that can be directly challenged in the Supreme Court under Article 32.
Historical_Context: The Right to Property was one of the most contentious articles in the Constitution. It was seen as a hurdle to socialist and land reform policies. It was amended several times and was the subject of numerous court cases, including the famous Kesavananda Bharati case. Ultimately, the 44th Amendment Act, 1978, removed it from the list of Fundamental Rights to give the state more power for socio-economic reforms.
Landmark_Cases: Kesavananda Bharati vs State of Kerala (1973): This case, which established the basic structure doctrine, was centered around the conflict between the right to property and Parliament's power to amend the Constitution to implement land reforms.
Related_Articles: Article 300A (Persons not to be deprived of property save by authority of law)
Article 31A, 31B, 31C (Exceptions to fundamental rights, related to property)

Title: Saving of laws providing for acquisition of estates, etc
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything contained in article 13, no law providing for—

(a) the acquisition by the State of any estate or of any rights therein or the extinguishment or modification of any such rights, or

(b) the taking over of the management of any property by the State for a limited period either in the public interest or in order to secure the proper management of the property, or

(c) the amalgamation of two or more corporations either in the public interest or in order to secure the proper management of any of the corporations, or

(d) the extinguishment or modification of any rights of managing agents, secretaries and treasurers, managing directors, directors or managers of corporations, or of any voting rights of shareholders thereof, or

(e) the extinguishment or modification of any rights accruing by virtue of any agreement, lease or licence for the purpose of searching for, or winning, any mineral or mineral oil, or the premature termination or cancellation of any such agreement, lease or licence,

 

shall be deemed to be void on the ground that it is inconsistent with, or takes away or abridges any of the rights conferred by [article 14 or article 19:

 

Provided that where such law is a law made by the Legislature of a State, the provisions of this article shall not apply thereto unless such law, having been reserved for the consideration of the President, has received his assent:

Provided further that where any law makes any provision for the acquisition by the State of any estate and where any land comprised therein is held by a person under his personal cultivation, it shall not be lawful for the State to acquire any portion of such land as is within the ceiling limit applicable to him under any law for the time being in force or any building or structure standing thereon or appurtenant thereto, unless the law relating to the acquisition of such land, building or structure, provides for payment of compensation at a rate which shall not be less than the market value thereof.

 

(2) In this article,—

(a) the expression ''estate'' shall, in relation to any local area, have the same meaning as that expression or its local equivalent has in the existing law relating to land tenures in force in that area and shall also include—

(i) any jagir, inam or muafi or other similar grant and in the States of Tamil Nadu and Kerala, any janmam right;

(ii) any land held under ryotwari settlement;

(iii) any land held or let for purposes of agriculture or for purposes ancillary thereto, including waste land, forest land, land for pasture or sites of buildings and other structures occupied by cultivators of land, agricultural labourers and village artisans;

(b) the expression ''rights'', in relation to an estate, shall include any rights vesting in a proprietor, subproprietor, under-proprietor, tenure-holder, 1 [raiyat, under-raiyat] or other intermediary and any rights or privileges in respect of land revenue.
Simplified_Description: No law providing for the acquisition by the State of any estate or of any rights therein or the extinguishment or modification of any such rights, shall be deemed to be void on the ground that it is inconsistent with, or takes away or abridges any of the rights conferred by.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Saves certain laws from being challenged on the grounds that they violate the fundamental rights under Articles 14 and 19.
The protected laws relate to the acquisition of estates and related rights by the state (agrarian reform), taking over management of properties, amalgamation of corporations, etc.
It is an exception to the supremacy of fundamental rights.
Laws made by a state legislature under this article require the President's assent.
Historical_Context: This article was introduced by the 1st Constitutional Amendment Act, 1951, to protect land reform and zamindari abolition laws from being struck down by courts. The judiciary had been invalidating these laws as they violated the fundamental right to property. Article 31A was created to immunize these socio-economic reform legislations from judicial review on certain grounds.
Landmark_Cases: Waman Rao vs Union of India (1981): The Supreme Court held that amendments to the Constitution made before the Kesavananda Bharati judgment (April 24, 1973) were valid, but those made after that date could be challenged if they violated the basic structure of the Constitution.
Related_Articles: Article 31B (Validation of certain Acts and Regulations)
Article 31C (Saving of laws giving effect to certain directive principles)
Article 14, 19 (Rights which are restricted by this article)

Title: Validation of certain Acts and Regulations
Original_Description: Without prejudice to the generality of the provisions contained in article 31A, none of the Acts and Regulations specified in the Ninth Schedule nor any of the provisions thereof shall be deemed to be void, or ever to have become void, on the ground that such Act, Regulation or provision is inconsistent with, or takes away or abridges any of the rights conferred by, any provisions of this Part, and notwithstanding any judgment, decree or order of any court or Tribunal to the contrary, each of the said Acts and Regulations shall, subject to the power of any competent Legislature to repeal or amend it, continue in force.
Simplified_Description: None of the Acts and Regulations specified in the Ninth Schedule nor any of the provisions thereof shall be deemed to be void, or ever to have become void.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Creates the Ninth Schedule of the Constitution.
States that any law placed in the Ninth Schedule cannot be challenged in court for violating any of the Fundamental Rights.
It provides a 'protective umbrella' or blanket immunity to laws placed within it.
However, the Supreme Court has ruled that this immunity is not absolute.
Historical_Context: Like Article 31A, this was also introduced by the 1st Constitutional Amendment Act, 1951, to protect land reform laws. The government's intention was to create a list of laws that would be completely immune from judicial review. Over the years, the Ninth Schedule grew to include laws on various other subjects, not just land reform.
Landmark_Cases: I.R. Coelho vs State of Tamil Nadu (2007): In a landmark judgment, the Supreme Court ruled that laws placed in the Ninth Schedule after April 24, 1973 (the date of the Kesavananda Bharati judgment) are open to judicial review if they violate the 'basic structure' of the Constitution, including the fundamental rights that form part of the basic structure.
Related_Articles: Article 31A (Saving of laws providing for acquisition of estates, etc)

Title: Saving of laws giving effect to certain directive principles
Original_Description:
Notwithstanding anything contained in article 13, no law giving effect to the policy of the State towards securing 4 [all or any of the principles laid down in Part IV] shall be deemed to be void on the ground that it is inconsistent with, or takes away or abridges any of the rights conferred by article 14 or article 19 and no law containing a declaration that it is for giving effect to such policy shall be called in question in any court on the ground that it does not give effect to such policy:

 

Provided that where such law is made by the Legislature of a State, the provisions of this article shall not apply thereto unless such law, having been reserved for the consideration of the President, has received his assent.
Simplified_Description: No law giving effect to the policy of the State towards securing 4 [all or any of the principles laid down in Part IV] shall be deemed to be void on the ground that it is inconsistent with, or takes away, or abridges, any rights conferred by article 14 or article 19. Provided that where such law is made by the Legislature of a State, the provisions of
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Aims to give primacy to Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSP) over certain Fundamental Rights.
It states that a law made to implement DPSPs under Article 39(b) and 39(c) cannot be challenged for violating the fundamental rights under Articles 14 or 19.
The 42nd Amendment expanded its scope to include all DPSPs, but the Supreme Court struck down this expansion.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 25th Amendment Act, 1971, to further the socialist agenda and ensure that laws aimed at reducing concentration of wealth and distributing resources could not be struck down by citing violation of equality or freedoms. It intensified the conflict between Fundamental Rights and Directive Principles.
Landmark_Cases: Kesavananda Bharati vs State of Kerala (1973): The court upheld the validity of the first part of Article 31C but struck down the second part, which barred judicial review of whether the law actually gave effect to the directive principles.
