Minerva Mills vs Union of India (1980): The Supreme Court struck down the expansion of Article 31C made by the 42nd Amendment, holding that the 'harmony and balance between fundamental rights and directive principles is an essential feature of the basic structure of the Constitution'.
Related_Articles: Part IV (Directive Principles of State Policy)

Title: Saving of laws in respect of anti-national activities
Original_Description: [Saving of laws in respect of anti-national activities.] Rep. by the Constitution (Forty-third Amendment) Act, 1977, s. 2 (w.e.f. 13-4-1978).
Simplified_Description: The Constitution (Forty-third Amendment) Act, 1977, s. 2 (w.e.f. 13-4-
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: This article has been repealed and is no longer part of the Constitution.
It was introduced to save laws made to prevent or prohibit 'anti-national activities' from being challenged for violating Articles 14, 19, and 31.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the highly controversial 42nd Amendment Act, 1976, during the Emergency. It gave the government sweeping powers to make laws against 'anti-national activities', a term which was very broadly defined. The article was quickly repealed by the 43rd Amendment Act, 1977, by the Janata Party government that came to power after the Emergency was lifted.
Landmark_Cases: Not applicable as the article was repealed shortly after its introduction.

Title: Remedies for enforcement of rights conferred by this Part
Original_Description:
(1) The right to move the Supreme Court by appropriate proceedings for the enforcement of the rights conferred by this Part is guaranteed.

 

(2) The Supreme Court shall have power to issue directions or orders or writs, including writs in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari, whichever may be appropriate, for the enforcement of any of the rights conferred by this Part.

 

(3) Without prejudice to the powers conferred on the Supreme Court by clauses (1) and (2), Parliament may by law empower any other court to exercise within the local limits of its jurisdiction all or any of the powers exercisable by the Supreme Court under clause (2).

 

(4) The right guaranteed by this article shall not be suspended except as otherwise provided for by this Constitution.
Simplified_Description: The Supreme Court shall have power to issue writs in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, quo warranto and certiorari, whichever may be appropriate. The right guaranteed by this article shall not be suspended.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Guarantees the right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.
It is itself a Fundamental Right, described by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar as the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution.
Empowers the Supreme Court to issue five types of writs: Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Certiorari, and Quo Warranto.
This right cannot be suspended except as provided by the Constitution (e.g., during an emergency under Article 359).
Historical_Context: The framers wanted to ensure that the Fundamental Rights were not mere declarations but were effectively enforceable. Article 32 provides a direct and guaranteed remedy, making the Supreme Court the protector and guarantor of Fundamental Rights.
Landmark_Cases: L. Chandra Kumar vs Union of India (1997): The Supreme Court held that the power of judicial review of the High Courts under Article 226 and the Supreme Court under Article 32 is a basic feature of the Constitution and cannot be taken away by a constitutional amendment.
Related_Articles: Article 226 (Similar power of High Courts to issue writs)
Article 359 (Suspension of the enforcement of the rights during emergencies)

Title: Constitutional validity of State laws not to be considered in proceedings under article 32
Original_Description: [Constitutional validity of State laws not to be considered in proceedings under article 32.] Rep. by the Constitution (Forty-third Amendment) Act, 1977, s. 3 (w.e.f. 13-4-1978).
Simplified_Description: State laws not to be considered in proceedings under article 32. Constitution (Forty-third Amendment) Act, 1977, s. 3 (w.e.f
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: This article has been repealed and is no longer part of the Constitution.
It sought to curtail the power of the Supreme Court under Article 32 by preventing it from considering the constitutional validity of state laws in writ proceedings.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976, during the Emergency, as part of a series of changes aimed at reducing the power of the judiciary. The idea was that only High Courts should first examine the validity of state laws. This provision was seen as an attack on the judiciary's power and was repealed by the 43rd Amendment Act, 1977, soon after the Emergency.
Landmark_Cases: Not applicable as the article was short-lived.

Title: Power of Parliament to modify the rights conferred by this Part in their application to Forces, etc
Original_Description:
Parliament may, by law, determine to what extent any of the rights conferred by this Part shall, in their application to,—

(a) the members of the Armed Forces; or

(b) the members of the Forces charged with the maintenance of public order; or

(c) persons employed in any bureau or other organisation established by the State for purposes of intelligence or counter intelligence; or

(d) person employed in, or in connection with, the telecommunication systems set up for the purposes of any Force, bureau or organisation referred to in clauses (a) to (c),

 

be restricted or abrogated so as to ensure the proper discharge of their duties and the maintenance of discipline among them.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may, by law, determine to what extent any of the rights conferred by this Part shall, in their application, be restricted or abrogated.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to restrict or abrogate the Fundamental Rights of members of the Armed Forces, paramilitary forces, police forces, intelligence agencies, and analogous forces.
The objective is to ensure the proper discharge of their duties and the maintenance of discipline.
The power to make such laws rests exclusively with the Parliament, not state legislatures.
Any law made under this article cannot be challenged on the ground of violating Fundamental Rights.
Historical_Context: This article acknowledges the special nature of services responsible for national security and public order. It recognizes that the need for discipline and operational efficiency in these forces may require a restriction of certain fundamental rights (like freedom of speech, forming unions, etc.) that are available to ordinary citizens.
Landmark_Cases: The laws enacted under this article, like the Army Act, 1950, have been challenged, but the courts have generally upheld the restrictions as long as they are for maintaining discipline and ensuring proper discharge of duties.
Related_Articles: Article 19 (Freedoms which are often restricted for armed forces)

Title: Restriction on rights conferred by this Part while martial law is in force in any area
Original_Description: Notwithstanding anything in the foregoing provisions of this Part, Parliament may by law indemnify any person in the service of the Union or of a State or any other person in respect of any act done by him in connection with the maintenance or restoration of order in any area within the territory of India where martial law was in force or validate any sentence passed, punishment inflicted, forfeiture ordered or other act done under martial law in such area.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may indemnify any person in the service of the Union or of a State or any other person in respect of any act done by him.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Restricts Fundamental Rights when martial law is in force in any area.
Empowers Parliament to indemnify (protect from legal liability) any government servant or other person for acts done to maintain or restore order in an area under martial law.
Parliament can also validate any sentence passed or punishment inflicted under martial law.
The term 'martial law' is not defined in the Constitution but implies military rule.
Historical_Context: This is an extraordinary provision that allows Parliament to suspend ordinary law and protect actions taken by authorities during a period of military rule. Martial law has not been declared in India so far, though some laws like the Armed Forces (Special Powers) Act (AFSPA) have been criticized for creating conditions akin to it.
Landmark_Cases: Naga People's Movement of Human Rights vs. Union of India (1998): While dealing with AFSPA, the court drew a distinction between a 'Proclamation of Emergency' and 'martial law'.
Related_Articles: Article 33 (Modification of rights for armed forces)

Title: Legislation to give effect to the provisions of this Part
Original_Description:
Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution,—

(a) Parliament shall have, and the Legislature of a State shall not have, power to make laws—

(i) with respect to any of the matters which under clause (3) of article 16, clause (3) of article 32, article 33 and article 34 may be provided for by law made by Parliament; and

(ii) for prescribing punishment for those acts which are declared to be offences under this Part;

(b) any law in force immediately before the commencement of this Constitution in the territory of India with respect to any of the matters referred to in sub-clause (i) of clause (a) or providing for punishment for any act referred to in sub-clause (ii) of that clause shall, subject to the terms thereof and to any adaptations and modifications that may be made therein under article 372, continue in force until altered or repealed or amended by Parliament.

 

Explanation.—In this article, the expression “law in force” has the same meaning as in article 372.
Simplified_Description: Parliament shall have, and the Legislature of a State shall not have, power to make laws. The expression “law in force” has the same meaning as in article 372.
Subject: Fundamental Rights
Key_Points: Gives exclusive power to the Parliament (and not state legislatures) to make laws on certain specific matters related to Fundamental Rights.

These matters include prescribing residence requirements for public employment (Art 16), empowering courts other than the Supreme Court and High Courts to issue writs (Art 32), restricting rights of armed forces personnel (Art 33), and indemnifying acts during martial law (Art 34).
Also gives Parliament exclusive power to prescribe punishment for offenses under Part III (e.g., untouchability under Article 17, forced labour under Article 23).
Historical_Context: This article ensures uniformity across the country in laws related to certain crucial aspects of fundamental rights and their enforcement. By vesting this power exclusively in the Parliament, it prevents states from creating differing standards on these important issues.
Landmark_Cases: This is a power-conferring article and is generally cited in conjunction with the articles it refers to (16, 32, 33, 34, 17, 23).

Title: Definition
Original_Description: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, “the State” has the same meaning as in Part III.
Simplified_Description: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, ‘the State’ has the same meaning as in Part III.
Subject: Directive Principles
Key_Points: Defines the term 'The State' for the purposes of Part IV (Directive Principles of State Policy).
It explicitly states that the definition of 'State' is the same as the one provided in Article 12 for Part III (Fundamental Rights).
This means the directives apply to all governmental and public authorities at the central, state, and local levels.
Historical_Context: By using the same definition as in Part III, the framers intended that the moral and political obligations laid down in the Directive Principles should be binding on the same wide array of public bodies that are legally bound by the Fundamental Rights. It creates a consistent framework for governance.
Landmark_Cases: The interpretation of 'State' in cases under Article 12, such as R.D. Shetty vs International Airport Authority (1979) and Ajay Hasia vs Khalid Mujib (1981), are equally applicable here.
Related_Articles: Article 12 (Definition of 'The State' for Fundamental Rights)

Title: Application of the principles contained in this Part
Original_Description: The provisions contained in this Part shall not be enforceable by any court, but the principles therein laid down are nevertheless fundamental in the governance of the country and it shall be the duty of the State to apply these principles in making laws.
Simplified_Description: The provisions contained in this Part shall not be enforceable by any court. The principles therein laid down are nevertheless fundamental in the governance of the country. It shall be the duty of the State to apply these principles in making laws.
Subject: Directive Principles
Key_Points: Explicitly states that the Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSP) are non-justiciable, meaning they cannot be enforced by courts.
Despite being non-justiciable, it declares them as 'fundamental in the governance of the country'.
Imposes a duty on the State to apply these principles while formulating policies and enacting laws.
Historical_Context: The framers created DPSPs as a set of ideals and goals for the newly independent nation. They were made non-justiciable because the nascent state lacked the financial resources to implement them all at once. However, their 'fundamental' nature was emphasized to create a moral obligation on future governments to work towards these socio-economic goals.
Landmark_Cases: State of Madras vs Champakam Dorairajan (1951): The Supreme Court held that Fundamental Rights would prevail over DPSPs in case of a conflict.

Minerva Mills vs Union of India (1980): The Court held that the harmony and balance between Fundamental Rights and Directive Principles is an essential feature of the 'basic structure' of the Constitution.
Related_Articles: Article 32 (Remedies for enforcement of Fundamental Rights)

Title: State to secure a social order for the promotion of welfare of the people
Original_Description:
(1)The State shall strive to promote the welfare of the people by securing and protecting as effectively as it may a social order in which justice, social, economic and political, shall inform all the institutions of the national life.

 

(2) The State shall, in particular, strive to minimise the inequalities in income, and endeavour to eliminate inequalities in status, facilities and opportunities, not only amongst individuals but also amongst groups of people residing in different areas or engaged in different vocations.
Simplified_Description: The State shall strive to promote the welfare of the people by securing and protecting as effectively as it may a social order in which justice, social, economic and political, shall inform all the institutions of the national life.
Subject: Directive Principles
Key_Points: Directs the state to build a social order based on justice (social, economic, and political).
Aims to promote the welfare of the people.
Mandates the state to strive to minimize inequalities in income, status, facilities, and opportunities.
This article encapsulates the idea of a 'welfare state'.
Historical_Context: This article reflects the socialist ideals of the framers. It aims to address the vast socio-economic inequalities prevalent in India. Clause (2) was added by the 44th Amendment Act, 1978, to explicitly state the goal of reducing inequalities, reinforcing the state's commitment to social and economic justice.
Landmark_Cases: This principle is often cited by courts to interpret laws in a way that promotes social welfare and reduces inequality. It serves as a guiding principle for legislative and executive action.
Related_Articles: Preamble (which also mentions Justice, social, economic and political)
Article 39 (Certain principles of policy to be followed by the State)

Title: Certain principles of policy to be followed by the State
Simplified_Description: The State shall, in particular, direct its policy towards securing the right to an adequate means of livelihood. The ownership and control of the material resources of the community are so distributed as best to subserve the common good.
Subject: Directive Principles
Key_Points: Lays down specific policy goals for the state.
Includes right to an adequate means of livelihood for all citizens.
Distribution of material resources for the common good.
Prevention of concentration of wealth.
Equal pay for equal work for men and women.
Protection of health of workers, and protection of children and youth against exploitation.
Historical_Context: This article contains key socialist principles intended to guide India's economic and social policy. Clauses (b) and (c) have been the constitutional basis for many nationalization and land reform laws. The principle of 'equal pay for equal work' has been a vital tool for gender justice in the workplace.
Landmark_Cases: Randhir Singh vs Union of India (1982): The Supreme Court held that 'equal pay for equal work' is a constitutional goal and capable of being enforced through Article 32.
State of Tamil Nadu vs L. Abu Kavur Bai (1984): The Supreme Court upheld the nationalization of transport services, stating it was in furtherance of the directive in Article 39(b) and (c).
Related_Articles: Article 16 (Equality of opportunity in public employment)
Article 31C (Saving of laws giving effect to certain directive principles)

Title: Equal justice and free legal aid
Original_Description: The State shall secure that the operation of the legal system promotes justice, on a basis of equal opportunity, and shall, in particular, provide free legal aid, by suitable legislation or schemes or in any other way, to ensure that opportunities for securing justice are not denied to any citizen by reason of economic or other disabilities.
Simplified_Description: The State shall secure that the operation of the legal system promotes justice, on a basis of equal opportunity, and shall, in particular, provide free legal aid.
Subject: Directive Principles
Key_Points: Directs the State to promote justice on the basis of equal opportunity.
Mandates the State to provide free legal aid to the poor.
Aims to ensure that justice is not denied to any citizen due to economic or other disabilities.
Historical_Context: This article was added by the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976. It was a significant step towards ensuring access to justice for all, recognizing that legal representation is often unaffordable for the poor. In pursuance of this article, the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987 was enacted to establish a nationwide network providing free legal aid.
Landmark_Cases: Hussainara Khatoon vs Home Secretary, State of Bihar (1979): The Supreme Court held that the right to free legal aid is an essential part of the Right to Life and Personal Liberty under Article 21.
Related_Articles: Article 21 (Protection of life and personal liberty)

Title: Organisation of village panchayats
Original_Description: The State shall take steps to organise village panchayats and endow them with such powers and authority as may be necessary to enable them to function as units of self-government.
Simplified_Description: The State shall take steps to organise village panchayats and endow them with such powers and authority as may be necessary to enable them to function as units of self-government.
Subject: Directive Principles
Key_Points: Directs the State to organize village panchayats.
Envisages these panchayats as units of self-government.
The State should provide them with necessary powers and authority to function effectively.
Historical_Context: This article is based on Gandhian principles of 'Gram Swaraj' or village self-rule. For a long time, it remained a non-enforceable directive with varying levels of implementation across states. This directive was given a practical and constitutional shape by the 73rd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1992, which added Part IX (The Panchayats) to the Constitution, making Panchayati Raj a constitutional mandate.
Landmark_Cases: Most litigation is now under Part IX of the Constitution rather than directly under Article 40, as Part IX provides the enforceable framework for Panchayati Raj.
Related_Articles: Article 243G (Powers, authority and responsibilities of Panchayats)

Title: Right to work, to education and to public assistance in certain cases
Original_Description: The State shall, within the limits of its economic capacity and development, make effective provision for securing the right to work, to education and to public assistance in cases of unemployment, old age, sickness and disablement, and in other cases of undeserved want.
Simplified_Description: The State shall make effective provision for securing the right to work, to education and to public assistance in cases of unemployment, old age, sickness and disablement.
Subject: Directive Principles
Key_Points: Directs the state to provide for the right to work, to education, and to public assistance.
This public assistance is specifically for cases of unemployment, old age, sickness, disablement, and other similar situations.
The implementation of this directive is subject to the 'economic capacity and development' of the State.
Historical_Context: This article outlines the social security obligations of a welfare state. While these rights are not fully enforceable due to the qualifier 'within the limits of its economic capacity', various government schemes have been launched in pursuance of this directive, such as the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA), old-age pension schemes, and social security schemes for the disabled.
Landmark_Cases: The principles in this article are often used by courts to uphold the validity of social welfare legislation and to interpret Article 21 (Right to Life) in a more inclusive manner.
Related_Articles: Article 21 (Protection of life and personal liberty)
Article 42 (Provision for just and humane conditions of work)

Title: Provision for just and humane conditions of work and maternity relief
Original_Description: The State shall make provision for securing just and humane conditions of work and for maternity relief.
Simplified_Description: The State shall make provision for securing just and humane conditions of work and for maternity relief.
Subject: Directive Principles
Key_Points: Directs the state to ensure just and humane conditions of work.
Specifically mandates the provision of maternity relief for women workers.
Historical_Context: This article emphasizes the importance of dignity and welfare in the workplace. It has been the guiding principle behind various labor laws in India, such as the Factories Act, 1948, which regulates working conditions, and the Maternity Benefit Act, 1961, which provides for paid leave and other benefits for women during pregnancy and childbirth.
Landmark_Cases: Courts have referred to this article to interpret labor laws in a manner that benefits workers and to uphold the rights of women in the workplace.

Title: Living wage, etc, for workers
Original_Description: The State shall endeavour to secure, by suitable legislation or economic organisation or in any other way, to all workers, agricultural, industrial or otherwise, work, a living wage, conditions of work ensuring a decent standard of life and full enjoyment of leisure and social and cultural opportunities and, in particular, the State shall endeavour to promote cottage industries on an individual or co-operative basis in rural areas.
Simplified_Description: The State shall endeavour to secure, by suitable legislation or economic organisation or in any other way, to all workers, agricultural, industrial or otherwise, work, a living wage.
Subject: Directive Principles
Key_Points: Directs the state to secure a living wage for all workers.
A 'living wage' is more than a 'minimum wage'; it should be enough to ensure a decent standard of life, leisure, and social/cultural opportunities.
Also directs the state to promote cottage industries on an individual or co-operative basis in rural areas.
Historical_Context: This article reflects the socialist and Gandhian principles of the constitution-makers. It aims for economic justice for the working class, going beyond mere subsistence. The promotion of cottage industries was a key part of Mahatma Gandhi's economic philosophy for rural self-sufficiency.
Landmark_Cases: PUDR vs Union of India (1982): While ruling on minimum wages, the Supreme Court discussed the concepts of minimum wage, fair wage, and living wage, acknowledging that a living wage as envisioned in Article 43 was still a goal to be achieved.
Related_Articles: Article 42 (Provision for just and humane conditions of work)

Title: Participation of workers in management of industries
Original_Description: The State shall take steps, by suitable legislation or in any other way, to secure the participation of workers in the management of undertakings, establishments or other organisations engaged in any industry.
Simplified_Description: The State shall take steps, by suitable legislation, to secure the participation of workers in the management of undertakings, establishments or other organisations engaged in any industry.
Subject: Directive Principles
Key_Points: Directs the state to take steps to ensure workers' participation in the management of industries.
Aims to promote industrial democracy.
Historical_Context: This article was added by the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976, during a period of increased emphasis on socialist policies. It aims to bridge the gap between labor and management and to give workers a voice in the decision-making processes of the industries they work in.
Landmark_Cases: This principle has been cited in industrial disputes to promote a more collaborative approach between management and workers.

Title: Uniform civil code for the citizens
Original_Description: The State shall endeavour to secure for the citizens a uniform civil code throughout the territory of India.
Simplified_Description: The State shall endeavour to secure for the citizens a uniform civil code throughout the territory of India.
Subject: Directive Principles
Key_Points: Directs the State to strive to secure a Uniform Civil Code (UCC) for all citizens.
A UCC would mean a single set of personal laws for all citizens, irrespective of their religion, in matters like marriage, divorce, inheritance, and adoption.
It is a directive, not a mandatory provision.
Historical_Context: This is one of the most debated Directive Principles. It was included to promote national integration by removing contradictions based on different religious personal laws. However, due to the sensitivities involved and the desire to protect the cultural identity of minority communities, it has not been implemented yet. The debate over its implementation continues to be a major political and social issue.
Landmark_Cases: Mohd. Ahmed Khan vs Shah Bano Begum (1985): The Supreme Court famously highlighted the need for a UCC and criticized the government's inaction.
Sarla Mudgal vs Union of India (1995): The court again urged the government to take steps towards framing a Uniform Civil Code.
Related_Articles: Article 25 (Freedom of conscience and free profession...)

Title: Provision for free and compulsory education for children
Original_Description: The State shall endeavour to provide, within a period of ten years from the commencement of this Constitution, for free and compulsory education for all children until they complete the age of fourteen years.
Simplified_Description: The State shall endeavour to provide, within a period of ten years from the commencement of this Constitution, for free and compulsory education for all children until they complete the age of 14.
Subject: Directive Principles
Key_Points: Originally, this article directed the state to provide free and compulsory education for all children up to the age of 14 within ten years of the Constitution's commencement.
The 86th Amendment Act, 2002, changed the subject matter of this article.
It now directs the State to provide early childhood care and education for all children until they complete the age of six years.
Historical_Context: The original Article 45 set a target for universal education, which was not met. The 86th Amendment transformed the right to education for children aged 6-14 into a Fundamental Right under Article 21A. Consequently, Article 45 was amended to focus on early childhood care and pre-school education for children below the age of six, which is now the focus of policies like the National Education Policy.
Landmark_Cases: Unni Krishnan, J.P. vs State of Andhra Pradesh (1993): Before the amendment, the Supreme Court interpreted Article 45 along with Article 21 to declare that the right to education was a fundamental right.

Title: Promotion of educational and economic interests of Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes and other weaker sections
Original_Description: The State shall promote with special care the educational and economic interests of the weaker sections of the people, and, in particular, of the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes, and shall protect them from social injustice and all forms of exploitation.
Simplified_Description: The State shall promote with special care the educational and economic interests of the weaker sections of the people. The State shall protect them from social injustice and all forms of exploitation.
Subject: Directive Principles
Key_Points: Directs the State to promote the educational and economic interests of the weaker sections of society.
Specifies a particular focus on Scheduled Castes (SCs) and Scheduled Tribes (STs).
Mandates the State to protect them from social injustice and all forms of exploitation.
Historical_Context: This article is a key directive aimed at affirmative action and social justice for historically marginalized communities. It provides the guiding principle for various reservation policies, welfare schemes, scholarships, and protective legislations like the Prevention of Atrocities Act.
Landmark_Cases: This article is often read with Articles 15(4) and 16(4) to justify reservation policies and other measures for the upliftment of weaker sections.
Related_Articles: Article 16 (Equality of opportunity in public employment)
Article 330, 332, 335 (Provisions relating to SCs and STs)

Title: Duty of the State to raise the level of nutrition and the standard of living and to improve public health
Original_Description: The State shall regard the raising of the level of nutrition and the standard of living of its people and the improvement of public health as among its primary duties and, in particular, the State shall endeavour to bring about prohibition of the consumption except for medicinal purposes of intoxicating drinks and of drugs which are injurious to health.
Simplified_Description: The State shall regard the raising of the level of nutrition and the standard of living of its people as among its primary duties. The State shall endeavour to bring about prohibition of the consumption except for medicinal purposes of intoxicating drinks.
Subject: Directive Principles
Key_Points: Makes it a primary duty of the State to improve public health, raise nutrition levels, and improve the standard of living.
Specifically directs the state to work towards the prohibition of intoxicating drinks and drugs that are injurious to health.
Consumption for medicinal purposes is an exception.
Historical_Context: This article reflects the Gandhian principle of prohibition. While a nationwide prohibition has not been implemented, this directive has been the constitutional basis for states that have enacted their own prohibition laws (e.g., Gujarat, Bihar). The broader duty to improve public health is the foundation for national health programs and policies.
Landmark_Cases: Parvez Aktar vs Union of India (1993): The court observed that the state has a duty to improve public health, which is a key part of the right to life under Article 21.
Related_Articles: Article 21 (Right to life, which includes right to health)
State List, Seventh Schedule (which gives states power to legislate on intoxicating liquors)

Title: Organisation of agriculture and animal husbandry
Original_Description: The State shall endeavour to organise agriculture and animal husbandry on modern and scientific lines and shall, in particular, take steps for preserving and improving the breeds, and prohibiting the slaughter, of cows and calves and other milch and draught cattle
Simplified_Description: The State shall endeavour to organise agriculture and animal husbandry on modern and scientific lines. The State shall, in particular, take steps for preserving and improving the breeds, and prohibiting the slaughter, of cows and calves.
Subject: Directive Principles
Key_Points: Directs the state to organize agriculture and animal husbandry on modern and scientific lines.
Specifically directs the state to take steps to prohibit the slaughter of cows, calves, and other milch and draught cattle.
Historical_Context: This article combines economic and cultural considerations. The directive to modernize agriculture was aimed at improving India's food security. The provision on cow slaughter reflects a mix of economic considerations (importance of cattle in an agrarian economy) and the cultural and religious sentiments of a large section of the population. Various states have enacted laws based on this directive to regulate or ban cattle slaughter.
Landmark_Cases: State of Gujarat vs Mirzapur Moti Kureshi Kassab Jamat (2005): The Supreme Court upheld the constitutional validity of a complete ban on cow slaughter, citing the economic importance of cattle and the principles of Article 48.
Related_Articles: State List, Seventh Schedule (which gives states power to legislate on agriculture and animal husbandry)

Title: Protection and improvement of environment and safeguarding of forests and wild life
Original_Description: The State shall endeavour to protect and improve the environment and to safeguard the forests and wild life of the country.
Simplified_Description: The State shall endeavour to protect and improve the environment and to safeguard the forests and wild life of the country.
Subject: Directive Principles
Key_Points: Directs the State to protect and improve the environment.
Mandates the State to safeguard the forests and wildlife of the country.
Historical_Context: This article was added by the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976, reflecting a growing global consciousness about environmental protection that began in the 1970s. It places a constitutional obligation on the government to protect India's natural heritage. This directive, along with the fundamental duty in Article 51A(g), forms the foundation of environmental jurisprudence in India.
Landmark_Cases: M.C. Mehta vs Union of India (various cases): In a series of Public Interest Litigations (PILs), the Supreme Court has invoked Article 48A and Article 21 to issue directions for pollution control (e.g., Ganga pollution case, Delhi vehicular pollution case).
Related_Articles: Article 21 (Right to life, which includes the right to a clean environment)
Article 51A(g) (Fundamental duty to protect the environment)

Title: Protection of monuments and places and objects of national importance
Original_Description: It shall be the obligation of the State to protect every monument or place or object of artistic or historic interest, declared by or [under law made by Parliament] to be of national importance, from spoliation, disfigurement, destruction, removal, disposal or export, as the case may be.
Simplified_Description: It shall be the obligation of the State to protect every monument or place or object of artistic or historic interest, declared by or under law made by Parliament.
Subject: Directive Principles
Key_Points: Makes it an obligation of the State to protect monuments, places, and objects of national importance.
The protection is against spoliation, disfigurement, destruction, removal, etc.
This applies to monuments and objects declared by or under law made by Parliament to be of national importance.
Historical_Context: This article was included to ensure the preservation of India's rich cultural and historical heritage. In pursuance of this directive, Parliament has enacted the Ancient Monuments and Archaeological Sites and Remains Act, 1958, to manage and protect monuments of national importance.
Landmark_Cases: This article provides the constitutional basis for heritage conservation laws and government actions to protect historical sites.
Related_Articles: Article 51A(f) (Fundamental duty to value and preserve the rich heritage of our composite culture)

Title: Separation of judiciary from executive
Original_Description: The State shall take steps to separate the judiciary from the executive in the public services of the State.
Simplified_Description: The State shall take steps to separate the judiciary from the executive in the public services of the State.
Subject: Directive Principles
Key_Points: Directs the State to separate the judiciary from the executive in the public services.
This is a key principle for ensuring the independence of the judiciary.
Historical_Context: The demand for the separation of the judiciary from the executive was a major theme of the Indian independence movement, as the fusion of these powers under British rule often led to injustice. This article made it a constitutional goal. This directive has been largely implemented through the enactment of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC), 1973, which separated the judicial functions of magistrates from their executive and administrative functions.
Landmark_Cases: This principle is considered a part of the 'basic structure' of the Constitution and is fundamental to the rule of law. It is invoked in cases concerning judicial independence.
Related_Articles: Part V, Chapter IV (The Union Judiciary)
Part VI, Chapter V (The High Courts in the States)

Title: Promotion of international peace and security
Simplified_Description: The State shall endeavour to promote international peace and security. The State shall strive to maintain just and honourable relations between nations.
Subject: Directive Principles
Key_Points: Outlines India's foreign policy objectives.
Directs the state to promote international peace and security.
Maintain just and honourable relations between nations.
Foster respect for international law and treaty obligations.
Encourage settlement of international disputes by arbitration.
Historical_Context: This article reflects the idealistic, pacifist ethos of the Indian freedom struggle and the vision of India as a global peacemaker. It forms the constitutional foundation for India's foreign policy, including its commitment to non-alignment (historically), the United Nations Charter, and peaceful resolution of conflicts.
Landmark_Cases: Vishakha vs State of Rajasthan (1997): The Supreme Court referred to international conventions (to which India is a signatory) to frame guidelines against sexual harassment at the workplace, demonstrating how Article 51 can be used to incorporate international law into domestic jurisprudence.
Related_Articles: Article 253 (Legislation for giving effect to international agreements)

Title: Fundamental duties
Simplified_Description: It shall be the duty of every citizen of India to abide by the Constitution and respect its ideals and institutions.
Subject: Fundamental Duties
Key_Points: Lists eleven fundamental duties for the citizens of India.
These duties are non-justiciable, meaning they are not enforceable by courts.
They serve as a moral and civic code of conduct for citizens.
Duties include respecting the Constitution, promoting harmony, protecting the environment, developing a scientific temper, and safeguarding public property.
Historical_Context: This part was not in the original Constitution. It was added by the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976, during the Emergency, based on the recommendations of the Swaran Singh Committee. The idea was that rights should be balanced with duties. The 11th duty, regarding education for children, was added by the 86th Amendment Act, 2002.
Landmark_Cases: AIIMS Students' Union vs AIIMS (2001): The Supreme Court observed that although Fundamental Duties are not enforceable, they can be used by courts to interpret the Constitution and other laws, and to assess the reasonableness of legal restrictions.
Related_Articles: Part IV (Directive Principles of State Policy)

Title: The President of India
Original_Description: There shall be a President of India.
Simplified_Description: There shall be a President of India. There shall be an Indian President. There
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: This article simply and formally establishes the office of the President of India.
The President is the head of the Indian State.
He is the first citizen of India and acts as the symbol of unity, integrity, and solidarity of the nation.
Historical_Context: The Constituent Assembly opted for a parliamentary system of government, where the President is the nominal or constitutional head of the executive, similar to the British monarch, while the real executive power is wielded by the Prime Minister and the Council of Ministers.
Landmark_Cases: This article itself is declaratory and not subject to litigation, but the powers and functions of the office it creates are dealt with in subsequent articles and related court cases.
Related_Articles: Article 74 (Council of Ministers to aid and advise President)

Title: Executive power of the Union
Original_Description:
(1) The executive power of the Union shall be vested in the President and shall be exercised by him either directly or through officers subordinate to him in accordance with this Constitution.

 

(2) Without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing provision, the supreme command of the Defence Forces of the Union shall be vested in the President and the exercise thereof shall be regulated by law.

 

(3) Nothing in this article shall—

 

(a) be deemed to transfer to the President any functions conferred by any existing law on the Government of any State or other authority; or

 

(b) prevent Parliament from conferring by law functions on authorities other than the President.
Simplified_Description: The executive power of the Union shall be vested in the President and shall be exercised by him either directly or through officers subordinate to him. Nothing in this article shall be deemed to transfer to the President any functions conferred by any existing law on the Government of any State.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Vests all executive power of the Union in the President.
States that this power shall be exercised by the President, either directly or through subordinate officers, in accordance with the Constitution.
Vests the supreme command of the Defence Forces in the President.
Historical_Context: While this article vests executive power in the President, it is read with Article 74, which mandates that the President must act on the aid and advice of the Council of Ministers headed by the Prime Minister. This combination establishes the President as the formal head of the executive, with the real power lying with the elected government.
Landmark_Cases: Ram Jawaya Kapur vs State of Punjab (1955): The Supreme Court clarified that the President is the formal head of the executive and the real executive powers are with the Council of Ministers.
Related_Articles: Article 74 (Council of Ministers to aid and advise President)
Article 77 (Conduct of business of the Government of India)

Title: Election of President
Original_Description:
The President shall be elected by the members of an electoral college consisting of—

 

(a) the elected members of both Houses of Parliament; and

 

(b) the elected members of the Legislative Assemblies of the States.

 

Explanation.—In this article and in article 55, ''State'' includes the National Capital Territory of Delhi and the Union territory of Pondicherry
Simplified_Description: In this article and in article 55, ''State'' includes the National Capital Territory of Delhi and the Union territory of Pondicherry. The President shall be elected by the members of an electoral college.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Specifies the composition of the electoral college for the election of the President.
The electoral college consists of: (a) elected members of the Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha, and (b) elected members of the Legislative Assemblies of the states.
Nominated members of Parliament and state legislatures are not part of the electoral college.
Historical_Context: The indirect election of the President was chosen to reflect the balance of power in India's federal structure. Including elected MPs and MLAs ensures that the President represents both the Union and the States. The 70th Amendment Act, 1992, included the elected members of the Legislative Assemblies of Delhi and Puducherry in the electoral college.
Landmark_Cases: Dr. N.B. Khare vs The Election Commission of India (1957): The Supreme Court dealt with issues concerning the presidential election process, including the effect of vacancies in the electoral college.
Related_Articles: Article 71 (Matters relating to the election of a President)

Title: Manner of election of President
Original_Description:
(1) As far as practicable, there shall be uniformity in the scale of representation of the different States at the election of the President.

 

(2) For the purpose of securing such uniformity among the States inter se as well as parity between the States as a whole and the Union, the number of votes which each elected member of Parliament and of the Legislative Assembly of each State is entitled to cast at such election shall be determined in the following manner:—

 

(a) every elected member of the Legislative Assembly of a State shall have as many votes as there are multiples of one thousand in the quotient obtained by dividing the population of the State by the total number of the elected members of the Assembly;

 

(b) if, after taking the said multiples of one thousand, the remainder is not less than five hundred, then the vote of each member referred to in sub-clause (a) shall be further increased by one;

 

(c) each elected member of either House of Parliament shall have such number of votes as may be obtained by dividing the total number of votes assigned to the members of the Legislative Assemblies of the States under sub-clauses (a) and (b) by the total number of the elected members of both Houses of Parliament, fractions exceeding onehalf being counted as one and other fractions being disregarded.

 

(3) The election of the President shall be held in accordance with the system of proportional representation by means of the single transferable vote and the voting at such election shall be by secret ballot.

 

Explanation.—In this article, the expression ''population'' means the population as ascertained at the last preceding census of which the relevant figures have been published: Provided that the reference in this Explanation to the last preceding census of which the relevant figures have been published shall, until the relevant figures for the first census taken after the year 1 [2026] have been published, be construed as a reference to the 1971 census.
Simplified_Description: There shall be uniformity in the scale of representation of the different States at the election of the President. The number of votes which each elected member of Parliament and of the Legislative Assembly of each State is entitled to cast at such election shall be determined.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Prescribes the manner of the presidential election.
It is based on the system of proportional representation by means of the single transferable vote.
Voting is done by secret ballot.
It lays down the formula for determining the value of votes of MLAs and MPs to ensure uniformity among states and parity between the states as a whole and the Union.
Historical_Context: The complex formula and the system of proportional representation were chosen to ensure that the President is not elected by a simple majority of votes but is a representative of the entire nation, reflecting the will of both the states and the Union.
Landmark_Cases: This article is primarily procedural and has been subject to interpretation in election-related disputes that fall under Article 71.
Related_Articles: Article 71 (Matters relating to the election of a President)

Title: Term of office of President
Simplified_Description: The President shall hold office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office. The President may, for violation of the Constitution, be removed from office by impeachment in the manner provided in article 61.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Fixes the term of office of the President at five years.
The President can resign by addressing the resignation to the Vice-President.
The President can be removed from office for 'violation of the Constitution' through impeachment as per Article 61.
The President continues to hold office, even after the five-year term expires, until their successor enters office.
Historical_Context: A fixed five-year term provides stability to the highest office of the Republic. The provisions for resignation and impeachment provide mechanisms for vacating the office under specific circumstances, ensuring accountability.
Landmark_Cases: The grounds for impeachment, 'violation of the Constitution', are not defined and remain open to interpretation by Parliament.
Related_Articles: Article 61 (Procedure for impeachment of the President)
Article 62 (Time of holding election to fill vacancy)

Title: Eligibility for re-election
Original_Description: A person who holds, or who has held, office as President shall, subject to the other provisions of this Constitution, be eligible for re-election to that office.
Simplified_Description: A person who holds, or who has held, office as President shall, subject to the other provisions of this Constitution, be eligible for re-election.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Makes a person who is or has been the President eligible for re-election.
Unlike the US Constitution, which limits the President to two terms, the Indian Constitution places no limit on the number of times a person can be re-elected as President.
Historical_Context: The framers decided not to impose a term limit on the presidency. However, a convention has developed where Presidents have generally served for a maximum of two terms. Dr. Rajendra Prasad is the only President to have been elected to the office twice.
Landmark_Cases: This article is straightforward and has not been a subject of litigation.

Title: Qualifications for election as President
Original_Description:
(1) No person shall be eligible for election as President unless he—

 

(a) is a citizen of India,

 

(b) has completed the age of thirty-five years, and

 

(c) is qualified for election as a member of the House of the People.

 

(2) A person shall not be eligible for election as President if he holds any office of profit under the Government of India or the Government of any State or under any local or other authority subject to the control of any of the said Governments.

 

Explanation.—For the purposes of this article, a person shall not be deemed to hold any office of profit by reason only that he is the President or Vice-President of the Union or the Governor of any State or is a Minister either for the Union or for any State
Simplified_Description: No person shall be eligible for election as President unless he has completed the age of thirty-five years and is a member of the House of the People. A person shall not be eligible if he holds any office of profit under the Government of India or under any local or other authority.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Lays down the qualifications required to be eligible for the office of President.
The person must be a citizen of India.
The person must have completed 35 years of age.
The person must be qualified for election as a member of the Lok Sabha.
The person must not hold any office of profit under the government.
Historical_Context: These qualifications were set to ensure that the person holding the highest office of the state is a citizen of sufficient age, maturity, and standing, and is not beholden to the executive through an 'office of profit'.
Landmark_Cases: The interpretation of what constitutes an 'office of profit' has been the subject of several court cases and parliamentary legislation, as it affects the eligibility of not just the President but also MPs and MLAs.

Title: Conditions of President's office
Original_Description:
(1) The President shall not be a member of either House of Parliament or of a House of the Legislature of any State, and if a member of either House of Parliament or of a House of the Legislature of any State be elected President, he shall be deemed to have vacated his seat in that House on the date on which he enters upon his office as President.

 

(2) The President shall not hold any other office of profit.

 

(3) The President shall be entitled without payment of rent to the use of his official residences and shall be also entitled to such emoluments, allowances and privileges as may be determined by Parliament by law and, until provision in that behalf is so made, such emoluments, allowances and privileges as are specified in the Second Schedule.

 

(4) The emoluments and allowances of the President shall not be diminished during his term of office.
Simplified_Description: The President shall not be a member of either House of Parliament or of a House of the Legislature of any State. The President shall be entitled without payment of rent to the use of his official residences. The emoluments and allowances of the President will not be diminished during his term of office.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: The President cannot be a member of Parliament or a State Legislature.
The President cannot hold any other office of profit.
The President is entitled to an official residence (Rashtrapati Bhavan) free of rent.
The President's salary and allowances cannot be reduced during their term of office.
Historical_Context: These conditions are designed to ensure the independence, dignity, and impartiality of the office of the President. The provision that emoluments cannot be diminished during the term of office protects the President from any potential political pressure from the executive or legislature.
Landmark_Cases: This article is largely procedural and not a frequent subject of litigation.
Related_Articles: Second Schedule (which details the emoluments of the President and other dignitaries)

Title: Oath or affirmation by the President
Original_Description:
Every President and every person acting as President or discharging the functions of the President shall, before entering upon his office, make and subscribe in the presence of the Chief Justice of India or, in his absence, the senior-most Judge of the Supreme Court available, an oath or affirmation in the following form, that is to say —

 

"I, A.B., do swear in the name of God / solemnly affirm that I will faithfully execute the office of President (or discharge the functions of the President) of India and will to the best of my ability preserve, protect and defend theConstitution and the law and that I will devote myself to the service and well-being of the people of India”.
Simplified_Description: Every President and every person acting as President or discharging the functions of the President shall, before entering upon his office, make and subscribe an oath or affirmation.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Prescribes the oath of office for the President.
The oath is to be administered by the Chief Justice of India (or the senior-most Supreme Court judge in their absence).
The President's oath is unique as it includes the pledge to 'preserve, protect and defend the Constitution and the law'.
Historical_Context: The specific wording of the President's oath underscores their role as the constitutional head and the ultimate guardian of the Constitution. Unlike the ministers' oath of 'allegiance' to the Constitution, the President's oath is to 'preserve, protect and defend' it, highlighting a higher level of responsibility.
Landmark_Cases: The oath is a constitutional requirement and its text can be referred to by courts to understand the nature and duties of the presidential office.
Related_Articles: Third Schedule (Forms of Oaths or Affirmations for other constitutional posts)

Title: Procedure for impeachment of the President
Original_Description:
(1) When a President is to be impeached for violation of the Constitution, the charge shall be preferred by either House of Parliament.

 

(2) No such charge shall be preferred unless—

 

(a) the proposal to prefer such charge is contained in a resolution which has been moved after at least fourteen days' notice in writing signed by not less than one-fourth of the total number of members of the House has been given of their intention to move the resolution, and

 

(b) such resolution has been passed by a majority of not less than two-thirds of the total membership of the House.

 

(3) When a charge has been so preferred by either House of Parliament, the other House shall investigate the charge or cause the charge to be investigated and the President shall have the right to appear and to be represented at such investigation.

 

(4) If as a result of the investigation a resolution is passed by a majority of not less than two-thirds of the total membership of the House by which the charge was investigated or caused to be investigated, declaring that the charge preferred against the President has been sustained, such resolution shall have the effect of removing the President from his office as from the date on which the resolution is so passed.
Simplified_Description: When a President is to be impeached for violation of the Constitution, the charge shall be preferred by either House of Parliament. When a charge has been so preferred, the other House shall investigate the charge or cause the charge to be investigated.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Lays down the procedure for the impeachment of the President for 'violation of the Constitution'.
The process can be initiated by either House of Parliament.
Charges must be signed by at least one-fourth of the members of the House and a 14-day notice must be given.
The resolution must be passed by a special majority of two-thirds of the total membership of that House.
The other House then investigates the charges. If it also passes the resolution by a two-thirds majority of its total membership, the President stands impeached.
Historical_Context: This article provides a quasi-judicial and difficult procedure for removing the President, ensuring that the head of state cannot be removed on frivolous political grounds. The high threshold of a two-thirds majority of the total membership of both Houses makes the process extremely challenging. No President of India has been impeached to date.
Landmark_Cases: This procedure has never been used, so there is no case law directly interpreting it.
Related_Articles: Article 56 (Term of office of President, which mentions impeachment)
Article 124(4) (Similar procedure for removal of a Supreme Court Judge)

Title: Time of holding election to fill vacancy in the office of President and the term of office of person elected to fill casual vacancy
Original_Description:
(1) An election to fill a vacancy caused by the expiration of the term of office of President shall be completed before the expiration of the term.

 

(2) An election to fill a vacancy in the office of President occurring by reason of his death, resignation or removal, or otherwise shall be held as soon as possible after, and in no case later than six months from, the date of occurrence of the vacancy; and the person elected to fill the vacancy shall, subject to the provisions of article 56, be entitled to hold office for the full term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office.
Simplified_Description: An election to fill a vacancy in the office of President occurring by reason of his death, resignation or removal, or otherwise shall be held as soon as possible after. The person elected to fill the vacancy shall be entitled to hold office for the full term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Mandates that an election to fill a vacancy caused by the expiry of the President's term must be completed before the term ends.
In case of a vacancy due to death, resignation, or impeachment, the election must be held within six months.
A person elected to fill such a mid-term vacancy is entitled to a full five-year term.
Historical_Context: This article ensures that the highest office of the land does not remain vacant for long, providing for constitutional continuity. The provision for a full five-year term for a president elected mid-term contrasts with the US system, where the Vice President serves out the remainder of the term.
Landmark_Cases: In re Presidential Election (1974): The Supreme Court clarified that the election for the President must be held before the expiration of the term and cannot be delayed on the grounds that a state assembly is dissolved.
Related_Articles: Article 65 (The Vice-President to act as President)

Title: The Vice-President of India
Original_Description: There shall be a Vice-President of India.
Simplified_Description: There shall be a Vice-President of India. There shall be an Indian President
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: This article simply and formally establishes the office of the Vice-President of India.
The Vice-President is the second-highest constitutional office in the country.
Historical_Context: The office of the Vice-President of India is modeled on that of the Vice President of the United States. However, the Indian Vice-President's primary role is to preside over the Rajya Sabha, and they step in for the President only in specific circumstances, unlike the more defined executive role of the US Vice President.
Landmark_Cases: This is a declaratory article and not subject to litigation.
Related_Articles: Article 64 (Vice-President to be ex-officio Chairman of the Council of States)

Title: The Vice-President to be ex officio Chairman of the Council of States
Original_Description:
The Vice-President shall be ex officio Chairman of the Council of States and shall not hold any other office of profit:

 

Provided that during any period when the VicePresident acts as President or discharges the functions of the President under article 65, he shall not perform the duties of the office of Chairman of the Council of States and shall not be entitled to any salary or allowance payable to the Chairman of the Council of States under article 97.
Simplified_Description: The Vice-President shall be ex officio Chairman of the Council of States. He shall not be entitled to any salary or allowance payable to the Chairman under article 97.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Specifies the primary function of the Vice-President: to serve as the ex-officio Chairman of the Rajya Sabha (Council of States).
Prohibits the Vice-President from holding any other office of profit.
The Vice-President draws their salary as the Chairman of the Rajya Sabha, not as the Vice-President.
Historical_Context: This provision gives the Vice-President a defined legislative role, similar to the US Vice President presiding over the Senate. It ensures that the upper house of Parliament has a presiding officer who is not a member of the house, thus expected to be impartial.
Landmark_Cases: This article defines a clear function and is not typically a subject of legal dispute.
Related_Articles: Article 89 (The Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Council of States)

Title: The Vice-President to act as President or to discharge his functions during casual vacancies in the office, or during the absence, of President
Original_Description:
(1) In the event of the occurrence of any vacancy in the office of the President by reason of his death, resignation or removal, or otherwise, the Vice-President shall act as President until the date on which a new President elected in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter to fill such vacancy enters upon his office.

 

(2) When the President is unable to discharge his functions owing to absence, illness or any other cause, the Vice-President shall discharge his functions until the date on which the President resumes his duties.

 

(3) The Vice-President shall, during, and in respect of, the period while he is so acting as, or discharging the functions of, President, have all the powers and immunities of the President and be entitled to such emoluments, allowances and privileges as may be determined by Parliament by law and, until provision in that behalf is so made, such emoluments, allowances and privileges as are specified in the Second Schedule.
Simplified_Description: The Vice-President shall act as President until the date on which a new President elected in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter to fill such vacancy enters upon his office.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Outlines the circumstances under which the Vice-President assumes the President's role.
The Vice-President 'acts as President' when the office is vacant (due to death, resignation, etc.) until a new President is elected.
The Vice-President 'discharges the functions' of the President when the President is temporarily unable to do so (due to absence, illness, etc.).
When acting as President, the Vice-President has all the powers and immunities of the President.
Historical_Context: This article provides for a smooth succession and continuity of the office of the Head of State. It ensures that there is no vacuum in the highest constitutional office. This provision has been invoked on occasions of the death of a sitting President, such as Dr. Zakir Hussain and Fakhruddin Ali Ahmed.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article ensuring continuity of office and has not been a subject of major litigation.
Related_Articles: Article 62 (Time of holding election to fill vacancy)
Article 70 (Discharge of President's functions in other contingencies)

Title: Election of Vice - President
Original_Description:
(1) The Vice-President shall be elected by the members of an electoral college consisting of the members of both Houses of Parliament in accordance with the system of proportional representation by means of the single transferable vote and the voting at such election shall be by secret ballot.

 

(2) The Vice-President shall not be a member of either House of Parliament or of a House of the Legislature of any State, and if a member of either House of Parliament or of a House of the Legislature of any State be elected Vice-President, he shall be deemed to have vacated his seat in that House on the date on which he enters upon his office as Vice-President.

 

(3) No person shall be eligible for election as VicePresident unless he —

 

(a) is a citizen of India;

 

(b) has completed the age of thirty-five years; and

 

(c) is qualified for election as a member of the Council of States

 

(4) A person shall not be eligible for election as Vice-President if he holds any office of profit under the Government of India or the Government of any State or under any local or other authority subject to the control of any of the said Governments.

 

Explanation.— For the purposes of this article, a person shall not be deemed to hold any office of profit by reason only that he is the President or Vice-President of the Union or the Governor of any State or is a Minister either for the Union or for any State.
Simplified_Description: The Vice-President shall be elected by the members of an electoral college consisting of members of both Houses of Parliament. The voting at such election shall be by secret ballot. No person shall be eligible for election as VicePresident unless he is a citizen of India.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Prescribes the method and qualifications for the election of the Vice-President.
The electoral college consists of all members (elected and nominated) of both Houses of Parliament.
The election is by proportional representation using the single transferable vote and secret ballot.
Qualifications include being a citizen of India, being at least 35 years old, and being qualified for election as a member of the Rajya Sabha.
Historical_Context: The electoral college for the Vice-President is different from that of the President, as it only includes members of Parliament. This is because the Vice-President's primary role is to be the Chairman of the Rajya Sabha, a parliamentary function. State legislators do not participate in this election.
Landmark_Cases: Disputes regarding the election of the Vice-President are adjudicated by the Supreme Court under Article 71.
Related_Articles: Article 71 (Matters relating to the election of a ... Vice-President)

Title: Term of office of Vice-President
Simplified_Description: The Vice-President shall hold office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office. A Vice- president may be removed from his office by a resolution of the Council of States.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Fixes the term of office for the Vice-President at five years.
The Vice-President can resign by writing to the President.
Lays down the procedure for removal: A resolution must be passed by the Rajya Sabha with an 'effective majority' (majority of all then members) and agreed to by the Lok Sabha with a simple majority.
A 14-day notice is required before moving such a resolution.
Historical_Context: The removal process for the Vice-President is simpler than the impeachment of the President. The initiative for removal must come from the Rajya Sabha, as the Vice-President is its Chairman. This reinforces the Vice-President's accountability to the house he presides over.
Landmark_Cases: No Vice-President has ever faced removal proceedings.
Related_Articles: Article 61 (Procedure for impeachment of the President)

Title: Time of holding election to fill vacancy in the office of Vice-President and the term of office of person elected to fill casual vacancy
Original_Description:
(1) An election to fill a vacancy caused by the expiration of the term of office of Vice-President shall be completed before the expiration of the term.

 

(2) An election to fill a vacancy in the office of VicePresident occurring by reason of his death, resignation or removal, or otherwise shall be held as soon as possible after the occurrence of the vacancy, and the person elected to fill the vacancy shall, subject to the provisions of article 67, be entitled to hold office for the full term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office.
Simplified_Description: An election to fill a vacancy in the office of VicePresident occurring by reason of his death, resignation or removal, or otherwise shall be held as soon as possible after the occurrence of the vacancy. The person elected to fill the vacancy shall, subject to the provisions of article 67, be entitled to hold office for the full term of five years.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: An election for a normal vacancy (end of term) must be completed before the term expires.
An election for a casual vacancy (death, resignation, removal) must be held 'as soon as possible'.
Unlike the 6-month deadline for the President's election, no specific time limit is given for the Vice-President's casual vacancy.
A person elected to fill a casual vacancy serves a full five-year term.
Historical_Context: This article ensures continuity in the office of the Vice-President. The lack of a strict deadline for filling a casual vacancy is because there is no provision for the Vice-President's role to be temporarily filled by another functionary (unlike the President's role, which the VP can assume). The Deputy Chairman of the Rajya Sabha can preside over the house in the interim.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article and has not been a subject of litigation.
Related_Articles: Article 62 (Time of holding election to fill vacancy in the office of President)

Title: Oath or affirmation by the Vice-President
Original_Description:
Every Vice-President shall, before entering upon his office, make and subscribe before the President, or some person appointed in that behalf by him, an oath or affirmation in the following form, that is to say —

 

“I, A.B., do swear in the name of God / solemnly affirm that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of India as by law established and that I will faithfully discharge the duty upon which I am about to enter.”
Simplified_Description: “I, A.B., do swear in the name of God / solemnly affirm that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of India as by law established.”
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Prescribes the oath of office for the Vice-President.
The oath is administered by the President or a person appointed by the President.
The Vice-President swears to bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution and to faithfully discharge their duties.
Historical_Context: The oath binds the Vice-President to the Constitution, similar to other high constitutional functionaries. The administration of the oath by the President signifies the hierarchical relationship between the two highest offices.
Landmark_Cases: The oath is a constitutional formality and not a subject of legal disputes.
Related_Articles: Article 60 (Oath or affirmation by the President)
Third Schedule (Forms of Oaths or Affirmations)

Title: Discharge of President's functions in other contingencies
Original_Description: Parliament may make such provisions as it thinks fit for the discharge of the functions of the President in any contingency not provided for in this Chapter.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may make such provisions as it thinks fit for the discharge of the functions of the President in any contingency not provided for in this Chapter.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to make laws for situations not covered by the Constitution where the President's functions need to be discharged.
This is a residual power to handle unforeseen contingencies related to the office of the President.
Historical_Context: This article provides a constitutional safety net. The framers foresaw that situations not explicitly mentioned in Articles 62 or 65 (like the simultaneous vacancy in the offices of both President and Vice-President) might arise. Parliament enacted the President (Discharge of Functions) Act, 1969, which provides that in such a case, the Chief Justice of India (or the senior-most Supreme Court judge) would act as President.
Landmark_Cases: This article provides the legal basis for the President (Discharge of Functions) Act, 1969.
Related_Articles: Article 62 (Time of holding election to fill vacancy)
Article 65 (The Vice-President to act as President)

Title: Matters relating to, or connected with, the election of a President or Vice-President
Original_Description:
(1) All doubts and disputes arising out of or in connection with the election of a President or Vice - President shall be inquired into and decided by the Supreme Court whose decision shall be final.

 

(2) If the election of a person as President or Vice - President is declared void by the Supreme Court, acts done by him in the exercise and performance of the powers and duties of the office of President or Vice - President, as the case may be, on or before the date of the decision of the Supreme Court shall not be invalidated by reason of that declaration.

 

(3) Subject to the provisions of this Constitution, Parliament may by law regulate any matter relating to or connected with the election of a President or Vice - President.

 

(4) The election of a person as President or Vice - President shall not be called in question on the ground of the existence of any vacancy for whatever reason among the members of the electoral college electing him
Simplified_Description: All doubts and disputes arising out of or in connection with the election of a President or Vice - President shall be inquired into and decided by the Supreme Court whose decision shall be final. Parliament may by law regulate any matter relating to or connected with the president's election.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Gives the Supreme Court exclusive and final jurisdiction over all doubts and disputes related to the election of the President or Vice-President.
If the election is declared void by the Supreme Court, acts done by the person as President/Vice-President before the court's decision remain valid.
The election cannot be challenged on the ground that the electoral college was incomplete (e.g., if a state assembly was dissolved).
Historical_Context: Placing the authority to decide presidential election disputes with the Supreme Court ensures that such a high-stakes issue is adjudicated by the highest judicial body in an impartial manner, free from political influence. This reinforces the sanctity and legitimacy of these high offices.
Landmark_Cases: Dr. N.B. Khare vs The Election Commission of India (1957): The court clarified that doubts and disputes can only be brought before the Supreme Court after the election is concluded, not during the process.

Title: Power of President to grant pardons, etc, and to suspend, remit or commute sentences in certain cases
Simplified_Description: The President shall have the power to grant pardons, reprieves, respites or remissions of punishment or to suspend, remit or commute the sentence of any person convicted of any offence.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Grants the President the power to grant pardons, reprieves, respites, remissions, and to suspend, remit, or commute sentences.
This pardoning power applies to offenses against Union laws, sentences by a Court Martial, and all cases of a death sentence.
This power is an executive power and is exercised on the advice of the Council of Ministers.
The exercise of this power is subject to judicial review on limited grounds.
Historical_Context: The pardoning power is a sovereign prerogative, intended to be a safeguard against judicial error or to be used in cases where clemency is justified. It acts as a final recourse for justice and mercy. The scope and reviewability of this power have been extensively debated and defined by the judiciary over time.
Landmark_Cases: Maru Ram vs Union of India (1980): The Supreme Court held that the President's pardoning power is not a private act but a public one, to be exercised on the advice of the Council of Ministers.

Epuru Sudhakar vs Government of Andhra Pradesh (2006): The Court ruled that the exercise of pardoning power is subject to judicial review on grounds of arbitrariness, mala fides, or if the decision was made without application of mind.
Related_Articles: Article 161 (Power of Governor to grant pardons...)

Title: Extent of executive power of the Union
