Original_Description:
(1) Subject to the provisions of this Constitution, the executive power of the Union shall extend —

 

(a) to the matters with respect to which Parliament has power to make laws; and

 

(b) to the exercise of such rights, authority and jurisdiction as are exercisable by the Government of India by virtue of any treaty or agreement:

 

Provided that the executive power referred to in subclause (a) shall not, save as expressly provided in this Constitution or in any law made by Parliament, extend in any State to matters with respect to which the Legislature of the State has also power to make laws.

 

(2) Until otherwise provided by Parliament, a State and any officer or authority of a State may, notwithstanding anything in this article, continue to exercise in matters with respect to which Parliament has power to make laws for that State such executive power or functions as the State or officer or authority thereof could exercise immediately before the commencement of this Constitution.
Simplified_Description: Executive power of the Union shall extend to the exercise of rights, authority and jurisdiction as are exercisable by the Government of India by virtue of any treaty or agreement.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Defines the extent of the executive power of the Union government.
The Union's executive power is co-extensive with the legislative power of the Parliament. This means the Union can take executive action on any subject in the Union List.
It also extends to rights, authority, and jurisdiction derived from any treaty or agreement.
Historical_Context: This article delineates the administrative boundaries of the central government, linking its executive authority directly to its legislative competence as defined in the Seventh Schedule. It establishes the principle that for every legislative power, there is a corresponding executive power.
Landmark_Cases: Ram Jawaya Kapur vs State of Punjab (1955): The court observed that executive power is not just about executing laws but also includes all functions of government that are not legislative or judicial.
Related_Articles: Article 162 (Extent of executive power of State)
Article 246 (Subject-matter of laws made by Parliament and by the Legislatures of States)
Seventh Schedule (Union List, State List, Concurrent List)

Title: Council of Ministers to aid and advise President
Original_Description:
(1) There shall be a Council of Ministers with the Prime Minister at the head to aid and advise the President who shall, in the exercise of his functions, act in accordance with such advice:

 

Provided that the President may require the Council of Ministers to reconsider such advice, either generally or otherwise, and the President shall act in accordance with the advice tendered after such reconsideration.

 

 (2) The question whether any, and if so what, advice was tendered by Ministers to the President shall not be inquired into in any court.
Simplified_Description: There shall be a Council of Ministers with the Prime Minister at the head to aid and advise the President. The question whether any, and if so what, advice was tendered by Ministers to the President shall not be inquired into in any court.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Establishes a Council of Ministers (CoM) headed by the Prime Minister.
The primary role of the CoM is to aid and advise the President.
Crucially, it mandates that the President 'shall act in accordance with such advice'.
The President has one power of review: they can ask the CoM to reconsider its advice once, but must accept the reconsidered advice.
The advice tendered by the ministers cannot be inquired into by any court.
Historical_Context: This article is the lynchpin of the parliamentary system in India. Originally, the wording was less explicit, leading to some ambiguity. The 42nd Amendment (1976) made the advice binding on the President. The 44th Amendment (1978) added the proviso allowing the President to ask for reconsideration once, providing a limited check.
Landmark_Cases: Shamsher Singh vs State of Punjab (1974): The Supreme Court clarified that the President is a constitutional head and must act on the aid and advice of the Council of Ministers.

Title: Other provisions as to Ministers
Original_Description:
(1) The Prime Minister shall be appointed by the President and the other Ministers shall be appointed by the President on the advice of the Prime Minister.

 

(1A) The total number of Ministers, including the Prime Minister, in the Council of Ministers shall not exceed fifteen per cent. of the total number of members of the House of the People.

 

(1B) A member of either House of Parliament belonging to any political party who is disqualified for being a member of that House under paragraph 2 of the Tenth Schedule shall also be disqualified to be appointed as a Minister under clause (1) for duration of the period commencing from the date of his disqualification till the date on which the term of his office as such member would expire or where he contests any election to either House of Parliament before the expiry of such period, till the date on which he is declared elected, whichever is earlier.

 

(2) The Ministers shall hold office during the pleasure of the President.

 

(3) The Council of Ministers shall be collectively responsible to the House of the People.

 

(4) Before a Minister enters upon his office, the President shall administer to him the oaths of office and of secrecy according to the forms set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule.

 

(5) A Minister who for any period of six consecutive months is not a member of either House of Parliament shall at the expiration of that period cease to be a Minister.

 

(6) The salaries and allowances of Ministers shall be such as Parliament may from time to time by law determine and, until Parliament so determines, shall be as specified in the Second Schedule.
Simplified_Description: The total number of Ministers, including the Prime Minister, in the Council of Ministers shall not exceed fifteen per cent. of the totalnumber of members of the House of the People. The Ministers shall hold office during the pleasure of the President.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: The President appoints the Prime Minister and other ministers on the PM's advice.
Ministers hold office 'during the pleasure of the President', which in practice means they can be removed by the PM.
The Council of Ministers is collectively responsible to the Lok Sabha.
The total number of ministers cannot exceed 15% of the total strength of the Lok Sabha.
A minister who is not a member of Parliament for six consecutive months ceases to be a minister.
Historical_Context: This article lays down the core principles of cabinet government: prime ministerial authority, collective responsibility, and accountability to the lower house of Parliament. The 15% size limit was added by the 91st Amendment Act, 2003, to prevent bloated cabinets and the associated problem of political defections.
Landmark_Cases: S.R. Bommai vs Union of India (1994): While dealing with President's rule, the court discussed the principle of collective responsibility and the importance of a government enjoying the confidence of the Lok Sabha.
Related_Articles: Article 74 (Council of Ministers to aid and advise President)

Title: Attorney-General for India
Original_Description:
(1) The President shall appoint a person who is qualified to be appointed a Judge of the Supreme Court to be Attorney-General for India.

 

(2) It shall be the duty of the Attorney-General to give advice to the Government of India upon such legal matters, and to perform such other duties of a legal character, as may from time to time be referred or assigned to him by the President, and to discharge the functions conferred on him by or under this Constitution or any other law for the time being in force.

 

(3) In the performance of his duties the AttorneyGeneral shall have right of audience in all courts in the territory of India.

 

(4) The Attorney-General shall hold office during the pleasure of the President, and shall receive such remuneration as the President may determine.
Simplified_Description: The Attorney-General for India is a judge of the Supreme Court of India. It is his duty to give advice to the Government of India on legal matters. He also has the right of audience in all courts in India.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Establishes the office of the Attorney-General for India.
The Attorney-General is appointed by the President and must be qualified to be a Supreme Court judge.
They are the chief legal advisor to the Government of India.
They have the right of audience in all courts in India.
They can speak and take part in the proceedings of both Houses of Parliament but do not have the right to vote.
Historical_Context: The office of the Attorney-General is designed to provide the Union government with legal expertise for its functions. They represent the government in legal proceedings and provide advice on complex legal matters. They are not a full-time government servant and are allowed to have a private legal practice, provided it does not conflict with their duties.
Landmark_Cases: The role and functions of the Attorney-General are generally well-defined and not a common subject of litigation.
Related_Articles: Article 88 (Rights of Ministers and Attorney-General as respects Houses)

Title: Conduct of business of the Government of India
Original_Description:
(1) All executive action of the Government of India shall be expressed to be taken in the name of the President.

 

(2) Orders and other instruments made and executed in the name of the President shall be authenticated in such manner as may be specified in rules to be made by the President, and the validity of an order or instrument which is so authenticated shall not be called in question on the ground that it is not an order or instrument made or executed by the President.

 

(3) The President shall make rules for the more convenient transaction of the business of the Government of India, and for the allocation among Ministers of the said business.
Simplified_Description: All executive action of the Government of India shall be expressed to be taken in the name of the President. The President shall make rules for the more convenient transaction of the business.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: All executive actions of the Union Government are formally taken in the name of the President.
The President makes rules for the authentication of orders and instruments made in their name.
The President also makes rules for the convenient transaction of business of the Government of India and for the allocation of this business among ministers.
Historical_Context: This article formalizes the constitutional position of the President as the head of the executive. While the decisions are made by the Council of Ministers, the official expression of those decisions is in the name of the President. The 'Allocation of Business Rules' made under this article are crucial for the day-to-day functioning of government ministries.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article. Courts have held that while actions must be expressed in the President's name, a failure to do so does not automatically invalidate the action if it can be shown that the decision was properly made by the government.
Related_Articles: Article 74 (Council of Ministers to aid and advise President)

Title: Duties of Prime Minister as respects the furnishing of information to the President, etc
Original_Description:
It shall be the duty of the Prime Minister —

 

(a) to communicate to the President all decisions of the Council of Ministers relating to the administration of the affairs of the Union and proposals for legislation;

 

(b) to furnish such information relating to the administration of the affairs of the Union and proposals for legislation as the President may call for; and

 

(c) if the President so requires, to submit for the consideration of the Council of Ministers any matter on which a decision has been taken by a Minister but which has not been considered by the Council.
Simplified_Description: It is the duty of the Prime Minister to communicate to the President all decisions of the Council of Ministers relating to the administration of the affairs of the Union and proposals for legislation.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Lays down the duties of the Prime Minister in relation to the President.
The PM must communicate all decisions of the Council of Ministers to the President.
The PM must furnish any information that the President calls for.
The PM must, if the President requires, submit a matter for the consideration of the whole Council of Ministers if a decision was taken by an individual minister alone.
Historical_Context: This article establishes a crucial communication link between the real executive (PM and CoM) and the nominal executive (President). It empowers the President to be kept informed about the affairs of the government. This 'right to be informed' is a key aspect of the President's constitutional role.
Landmark_Cases: The relationship defined by this article is primarily between the PM and the President and is governed by constitutional convention rather than court cases.
Related_Articles: Article 74 (Council of Ministers to aid and advise President)

Title: Constitution of Parliament
Original_Description: There shall be a Parliament for the Union which shall consist of the President and two Houses to be known respectively as the Council of States and the House of the People.
Simplified_Description: There shall be a Parliament for the Union which shall consist of the President and two Houses to be known respectively as the Council of States and the House of the People.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Establishes the Parliament of India.
States that Parliament consists of three parts: the President, the Council of States (Rajya Sabha), and the House of the People (Lok Sabha).
This highlights that the President is an integral part of the legislature, even though they do not sit in either house.
Historical_Context: The framers chose a bicameral legislature. The Lok Sabha represents the people directly, while the Rajya Sabha represents the states. The inclusion of the President as part of Parliament is based on the British model, where the Crown-in-Parliament is the sovereign legislative body. The President's role in assenting to bills (Article 111) is a key legislative function.
Landmark_Cases: This is a foundational, descriptive article and not a subject of litigation.
Related_Articles: Article 80 (Composition of the Council of States)
Article 81 (Composition of the House of the People)

Title: Composition of the Council of States
Original_Description:
The Council of States] shall consist of —

 

(a) twelve members to be nominated by the President in accordance with the provisions of clause (3); and

 

(b) not more than two hundred and thirty-eight representatives of the States and of the Union territories.

 

(2) The allocation of seats in the Council of States to be filled by representatives of the States and of the Union territories] shall be in accordance with the provisions in that behalf contained in the Fourth Schedule.

 

(3) The members to be nominated by the President under sub-clause (a) of clause (1) shall consist of persons having special knowledge or practical experience in respect of such matters as the following, namely:-

 

Literature, science, art and social service.

 

(4) The representatives of each State  in the Council of States shall be elected by the elected members of the Legislative Assembly of the State in accordance with the system of proportional representation by means of the single transferable vote.

 

(5) The representatives of the Union territories in the Council of States shall be chosen in such manner as Parliament may by law prescribe.
Simplified_Description: The Council of States] shall consist of not more than two hundred and thirty-eight representatives of the States and of the Union territories. The members to be nominated by the President under sub-clause (a) of clause (1) shall consist. of persons having special knowledge or practical experience in respect of such matters as the following.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Specifies the composition of the Rajya Sabha.
The maximum strength is 250 members.
12 members are nominated by the President from among persons with special knowledge or practical experience in literature, science, art, and social service.
Up to 238 members are representatives of the States and Union Territories, elected indirectly by the elected members of the State Legislative Assemblies.
Historical_Context: The Rajya Sabha was created to provide a forum for the states in the federal legislature and to act as a revising chamber that can hold the directly elected Lok Sabha to account. The nomination of 12 members was intended to bring distinguished experts and eminent personalities into Parliament who might not participate in the electoral process.
Landmark_Cases: The process of nomination and election to the Rajya Sabha is governed by this article and the Representation of the People Act, 1951.
Related_Articles: Article 81 (Composition of the House of the People)
Fourth Schedule (Allocation of seats in the Council of States)

Title: Composition of the House of the People
Original_Description:
(1) Subject to the provisions of article, the House of the People shall consist of —

 

(a) not more than 4 [five hundred and thirty members] chosen by direct election from territorial constituencies in the States, and

 

(b) not more than 5 [twenty members] to represent the Union territories, chosen in such manner as Parliament may by law provide.

 

(2) For the purposes of sub-clause (a) of clause (1),—

 

(a) there shall be allotted to each State a number of seats in the House of the People in such manner that the ratio between that number and the population of the State is, so far as practicable, the same for all States; and

 

(b) each State shall be divided into territorial constituencies in such manner that the ratio between the population of each constituency and the number of seats allotted to it is, so far as practicable, the same throughout the State:

 

Provided that the provisions of sub-clause (a) of this clause shall not be applicable for the purpose of allotment of seats in the House of the People to any State so long as the population of that State does not exceed six millions.

 

(3) In this article, the expression “population” means the population as ascertained at the last preceding census of which the relevant figures have been published:

 

Provided that the reference in this clause to the last preceding census of which the relevant figures have been published shall, until the relevant figures for the first census taken after the year 2026 have been published, be construed,—

 

(i) for the purposes of sub-clause (a) of clause (2) and the proviso to that clause, as a reference to the 1971 census; and

 

(ii) for the purposes of sub-clause (b) of clause (2) as a reference to the 2001 census.
Simplified_Description: The House of the People shall consist of not more than 4 [five hundred and thirty members] chosen by direct election from territorial constituencies in the States. The ratio between that number and the population of the State is, so far as practicable, the same for all States. In this article, the expression “population” means the population as ascertained at the last preceding census of
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Specifies the composition of the Lok Sabha.
The maximum strength is fixed at 552 (currently 550, as the Anglo-Indian nomination has been discontinued).
Up to 530 members represent the States, and up to 20 members represent the Union Territories.
Members are chosen by direct election on the basis of adult suffrage.
Seats are allocated to states in such a way that the ratio between the number of seats and the state's population is, as far as practicable, the same for all states.
Historical_Context: The Lok Sabha is the body that represents the will of the people directly. Its composition is based on population to ensure democratic representation. The provision for representation of Anglo-Indians by nomination (Article 331) was not extended by the 104th Amendment Act, 2019.
Landmark_Cases: Delimitation exercises, which redraw constituency boundaries based on census data, are based on the principles laid out in this article.
Related_Articles: Article 80 (Composition of the Council of States)
Article 326 (Elections...to be on the basis of adult suffrage)

Title: Readjustment after each census
Original_Description:
Upon the completion of each census, the allocation of seats in the House of the People to the States and the division of each State into territorial constituencies shall be readjusted by such authority and in such manner as Parliament may by law determine:

 

Provided that such readjustment shall not affect representation in the House of the People until the dissolution of the then existing House:

 

Provided further that such readjustment shall take effect from such date as the President may, by order, specify and until such readjustment takes effect, any election to the House may be held on the basis of the territorial constituencies existing before such readjustment:

 

Provided also that until the relevant figures for the first census taken after the year 2026 have been published, it shall not be necessary to readjust - 

 

(i) the allocation of seats in the House of People to the States as readjusted on the basis of the 1971 census; and

 

(ii) the division of each State into territorial constituencies as may be readjusted on the basis of the 2001 census,

 

under this article.
Simplified_Description: Upon the completion of each census, the allocation of seats in the House of the People to the States and the division of each State into territorial constituencies shall be readjusted by such authority and in such manner as Parliament may by law determine.Provided that such readjustment shall not affect representation until the dissolution of the then existing House.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Mandates the readjustment of Lok Sabha seats among states after every census.
Also mandates the redrawing of territorial constituencies within each state.
Parliament is empowered to determine the authority (i.e., the Delimitation Commission) and the manner of this readjustment.
Such readjustment only takes effect from a date specified by the President and does not affect the existing Lok Sabha.
Constitutional amendments have frozen the allocation of seats among states based on the 1971 census.
Historical_Context: The purpose of this article is to ensure the democratic principle of 'one person, one vote, one value' by realigning political representation with demographic changes. However, the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976, froze the allocation of seats based on the 1971 census until the year 2000 to encourage states to pursue population control measures without fearing a loss of political representation. The 84th Amendment Act, 2001, extended this freeze until the first census after 2026, but allowed for the readjustment of constituencies within states based on the 1991 (later updated to 2001) census.
Landmark_Cases: The actions and recommendations of the Delimitation Commission, set up under laws made through this article, have been the subject of various legal proceedings, although the final orders of the Commission are not questionable in court.
Related_Articles: Article 81 (Composition of the House of the People)
Article 327 (Power of Parliament to make provision with respect to elections)

Title: Duration of Houses of Parliament
Original_Description:
(1) The Council of States shall not be subject to dissolution, but as nearly as possible one-third of the members thereof shall retire as soon as may be on the expiration of every second year in accordance with the provisions made in that behalf by Parliament by law.

 

(2) The House of the People, unless sooner dissolved, shall continue for five years from the date appointed for its first meeting and no longer and the expiration of the said period of five years shall operate as a dissolution of the House:

 

Provided that the said period may, while a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation, be extended by Parliament by law for a period not exceeding one year at a time and not extending in any case beyond a period of six months after the Proclamation has ceased to operate.
Simplified_Description: The House of the People, unless sooner dissolved, shall continue for five years from the date appointed for its first meeting and no longer. The expiration of the said period of five years shall operate as a dissolution of the House.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: The Rajya Sabha (Council of States) is a permanent body and is not subject to dissolution.
One-third of the members of the Rajya Sabha retire every two years.
The Lok Sabha (House of the People) has a normal term of five years from the date of its first meeting.
The Lok Sabha can be dissolved before the completion of its term by the President.
The term of the Lok Sabha can be extended by Parliament for one year at a time during a national emergency.
Historical_Context: The continuous nature of the Rajya Sabha ensures there is always a legislative body at the Union level, providing stability. The fixed five-year term for the Lok Sabha ensures democratic accountability. During the Emergency, the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976, controversially extended the Lok Sabha's term to six years, but the 44th Amendment Act, 1978, restored it to five years.
Landmark_Cases: This article's provisions are fundamental to parliamentary procedure and are generally not a source of litigation, except in cases concerning the dissolution of the Lok Sabha.
Related_Articles: Article 85 (Sessions of Parliament, prorogation and dissolution)

Title: Qualification for membership of Parliament
Original_Description:
A person shall not be qualified to be chosen to fill a seat in Parliament unless he —

 

(a) is a citizen of India, and makes and subscribes before some person authorised in that behalf by the Election Commission an oath or affirmation according to the form set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule;

 

(b) is, in the case of a seat in the Council of States, not less than thirty years of age and, in the case of a seat in the House of the People, not less than twenty-five years of age; and

 

(c) possesses such other qualifications as may be prescribed in that behalf by or under any law made by Parliament.
Simplified_Description: A person shall not be qualified to be chosen to fill a seat in Parliament unless he is a citizen of India, and makes and subscribes before some person authorised in that behalf by the Election Commission.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Specifies the eligibility criteria for becoming a Member of Parliament (MP).
A candidate must be a citizen of India.
Minimum age for Rajya Sabha is 30 years.
Minimum age for Lok Sabha is 25 years.
Parliament can prescribe other qualifications by law (as done in the Representation of the People Act, 1951).
Historical_Context: These qualifications were set to ensure a minimum level of maturity and a fundamental commitment (citizenship) for the nation's lawmakers. The higher age limit for the Rajya Sabha reflects its intended role as the 'House of Elders', providing a more seasoned perspective on legislation.
Landmark_Cases: Cases related to the qualifications and disqualifications of MPs are often heard by the courts, usually interpreting the provisions of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, which was enacted under the authority of this article.

Title: Sessions of Parliament, prorogation and dissolution
Original_Description:
(1) The President shall from time to time summon each House of Parliament to meet at such time and place as he thinks fit, but six months shall not intervene between its last sitting in one session and the date appointed for its first sitting in the next session.

 

(2) The President may from time to time —

 

(a) prorogue the Houses or either House;

 

(b) dissolve the House of the People.
Simplified_Description: The President may from time to time summon each House of Parliament to meet at such time and place as he thinks fit. Six months shall not intervene between its last sitting in one session and the date appointed for its first sitting in the next session.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: The President has the power to summon (call a session), prorogue (end a session), and dissolve the Lok Sabha.
The maximum gap between two sessions of Parliament cannot be more than six months.
Prorogation ends a session, while dissolution ends the life of the Lok Sabha itself.
The Rajya Sabha, being a permanent house, is not subject to dissolution.
Historical_Context: This article establishes the executive's power over the legislative schedule. The six-month rule is a crucial safeguard that prevents a government from avoiding parliamentary scrutiny for an extended period. The President's power to dissolve the Lok Sabha is a key feature of the parliamentary system, exercised on the advice of the Council of Ministers, which can lead to early elections.
Landmark_Cases: S.R. Bommai vs Union of India (1994): While primarily about state governments, the case discussed the principles of parliamentary democracy and the confidence of the house, which are relevant to the dissolution of the Lok Sabha.
Related_Articles: Article 74 (Council of Ministers to aid and advise President)

Title: Right of President to address and send messages to Houses
Original_Description:
(1) The President may address either House of Parliament or both Houses assembled together, and for that purpose require the attendance of members.

 

(2) The President may send messages to either House of Parliament, whether with respect to a Bill then pending in Parliament or otherwise, and a House to which any message is so sent shall with all convenient despatch consider any matter required by the message to be taken into consideration
Simplified_Description: The President may send messages to either House of Parliament, whether with respect to a Bill then pending in Parliament or otherwise. Both Houses assembled together, and for that purpose require the attendance of members.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Gives the President the right to address either House of Parliament or a joint sitting of both Houses.
Gives the President the right to send messages to Parliament, concerning a pending bill or any other matter.
The House to which a message is sent must consider it with 'all convenient despatch'.
Historical_Context: This is a general power of the President to communicate with Parliament. It is distinct from the 'special address' under Article 87. The right to send messages has been rarely used, as formal communication between the executive and legislature typically happens through ministers.
Landmark_Cases: This article outlines a power of the President and is not typically a subject of legal disputes.

Title: Special address by the President
Original_Description:
(1) At the commencement of the first session after each general election to the House of the People and at the commencement of the first session of each year the President shall address both Houses of Parliament assembled together and inform Parliament of the causes of its summons.

 

(2) Provision shall be made by the rules regulating the procedure of either House for the allotment of time for discussion of the matters referred to in such address.
Simplified_Description: The President shall inform Parliament of the causes of its summons. Provision shall be made by the rules regulating the procedure of either House for the allotment of time for discussion of the matters referred to.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Mandates a 'special address' by the President on two occasions: the first session after a general election, and the first session of every year.
The address is delivered to both Houses of Parliament assembled together.
In the address, the President informs Parliament of the 'causes of its summons', which essentially means outlining the government's policies and legislative agenda for the upcoming year.
The address is followed by a 'Motion of Thanks' which is debated and voted upon.
Historical_Context: This procedure is derived from the 'Speech from the Throne' in the British Parliament. The President's address is prepared by the government and serves as a statement of its policy intentions. The defeat of a Motion of Thanks is considered a vote of no-confidence and can lead to the government's resignation.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article and is a part of established parliamentary practice.
Related_Articles: Article 86 (Right of President to address and send messages to Houses)

Title: Rights of Ministers and Attorney General as respects Houses
Original_Description: Every Minister and the Attorney-General of India shall have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of, either House, any joint sitting of the Houses, and any committee of Parliament of which he may be named a member, but shall not by virtue of this article be entitled to vote.
Simplified_Description: Every Minister and the Attorney-General of India shall have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of, either House.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Grants Ministers and the Attorney-General the right to speak and participate in the proceedings of both the Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha.
They can also participate in joint sittings and parliamentary committees of which they are members.
Crucially, it clarifies that this right to participate does not give them the right to vote in a House of which they are not a member.
Historical_Context: This provision allows for better coordination and functioning of the government. For example, a minister who is a member of the Rajya Sabha can go to the Lok Sabha to introduce a bill or answer questions related to their ministry, and vice versa. It also allows the government's chief legal officer, the Attorney-General, to present the government's legal position directly to Parliament.
Landmark_Cases: This article defines the rights of participation and is a clear procedural rule.

Title: The Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Council of States
Original_Description:
(1) The Vice-President of India shall be ex officio Chairman of the Council of States.

 

(2) The Council of States shall, as soon as may be, choose a member of the Council to be Deputy Chairman thereof and, so often as the office of Deputy Chairman becomes vacant, the Council shall choose another member to be Deputy Chairman thereof.
Simplified_Description: The Vice-President of India shall be ex officio Chairman of the Council of States. The Council of State shall, as soon as may be, choose a member of the council to be Deputy Chairman thereof.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Declares that the Vice-President of India is the ex-officio Chairman of the Rajya Sabha.
Mandates that the Rajya Sabha shall elect one of its own members to be the Deputy Chairman.
Historical_Context: This article establishes the leadership structure of the Rajya Sabha. Having the Vice-President as the Chairman provides the house with a presiding officer of high rank who is not a member of any political party within the house. The Deputy Chairman, elected from among the members, presides in the Chairman's absence and is usually a member of the ruling coalition.
Landmark_Cases: This is a structural article and not a subject of legal dispute.
Related_Articles: Article 64 (The Vice-President to be ex officio Chairman...)
Article 93 (The Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the House of the People)

Title: Vacation and resignation of, and removal from, the office of Deputy Chairman
Original_Description:
A member holding office as Deputy Chairman of the Council of States —

 

(a) shall vacate his office if he ceases to be a member of the Council;

 

(b) may at any time, by writing under his hand addressed to the Chairman, resign his office; and

 

(c) may be removed from his office by a resolution of the Council passed by a majority of all the then members of the Council:

 

Provided that no resolution for the purpose of clause (c) shall be moved unless at least fourteen days’ notice has been given of the intention to move the resolution.
Simplified_Description: A member holding office as Deputy Chairman of the Council of States —. shall vacate his office if he ceases to be a member. A member may resign his office by writing under his hand addressed to the Chairman.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Specifies how the office of the Deputy Chairman of the Rajya Sabha can become vacant.
The Deputy Chairman must vacate the office if they cease to be a member of the Rajya Sabha.
They can resign by writing to the Chairman (the Vice-President).
They can be removed by a resolution passed by the Rajya Sabha with an 'effective majority' (a majority of all the then members of the Council).
Historical_Context: This article outlines the procedures for ensuring accountability and transition in the office of the Deputy Chairman, mirroring similar provisions for other presiding officers.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article governing the functioning of the Rajya Sabha.
Related_Articles: Article 94 (Vacation and resignation of... Speaker and Deputy Speaker)

Title: Power of the Deputy Chairman or other person to perform the duties of the office of, or to act as, Chairman
Original_Description:
(1) While the office of Chairman is vacant, or during any period when the Vice-President is acting as, or discharging the functions of, President, the duties of the office shall be performed by the Deputy Chairman, or, if the office of Deputy Chairman is also vacant, by such member of the Council of States as the President may appoint for the purpose.

 

(2) During the absence of the Chairman from any sitting of the Council of States the Deputy Chairman, or, if he is also absent, such person as may be determined by the rules of procedure of the Council, or, if no such person is present, such other person as may be determined by the Council, shall act as Chairman.
Simplified_Description: While the office of Chairman is vacant, or during any period when the Vice-President is acting as, or discharging the functions of, President, the duties of the office shall be performed by the Deputy Chairman. The Deputy Chairman, or, if he is also absent, such person as may be determined by the rules of procedure of the Council, shall act as Chairman.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: The Deputy Chairman performs the duties of the Chairman when the Chairman's office is vacant.
The Deputy Chairman also performs the Chairman's duties when the Vice-President is acting as the President.
The Deputy Chairman presides over the Rajya Sabha during the temporary absence of the Chairman.
If the Deputy Chairman is also absent, a member from the panel of Vice-Chairpersons (determined by the rules of the House) presides.
Historical_Context: This article ensures that the proceedings of the Rajya Sabha can continue uninterrupted even in the absence or vacancy of the Chairman's office.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural provision for the internal functioning of Parliament.
Related_Articles: Article 65 (The Vice-President to act as President...)

Title: The Chairman or the Deputy Chairman not to preside while a resolution for his removal from office is under consideration
Original_Description:
(1) At any sitting of the Council of States, while any resolution for the removal of the Vice-President from his office is under consideration, the Chairman, or while any resolution for the removal of the Deputy Chairman from his office is under consideration, the Deputy Chairman, shall not, though he is present, preside, and the provisions of clause (2) of article 91 shall apply in relation to every such sitting as they apply in relation to a sitting from which the Chairman, or, as the case may be, the Deputy Chairman, is absent.

 

(2) The Chairman shall have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of, the Council of States while any resolution for the removal of the Vice-President from his office is under consideration in the Council, but, notwithstanding anything in article 100, shall not be entitled to vote at all on such resolution or on any other matter during such proceedings.
Simplified_Description: At any sitting of the Council of States, while any resolution for the removal of the Vice-President from his office is under consideration, the Chairman, or the Deputy Chairman, shall not, though he is present, preside. The provisions of clause (2) of article 91 shall apply in relation to every such sitting.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Prohibits the Chairman (Vice-President) from presiding over the Rajya Sabha when a resolution for his removal is being considered.
Similarly, the Deputy Chairman cannot preside when a resolution for their removal is under consideration.
The person facing removal can be present, speak, and participate in the proceedings.
The Chairman (Vice-President) is not entitled to vote at all on the resolution for their removal.
Historical_Context: This provision is based on the principles of natural justice, ensuring that a person does not act as a judge in their own cause. It guarantees a fair process when the removal of a presiding officer is being debated.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural rule of Parliament and has not been the subject of court cases.
Related_Articles: Article 67 (Term of office of Vice-President, including removal)
Article 90 (Removal from the office of Deputy Chairman)
Article 96 (Similar provision for the Speaker and Deputy Speaker)

Title: The Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the House of the People
Original_Description: The House of the People shall, as soon as may be, choose two members of the House to be respectively Speaker and Deputy Speaker thereof and, so often as the office of Speaker or Deputy Speaker becomes vacant, the House shall choose another member to be Speaker or Deputy Speaker, as the case may be.
Simplified_Description: The House of the People shall, as soon as may be, choose two members of the House to be respectively Speaker and Deputy Speaker thereof. The House shall choose another member to be Speaker or Deputy Speaker, as the case may be.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Mandates that the Lok Sabha must choose two of its members to be the Speaker and Deputy Speaker.
The election of the Speaker is one of the first acts of a newly constituted Lok Sabha.
When the office of Speaker or Deputy Speaker becomes vacant, the House must elect another member to fill the vacancy.
Historical_Context: The offices of the Speaker and Deputy Speaker are crucial for the functioning of the Lok Sabha. The Speaker is the presiding officer and the custodian of the powers and privileges of the House. By convention, the Speaker is usually from the ruling party, and the post of Deputy Speaker is offered to the opposition, although this is not always followed.
Landmark_Cases: This is a foundational article for the structure of the Lok Sabha.
Related_Articles: Article 89 (The Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Council of States)

Title: Vacation and resignation of, and removal from, the offices of Speaker and Deputy Speaker
Original_Description:
A member holding office as Speaker or Deputy Speaker of the House of the People —

 

(a) shall vacate his office if he ceases to be a member of the House of the People;

 

(b) may at any time, by writing under his hand addressed, if such member is the Speaker, to the Deputy Speaker, and if such member is the Deputy Speaker, to the Speaker, resign his office; and

 

(c) may be removed from his office by a resolution of the House of the People passed by a majority of all the then members of the House:

 

Provided that no resolution for the purpose of clause (c) shall be moved unless at least fourteen days' notice has been given of the intention to move the resolution: Provided further that, whenever the House of the People is dissolved, the Speaker shall not vacate his office until immediately before the first meeting of the House of the People after the dissolution.
Simplified_Description: A member holding office as Speaker or Deputy Speaker of the House of the People —. shall vacate his office if he ceases to be a member. The Speaker may be removed from his office by a resolution passed by a majority of all the then members.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Specifies how the offices of Speaker and Deputy Speaker become vacant.
They must vacate their office if they cease to be a member of the Lok Sabha.
The Speaker can resign by writing to the Deputy Speaker, and vice versa.
They can be removed by a resolution passed by an 'effective majority' (majority of all the then members) of the Lok Sabha.
The Speaker does not vacate their office upon dissolution of the Lok Sabha but continues until the first meeting of the new House.
Historical_Context: The provision for the Speaker to continue in office until the new Lok Sabha meets ensures that there is no vacuum in the office. This is important as the Speaker has administrative duties and represents the House even when it is dissolved.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article governing the functioning of the Lok Sabha.
Related_Articles: Article 90 (Vacation and resignation of... Deputy Chairman)

Title: Power of the Deputy Speaker or other person to perform the duties of the office of, or to act as, Speaker
Original_Description:
(1) While the office of Speaker is vacant, the duties of the office shall be performed by the Deputy Speaker or, if the office of Deputy Speaker is also vacant, by such member of the House of the People as the President may appoint for the purpose.

 

(2) During the absence of the Speaker from any sitting of the House of the People the Deputy Speaker or, if he is also absent, such person as may be determined by the rules of procedure of the House, or, if no such person is present, such other person as may be determined by the House, shall act as Speaker.
Simplified_Description: While the office of Speaker is vacant, the duties of the office shall be performed by the Deputy Speaker or, if the office is also vacant, by such member of the House of the People as the President may appoint.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: The Deputy Speaker performs the duties of the Speaker when the Speaker's office is vacant.
The Deputy Speaker presides over the Lok Sabha during the temporary absence of the Speaker.
If the office of the Deputy Speaker is also vacant, the President can appoint a member of the Lok Sabha to perform the Speaker's duties.
If both are absent from a sitting, a member from the panel of Chairpersons presides.
Historical_Context: This article ensures the uninterrupted functioning of the Lok Sabha. The recent vacancy in the post of Deputy Speaker for an extended period has led to debates about the mandatory nature ('shall be performed') of this article.
Landmark_Cases: A petition has been filed in the Supreme Court concerning the non-election of a Deputy Speaker, which may lead to a judicial interpretation of this article.

Title: The Speaker or the Deputy Speaker not to preside while a resolution for his removal from office is under consideration
Original_Description:
(1) At any sitting of the House of the People, while any resolution for the removal of the Speaker from his office is under consideration, the Speaker, or while any resolution for the removal of the Deputy Speaker from his office is under consideration, the Deputy Speaker, shall not, though he is present, preside, and the provisions of clause (2) of article 95 shall apply in relation to every such sitting as they apply in relation to a sitting from which the Speaker, or, as the case may be, the Deputy Speaker, is absent.

 

(2) The Speaker shall have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of, the House of the People while any resolution for his removal from office is under consideration in the House and shall, notwithstanding anything in article 100, be entitled to vote only in the first instance on such resolution or on any other matter during such proceedings but not in the case of an equality of votes
Simplified_Description: At any sitting of the House of the People, while any resolution for the removal of the Speaker from his office is under consideration, the Speaker, or the Deputy Speaker, shall not preside. The Speaker shall have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of, the House.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Prohibits the Speaker or Deputy Speaker from presiding over the Lok Sabha when a resolution for their removal is being considered.
The person facing removal has the right to be present, speak, and participate in the proceedings.
When such a resolution is being debated, the Speaker can vote in the first instance like any other member, but loses their casting vote in case of a tie.
Historical_Context: This provision is based on the principles of natural justice, ensuring fairness in the process of removing a presiding officer. The change in voting rights (from casting vote to ordinary vote) reflects their temporary status as an ordinary member during the proceedings.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural rule of Parliament and has not been a subject of court cases.
Related_Articles: Article 92 (Similar provision for the Chairman and Deputy Chairman)
Article 94 (Removal from the offices of Speaker and Deputy Speaker)

Title: Salaries and allowances of the Chairman and Deputy Chairman and the Speaker and Deputy Speaker
Original_Description: There shall be paid to the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman of the Council of States, and to the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker of the House of the People, such salaries and allowances as may be respectively fixed by Parliament by law and, until provision in that behalf is so made, such salaries and allowances as are specified in the Second Schedule.
Simplified_Description: There shall be paid to the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman of the Council of States, and to the Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the House of the People, such salaries and allowances as may be respectively fixed by Parliament by law.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to determine the salaries and allowances of the presiding officers of both Houses.
This includes the Chairman & Deputy Chairman of the Rajya Sabha and the Speaker & Deputy Speaker of the Lok Sabha.
Until Parliament makes a law, their salaries are as specified in the Second Schedule.
These salaries are charged on the Consolidated Fund of India and are not subject to the annual vote of Parliament.
Historical_Context: By charging the salaries of presiding officers on the Consolidated Fund, the Constitution ensures their independence from the executive and from the political pressures of the annual budget process.
Landmark_Cases: This is a financial and procedural article.
Related_Articles: Article 112(3) (Expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of India)

Title: Secretariat of Parliament
Original_Description:
(1) Each House of Parliament shall have a separate secretarial staff:

 

Provided that nothing in this clause shall be construed as preventing the creation of posts common to both Houses of Parliament.

 

(2) Parliament may by law regulate the recruitment, and the conditions of service of persons appointed, to the secretarial staff of either House of Parliament.

 

(3) Until provision is made by Parliament under clause (2), the President may, after consultation with the Speaker of the House of the People or the Chairman of the Council of States, as the case may be, make rules regulating the recruitment, and the conditions of service of persons appointed, to the secretarial staff of the House of the People or the Council of States, and any rules so made shall have effect subject to the provisions of any law made under the said clause.
Simplified_Description: Each House of Parliament shall have a separate secretarial staff. Parliament may by law regulate the recruitment, and the conditions of service of persons appointed.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Mandates a separate secretarial staff for each House of Parliament.
Allows for the creation of posts common to both Houses.
Empowers Parliament to regulate the recruitment and service conditions of the secretarial staff.
Until Parliament does so, the President makes rules in consultation with the Speaker or the Chairman.
Historical_Context: An independent secretariat for each House is crucial for maintaining the independence of the legislature from the executive. The secretariats of the Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha function under the overall control of the Speaker and Chairman respectively, not under any government ministry.
Landmark_Cases: This article ensures the administrative independence of Parliament.

Title: Oath or affirmation by members
Original_Description: Every member of either House of Parliament shall, before taking his seat, make and subscribe before the President, or some person appointed in that behalf by him, an oath or affirmation according to the form set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule.
Simplified_Description: Every member of either House of Parliament must take an oath before taking their seats. The oath must be in the form set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Requires every Member of Parliament (MP) to take an oath or make an affirmation before taking their seat in the House.
The oath is administered by the President or a person appointed by the President (usually the pro-tem Speaker).
The form of the oath is prescribed in the Third Schedule.
The oath is to bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution and to uphold the sovereignty and integrity of India.
Historical_Context: The oath-taking ceremony is a solemn procedure that marks the official commencement of an MP's term. It binds them to the principles of the Constitution. A member cannot participate in the proceedings of the House or vote without taking the oath.
Landmark_Cases: This is a mandatory procedural requirement.
Related_Articles: Article 104 (Penalty for sitting and voting before making oath...)
Third Schedule (Forms of Oaths or Affirmations)

Title: Voting in Houses, power of Houses to act notwithstanding vacancies and quorum
Original_Description:
(1) Save as otherwise provided in this Constitution, all questions at any sitting of either House or joint sitting of the Houses shall be determined by a majority of votes of the members present and voting, other than the Speaker or person acting as Chairman or Speaker.

 

The Chairman or Speaker, or person acting as such, shall not vote in the first instance, but shall have and exercise a casting vote in the case of an equality of votes.

 

(2) Either House of Parliament shall have power to act notwithstanding any vacancy in the membership thereof, and any proceedings in Parliament shall be valid notwithstanding that it is discovered subsequently that some person who was not entitled so to do sat or voted or otherwise took part in the proceedings.

 

(3) Until Parliament by law otherwise provides, the quorum to constitute a meeting of either House of Parliament shall be one-tenth of the total number of members of the House. (4) If at any time during a meeting of a House there is no quorum, it shall be the duty of the Chairman or Speaker, or person acting as such, either to adjourn the House or to suspend the meeting until there is a quorum.
Simplified_Description: The Chairman or Speaker, or person acting as such, shall not vote in the first instance. The quorum to constitute a meeting of either House of Parliament shall be one-tenth of the total number of members of the House.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Decisions in the Houses are made by a majority of members present and voting.
The presiding officer (Speaker/Chairman) does not vote in the first instance but has a 'casting vote' in case of a tie.
The quorum (minimum number of members required to be present) for a meeting is one-tenth of the total membership of the House.
The proceedings of a House are valid even if there are vacancies in its membership.
Historical_Context: This article lays down the basic rules for decision-making in Parliament. The concept of a casting vote for the presiding officer is a common feature in Westminster-style parliaments, meant to be used to maintain the status quo. The quorum requirement ensures that a small number of members cannot take major decisions.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article governing parliamentary business.
Related_Articles: Article 96 (Voting by Speaker during removal resolution)

Title: Vacation of seats
Original_Description:
(1) No person shall be a member of both Houses of Parliament and provision shall be made by Parliament by law for the vacation by a person who is chosen a member of both Houses of his seat in one House or the other.

 

(2) No person shall be a member both of Parliament and of a House of the Legislature of a State and if a person is chosen a member both of Parliament and of a House of the Legislature of a State, then, at the expiration of such period as may be specified in rules made by the President, that person's seat in Parliament shall become vacant, unless he has previously resigned his seat in the Legislature of the State.

 

(3) If a member of either House of Parliament —

 

(a) becomes subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in clause (1) or clause (2) of article 102, or 5

 

(b) resigns his seat by writing under his hand addressed to the Chairman or the Speaker, as the case may be, and his resignation is accepted by the Chairman or the Speaker, as the case may be, his seat shall thereupon become vacant:

 

his seat shall thereupon become vacant:

 

Provided that in the case of any resignation referred to in sub-clause (b), if from information received or otherwise and after making such inquiry as he thinks fit, the Chairman or the Speaker, as the case may be, is satisfied that such resignation is not voluntary or genuine, he shall not accept such resignation.

 

(4) If for a period of sixty days a member of either House of Parliament is without permission of the House absent from all meetings thereof, the House may declare his seat vacant:

 

Provided that in computing the said period of sixty days no account shall be taken of any period during which the House is prorogued or is adjourned for more than four consecutive days.
Simplified_Description: No person shall be a member both of Parliament and of a House of the Legislature of a State. If a member of either House of Parliament becomes subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in clause (1) or clause (2) of article 102, his seat shall thereupon become vacant.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Lists the circumstances under which a Member of Parliament's seat becomes vacant.
A person cannot be a member of both Houses of Parliament simultaneously.
A person cannot be a member of both Parliament and a State Legislature simultaneously.
A seat becomes vacant if a member resigns, is disqualified, or is absent from the sittings of the House for 60 days without permission.
Historical_Context: These provisions ensure that members are committed to a single legislative body and are actively participating in its proceedings. The rule against dual membership is fundamental to the clear division of roles in a federal structure. The rule on absence is to ensure accountability and regular participation.
Landmark_Cases: The process of accepting resignations and the grounds for disqualification have been subject to judicial scrutiny.

Title: Disqualifications for membership
Simplified_Description: A person shall be disqualified for being chosen as, and for being, a member of either House of Parliament. A person shall not be deemed to hold an office of profit under the Government of India or any State by reason only that he is a Minister either for the Union or such State.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Lists the grounds for disqualification of a Member of Parliament.
These include: holding an office of profit, being of unsound mind, being an undischarged insolvent, not being an Indian citizen, and being disqualified under any law made by Parliament.
This last point (1e) allows Parliament to add more grounds for disqualification, which it has done through the Representation of the People Act, 1951.
Disqualification under the Tenth Schedule (anti-defection law) is also a ground.
Historical_Context: These disqualifications are meant to ensure that legislators are of sound character, are not under conflicting obligations (office of profit), and maintain allegiance to the country. The Representation of the People Act adds further disqualifications, such as conviction for certain criminal offenses.
Landmark_Cases: Jaya Bachchan vs Union of India (2006): A key case that clarified the meaning of 'office of profit'.
Lily Thomas vs Union of India (2013): The Supreme Court struck down a provision in the Representation of the People Act that allowed convicted MPs/MLAs to continue in office if they filed an appeal.
Related_Articles: Article 103 (Decision on questions as to disqualifications)

Title: Decision on questions as to disqualifications of members
Original_Description:
(1) If any question arises as to whether a member of either House of Parliament has become subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in clause (1) of article 102, the question shall be referred for the decision of the President and his decision shall be final.

 

(2) Before giving any decision on any such question, the President shall obtain the opinion of the Election Commission and shall act according to such opinion.
Simplified_Description: The President's decision on disqualifications is final. The President shall obtain the opinion of the Election Commission before making a decision.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Specifies the authority to decide on disqualification of an MP under Article 102(1).
The decision is made by the President of India.
Before making the decision, the President must obtain the opinion of the Election Commission of India.
The President is bound to act according to the Election Commission's opinion.
This article does not apply to disqualification on grounds of defection (which is decided by the Presiding Officer under the Tenth Schedule).
Historical_Context: This article provides a clear mechanism for adjudicating disqualification cases (other than defection). By involving the Election Commission, a quasi-judicial body, and making its advice binding, the process is intended to be fair and based on expert opinion, rather than being a purely political decision.
Landmark_Cases: This process has been followed in several 'office of profit' cases and other disqualification matters referred to the President.

Title: Penalty for sitting and voting before making oath or affirmation under article 99 or when not qualified or when disqualified
Original_Description: If a person sits or votes as a member of either House of Parliament before he has complied with the requirements of article 99, or when he knows that he is not qualified or that he is disqualified for membership thereof, or that he is prohibited from so doing by the provisions of any law made by Parliament, he shall be liable in respect of each day on which he so sits or votes to a penalty of five hundred rupees to be recovered as a debt due to the Union.
Simplified_Description: If a person sits or votes as a member of either House of Parliament before he has complied with the requirements of article 99, or when he knows that he is not qualified, he will be liable to a penalty of five hundred rupees.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Imposes a penalty for sitting and voting in Parliament under certain circumstances.
The penalty is ₹500 per day.
It applies if a person participates without taking the oath (under Article 99).
It also applies if a person participates knowing they are not qualified or have been disqualified.
Historical_Context: This article acts as a deterrent and enforcement mechanism for the rules regarding oath-taking and qualification for membership in Parliament, ensuring that only duly qualified and sworn-in members participate in legislative proceedings.
Landmark_Cases: This is a penal provision and has been invoked in rare instances.

Title: Powers, privileges, etc, of the Houses of Parliament and of the members and committees thereof
Original_Description:
(1) Subject to the provisions of this Constitution and to the rules and standing orders regulating the procedure of Parliament, there shall be freedom of speech in Parliament.

 

(2) No member of Parliament shall be liable to any proceedings in any court in respect of any thing said or any vote given by him in Parliament or any committee thereof, and no person shall be so liable in respect of the publication by or under the authority of either House of Parliament of any report, paper, votes or proceedings.

 

(3) In other respects, the powers, privileges and immunities of each House of Parliament, and of the members and the committees of each House, shall be such as may from time to time be defined by Parliament by law, and, until so defined, shall be those of that House and of its members and committees immediately before the coming into force of section 15 of the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978.

 

(4) The provisions of clauses (1), (2) and (3) shall apply in relation to persons who by virtue of this Constitution have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of, a House of Parliament or any committee thereof as they apply in relation to members of Parliament.
Simplified_Description: There shall be freedom of speech in Parliament. No member of Parliament shall be liable to any proceedings in any court in respect of any thing said or any vote given.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Guarantees freedom of speech for Members of Parliament within the House.
Provides absolute immunity to MPs from any court proceedings for anything said or any vote cast in Parliament or its committees.
States that other powers, privileges, and immunities of the Houses and their members are to be defined by Parliament by law.
This includes the power to punish for contempt or breach of privilege.
Historical_Context: Parliamentary privileges are essential for the independence and effectiveness of the legislature. They allow MPs to debate freely without fear of legal consequences. The scope of these privileges, particularly the power to punish for contempt and their relationship with fundamental rights, has been a recurring point of tension between the Parliament and the judiciary.
Landmark_Cases: Keshav Singh's Case (1965): A landmark case that dealt with the conflict between legislative privileges under Article 105 and an individual's fundamental rights, particularly Article 21.

P.V. Narasimha Rao vs State (CBI) (1998): The Supreme Court held that the immunity under Article 105(2) extends to bribery cases, i.e., an MP cannot be prosecuted for taking a bribe to vote or speak in Parliament. (This was later overruled in part in 2024).
Related_Articles: Article 19(1)(a) (Freedom of speech for citizens, which is not absolute)
Article 194 (Powers, privileges, etc., of the Houses of Legislatures of States)

Title: Salaries and allowances of members
Original_Description: Members of either House of Parliament shall be entitled to receive such salaries and allowances as may from time to time be determined by Parliament by law and, until provision in that respect is so made, allowances at such rates and upon such conditions as were immediately before the commencement of this Constitution applicable in the case of members of the Constituent Assembly of the Dominion of India.
Simplified_Description: Members of either House of Parliament shall be entitled to receive such salaries and allowances as may from time to time be determined by Parliament by law.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to determine the salaries and allowances of its own members.
This is done by enacting a law.
Until such a law is made, the allowances were to be the same as for members of the Constituent Assembly.
Historical_Context: This article gives the legislature autonomy in determining the financial compensation for its members. The salaries and allowances of MPs are periodically revised by Parliament through legislation, which has sometimes been a subject of public debate.
Landmark_Cases: This is a financial and procedural article.
Related_Articles: Article 195 (Salaries and allowances of members of State Legislatures)

Title: Provisions as to introduction and passing of Bills
Original_Description:
(1) Subject to the provisions of articles 109 and 117 with respect to Money Bills and other financial Bills, a Bill may originate in either House of Parliament.

 

(2) Subject to the provisions of articles 108 and 109, a Bill shall not be deemed to have been passed by the Houses of Parliament unless it has been agreed to by both Houses, either without amendment or with such amendments only as are agreed to by both Houses.

 

(3) A Bill pending in Parliament shall not lapse by reason of the prorogation of the Houses.

 

(4) A Bill pending in the Council of States which has not been passed by the House of the People shall not lapse on a dissolution of the House of the People.

 

(5) A Bill which is pending in the House of the People, or which having been passed by the House of the People is pending in the Council of States, shall, subject to the provisions of article 108, lapse on a dissolution of the House of the People.
Simplified_Description: A Bill may originate in either House of Parliament. A Bill pending in Parliament shall not lapse by reason of the prorogation of the Houses.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: An ordinary bill can be introduced in either the Lok Sabha or the Rajya Sabha.
A bill must be passed by both Houses to become law.
Prorogation (ending a session) of the House does not lead to the lapsing of a bill.
Dissolution of the Lok Sabha leads to the lapsing of all bills pending in the Lok Sabha.
Bills passed by the Lok Sabha but pending in the Rajya Sabha also lapse on dissolution.
A bill pending in the Rajya Sabha which has not been passed by the Lok Sabha does not lapse.
Historical_Context: This article lays down the fundamental rules of the legislative process, particularly the life cycle of a bill. The rules about the lapsing of bills are important for understanding the impact of parliamentary sessions and general elections on pending legislation.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article central to the legislative process.
Related_Articles: Article 109 (Special procedure in respect of Money Bills)

Title: Joint sitting of both Houses in certain cases
Original_Description:
(1) If after a Bill has been passed by one House and transmitted to the other House —

 

(a) the Bill is rejected by the other House; or

 

(b) the Houses have finally disagreed as to the amendments to be made in the Bill; or

 

(c) more than six months elapse from the date of the reception of the Bill by the other House without the Bill being passed by it,

 

the President may, unless the Bill has elapsed by reason of a dissolution of the House of the People, notify to the Houses by message if they are sitting or by public notification if they are not sitting, his intention to summon them to meet in a joint sitting for the purpose of deliberating and voting on the Bill:

 

Provided that nothing in this clause shall apply to a Money Bill.

 

(2) In reckoning any such period of six months as is referred to in clause (1), no account shall be taken of any period during which the House referred to in sub-clause (c) of that clause is prorogued or adjourned for more than four consecutive days.

 

(3) Where the President has under clause (1) notified his intention of summoning the Houses to meet in a joint sitting, neither House shall proceed further with the Bill, but the President may at any time after the date of his notification summon the Houses to meet in a joint sitting for the purpose specified in the notification and, if he does so, the Houses shall meet accordingly.

 

(4) If at the joint sitting of the two Houses the Bill, with such amendments, if any, as are agreed to in joint sitting, is passed by a majority of the total number of members of both Houses present and voting, it shall be deemed for the purposes of this Constitution to have been passed by both Houses:

 

Provided that at a joint sitting —

 

(a) if the Bill, having been passed by one House, has not been passed by the other House with amendments and returned to the House in which it originated, no amendment shall be proposed to the Bill other than such amendments (if any) as are made necessary by the delay in the passage of the Bill;

 

(b) if the Bill has been so passed and returned, only such amendments as aforesaid shall be proposed to the Bill and such other amendments as are relevant to the matters with respect to which the Houses have not agreed;

 

and the decision of the person presiding as to the amendments which are admissible under this clause shall be final.

 

(5) A joint sitting may be held under this article and a Bill passed thereat, notwithstanding that a dissolution of the House of the People has intervened since the President notified his intention to summon the Houses to meet therein.
Simplified_Description: The President may, unless the Bill has elapsed by reason of a dissolution of the House of the People, notify to the Houses of his intention to summon them to meet in a joint sitting for the purpose of deliberating and voting on the Bill. If at the joint sitting of the two Houses the Bill, with such amendments, if any, as are agreed to in joint sitting, is
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Provides a mechanism for resolving a deadlock between the Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha on an ordinary bill.
The President can summon a joint sitting of both Houses if a bill is rejected by one House, if they disagree on amendments, or if more than six months pass.
The Speaker of the Lok Sabha presides over the joint sitting.
Decisions are taken by a simple majority of the total number of members of both Houses present and voting.
This provision does not apply to Money Bills or Constitutional Amendment Bills.
Historical_Context: The joint sitting mechanism tends to favor the will of the Lok Sabha, as it has a much larger membership than the Rajya Sabha. This is a tool to overcome legislative obstruction by the upper house. It has been used only three times in India's history: for the Dowry Prohibition Act (1961), the Banking Service Commission (Repeal) Act (1978), and the Prevention of Terrorism Act (2002).
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article for resolving legislative deadlocks.
Related_Articles: Article 107 (Provisions as to introduction and passing of Bills)

Title: Special procedure in respect of Money Bills
Original_Description:
(1) A Money Bill shall not be introduced in the Council of States.

 

(2) After a Money Bill has been passed by the House of the People it shall be transmitted to the Council of States for its recommendations and the Council of States shall within a period of fourteen days from the date of its receipt of the Bill return the Bill to the House of the People with its recommendations and the House of the People may thereupon either accept or reject all or any of the recommendations of the Council of States.

 

(3) If the House of the People accepts any of the recommendations of the Council of States, the Money Bill shall be deemed to have been passed by both Houses with the amendments recommended by the Council of States and accepted by the House of the People.

 

(4) If the House of the People does not accept any of the recommendations of the Council of States, the Money Bill shall be deemed to have been passed by both Houses in the form in which it was passed by the House of the People without any of the amendments recommended by the Council of States.

 

(5) If a Money Bill passed by the House of the People and transmitted to the Council of States for its recommendations is not returned to the House of the People within the said period of fourteen days, it shall be deemed to have been passed by both Houses at the expiration of the said period in the form in which it was passed by the House of the People.
Simplified_Description: A Money Bill shall not be introduced in the Council of States. After a Money Bill has been passed by the House of the People it shall be transmitted to the Council of States for its recommendations. The Council of State shall within a period of fourteen days from the date of its receipt of the Bill return the Bill to the House of People. The House of People may
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: A Money Bill can only be introduced in the Lok Sabha.
After being passed by the Lok Sabha, it is sent to the Rajya Sabha.
The Rajya Sabha has limited powers; it cannot reject or amend a Money Bill.
It must return the bill within 14 days, with or without recommendations.
The Lok Sabha can either accept or reject the Rajya Sabha's recommendations.
If the Rajya Sabha does not return the bill in 14 days, it is deemed to have been passed by both Houses.
Historical_Context: This special procedure ensures the financial supremacy of the Lok Sabha, which is the directly elected house and represents the will of the people. It prevents the indirectly elected Rajya Sabha from blocking the government's financial agenda.
Landmark_Cases: K.S. Puttaswamy vs Union of India (2018) (Aadhaar case): The case involved a major debate on whether the Aadhaar Bill was correctly classified as a Money Bill to bypass the Rajya Sabha.
Related_Articles: Article 117 (Special provisions as to financial Bills)

Title: Definition of “Money Bills”
Simplified_Description: A Bill is deemed to be a Money Bill if it contains only provisions dealing with the imposition, abolition, remission, alteration or regulation of any tax. The decision of the Speaker of the House of the People thereon shall be final.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Defines a Money Bill as a bill containing 'only' provisions related to taxation, government borrowing, appropriation of funds, and other specified financial matters.
Declares that the decision of the Speaker of the Lok Sabha on whether a bill is a Money Bill is final.
Requires the Speaker to certify a bill as a Money Bill before it is sent to the Rajya Sabha or presented to the President.
Historical_Context: The restrictive definition ('only provisions') is meant to prevent the government from including non-financial matters in a Money Bill to bypass the Rajya Sabha's scrutiny. However, the finality of the Speaker's decision has been a contentious issue, leading to accusations of misuse of the provision.
Landmark_Cases: K.S. Puttaswamy vs Union of India (2018) (Aadhaar case): The Supreme Court examined the scope of 'finality' of the Speaker's decision and held that it is subject to judicial review, though it upheld the certification of the Aadhaar Bill in that specific instance.
