Related_Articles: Article 109 (Special procedure in respect of Money Bills)

Title: Assent to Bills
Original_Description:
When a Bill has been passed by the Houses of Parliament, it shall be presented to the President, and the President shall declare either that he assents to the Bill, or that he withholds assent therefrom:

 

      Provided that the President may, as soon as possible after the presentation to him of a Bill for assent, return the Bill if it is not a Money Bill to the Houses with a message requesting that they will reconsider the Bill or any specified provisions thereof and, in particular, will consider the desirability of introducing any such amendments as he may recommend in his message, and when a Bill is so returned, the Houses shall reconsider the Bill accordingly, and if the Bill is passed again by the Houses with or without amendment and presented to the President for assent, the President shall not withhold assent therefrom.
Simplified_Description: When a Bill has been passed by the Houses of Parliament, it shall be presented to the President, and the President shall declare either that he assents to the Bill, or that he withholds assent therefrom. Provided that the President may, as soon as possible after the presentation to him of a Bill for assent, return the Bill.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Describes the President's role after a bill is passed by both Houses of Parliament.
The President has three options for an ordinary bill: give assent, withhold assent (absolute veto), or return the bill for reconsideration (suspensive veto).
If the Parliament passes the bill again (with or without amendments) after reconsideration, the President must give their assent.
In the case of a Money Bill, the President can only give or withhold assent; they cannot return it for reconsideration.
The Constitution does not prescribe a time limit for the President to act, giving rise to the 'pocket veto'.
Historical_Context: The President's veto power is a check on the legislature. However, in India's parliamentary system, it is limited. The absolute veto is generally exercised only on the advice of the cabinet (e.g., for a private member's bill). The suspensive veto is a more direct presidential check, but it can be overridden. The pocket veto (indefinitely delaying a decision) was famously used by President Zail Singh in 1986 on the Indian Post Office (Amendment) Bill.
Landmark_Cases: The exercise of veto power is a political process, guided by constitutional conventions.
Related_Articles: Article 74 (Council of Ministers to aid and advise President)
Article 200 (Assent to Bills by the Governor)

Title: Annual financial statement
Simplified_Description: The President shall in respect of every financial year cause to be laid before both the Houses of Parliament a statement of the estimated receipts and expenditure of the Government of India for that year. The estimates of expenditure embodied in the annual financial statement shall show separately.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Mandates the presentation of an 'Annual Financial Statement', popularly known as the Union Budget, before Parliament for every financial year.
The President is responsible for causing it to be laid before both Houses.
The statement must show the estimated receipts and expenditures of the government.
It must distinguish between expenditure 'charged' on the Consolidated Fund of India and expenditure 'made' from it.
Expenditure 'charged' (e.g., salaries of President, Supreme Court judges) is not subject to a vote, though it can be discussed.
Historical_Context: This article establishes the constitutional requirement for the annual budget, which is a fundamental aspect of parliamentary control over public finances. It ensures that the government cannot raise or spend money without the approval of the people's representatives.
Landmark_Cases: This is a core financial and procedural article of the Constitution.
Related_Articles: Article 113 (Procedure in Parliament with respect to estimates)

Title: Procedure in Parliament with respect to estimates
Original_Description:
(1) So much of the estimates as relates to expenditure charged upon the Consolidated Fund of India shall not be submitted to the vote of Parliament, but nothing in this clause shall be construed as preventing the discussion in either House of Parliament of any of those estimates.

 

(2) So much of the said estimates as relates to other expenditure shall be submitted in the form of demands for grants to the House of the People, and the House of the People shall have power to assent, or to refuse to assent, to any demand, or to assent to any demand subject to a reduction of the amount specified therein.

 

(3) No demand for a grant shall be made except on the recommendation of the President.
Simplified_Description: Nothing in this clause shall be construed as preventing the discussion in either House of Parliament of any of those estimates. So much of the said estimates as relates to other expenditure shall be submitted in the form of demands for grants. No demand for a grant shall be made except on the recommendation of the President.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of India can be discussed but not voted upon by Parliament.
All other expenditure is presented to the Lok Sabha in the form of 'Demands for Grants'.
The Lok Sabha has the power to assent, refuse, or reduce a Demand for Grant.
No demand for a grant can be made except on the recommendation of the President.
Historical_Context: This article operationalizes parliamentary control over government spending. By giving the Lok Sabha the power to vote on Demands for Grants, it makes the government financially accountable to the directly elected house. The process of voting on these demands is a key part of the budget session.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article central to the budget process.

Title: Appropriation Bills
Original_Description:
(1) As soon as may be after the grants under article 113 have been made by the House of the People, there shall be introduced a Bill to provide for the appropriation out of the Consolidated Fund of India of all moneys required to meet —

 

(a) the grants so made by the House of the People; and

 

(b) the expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of India but not exceeding in any case the amount shown in the statement previously laid before Parliament.

 

(2) No amendment shall be proposed to any such Bill in either House of Parliament which will have the effect of varying the amount or altering the destination of any grant so made or of varying the amount of any expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of India, and the decision of the person presiding as to whether an amendment is inadmissible under this clause shall be final.

 

(3) Subject to the provisions of articles 115 and 116, no money shall be withdrawn from the Consolidated Fund of India except under appropriation made by law passed in accordance with the provisions of this article.
Simplified_Description: Article 113 provides for the appropriation out of the Consolidated Fund of India of all moneys required to meet the needs of the country. No amendment shall be proposed to any such Bill in either House of Parliament which will have the effect of varying the amount or altering the destination of any grant.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Mandates that after the Demands for Grants are passed by the Lok Sabha, an 'Appropriation Bill' must be introduced.
This bill authorizes the government to withdraw money from the Consolidated Fund of India.
It includes both the voted grants and the expenditure charged on the Fund.
Crucially, it states that no money can be withdrawn from the Consolidated Fund except under an appropriation made by law.
No amendment can be proposed to this bill that would alter the amount or destination of any grant.
Historical_Context: This article embodies the principle of 'no taxation without representation' and extends it to 'no expenditure without authorization'. The Appropriation Act is the legal authority for the government to spend money. Its passage is essential for the government to function.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article central to the budget process.
Related_Articles: Article 113 (Procedure in Parliament with respect to estimates)

Title: Supplementary, additional or excess grants
Original_Description:
(1) The President shall —

 

(a) if the amount authorised by any law made in accordance with the provisions of article 114 to be expended for a particular service for the current financial year is found to be insufficient for the purposes of that year or when a need has arisen during the current financial year for supplementary or additional expenditure upon some new service not contemplated in the annual financial statement for that year, or

 

(b) if any money has been spent on any service during a financial year in excess of the amount granted for that service and for that year,

 

cause to be laid before both the Houses of Parliament another statement showing the estimated amount of that expenditure or cause to be presented to the House of the People a demand for such excess, as the case may be.

 

(2) The provisions of articles 112, 113 and 114 shall have effect in relation to any such statement and expenditure or demand and also to any law to be made authorising the appropriation of moneys out of the Consolidated Fund of India to meet such expenditure or the grant in respect of such demand as they have effect in relation to the annual financial statement and the expenditure mentioned therein or to a demand for a grant and the law to be made for the authorisation of appropriation of moneys out of the Consolidated Fund of India to meet such expenditure or grant.
Simplified_Description: The President can ask for extra money to be spent on a service in excess of the amount granted for that service. The provisions of articles 112, 113 and 114 shall have effect in relation to any such statement and expenditure.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Provides a mechanism for the government to get parliamentary approval for extra expenditure during a financial year.
Supplementary Grant: When funds for a particular service are found to be insufficient.
Additional Grant: When there is a need for expenditure on a new service not contemplated in the budget.
Excess Grant: When money has been spent in excess of the amount granted. This is regularized after the expenditure, post-scrutiny by the Public Accounts Committee.
The same procedure of Demands for Grants and Appropriation Bill applies to these grants.
Historical_Context: This article provides the necessary flexibility for government finances, allowing it to deal with unforeseen expenditures that were not part of the annual budget, while still maintaining the principle of parliamentary accountability.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article related to public finance.

Title: Votes on account, votes of credit and exceptional grants
Simplified_Description: The House of the People shall have power to make any grant in advance in respect of the estimated expenditure for a part of any financial year. The provisions of articles 113 and 114 shall have effect in relation to the making of any grant under clause (1) and to any law to be made.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Provides for three types of special grants by the Lok Sabha:
1. Vote on Account: An advance grant made to enable the government to meet its expenses for a part of the new financial year, pending the full passage of the budget.
2. Vote of Credit: A blank cheque granted to the executive to meet an unexpected demand where the details cannot be stated.
3. Exceptional Grant: Granted for a special purpose which does not form part of the ordinary expenditure of a financial year.
Historical_Context: The 'Vote on Account' is a routine practice, especially in an election year when a full budget cannot be presented. 'Votes of Credit' and 'Exceptional Grants' are extraordinary financial powers and are very rarely used.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article related to public finance.
Related_Articles: Article 113 (Procedure in Parliament with respect to estimates)

Title: Special provisions as to financial Bills
Original_Description:
(1) A Bill or amendment making provision for any of the matters specified in sub-clauses (a) to (f) of clause (1) of article 110 shall not be introduced or moved except on the recommendation of the President and a Bill making such provision shall not be introduced in the Council of States:

 

Provided that no recommendation shall be required under this clause for the moving of an amendment making provision for the reduction or abolition of any tax.

 

(2) A Bill or amendment shall not be deemed to make provision for any of the matters aforesaid by reason only that it provides for the imposition of fines or other pecuniary penalties, or for the demand or payment of fees for licences or fees for services rendered, or by reason that it provides for the imposition, abolition, remission, alteration or regulation of any tax by any local authority or body for local purposes.

 

(3) A Bill which, if enacted and brought into operation, would involve expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of India shall not be passed by either House of Parliament unless the President has recommended to that House the consideration of the Bill.
Simplified_Description: A Bill or amendment making provision for any of the matters specified in sub-clauses (a) to (f) of clause (1) of article 110 shall not be introduced or moved except on the recommendation of the President. A Bill which, if enacted and brought into operation, would involve expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of India will not be passed.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Deals with 'Financial Bills', which are different from Money Bills.

Financial Bills (Category I): Contain provisions of Article 110 but also other general matters. They can only be introduced in the Lok Sabha on the President's recommendation. Otherwise, they follow the procedure of an ordinary bill.

Financial Bills (Category II): Contain provisions involving expenditure from the Consolidated Fund. They can be introduced in either House but require the President's recommendation for consideration.
A Money Bill is a specific type of Financial Bill.
Historical_Context: This article creates categories of financial legislation that are not as restrictive as Money Bills but still require executive pre-approval (President's recommendation) due to their financial implications. This ensures executive control over public finances.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article defining types of financial legislation.
Related_Articles: Article 109 (Special procedure in respect of Money Bills)

Title: Rules of procedure
Original_Description:
(1) Each House of Parliament may make rules for regulating, subject to the provisions of this Constitution, its procedure and the conduct of its business.

 

(2) Until rules are made under clause (1), the rules of procedure and standing orders in force immediately before the commencement of this Constitution with respect to the Legislature of the Dominion of India shall have effect in relation to Parliament subject to such modifications and adaptations as may be made therein by the Chairman of the Council of States or the Speaker of the House of the People, as the case may be.

 

(3) The President, after consultation with the Chairman of the Council of States and the Speaker of the House of the People, may make rules as to the procedure with respect to joint sittings of, and communications between, the two Houses.

 

(4) At a joint sitting of the two Houses the Speaker of the House of the People, or in his absence such person as may be determined by rules of procedure made under clause (3), shall preside.
Simplified_Description: Each House of Parliament may make rules for regulating, subject to the provisions of this Constitution, its procedure and the conduct of its business. Until rules are made under clause (1), rules of procedure and standing orders in force with respect to the Legislature of the Dominion of India shall have effect.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Empowers each House of Parliament to make its own rules of procedure and conduct of business.
The President, after consulting the Speaker and Chairman, makes rules for joint sittings.
The Speaker of the Lok Sabha presides over a joint sitting.
Historical_Context: This article gives autonomy to the Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha to manage their internal affairs. The 'Rules of Procedure and Conduct of Business' for each House are detailed documents that govern every aspect of parliamentary functioning, from asking questions to debating bills.
Landmark_Cases: Courts generally do not interfere with the internal proceedings of the House, which are governed by these rules, unless there is a gross violation of the Constitution.
Related_Articles: Article 122 (Courts not to inquire into proceedings of Parliament)

Title: Regulation by law of procedure in Parliament in relation to financial business
Original_Description: Parliament may, for the purpose of the timely completion of financial business, regulate by law the procedure of, and the conduct of business in, each House of Parliament in relation to any financial matter or to any Bill for the appropriation of moneys out of the Consolidated Fund of India, and, if and so far as any provision of any law so made is inconsistent with any rule made by a House of Parliament under clause (1) of article 118 or with any rule or standing order having effect in relation to Parliament under clause (2) of that article, such provision shall prevail.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may regulate by law the procedure of, and the conduct of business in, each House of Parliament in relation to any financial matter or to any Bill for the appropriation of moneys out of the Consolidated Fund of India.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Allows Parliament to make a law to regulate its own procedure for financial business.
This is done to ensure the 'timely completion' of financial matters, like the passing of the budget.
If a law is made under this article, its provisions will override any rules made by the House under Article 118.
Historical_Context: This article provides an additional tool to streamline the budget process. It recognizes that financial business is time-sensitive and gives Parliament the power to create a binding legal framework for its own procedures to avoid delays.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article.

Title: Language to be used in Parliament
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything in Part XVII, but subject to the provisions of article 348, business in Parliament shall be transacted in Hindi or in English:

 

       Provided that the Chairman of the Council of States or Speaker of the House of the People, or person acting as such, as the case may be, may permit any member who cannot adequately express himself in Hindi or in English to address the House in his mother-tongue.

 

(2) Unless Parliament by law otherwise provides, this article shall, after the expiration of a period of fifteen years from the commencement of this Constitution, have effect as if the words "or in English" were omitted therefrom.
Simplified_Description: Business in Parliament shall be transacted in Hindi or in English. Chairman of the Council of States or Speaker of the House of the People may permit any member who cannot adequately express himself in Hindi to address the House in his mother-tongue.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Specifies that the business in Parliament shall be transacted in Hindi or English.
The presiding officer of a House can permit a member to speak in their mother tongue if they cannot express themselves in Hindi or English.
The Constitution originally provided for the discontinuation of English after 15 years, but this was overridden by the Official Languages Act, 1963.
Historical_Context: The language issue was one of the most contentious in the Constituent Assembly. This article represented a compromise. While Hindi was designated the official language, the continuation of English was permitted. The Official Languages Act, 1963, allowed for the continued use of English alongside Hindi indefinitely, addressing the concerns of non-Hindi speaking states.
Landmark_Cases: This article governs the internal functioning of Parliament.

Title: Restriction on discussion in Parliament
Original_Description: No discussion shall take place in Parliament with respect to the conduct of any Judge of the Supreme Court or of a High Court in the discharge of his duties except upon a motion for presenting an address to the President praying for the removal of the Judge as hereinafter provided.
Simplified_Description: No discussion shall take place in Parliament with respect to the conduct of any Judge of the Supreme Court or of a High Court in the discharge of his duties except upon a motion for presenting an address to the President praying for the removal.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Prohibits any discussion in Parliament about the conduct of a Supreme Court or High Court judge in the discharge of their duties.
The only exception is when Parliament is considering a motion for the impeachment (removal) of a judge.
This restriction applies to both Houses of Parliament.
Historical_Context: This article is a crucial provision for protecting the independence of the judiciary. It prevents the legislature from using its floor to exert political pressure on judges or to criticize their judicial conduct, thereby insulating them from political attacks and allowing them to perform their duties without fear or favor.
Landmark_Cases: In the matter of Keshav Singh (1965): The court emphasized the importance of mutual respect between the judiciary and the legislature, and the role of provisions like Article 121 in maintaining that balance.
Related_Articles: Article 124(4) (Procedure for removal of a Judge)

Title: Courts not to inquire into proceedings of Parliament
Original_Description:
(1) The validity of any proceedings in Parliament shall not be called in question on the ground of any alleged irregularity of procedure.

 

(2) No officer or member of Parliament in whom powers are vested by or under this Constitution for regulating procedure or the conduct of business, or for maintaining order, in Parliament shall be subject to the jurisdiction of any court in respect of the exercise by him of those powers.
Simplified_Description: The validity of any proceedings in Parliament shall not be called in question on the ground of any alleged irregularity of procedure. No officer or member of Parliament in whom powers are vested by or under this Constitution shall be subject to the jurisdiction of any court in respect of the exercise by him of those powers.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Bars courts from inquiring into the validity of parliamentary proceedings on the grounds of procedural irregularity.
Provides immunity to the officers and members of Parliament responsible for conducting business and regulating procedure from the jurisdiction of courts.
This upholds the principle of the separation of powers and the autonomy of the legislature.
Historical_Context: This article protects the internal autonomy of Parliament. It ensures that the judiciary cannot interfere with the day-to-day proceedings of the legislature. However, this immunity is not absolute. The courts can intervene if the procedure is unconstitutional or violates a mandatory provision of the Constitution, as opposed to a mere 'irregularity'.
Landmark_Cases: Raja Ram Pal vs Hon'ble Speaker, Lok Sabha (2007) (Cash for Query case): The Supreme Court held that while courts cannot review procedural irregularities, they can review proceedings for illegality or unconstitutionality. The court upheld the expulsion of the MPs in this case.

Title: Power of President to promulgate Ordinances during recess of Parliament
Original_Description:
(1) If at any time, except when both Houses of Parliament are in session, the President is satisfied that circumstances exist which render it necessary for him to take immediate action, he may promulgate such Ordinances as the circumstances appear to him to require.

 

(2) An Ordinance promulgated under this article shall have the same force and effect as an Act of Parliament, but every such Ordinance —

 

(a) shall be laid before both Houses of Parliament and shall cease to operate at the expiration of six weeks from the reassembly of Parliament, or, if before the expiration of that period resolutions disapproving it are passed by both Houses, upon the passing of the second of those resolutions; and

 

(b) may be withdrawn at any time by the President.

 

      Explanation.—Where the Houses of Parliament are summoned to reassemble on different dates, the period of six weeks shall be reckoned from the later of those dates for the purposes of this clause.

 

(3) If and so far as an Ordinance under this article makes any provision which Parliament would not under this Constitution be competent to enact, it shall be void.
Simplified_Description: An Ordinance promulgated under this article shall have the same force and effect as an Act of Parliament. Every such Ordinance shall be laid before both Houses of Parliament and shall cease to operate at the expiration of six weeks from the reassembly.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Gives the President the legislative power to issue Ordinances when both Houses of Parliament are not in session.
This power can only be used if the President is satisfied that immediate action is necessary.
An Ordinance has the same force as an Act of Parliament but is temporary in nature.
It must be laid before Parliament when it reassembles and ceases to operate six weeks after reassembly, unless it is approved or disapproved earlier.
The President can withdraw an ordinance at any time.
Historical_Context: This power was provided as a mechanism to deal with unforeseen and urgent matters when Parliament is not available to legislate. However, it has been frequently criticized for its overuse by the executive to bypass parliamentary debate and scrutiny. The re-promulgation of ordinances without seeking parliamentary approval has been particularly condemned by the Supreme Court.
Landmark_Cases: R.C. Cooper vs Union of India (1970): The Supreme Court held that the President's 'satisfaction' is not immune from judicial review.
D.C. Wadhwa vs State of Bihar (1987): The court strongly condemned the practice of re-promulgating ordinances, calling it a 'fraud on the Constitution' and an abuse of power.
Related_Articles: Article 213 (Power of Governor to promulgate Ordinances)

Title: Establishment and constitution of Supreme Court
Original_Description:
(1) There shall be a Supreme Court of India consisting of a Chief Justice of India and, until Parliament by law prescribes a larger number, of not more than seven other Judges.

 

(2) Every Judge of the Supreme Court shall be appointed by the President by warrant under his hand and seal after consultation with such of the Judges of the Supreme Court and of the High Courts in the States as the President may deem necessary for the purpose and shall hold office until he attains the age of sixty-five years:

 

     Provided that in the case of appointment of a Judge other than the Chief Justice, the Chief Justice of India shall always be consulted:

 

Provided further that — 

(a) a Judge may, by writing under his hand addressed to the President, resign his office;

 

(b) a Judge may be removed from his office in the manner provided in clause (4).

 

(2A) The age of a Judge of the Supreme Court shall be determined by such authority and in such manner as Parliament may by law provide.

 

(3) A person shall not be qualified for appointment as a Judge of the Supreme Court unless he is a citizen of India and —

 

(a) has been for at least five years a Judge of a High Court or of two or more such Courts in succession; or

 

(b) has been for at least ten years an advocate of a High Court or of two or more such Courts in succession; or

 

(c) is, in the opinion of the President, a distinguished jurist.

 

Explanation I.—In this clause "High Court'' means a High Court which exercises, or which at any time before the commencement of this Constitution exercised, jurisdiction in any part of the territory of India.

 

Explanation II.—In computing for the purpose of this clause the period during which a person has been an advocate, any period during which a person has held judicial office not inferior to that of a district judge after he became an advocate shall be included.

 

(4) A Judge of the Supreme Court shall not be removed from his office except by an order of the President passed after an address by each House of Parliament supported by a majority of the total membership of that House and by a majority of not less than two - thirds of the members of that House present and voting has been presented to the President in the same session for such removal on the ground of proved misbehaviour or incapacity.

 

(5) Parliament may by law regulate the procedure for the presentation of an address and for the investigation and proof of the misbehaviour or incapacity of a Judge under clause (4).

 

(6) Every person appointed to be a Judge of the Supreme Court shall, before he enters upon his office, make and subscribe before the President, or some person appointed in that behalf by him, an oath or affirmation according to the form set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule.

 

(7) No person who has held office as a Judge of the Supreme Court shall plead or act in any court or before any authority within the territory of India.
Simplified_Description: There shall be a Supreme Court of India consisting of a Chief Justice of India and, until Parliament by law prescribes a larger number, of not more than seven other Judges. The age of a Judge of the Supreme Court shall be determined by such authority and in such manner as Parliament may by law provide. A person shall not be qualified for appointment as a judge unless he is a citizen
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Establishes the Supreme Court of India.
Provides for the appointment of the Chief Justice of India (CJI) and other judges by the President.
Sets the retirement age for Supreme Court judges at 65 years.
Specifies the qualifications for appointment as a judge.
Lays down the stringent procedure for the removal of a judge (impeachment), requiring a special majority in both Houses of Parliament.
Historical_Context: This article created the apex judicial body of the country. The method of appointment of judges has been a subject of significant evolution. Through a series of cases ('The Three Judges Cases'), the judiciary established the 'Collegium System' where the CJI and a collegium of senior judges have primacy in appointments. An attempt to replace this with a National Judicial Appointments Commission (NJAC) through the 99th Amendment was struck down by the Supreme Court.
Landmark_Cases: S.P. Gupta vs Union of India (First Judges Case, 1981): Gave the executive primacy in judicial appointments.
Supreme Court Advocates-on-Record Association vs Union of India (Second Judges Case, 1993): Created the Collegium system, giving primacy to the judiciary.
Supreme Court Advocates-on-Record Association vs Union of India (Fourth Judges Case, 2015): Struck down the 99th Amendment and the NJAC Act as unconstitutional.
Related_Articles: Article 129 (Supreme Court to be a court of record)
Article 141 (Law declared by Supreme Court to be binding on all courts)

Title: Salaries, etc, of Judges
Original_Description:
(1) There shall be paid to the Judges of the Supreme Court such salaries as may be determined by Parliament by law and, until provision in that behalf is so made, such salaries as are specified in the Second Schedule.

 

(2) Every Judge shall be entitled to such privileges and allowances and to such rights in respect of leave of absence and pension as may from time to time be determined by or under law made by Parliament and, until so determined, to such privileges, allowances and rights as are specified in the Second Schedule:

 

     Provided that neither the privileges nor the allowances of a Judge nor his rights in respect of leave of absence or pension shall be varied to his disadvantage after his appointment.
Simplified_Description: Every Judge shall be entitled to such privileges and allowances and to such rights in respect of leave of absence and pension as may from time to time be determined by or under law made by Parliament.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to determine the salaries, allowances, privileges, leave, and pension of Supreme Court judges.
Crucially, it provides that these cannot be varied to a judge's disadvantage after their appointment.
The salaries and allowances are charged on the Consolidated Fund of India.
Historical_Context: The provision that the financial terms of a judge cannot be altered to their disadvantage is a vital safeguard for judicial independence. It ensures that judges can make decisions without fear of financial repercussions from the executive or legislature.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural and financial article ensuring judicial independence.
Related_Articles: Article 112(3) (Expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of India)
Article 221 (Salaries, etc., of High Court Judges)

Title: Appointment of acting Chief Justice
Original_Description: When the office of Chief Justice of India is vacant or when the Chief Justice is, by reason of absence or otherwise, unable to perform the duties of his office, the duties of the office shall be performed by such one of the other Judges of the Court as the President may appoint for the purpose.
Simplified_Description: The office of Chief Justice of India is vacant or when the Chief Justice is, by reason of absence or otherwise, unable to perform the duties of his office. The duties of the office shall be performed by such one of the other Judges of the Court as the President may appoint for the purpose.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Allows the President to appoint an acting Chief Justice of India (CJI).
This can be done when the office of the CJI is vacant.
It can also be done when the CJI is temporarily absent or unable to perform their duties.
The President appoints one of the other judges of the Supreme Court for this role.
Historical_Context: This provision ensures that the leadership of the judiciary is never in a vacuum. It allows for the seamless continuation of the administrative and judicial functions of the Chief Justice of India during any temporary or permanent vacancy.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article.
Related_Articles: Article 124 (Establishment and constitution of Supreme Court)
Article 223 (Appointment of acting Chief Justice of a High Court)

Title: Appointment of ad hoc Judges
Original_Description:
(1) If at any time there should not be a quorum of the Judges of the Supreme Court available to hold or continue any session of the Court, the Chief Justice of India may, with the previous consent of the President and after consultation with the Chief Justice of the High Court concerned, request in writing the attendance at the sittings of the Court, as an ad hoc Judge, for such period as may be necessary, of a Judge of a High Court duly qualified for appointment as a Judge of the Supreme Court to be designated by the Chief Justice of India.   

 

(2) It shall be the duty of the Judge who has been so designated, in priority to other duties of his office, to attend the sittings of the Supreme Court at the time and for the period for which his attendance is required, and while so attending he shall have all the jurisdiction, powers and privileges, and shall discharge the duties, of a Judge of the Supreme Court.
Simplified_Description: If at any time there should not be a quorum of the Judges of the Supreme Court available to hold or continue any session of the Court, the Chief Justice of India may, with the previous consent of the President, request in writing the attendance of an ad hoc Judge.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Provides for the appointment of ad hoc (temporary) judges to the Supreme Court.
This can be done if there is a lack of quorum of permanent judges to hold or continue a session.
The Chief Justice of India can initiate the process with the prior consent of the President.
A High Court judge who is qualified to be a Supreme Court judge can be appointed as an ad hoc judge.
The CJI must also consult the Chief Justice of the concerned High Court.
Historical_Context: This article is a mechanism to deal with a temporary shortage of judges in the Supreme Court, ensuring that its work is not hampered. It allows the Court to draw on the expertise of senior High Court judges to clear backlogs or to constitute benches when needed.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article to ensure the smooth functioning of the Supreme Court.
Related_Articles: Article 128 (Attendance of retired Judges at sittings of the Supreme Court)

Title: Attendance of retired Judges at sittings of the Supreme Court
Original_Description:
Notwithstanding anything in this Chapter, the Chief Justice of India may at any time, with the previous consent of the President, request any person who has held the office of a Judge of the Supreme Court or of the Federal Court or who has held the office of a Judge of a High Court and is duly qualified for appointment as a Judge of the Supreme Court] to sit and act as a Judge of the Supreme Court, and every such person so requested shall, while so sitting and acting, be entitled to such allowances as the President may by order determine and have all the jurisdiction, powers and privileges of, but shall not otherwise be deemed to be, a Judge of that Court:

 

    Provided that nothing in this article shall be deemed to require any such person as aforesaid to sit and act as a Judge of that Court unless he consents so to do.
Simplified_Description: The Chief Justice of India may at any time, with the previous consent of the President, request any person who has held the office of a Judge of the Supreme Court or of the Federal Court.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Allows the Chief Justice of India to request a retired Supreme Court judge or a retired High Court judge (who is qualified for SC appointment) to act as a judge of the Supreme Court.
This requires the previous consent of the President.
The consent of the retired judge is also necessary.
This is a temporary arrangement to help manage the court's workload.
Historical_Context: Similar to Article 127, this is another tool to leverage the experience of retired judges to deal with the backlog of cases in the Supreme Court. It allows the judiciary to utilize a pool of experienced talent when required.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article to ensure the smooth functioning of the Supreme Court.
Related_Articles: Article 224A (Appointment of retired Judges at sittings of High Courts)

Title: Supreme Court to be a court of record
Original_Description: The Supreme Court shall be a court of record and shall have all the powers of such a court including the power to punish for contempt of itself.
Simplified_Description: The Supreme Court shall be a court of record and shall have all the powers of such a court including the power to punish for contempt of itself.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Declares the Supreme Court to be a 'court of record'.
As a court of record, its judgments, proceedings, and acts are recorded for perpetual memory and testimony.
These records have evidentiary value and cannot be questioned when produced before any court.
It explicitly gives the Supreme Court the power to punish for 'contempt of itself'.
Historical_Context: The status of a 'court of record' is a feature of superior courts in common law systems. The power to punish for contempt is considered essential for a superior court to maintain its authority, dignity, and to ensure that its orders are obeyed. The scope of this contempt power has been a subject of debate, balancing the need for judicial authority with the freedom of speech.
Landmark_Cases: In re Arundhati Roy (2002): The Supreme Court exercised its contempt powers and convicted the petitioner for scandalizing the court.
Prashant Bhushan contempt case (2020): A recent high-profile case where the court held advocate Prashant Bhushan guilty of criminal contempt for his tweets about the judiciary.
Related_Articles: Article 142 (Enforcement of decrees and orders of Supreme Court...)
Article 215 (High Courts to be courts of record)

Title: Seat of Supreme Court
Original_Description: The Supreme Court shall sit in Delhi or in such other place or places, as the Chief Justice of India may, with the approval of the President, from time to time, appoint.
Simplified_Description: The Supreme Court shall sit in Delhi or in such other place or places, as the Chief Justice of India may, with the approval of the President, from time to time, appoint.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Designates Delhi as the seat of the Supreme Court.
Empowers the Chief Justice of India to appoint other places as the seat of the Supreme Court.
This decision requires the approval of the President.
This provision allows for the possibility of having regional benches of the Supreme Court.
Historical_Context: While Delhi is the permanent seat, this article provides flexibility. There have been repeated demands and recommendations from parliamentary committees and the Law Commission to establish regional benches of the Supreme Court in different parts of the country to improve access to justice. However, the proposal has not been implemented, primarily due to resistance from the Supreme Court itself.
Landmark_Cases: This article is primarily administrative and not a source of litigation.
Related_Articles: Article 124 (Establishment and constitution of Supreme Court)

Title: Original jurisdiction of the Supreme Court
Original_Description:
Subject to the provisions of this Constitution, the Supreme Court shall, to the exclusion of any other court, have original jurisdiction in any dispute —

 

(a) between the Government of India and one or more States; or

 

(b) between the Government of India and any State or States on one side and one or more other States on the other; or

 

 (c) between two or more States, if and in so far as the dispute involves any question (whether of law or fact) on which the existence or extent of a legal right depends:

 

       Provided that the said jurisdiction shall not extend to a dispute arising out of any treaty, agreement, covenant, engagement, sanad or other similar instrument which, having been entered into or executed before the commencement of this Constitution, continues in operation after such commencement, or which provides that the said jurisdiction shall not extend to such a dispute.
Simplified_Description: The Supreme Court shall, to the exclusion of any other court, have original jurisdiction in any dispute — between the Government of India and one or more States; or between two or more states.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Defines the original jurisdiction of the Supreme Court, i.e., cases that can be directly filed in the Supreme Court.
This jurisdiction is exclusive and deals with disputes between different units of the Indian federation.
It covers disputes between: (a) the Centre and one or more states; (b) the Centre and some states on one side and other states on the other; and (c) two or more states.
The dispute must involve a question of law or fact on which a legal right depends.
Historical_Context: In a federal system, a neutral umpire is needed to resolve disputes between the constituent units. This article designates the Supreme Court as that umpire, giving it the crucial role of adjudicating federal disputes and maintaining the constitutional balance between the Union and the States.
Landmark_Cases: State of West Bengal vs Union of India (1962): One of the earliest cases under this article, dealing with the Centre's power to acquire state property.
State of Karnataka vs Union of India (1977): The court clarified the scope of disputes that can be brought under Article 131.
Related_Articles: Article 262 (Adjudication of disputes relating to waters of interState rivers)
Article 263 (Provisions with respect to an inter-State Council)

Title: Appellate jurisdiction of Supreme Court in appeals from High Courts in certain cases
Original_Description:
(1) An appeal shall lie to the Supreme Court from any judgment, decree or final order of a High Court in the territory of India, whether in a civil, criminal or other proceeding, if the High Court certifies under article 134A that the case involves a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of this Constitution.

 

(3) Where such a certificate is given, any party in the case may appeal to the Supreme Court on the ground that any such question as aforesaid has been wrongly decided.

 

Explanation.—For the purposes of this article, the expression “final order” includes an order deciding an issue which, if decided in favour of the appellant, would be sufficient for the final disposal of the case.
Simplified_Description: An appeal shall lie to the Supreme Court from any judgment, decree or final order of a High Court in the territory of India. The High Court certifies under article 134A that the case involves a substantial question of law.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Establishes the Supreme Court's appellate jurisdiction in constitutional cases.
An appeal can be made from any judgment, decree, or final order of a High Court.
This applies to civil, criminal, and other proceedings.
The key condition is that the High Court must certify that the case involves a 'substantial question of law' regarding the interpretation of the Constitution.
Historical_Context: This article establishes the Supreme Court as the final authority on constitutional interpretation, ensuring uniformity in the application and understanding of the Constitution across the country. It replaced the jurisdiction previously held by the Federal Court and the Privy Council.
Landmark_Cases: This article is a procedural gateway for all major constitutional cases that reach the Supreme Court on appeal, including landmark cases like Kesavananda Bharati vs State of Kerala (1973).
Related_Articles: Article 134A (Certificate for appeal to the Supreme Court)

Title: Appellate jurisdiction of Supreme Court in appeals from High Courts in regard to civil matters
Original_Description:
(1) An appeal shall lie to the Supreme Court from any judgment, decree or final order in a civil proceeding of a High Court in the territory of India if the High Court certifies under article 134A—

 

(a) that the case involves a substantial question of law of general importance; and

 

(b) that in the opinion of the High Court the said question needs to be decided by the Supreme Court.

 

(2) Notwithstanding anything in article 132, any party appealing to the Supreme Court under clause (1) may urge as one of the grounds in such appeal that a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of this Constitution has been wrongly decided.

 

(3) Notwithstanding anything in this article, no appeal shall, unless Parliament by law otherwise provides, lie to the Supreme Court from the judgment, decree or final order of one Judge of a High Court.
Simplified_Description: An appeal shall lie to the Supreme Court from any judgment, decree or final order in a civil proceeding of a High Court in the territory of India if the case involves a substantial question of law of general importance.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Defines the Supreme Court's appellate jurisdiction in civil cases.
An appeal lies from a High Court's judgment, decree, or final order in a civil proceeding.

Two conditions must be met: (a) the case must involve a 'substantial question of law of general importance', and (b) the High Court must opine that this question needs to be decided by the Supreme Court.
Historical_Context: Originally, this article had a monetary threshold for appeals. The 30th Amendment Act, 1972, removed the monetary limit and replaced it with the present criteria, focusing on the significance of the legal question involved rather than the financial value of the dispute. This made access to the Supreme Court in civil matters more equitable.
Landmark_Cases: This is a jurisdictional article that sets the criteria for civil appeals to the Supreme Court.

Title: Appellate jurisdiction of Supreme Court in regard to criminal matters
Original_Description:
(1) An appeal shall lie to the Supreme Court from any judgment, final order or sentence in a criminal proceeding of a High Court in the territory of India if the High Court —

 

(a) has on appeal reversed an order of acquittal of an accused person and sentenced him to death; or

 

(b) has withdrawn for trial before itself any case from any court subordinate to its authority and has in such trial convicted the accused person and sentenced him to death; or

 

(c) certifies under article 134A] that the case is a fit one for appeal to the Supreme Court:

 

Provided that an appeal under sub-clause (c) shall lie subject to such provisions as may be made in that behalf under clause (1) of article 145 and to such conditions as the High Court may establish or require.

 

(2) Parliament may by law confer on the Supreme Court any further powers to entertain and hear appeals from any judgment, final order or sentence in a criminal proceeding of a High Court in the territory of India subject to such conditions and limitations as may be specified in such law.
Simplified_Description: An appeal shall lie to the Supreme Court from any judgment, final order or sentence in a criminal proceeding of a High Court in the territory of India. An appeal under sub-clause (c) shall lie subject to such provisions as may be made in that behalf under clause (1) of article 145.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Defines the Supreme Court's appellate jurisdiction in criminal cases.

An appeal lies 'as a matter of right' in two scenarios: (a) if the High Court reverses an acquittal and sentences the accused to death, or (b) if the High Court withdraws a case from a subordinate court and sentences the accused to death.
An appeal also lies if the High Court certifies that the case is a 'fit one for appeal'.
Parliament can confer further powers on the Supreme Court to hear criminal appeals.
Historical_Context: This article provides a crucial safeguard in capital punishment cases, granting an automatic right of appeal to the Supreme Court in specific circumstances where a High Court imposes a death sentence after an acquittal. This reflects the high value placed on life and liberty.
Landmark_Cases: This article is frequently invoked in criminal appeals, particularly those involving the death penalty.

Title: Certificate for appeal to the Supreme Court
Original_Description:
Every High Court, passing or making a judgment, decree, final order, or sentence, referred to in clause (1) of article 132 or clause (1) of article 133, or clause (1) of article 134, —

 

(a) may, if it deems fit so to do, on its own motion; and

 

(b) shall, if an oral application is made, by or on behalf of the party aggrieved, immediately after the passing or making of such judgment, decree, final order or sentence,

 

determine, as soon as may be after such passing or making, the question whether a certificate of the nature referred to in clause (1) of article 132, or clause (1) of article 133 or, as the case may be, sub-clause (c) of clause (1) of article 134, may be given in respect of that case.
Simplified_Description: Every High Court, passing or making a judgment, decree, final order, or sentence, referred to in clause (1) of article 132 or clause ( 1) of. article 133, may, if it deems fit so to do, on its own motion.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Outlines the procedure for obtaining a certificate from the High Court for an appeal to the Supreme Court under Articles 132, 133, or 134(1)(c).
The High Court can issue the certificate on its own motion.
Alternatively, the party must make an oral application immediately after the judgment is delivered.
The High Court must then determine if the certificate should be granted.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 44th Amendment Act, 1978. It was introduced to streamline the process of appealing to the Supreme Court and to avoid delays by requiring the application for a certificate to be made immediately, while the case is still fresh in the minds of the judges.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article that facilitates the appellate process.

Title: Jurisdiction and powers of the Federal Court under existing law to be exercisable by the Supreme Court
Original_Description: Until Parliament by law otherwise provides, the Supreme Court shall also have jurisdiction and powers with respect to any matter to which the provisions of article 133 or article 134 do not apply if jurisdiction and powers in relation to that matter were exercisable by the Federal Court immediately before the commencement of this Constitution under any existing law.
Simplified_Description: Until Parliament by law otherwise provides, the Supreme Court shall also have jurisdiction and powers with respect to any matter to which the provisions of article 133 or article 134 do not apply.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Transfers the jurisdiction of the pre-Constitution Federal Court to the Supreme Court.
This applied to cases that were not covered by Articles 133 and 134 but were within the Federal Court's jurisdiction before 1950.
This was a transitional provision to ensure continuity of the legal system.
Historical_Context: The Supreme Court of India replaced the Federal Court, which was established under the Government of India Act, 1935. This article ensured that any appellate jurisdiction that the Federal Court had, which was not explicitly mentioned in the new Constitution, was inherited by the Supreme Court, thus preventing any jurisdictional vacuum.
Landmark_Cases: This article was relevant in the early years of the republic but has limited application today as parliamentary laws have since codified the Supreme Court's jurisdiction.

Title: Special leave to appeal by the Supreme Court
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything in this Chapter, the Supreme Court may, in its discretion, grant special leave to appeal from any judgment, decree, determination, sentence or order in any cause or matter passed or made by any court or tribunal in the territory of India.

 

(2) Nothing in clause (1) shall apply to any judgment, determination, sentence or order passed or made by any court or tribunal constituted by or under any law relating to the Armed Forces.
Simplified_Description: The Supreme Court may, in its discretion, grant special leave to appeal from any judgment, decree, determination, sentence or order in any cause or matter passed or made by any court or tribunal in the territory of India. Nothing in clause (1) shall apply to any judgment or tribunal constituted by or under any law relating to the Armed Forces.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Confers a special, discretionary power on the Supreme Court to grant 'Special Leave to Appeal' (SLP).
This power is extraordinarily wide, covering any judgment, order, or determination from any court or tribunal in India.
It is not a right but a matter of the court's discretion.
The only exception is orders passed by military courts or tribunals.
It is a residual power to ensure that justice is done in exceptional cases.
Historical_Context: This article makes the Supreme Court the ultimate court of appeal and a court of justice. It serves as a constitutional safety valve, allowing the Apex Court to intervene in any case where it feels a grave injustice has occurred or a significant point of law needs to be settled, even if no regular appeal is provided for by law.
Landmark_Cases: Pritam Singh vs The State (1950): The Supreme Court laid down that it would grant special leave only in exceptional cases where substantial and grave injustice has been done.
Dhakeswari Cotton Mills Ltd. vs CIT (1954): Reaffirmed that this power is to be used to correct grave miscarriages of justice.

Title: Review of judgments or orders by the Supreme Court
Original_Description: Subject to the provisions of any law made by Parliament or any rules made under article 145, the Supreme Court shall have power to review any judgment pronounced or order made by it.
Simplified_Description: The Supreme Court shall have power to review any judgment pronounced or order made by it. Subject to the provisions of any law made by Parliament or any rules made under article 145.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Gives the Supreme Court the power to review its own judgments and orders.
This power is subject to laws made by Parliament or rules made by the Supreme Court itself (under Article 145).
A review petition is heard on very limited grounds, such as the discovery of new evidence or an error apparent on the face of the record.
It is not a re-hearing of the appeal.
Historical_Context: This provision acknowledges the fallibility of the highest court and provides an internal mechanism for self-correction. It allows the court to rectify grave errors in its own judgments to prevent a miscarriage of justice. This power is exercised with great caution.
Landmark_Cases: A. R. Antulay vs R. S. Nayak (1988): The Supreme Court used its review power to correct a judgment where it had given directions that were contrary to the provisions of a statute.

Title: Enlargement of the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court
Original_Description:
(1) The Supreme Court shall have such further jurisdiction and powers with respect to any of the matters in the Union List as Parliament may by law confer.

 

(2) The Supreme Court shall have such further jurisdiction and powers with respect to any matter as the Government of India and the Government of any State may by special agreement confer, if Parliament by law provides for the exercise of such jurisdiction and powers by the Supreme Court.
Simplified_Description: The Supreme Court shall have such further jurisdiction and powers with respect to any of the matters in the Union List as Parliament may by law confer.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to expand the jurisdiction and powers of the Supreme Court.
Parliament can confer additional jurisdiction with respect to any matter on the Union List.
Further jurisdiction can also be conferred by a special agreement between the Union and State governments, if Parliament provides for it by law.
Historical_Context: This article provides for the future growth and adaptation of the Supreme Court's role. It allows the Parliament to vest more responsibilities in the Apex Court as and when the need arises, ensuring that the court's jurisdiction can evolve with the changing needs of the country.
Landmark_Cases: This is a power-conferring article and its exercise is a legislative function.

Title: Conferment on the Supreme Court of powers to issue certain writs
Original_Description: Parliament may by law confer on the Supreme Court power to issue directions, orders or writs, including writs in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari, or any of them, for any purposes other than those mentioned in clause (2) of article 32.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may confer on the Supreme Court power to issue directions, orders or writs, including writs in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Allows Parliament to empower the Supreme Court to issue writs (Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, etc.).
This power would be for purposes other than the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.
Under Article 32, the Supreme Court can already issue writs for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.
This article allows for the expansion of the Supreme Court's writ jurisdiction to cover other legal rights as well.
Historical_Context: While Article 32 establishes the Supreme Court's writ jurisdiction for fundamental rights, this article creates a provision to extend it further. Currently, this power has not been conferred by Parliament, so the Supreme Court's general writ jurisdiction (for non-fundamental rights) is not as wide as that of the High Courts under Article 226, which can issue writs 'for any other purpose'.
Landmark_Cases: This is a power-conferring article that has not yet been acted upon by Parliament.
Related_Articles: Article 32 (Remedies for enforcement of rights conferred by this Part)
Article 226 (Power of High Courts to issue certain writs)

Title: Transfer of certain cases
Original_Description:
(1) Where cases involving the same or substantially the same questions of law are pending before the Supreme Court and one or more High Courts or before two or more High Courts and the Supreme Court is satisfied on its own motion or on an application made by the Attorney-General of India or by a party to any such case that such questions are substantial questions of general importance, the Supreme Court may withdraw the case or cases pending before the High Court or the High Courts and dispose of all the cases itself:

 

          Provided that the Supreme Court may after determining the said questions of law return any case so withdrawn together with a copy of its judgment on such questions to the High Court from which the case has been withdrawn, and the High Court shall on receipt thereof, proceed to dispose of the case in conformity with such judgment.

 

(2) The Supreme Court may, if it deems it expedient so to do for the ends of justice, transfer any case, appeal or other proceedings pending before any High Court to any other High Court.
Simplified_Description: Cases involving the same or substantially the same questions of law are pending before the Supreme Court and one or more High Courts. Supreme Court may withdraw case or cases pending before High Court or the High Courts and dispose of all the cases itself.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Gives the Supreme Court the power to transfer cases to itself from one or more High Courts.
This can be done if the cases involve the same or substantially the same questions of law of general importance.
The Supreme Court can also transfer a case, appeal, or proceeding from one High Court to another High Court for the ends of justice.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976, and modified by the 44th Amendment Act, 1978. It is an important tool to avoid conflicting judgments from different High Courts on the same legal question and to ensure an authoritative and final decision on issues of national importance.
Landmark_Cases: This power is frequently used by the Supreme Court to consolidate and hear related matters, especially in cases with wide-ranging implications.
Related_Articles: Article 228 (Transfer of certain cases to High Court)

Title: Ancillary powers of Supreme Court
Original_Description: Parliament may by law make provision for conferring upon the Supreme Court such supplemental powers not inconsistent with any of the provisions of this Constitution as may appear to be necessary or desirable for the purpose of enabling the Court more effectively to exercise the jurisdiction conferred upon it by or under this Constitution.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may by law make provision for conferring upon the Supreme Court such supplemental powers not inconsistent with any of the provisions of this Constitution.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to grant the Supreme Court supplemental or ancillary powers.
These powers must be necessary for the court to exercise its jurisdiction more effectively.
Any such powers conferred must not be inconsistent with the provisions of the Constitution.
Historical_Context: This is an enabling provision that allows Parliament to strengthen the Supreme Court's functional capacity. It ensures that the court's jurisdiction is not rendered ineffective due to a lack of necessary supporting powers.
Landmark_Cases: This is a legislative power conferred on Parliament.
Related_Articles: Article 138 (Enlargement of the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court)

Title: Law declared by Supreme Court to be binding on all courts
Original_Description: The law declared by the Supreme Court shall be binding on all courts within the territory of India.
Simplified_Description: The law declared by the Supreme Court shall be binding on all courts within the territory of India.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Establishes the doctrine of precedent (stare decisis) in India.
The law declared by the Supreme Court is the law of the land.
All other courts in India, including all High Courts, are bound by the decisions of the Supreme Court.
This ensures uniformity and certainty in the legal system.
Historical_Context: This article is the source of the immense authority of the Supreme Court. It transforms the court from a mere interpreter of law to a source of law itself. Its pronouncements create binding precedents that shape legal and constitutional jurisprudence across the country. The Supreme Court itself is not bound by its previous decisions and can overrule them.
Landmark_Cases: Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd. vs State of Bihar (1955): The Supreme Court held that it is not bound by its own previous decisions and can depart from them in the interest of justice and the development of law.
Related_Articles: Article 129 (Supreme Court to be a court of record)
Article 144 (Civil and judicial authorities to act in aid of the Supreme Court)

Title: Enforcement of decrees and orders of Supreme Court and orders as to discovery, etc
Original_Description:
(1) The Supreme Court in the exercise of its jurisdiction may pass such decree or make such order as is necessary for doing complete justice in any cause or matter pending before it, and any decree so passed order so made shall be enforceable throughout the territory of India in such manner as may be prescribed by or under any law made by Parliament and, until provision in that behalf is so made, in such manner as the President may by order prescribe.

 

(2) Subject to the provisions of any law made in this behalf by Parliament, the Supreme Court shall, as respects the whole of the territory of India, have all and every power to make any order for the purpose of securing the attendance of any person, the discovery or production of any documents, or the investigation or punishment of any contempt of itself.
Simplified_Description: The Supreme Court of India has the power to make any order for the purpose of securing the attendance of any person, or the production of any documents.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Grants the Supreme Court extraordinary power to pass any order necessary for 'doing complete justice' in any case before it.
This power allows the court to go beyond the strict confines of law and procedure to ensure a just outcome.
Orders passed under this article are enforceable throughout the territory of India.
Historical_Context: This unique provision gives the Supreme Court plenary power to ensure that justice is not defeated by technicalities. It has been used in various situations, such as providing relief in the Bhopal Gas Tragedy case, ordering the clean-up of the Taj Mahal, and regularizing the services of certain employees. The exercise of this power is sometimes seen as judicial overreach, but it is also seen as a vital tool for justice.
Landmark_Cases: Union Carbide Corporation vs Union of India (1989) (Bhopal Gas Tragedy case): The Supreme Court used this power to approve the final settlement between the government and the company to provide compensation to victims.
Supreme Court Bar Association vs Union of India (1998): The court held that the power under Article 142 cannot be used to create new law or to violate existing substantive law.

Title: Power of President to consult Supreme Court
Original_Description:
(1) If at any time it appears to the President that a question of law or fact has arisen, or is likely to arise, which is of such a nature and of such public importance that it is expedient to obtain the opinion of the Supreme Court upon it, he may refer the question to that Court for consideration and the Court may, after such hearing as it thinks fit, report to the President its opinion thereon.

 

(2) The President may, notwithstanding anything in the proviso to article 131, refer a dispute of the kind mentioned in the said proviso to the Supreme Court for opinion and the Supreme Court shall, after such hearing as it thinks fit, report to the President its opinion thereon.
Simplified_Description: The President may refer a dispute of the kind mentioned in the said proviso to the Supreme Court for opinion. The Supreme Court shall, after such hearing as it thinks fit, report to the President.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Establishes the Advisory Jurisdiction of the Supreme Court.
The President can refer a question of law or fact of public importance to the Supreme Court for its opinion.
The Supreme Court is not bound to give its opinion on a reference made under clause (1).
The opinion given by the Supreme Court is not binding on the President.
It is a consultative mechanism between the executive and the judiciary.
Historical_Context: This provision allows the executive to seek an authoritative legal opinion on important issues before taking action, which can help in avoiding future litigation. This power has been used on several occasions to seek clarity on complex constitutional and legal matters, such as the Berubari Union issue, the appointment of judges, and the allocation of natural resources.
Landmark_Cases: In re The Delhi Laws Act (1951)
In re Berubari Union (1960)
In re Special Reference No. 1 of 1998 (Third Judges Case)
Related_Articles: Article 74 (Council of Ministers to aid and advise President)

Title: Civil and judicial authorities to act in aid of the Supreme Court
Original_Description: All authorities, civil and judicial, in the territory of India shall act in aid of the Supreme Court.
Simplified_Description: All authorities, civil and judicial, in the territory of India shall act in aid of the Supreme Court.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Mandates all civil and judicial authorities in India to assist the Supreme Court.
This ensures that the orders and judgments of the Supreme Court are effectively implemented.
It places a constitutional obligation on all government departments, courts, and officials to cooperate with the Apex Court.
Historical_Context: This article provides the necessary executive and judicial support to make the Supreme Court's authority effective. Without the cooperation of other state organs, the court's judgments would be mere declarations. This provision gives them the necessary force and ensures compliance.
Landmark_Cases: This article is often cited in contempt proceedings or when the court issues directions to government authorities to ensure compliance with its orders.
Related_Articles: Article 141 (Law declared by Supreme Court to be binding)
Article 142 (Enforcement of decrees and orders of Supreme Court)

Title: Rules of Court, etc
Simplified_Description: The Supreme Court may from time to time, with the approval of the President, make rules for regulating generally the practice and procedure of the Court. The rules include rules as to the procedure for hearing appeals and other matters pertaining to appeals.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Empowers the Supreme Court to make its own rules for regulating its practice and procedure, subject to the President's approval.

Mandates that a bench of at least five judges (a Constitution Bench) is required to hear cases involving a substantial question of constitutional interpretation or for rendering an opinion under Article 143.
Judgments are delivered by a majority opinion, but dissenting judges can deliver their own opinions.
All judgments must be delivered in open court.
Historical_Context: This article ensures the administrative independence of the Supreme Court. The power to frame its own rules allows the court to manage its functioning efficiently. The requirement of a Constitution Bench for important constitutional matters ensures that such issues receive thorough consideration by a larger number of senior judges.
Landmark_Cases: The Supreme Court Rules, framed under this article, govern all procedural aspects of litigation in the court.

Title: Officers and servants and the expenses of the Supreme Court
Original_Description:
(1) Appointments of officers and servants of the Supreme Court shall be made by the Chief Justice of India or such other Judge or officer of the Court as he may direct:

 

      Provided that the President may by rule require that in such cases as may be specified in the rule, no person not already attached to the Court shall be appointed to any office connected with the Court, save after consultation with the Union Public Service Commission.

 

(2) Subject to the provisions of any law made by Parliament, the conditions of service of officers and servants of the Supreme Court shall be such as may be prescribed by rules made by the Chief Justice of India or by some other Judge or officer of the Court authorised by the Chief Justice of India to make rules for the purpose:

 

     Provided that the rules made under this clause shall, so far as they relate to salaries, allowances, leave or pensions, require the approval of the President.

 

(3) The administrative expenses of the Supreme Court, including all salaries, allowances and pensions payable to or in respect of the officers and servants of the Court, shall be charged upon the Consolidated Fund of India, and any fees or other moneys taken by the Court shall form part of that Fund.
Simplified_Description: The President may by rule require that in such cases as may be specified in the rule, no person not already attached to the Court shall be appointed to any office connected with the Court. The administrative expenses of the Supreme Court, including all salaries, allowances and pensions, shall be charged upon the Consolidated Fund of India.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Gives the Chief Justice of India the power to appoint officers and staff of the Supreme Court.
The conditions of service for the staff are prescribed by rules made by the CJI.
All administrative expenses of the Supreme Court, including salaries and pensions of its staff, are charged on the Consolidated Fund of India.
This means the court's budget is not subject to the vote of Parliament.
Historical_Context: This article is another cornerstone of judicial independence. By giving the CJI control over the court's staff and making its expenses non-votable, the Constitution ensures that the court is not dependent on the executive for its administrative and financial needs, thereby preventing any potential leverage or pressure.
Landmark_Cases: This article protects the administrative autonomy of the Supreme Court.
Related_Articles: Article 112(3) (Expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund)
Article 229 (Officers and servants and the expenses of High Courts)

Title: Interpretation
Original_Description: In this Chapter and in Chapter V of Part VI, references to any substantial question of law as to the interpretation of this Constitution shall be construed as including references to any substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Government of India Act, 1935 (including any enactment amending or supplementing that Act), or of any Order in Council or order made thereunder, or of the Indian Independence Act, 1947, or of any order made thereunder.
Simplified_Description: In this Chapter and in Chapter V of Part VI, references to any substantial question of law as to the interpretation of this Constitution shall be construed as including references to the Government of India Act, 1935. This includes any enactment amending or supplementing that Act.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: This is an interpretation clause.

It clarifies that for the purposes of the Supreme Court's and High Courts' jurisdiction, a 'substantial question of law as to the interpretation of this Constitution' also includes the interpretation of the Government of India Act, 1935, and the Indian Independence Act, 1947.
This was relevant for cases that arose before the Constitution came into force but were decided after.
Historical_Context: This was a transitional provision to ensure that the new Supreme Court and High Courts could interpret and apply the laws under which the country was governed just before 1950. It ensured legal continuity and allowed for the resolution of legal issues that straddled the pre- and post-Constitution periods. Its relevance has diminished over time.
Landmark_Cases: This article was primarily relevant for cases in the early years of the republic.

Title: Comptroller and Auditor-General of India
Original_Description:
(1) There shall be a Comptroller and Auditor-General of India who shall be appointed by the President by warrant under his hand and seal and shall only be removed from office in like manner and on the like grounds as a Judge of the Supreme Court.

 

(2) Every person appointed to be the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India shall, before he enters upon his office, make and subscribe before the President, or some person appointed in that behalf by him, an oath or affirmation according to the form set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule.

 

(3) The salary and other conditions of service of the Comptroller and Auditor-General shall be such as may be determined by Parliament by law and, until they are so determined, shall be as specified in the Second Schedule:

 

    Provided that neither the salary of a Comptroller and Auditor-General nor his rights in respect of leave of absence, pension or age of retirement shall be varied to his disadvantage after his appointment.

 

(4) The Comptroller and Auditor-General shall not be eligible for further office either under the Government of India or under the Government of any State after he has ceased to hold his office.

 

(5) Subject to the provisions of this Constitution and of any law made by Parliament, the conditions of service of persons serving in the Indian Audit and Accounts Department and the administrative powers of the Comptroller and Auditor-General shall be such as may be prescribed by rules made by the President after consultation with the Comptroller and Auditor-General.

 

(6) The administrative expenses of the office of the Comptroller and Auditor-General, including all salaries, allowances and pensions payable to or in respect of the persons serving in that office, shall be charged upon the Consolidated Fund of India.
Simplified_Description: There shall be a Comptroller and Auditor-General of India who shall be appointed by the President by warrant under his hand and seal. The salary and other conditions of service of the Comptroller shall be such as may be determined by Parliament by law.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Establishes the independent office of the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India (CAG).
The CAG is appointed by the President.
