Provides for security of tenure: the CAG can only be removed in the same manner and on the same grounds as a Supreme Court judge.
The CAG is not eligible for further office under the government after they cease to hold their office.
The administrative expenses of the CAG's office are charged on the Consolidated Fund of India.
Historical_Context: The CAG is envisaged as the guardian of the public purse. The Constitution ensures the CAG's independence so that they can audit government expenditure without fear or favor. Dr. B.R. Ambedkar called the CAG one of the most important officers under the Constitution, as their role is crucial for upholding the financial accountability of the executive to the Parliament.
Landmark_Cases: The reports of the CAG (e.g., on the 2G spectrum allocation, coal block allocation) have often become the basis for major public debates, parliamentary inquiries, and judicial proceedings.
Related_Articles: Article 149 (Duties and powers of the CAG)

Title: Duties and powers of the Comptroller and Auditor-General
Original_Description: The Comptroller and Auditor-General shall perform such duties and exercise such powers in relation to the accounts of the Union and of the States and of any other authority or body as may be prescribed by or under any law made by Parliament and, until provision in that behalf is so made, shall perform such duties and exercise such powers in relation to the accounts of the Union and of the States as were conferred on or exercisable by the Auditor-General of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution in relation to the accounts of the Dominion of India and of the Provinces respectively
Simplified_Description: The Comptroller and Auditor-General shall perform such duties and exercise such powers in relation to the accounts of the Union and of the States and of any other authority or body as may be prescribed.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to prescribe the duties and powers of the CAG.
These duties relate to the accounts of the Union, the States, and any other authority or body specified by law.
The primary duty is to audit all expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of India and of each state, and to ascertain whether the money was spent legally and for the purpose for which it was granted.
Historical_Context: This article allows for the role of the CAG to be defined and expanded by legislation. The Parliament enacted the CAG's (Duties, Powers and Conditions of Service) Act, 1971, which details the scope of the CAG's audit, including the audit of government companies and corporations.
Landmark_Cases: The interpretation of the CAG's powers, especially in relation to auditing private entities involved in public-private partnerships (PPPs) or revenue-sharing agreements with the government, has been a subject of legal debate.

Title: Form of accounts of the Union and of the States
Original_Description: The accounts of the Union and of the States shall be kept in such form as the President may, on the advice of the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India, prescribe.
Simplified_Description: The accounts of the Union and of the States shall be kept in such form as the President may, on the advice of the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India, prescribe.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Gives the President the power to prescribe the form in which the accounts of the Union and the States are to be maintained.
This power is to be exercised on the advice of the CAG.
This ensures uniformity and professional standards in government accounting.
Historical_Context: This article establishes the CAG's role not just as an auditor but also as an advisor on accounting standards for the government. This dual role helps in maintaining consistency between how accounts are kept and how they are audited.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural and administrative article.

Title: Audit reports
Original_Description:
(1) The reports of the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India relating to the accounts of the Union shall be submitted to the President, who shall cause them to be laid before each House of Parliament.

 

(2) The reports of the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India relating to the accounts of a State shall be submitted to the Governor of the State, who shall cause them to be laid before the Legislature of the State.
Simplified_Description: The reports of the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India relating to the accounts of the Union shall be submitted to the President, who shall cause them to be laid before each House of Parliament.
Subject: The Union
Key_Points: Mandates that the CAG submits their audit reports on the Union's accounts to the President.
The President must then cause these reports to be laid before both Houses of Parliament.
Similarly, the CAG's reports on a State's accounts are submitted to the Governor, who lays them before the State Legislature.
These reports are then examined by the Public Accounts Committee (PAC) of the Parliament/Legislature.
Historical_Context: This article completes the chain of financial accountability. The CAG audits the government, the report is presented to the legislature, and a committee of the legislature (the PAC) scrutinizes the report and questions the executive. This process makes the CAG the 'friend, philosopher and guide' of the PAC and a crucial agent of legislative control over the executive.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article forming a key part of the accountability mechanism.
Related_Articles: Article 149 (Duties and powers of the CAG)

Title: Definition
Original_Description: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, the expression “State” does not include the State of Jammu and Kashmir.
Simplified_Description: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, the expression “State” does not include the State of Jammu and Kashmir
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Provided a specific definition of 'State' for the purposes of Part VI.
Originally, it excluded the State of Jammu and Kashmir, which had a special status and its own constitution.
This article has become redundant after the abrogation of Article 370.
Historical_Context: This was a provision that reflected the special constitutional status granted to Jammu and Kashmir under Article 370. Since the provisions of Part VI (dealing with the structure of state governments) did not automatically apply to J&K, it was excluded from the definition. Following the Constitution (Application to Jammu and Kashmir) Order, 2019, which effectively abrogated Article 370, this article's exclusionary clause is no longer operative as J&K has been reorganized and its special status removed.
Landmark_Cases: This was a definitional clause linked to Article 370.
Related_Articles: Article 370 (Temporary provisions with respect to the State of Jammu and Kashmir)

Title: Governors of States
Original_Description:
There shall be a Governor for each State:

 

Provided that nothing in this article shall prevent the appointment of the same person as Governor for two or more States.
Simplified_Description: Provided that nothing in this article shall prevent the appointment of the same person as Governor for two or more States. There shall be a Governor for each State.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Establishes the office of the Governor for each state.
The Governor is the head of the executive in the state.
The same person can be appointed as the Governor for two or more states.
Historical_Context: The Governor's office is a continuation of the gubernatorial post from the British era. However, in the Constitution, the Governor is intended to be the constitutional head of the state, acting on the advice of the state's council of ministers. The provision for a common Governor for multiple states was added by the 7th Amendment Act, 1956, as part of the states' reorganization.
Landmark_Cases: The Governor's role and powers have been a major subject of litigation, especially in cases concerning Article 356, such as S.R. Bommai vs Union of India (1994).

Title: Executive power of State
Original_Description:
(1) The executive power of the State shall be vested in the Governor and shall be exercised by him either directly or through officers subordinate to him in accordance with this Constitution.

 

(2) Nothing in this article shall —

 

(a) be deemed to transfer to the Governor any functions conferred by any existing law on any other authority; or

 

(b) prevent Parliament or the Legislature of the State from conferring by law functions on any authority subordinate to the Governor.
Simplified_Description: The executive power of the State shall be vested in the Governor and shall be exercised by him either directly or through officers subordinate to him. Nothing in this article shall be deemed to transfer to the Governor any functions conferred by any existing law on any other authority.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Vests the executive power of the State in the Governor.
This power is to be exercised by the Governor, either directly or through subordinate officers, according to the Constitution.
This is the state-level equivalent of Article 53 for the President.
Historical_Context: Similar to the President at the Union level, this article makes the Governor the formal head of the state executive. However, this power is exercised in accordance with Article 163, which mandates that the Governor must act on the aid and advice of the state's Council of Ministers, except in matters of their discretion.
Landmark_Cases: Shamsher Singh vs State of Punjab (1974): The Supreme Court clarified that the Governor, like the President, is a constitutional head and must act on the aid and advice of the Council of Ministers, except in the few areas where they have discretionary powers.
Related_Articles: Article 163 (Council of Ministers to aid and advise Governor)

Title: Appointment of Governor
Original_Description: The Governor of a State shall be appointed by the President by warrant under his hand and seal.
Simplified_Description: The Governor of a State shall be appointed by the President by warrant under his hand and seal.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Specifies that the Governor of a state is appointed by the President.
The appointment is made 'by warrant under his hand and seal'.
The Governor is not elected but is a nominee of the Central Government.
Historical_Context: The Constituent Assembly debated whether the Governor should be elected or appointed. It was decided to have an appointed Governor to avoid a parallel center of power to the elected Chief Minister and to ensure that the Governor could act as a vital link between the Union and the State. This method of appointment has been a source of controversy, with allegations that the office is used for political purposes by the central government.
Landmark_Cases: Hargovind Pant vs Raghukul Tilak (1979): The Supreme Court held that the office of the Governor is not an employment under the Government of India and is an independent constitutional office.

Title: Term of office of Governor
Original_Description:
(1) The Governor shall hold office during the pleasure of the President.

 

(2) The Governor may, by writing under his hand addressed to the President, resign his office.

 

(3) Subject to the foregoing provisions of this article, a Governor shall hold office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office:

 

    Provided that a Governor shall, notwithstanding the expiration of his term, continue to hold office until his successor enters upon his office.
Simplified_Description: A Governor shall hold office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office. A Governor shall, notwithstanding the expiration of his term, continue to hold office until his successor enters on the office.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: The Governor holds office for a normal term of five years.
However, the Governor holds office 'during the pleasure of the President', which means they can be removed by the President at any time.
The Governor can resign by writing to the President.
They continue to hold office beyond their five-year term until their successor takes over.
Historical_Context: The 'pleasure doctrine' has been a highly contentious aspect of the Governor's tenure, as it has been used by central governments to remove Governors appointed by previous regimes. The lack of a fixed tenure and the pleasure of the President have been seen as undermining the independence and impartiality of the Governor's office.
Landmark_Cases: B.P. Singhal vs Union of India (2010): The Supreme Court held that the power to remove a Governor under the 'pleasure doctrine' is not absolute or arbitrary. A Governor cannot be removed for reasons that are irrelevant, arbitrary, or mala fide.

Title: Qualifications for appointment as Governor
Original_Description: No person shall be eligible for appointment as Governor unless he is a citizen of India and has completed the age of thirty-five years.
Simplified_Description: No person shall be eligible for appointment as Governor unless he is a citizen of India and has completed the age of thirty-five years.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Lays down the qualifications for the office of Governor.
There are only two qualifications specified: the person must be a citizen of India and must have completed 35 years of age.
Historical_Context: The qualifications are minimal. In practice, certain conventions have been followed, though not always. These conventions suggest that the Governor should be an outsider to the state they are appointed to and that the Chief Minister of the state should be consulted before the appointment. These conventions, however, are not legally binding.
Landmark_Cases: This is a straightforward eligibility article.

Title: Conditions of Governor's office
Original_Description:
(1) The Governor shall not be a member of either House of Parliament or of a House of the Legislature of any State specified in the First Schedule, and if a member of either House of Parliament or of a House of the Legislature of any such State be appointed Governor, he shall be deemed to have vacated his seat in that House on the date on which he enters upon his office as Governor.

 

(2) The Governor shall not hold any other office of profit.

 

(3) The Governor shall be entitled without payment of rent to the use of his official residences and shall be also entitled to such emoluments, allowances and privileges as may be determined by Parliament by law and, until provision in that behalf is so made, such emoluments, allowances and privileges as are specified in the Second Schedule. 

 

(3A) Where the same person is appointed as Governor of two or more States, the emoluments and allowances payable to the Governor shall be allocated among the States in such proportion as the President may by order determine.]

 

(4) The emoluments and allowances of the Governor shall not be diminished during his term of office.
Simplified_Description: The Governor shall not be a member of either House of Parliament or of a House of the Legislature of any State specified in the First Schedule. The Governor shall be entitled without payment of rent to the use of his official residences and shall be also entitled to such emoluments, allowances and privileges as may be determined by Parliament.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: The Governor cannot be a member of Parliament or a State Legislature.
The Governor cannot hold any other office of profit.
They are entitled to an official residence (Raj Bhavan) free of rent.
Their salary and allowances cannot be reduced during their term of office.
Historical_Context: These conditions are similar to those for the President and are intended to ensure the independence and impartiality of the Governor's office. By preventing them from holding other offices and protecting their emoluments, the Constitution seeks to insulate them from political and financial pressures.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article governing the office of the Governor.

Title: Oath or affirmation by the Governor
Original_Description:
Every Governor and every person discharging the functions of the Governor shall, before entering upon his office, make and subscribe in the presence of the Chief Justice of the High Court exercising jurisdiction in relation to the State, or, in his absence, the seniormost Judge of that Court available, an oath or affirmation in the following form, that is to say —

 

 “I, A. B., do swear in the name of God that I will faithfully execute the office of Governor (or discharge the functions of the Governor) of .............(name of the State) and will to the best of my ability preserve,     protect  and defend the Constitution and the law and that I will devote myself to the service and well-being of the people of ..………(name of the State).”
Simplified_Description: Every Governor and every person discharging the functions of the Governor shall make and subscribe in the presence of the Chief Justice of the High Court exercising jurisdiction in relation to the State.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Prescribes the oath of office for the Governor.
The oath is administered by the Chief Justice of the concerned High Court (or the senior-most judge in their absence).
Similar to the President, the Governor's oath includes the pledge to 'preserve, protect and defend the Constitution and the law'.
Historical_Context: The Governor's oath mirrors the President's, emphasizing their crucial role as the guardian of the Constitution at the state level. This duty becomes particularly relevant when the Governor has to exercise their discretionary powers, such as in recommending President's rule.
Landmark_Cases: The oath is a constitutional requirement reflecting the duties of the Governor.
Related_Articles: Article 60 (Oath or affirmation by the President)

Title: Discharge of the functions of the Governor in certain contingencies
Original_Description: The President may make such provision as he thinks fit for the discharge of the functions of the Governor of a State in any contingency not provided for in this Chapter.
Simplified_Description: The President may make such provision as he thinks fit for the discharge of the functions of the Governor of a State.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Empowers the President to make provisions for handling any unforeseen situation regarding the discharge of the Governor's functions.
This is a residual power to deal with contingencies not explicitly mentioned in the Constitution.
Historical_Context: This article acts as a constitutional safety net. For instance, if a vacancy occurs in the Governor's office and no new appointment is made immediately, the President can use this power to appoint the Chief Justice of the High Court to temporarily discharge the Governor's functions.
Landmark_Cases: This is an enabling provision for the President.
Related_Articles: Article 70 (Discharge of President's functions in other contingencies)

Title: Power of Governor to grant pardons, etc, and to suspend, remit or commute sentences in certain cases
Original_Description: The Governor of a State shall have the power to grant pardons, reprieves, respites or remissions of punishment or to suspend, remit or commute the sentence of any person convicted of any offence against any law relating to a matter to which the executive power of the State extends.
Simplified_Description: The Governor of a State shall have the power to grant pardons, reprieves, respites or remissions of punishment.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Grants the Governor the power to grant pardons, reprieves, respites, remissions, and to suspend, remit, or commute sentences.
This power applies to offenses against state laws.
Unlike the President, the Governor cannot pardon a death sentence (though they can suspend, remit, or commute it).
The Governor's pardoning power does not extend to sentences by a Court Martial.
This power is subject to judicial review on limited grounds.
Historical_Context: This is the state-level counterpart to the President's pardoning power under Article 72. It serves as a check on potential judicial errors and provides a mechanism for mercy. The extent of the Governor's power versus the President's power, especially in death penalty cases, has been a subject of judicial interpretation.
Landmark_Cases: Maru Ram vs Union of India (1980): Held that the pardoning power is to be exercised on the advice of the state government.
Epuru Sudhakar vs Govt. of A.P. (2006): Reaffirmed that the exercise of this power is subject to judicial review if it is arbitrary, mala fide, or irrational.
Related_Articles: Article 72 (Power of President to grant pardons...)

Title: Extent of executive power of State
Original_Description:
Subject to the provisions of this Constitution, the executive power of a State shall extend to the matters with respect to which the Legislature of the State has power to make laws:

 

   Provided that in any matter with respect to which the Legislature of a State and Parliament have power to make laws, the executive power of the State shall be subject to, and limited by, the executive power expressly conferred by this Constitution or by any law made by Parliament upon the Union or authorities thereof.
Simplified_Description: The executive power of a State shall extend to the matters with respect to which the Legislature of the State has power to make laws. The executive power of the State shall be subject to, and limited by, the executive power expressly conferred by this Constitution.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Defines the extent of the executive power of a state government.
The state's executive power is co-extensive with the legislative power of the State Legislature (i.e., subjects in the State List and Concurrent List).
On matters in the Concurrent List, the state's executive power is subject to the executive power of the Union.
Historical_Context: This article delineates the administrative authority of the state governments, mirroring Article 73 for the Union. It establishes the principle that a government's executive reach corresponds to its legislative competence.
Landmark_Cases: This is a foundational article defining the scope of state executive authority.
Related_Articles: Article 73 (Extent of executive power of the Union)

Title: Council of Ministers to aid and advise Governor
Original_Description:
(1) There shall be a Council of Ministers with the Chief Minister at the head to aid and advise the Governor in the exercise of his functions, except in so far as he is by or under this Constitution required to exercise his functions or any of them in his discretion.

 

(2) If any question arises whether any matter is or is not a matter as respects which the Governor is by or under this Constitution required to act in his discretion, the decision of the Governor in his discretion shall be final, and the validity of anything done by the Governor shall not be called in question on the ground that he ought or ought not to have acted in his discretion. 

 

(3) The question whether any, and if so what, advice was tendered by Ministers to the Governor shall not be inquired into in any court.
Simplified_Description: There shall be a Council of Ministers with the Chief Minister at the head to aid and advise the Governor. The question whether any, and if so what, advice was tendered by Ministers to the Governor shall not be inquired into in any court.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Establishes a Council of Ministers (CoM) headed by the Chief Minister to aid and advise the Governor.
The Governor must act on this advice, *except* in matters where the Constitution grants them discretionary powers.
The Governor's decision on whether a matter falls within their discretion is final.
The advice tendered by ministers cannot be questioned in any court.
Historical_Context: This article is the foundation of the parliamentary system at the state level. The 'discretionary power' of the Governor is a significant point of difference from the President's role and has been a major source of controversy in Union-State relations, particularly in the appointment of Chief Ministers, dismissal of governments, and recommending President's Rule.
Landmark_Cases: Shamsher Singh vs State of Punjab (1974): Clarified that the Governor acts as a constitutional head, and discretionary powers are limited to specific situations mentioned in the Constitution.
Nabam Rebia and Bamang Felix vs Deputy Speaker (2016): The Supreme Court curtailed the discretionary powers of the Governor regarding the summoning and functioning of the legislative assembly.
Related_Articles: Article 74 (Council of Ministers to aid and advise President)

Title: Other provisions as to Ministers
Original_Description:
(1) The Chief Minister shall be appointed by the Governor and the other Ministers shall be appointed by the Governor on the advice of the Chief Minister, and the Ministers shall hold office during the pleasure of the Governor:

 

   Provided that in the States of 1 [Chhattisgarh, Jharkhand], Madhya Pradesh and Orissa, there shall be a Minister in charge of tribal welfare who may in addition be in charge of the welfare of the Scheduled Castes and backward classes or any other work.

 

(1A) The total number of Ministers, including the Chief Minister, in the Council of Ministers in a State shall not exceed fifteen per cent. of the total number of members of the Legislative Assembly of that State: Provided that the number of Ministers, including the Chief Minister in a State shall not be less than twelve:

 

   Provided further that where the total number of Ministers including the Chief Minister in the Council of Ministers in any State at the commencement of the Constitution (Ninety-first Amendment) Act, 2003 exceeds the said fifteen per cent. or the number specified in the first proviso, as the case may be, then the total number of Ministers in that State shall be brought in conformity with the provisions of this clause within six months from such date as the President may by public notification appoint.

 

(1B) A member of the Legislative Assembly of a State or either House of the Legislature of a State having Legislative Council belonging to any political party who is disqualified for being a member of that House under paragraph 2 of the Tenth Schedule shall also be disqualified to be appointed as a Minister under clause (1) for duration of the period commencing from the date of his disqualification till the date on which the term of his office as such member would expire or where he contests any election to the Legislative Assembly of a State or either House of the Legislature of a State having Legislative Council, as the case may be, before the expiry of such period, till the date on which he is declared elected, whichever is earlier.

 

(2) The Council of Ministers shall be collectively responsible to the Legislative Assembly of the State.

 

(3) Before a Minister enters upon his office, the Governor shall administer to him the oaths of office and of secrecy according to the forms set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule.

 

(4) A Minister who for any period of six consecutive months is not a member of the Legislature of the State shall at the expiration of that period cease to be a Minister.

 

(5) The salaries and allowances of Ministers shall be such as the Legislature of the State may from time to time by law determine and, until the Legislature of the State so determines, shall be as specified in the Second Schedule.
Simplified_Description: The total number of Ministers, including the Chief Minister, in the Council of Ministers in a State shall not exceed fifteen per cent. of the total number. of members of the Legislative Assembly of that State. A Minister who for any period of six consecutive months is not a member of the Legislature of the State shall at the expiration of that period cease to be a Minister.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: The Governor appoints the Chief Minister (CM) and other ministers on the CM's advice.
Ministers hold office 'during the pleasure of the Governor', which is exercised on the advice of the CM.
The Council of Ministers is collectively responsible to the State Legislative Assembly.
The total number of ministers is capped at 15% of the Assembly's strength (with a minimum of 12).
A minister must become a member of the state legislature within six months of their appointment.
Historical_Context: This article details the mechanics of state government formation and accountability. The principle of collective responsibility is the bedrock of the cabinet system. The 91st Amendment Act, 2003, introduced the 15% cap on the size of the ministry to curb the practice of having oversized cabinets to placate political allies.
Landmark_Cases: S.R. Bommai vs Union of India (1994): The court held that the question of whether a government has lost its majority should be tested on the floor of the House, which is the ultimate forum for collective responsibility.
Related_Articles: Article 163 (Council of Ministers to aid and advise Governor)

Title: Advocate-General for the State
Original_Description:
(1) The Governor of each State shall appoint a person who is qualified to be appointed a Judge of a High Court to be Advocate-General for the State.

 

(2) It shall be the duty of the Advocate-General to give advice to the Government of the State upon such legal matters, and to perform such other duties of a legal character, as may from time to time be referred or assigned to him by the Governor, and to discharge the functions conferred on him by or under this Constitution or any other law for the time being in force.

 

(3) The Advocate-General shall hold office during the pleasure of the Governor, and shall receive such remuneration as the Governor may determine.
Simplified_Description: The Advocate-General of each State is a Judge of a High Court. He advises the Government of the State on such legal matters as may be referred or assigned to him.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Establishes the office of the Advocate-General for each state.
The Advocate-General is appointed by the Governor and must be qualified to be a High Court judge.
They are the chief legal advisor to the State Government.
They have the right to speak and participate in the proceedings of the State Legislature but do not have the right to vote.
They hold office during the pleasure of the Governor.
Historical_Context: The Advocate-General is the state-level counterpart of the Attorney-General for India. This office ensures that the state government has access to expert legal advice for its functions and is represented in legal proceedings.
Landmark_Cases: This is a structural article defining a constitutional office.
Related_Articles: Article 177 (Rights of Ministers and Advocate-General as respects the Houses)

Title: Conduct of business of the Government of a State
Original_Description:
(1) All executive action of the Government of a State shall be expressed to be taken in the name of the Governor.

 

(2) Orders and other instruments made and executed in the name of the Governor shall be authenticated in such manner as may be specified in rules to be made by the Governor, and the validity of an order or instrument which is so authenticated shall not be called in question on the ground that it is not an order or instrument made or executed by the Governor.

 

(3) The Governor shall make rules for the more convenient transaction of the business of the Government of the State, and for the allocation among Ministers of the said business in so far as it is not business with respect to which the Governor is by or under this Constitution required to act in his discretion.
Simplified_Description: All executive action of the Government of a State shall be expressed to be taken in the name of the Governor. Governor shall make rules for the more convenient transaction of the business.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: All executive actions of the State Government are formally taken in the name of the Governor.
The Governor makes rules for the authentication of orders and instruments made in their name.
The Governor also makes rules for the convenient transaction of government business and its allocation among ministers.
Historical_Context: This article formalizes the Governor's position as the constitutional head of the state executive, mirroring Article 77 for the President. It provides the framework for the formal expression and conduct of state government business.
Landmark_Cases: Similar to Article 77, courts have held that a failure to use the Governor's name does not automatically invalidate an executive action if the decision was properly made.
Related_Articles: Article 163 (Council of Ministers to aid and advise Governor)

Title: Duties of Chief Minister as respects the furnishing of information to Governor, etc
Original_Description:
It shall be the duty of the Chief Minister of each State —

 

(a) to communicate to the Governor of the State all decisions of the Council of Ministers relating to the administration of the affairs of the State and proposals for legislation;

 

(b) to furnish such information relating to the administration of the affairs of the State and proposals for legislation as the Governor may call for; and

 

(c) if the Governor so requires, to submit for the consideration of the Council of Ministers any matter on which a decision has been taken by a Minister but which has not been considered by the Council.
Simplified_Description: It is the duty of the Chief Minister of each State to communicate to the Governor all decisions of the Council of Ministers.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Lays down the duties of the Chief Minister towards the Governor.
The CM must communicate all decisions of the Council of Ministers to the Governor.
The CM must provide any information that the Governor calls for.
The CM must, if the Governor requires, submit a decision taken by an individual minister for the consideration of the entire Council of Ministers.
This is the state-level counterpart to Article 78.
Historical_Context: This article establishes the Governor's 'right to be informed' and acts as a vital communication channel between the constitutional head and the real executive of the state. It allows the Governor to be aware of the government's functioning and, if necessary, to advise the Chief Minister or ensure that decisions are made with collective responsibility.
Landmark_Cases: The relationship defined by this article is primarily governed by constitutional convention.
Related_Articles: Article 163 (Council of Ministers to aid and advise Governor)

Title: Constitution of Legislatures in States
Original_Description:
(1) For every State there shall be a Legislature which shall consist of the Governor, and —

 

(a) in the States of Andhra Pradesh, Bihar, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Karnataka, and Uttar Pradesh, two Houses;

 

(b) in other States, one House.

 

(2) Where there are two Houses of the Legislature of a State, one shall be known as the Legislative Council and the other as the Legislative Assembly, and where there is only one House, it shall be known as the Legislative Assembly.
Simplified_Description: For every State there shall be a Legislature which shall consist of the Governor, and — in the States of Andhra Pradesh, Bihar, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Karnataka, and Uttar Pradesh, two Houses. In other States, one House. Where there are two Houses of the Legislature of a State, one shall be known as the Legislative Council.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Establishes the legislature for every state.
A state legislature consists of the Governor and the legislative house(s).
Provides for both bicameral (two Houses) and unicameral (one House) legislatures.
The upper house is the Legislative Council (Vidhan Parishad), and the lower house is the Legislative Assembly (Vidhan Sabha).
Most states have a unicameral legislature.
Historical_Context: The Constitution provides states with the choice of having a second legislative chamber. The Legislative Council is seen as a body for deeper deliberation and for accommodating experts in the legislative process. The list of states with bicameral legislatures changes over time as states can create or abolish their Legislative Councils under Article 169.
Landmark_Cases: This is a structural article defining state legislatures.
Related_Articles: Article 169 (Abolition or creation of Legislative Councils)

Title: Abolition or creation of Legislative Councils in States
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything in article 168, Parliament may by law provide for the abolition of the Legislative Council of a State having such a Council or for the creation of such a Council in a State having no such Council, if the Legislative Assembly of the State passes a resolution to that effect by a majority of the total membership of the Assembly and by a majority of not less than two-thirds of the members of the Assembly present and voting.

 

(2) Any law referred to in clause (1) shall contain such provisions for the amendment of this Constitution as may be necessary to give effect to the provisions of the law and may also contain such supplemental, incidental and consequential provisions as Parliament may deem necessary.

 

(3) No such law as aforesaid shall be deemed to be an amendment of this Constitution for the purposes of article 368.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may by law provide for the abolition of the Legislative Council of a State having such a Council. If the Legislative Assembly of the State passes a resolution to that effect.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Lays down the procedure for creating or abolishing a Legislative Council in a state.
The process starts with the State Legislative Assembly passing a resolution by a special majority (majority of the total membership and two-thirds of members present and voting).
Based on this resolution, the Parliament may then pass a law to create or abolish the council.
This law passed by Parliament is not considered a constitutional amendment under Article 368.
Historical_Context: This flexible procedure allows states to decide for themselves whether they need a second legislative house, based on their political and administrative needs. Several states have used this provision to either create or abolish their Legislative Councils over the years.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article.

Title: Composition of the Legislative Assemblies
Original_Description:
(1) Subject to the provisions of article 333, the Legislative Assembly of each State shall consist of not more than five hundred, and not less than sixty, members chosen by direct election from territorial constituencies in the State.

 

(2) For the purposes of clause (1), each State shall be divided into territorial constituencies in such manner that the ratio between the population of each constituency and the number of seats allotted to it shall, so far as practicable, be the same throughout the State.

Explanation.—In this clause, the expression “population” means the population as ascertained at the last preceding census of which the relevant figures have been published:

Provided that the reference in this Explanation to the last preceding census of which the relevant figures have been published published shall, until the relevant figures for the first census taken after the year 2026 have been published, be construed as a reference to the 2001 census. 

 

(3) Upon the completion of each census, the total number of seats in the Legislative Assembly of each State and the division of each State into territorial constituencies shall be readjusted by such authority and in such manner as Parliament may by law determine:

Provided that such readjustment shall not affect representation in the Legislative Assembly until the dissolution of the then existing Assembly: 

Provided further that such readjustment shall take effect from such date as the President may, by order, specify and until such readjustment takes effect, any election to the Legislative Assembly may be held on the basis of the territorial constituencies existing before such readjustment:

Provided also that until the relevant figures for the first census taken after the year 2026 have been published, it shall not be necessary to readjust— (i) the total number of seats in the Legislative Assembly of each State as readjusted on the basis of the 1971 census; and (ii) the division of such State into territorial constituencies as may be readjusted on the basis of the 2001 census, under this clause.
Simplified_Description: The Legislative Assembly of each State shall consist of not more than five hundred, and not less than sixty, members chosen by direct election from territorial constituencies in the State. The ratio between the population of each constituency and the number of seats allotted to it shall, so far as practicable, be the same throughout the state. Upon the completion of each census, the total number of. seats
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Specifies the composition of the State Legislative Assembly (Vidhan Sabha).
Members are chosen by direct election.
The strength of the Assembly must be between 60 and 500 members.
Exceptions for smaller states (like Goa, Sikkim) are provided in other articles.
Constituencies are to be demarcated such that the ratio of population to the number of seats is uniform across the state.
Historical_Context: This article ensures that the lower house of the state legislature is directly elected by the people, making it the primary body of democratic representation at the state level. The readjustment of seats and constituencies after each census (similar to the Lok Sabha) is currently frozen until the first census after 2026.
Landmark_Cases: Cases related to the Delimitation Commission's work at the state level are based on the principles of this article.
Related_Articles: Article 81 (Composition of the House of the People)
Article 326 (Elections...to be on the basis of adult suffrage)

Title: Composition of the Legislative Councils
Simplified_Description: The total number of members in the Legislative Council of a State having such a Council shall not exceed one-third. Until Parliament by law otherwise provides, the composition of the Legislative Council of a State shall be as provided in clause (3)
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Specifies the composition of the State Legislative Council (Vidhan Parishad).
The strength of the Council cannot be more than one-third of the strength of the Legislative Assembly, and not less than 40.
Members are chosen through a complex system of indirect elections and nominations:
1/3 elected by MLAs.
1/3 elected by local bodies.
1/12 elected by graduates.
1/12 elected by teachers.
1/6 nominated by the Governor.
Historical_Context: The complex composition of the Legislative Council is designed to bring a variety of perspectives into the legislature, including those of local governments, the educated class, and experts nominated by the Governor. It is intended to be a house of revision and expertise, different in character from the directly elected Assembly.
Landmark_Cases: The election and nomination process has sometimes been the subject of election petitions and disputes.
Related_Articles: Article 169 (Abolition or creation of Legislative Councils)

Title: Duration of State Legislatures
Original_Description:
(1) Every Legislative Assembly of every State, unless sooner dissolved, shall continue for five years from the date appointed for its first meeting and no longer and the expiration of the said period of 1 [five years] shall operate as a dissolution of the Assembly: Provided that the said period may, while a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation, be extended by Parliament by law for a period not exceeding one year at a time and not extending in any case beyond a period of six months after the Proclamation has ceased to operate.

 

(2) The Legislative Council of a State shall not be subject to dissolution, but as nearly as possible one-third of the members thereof shall retire as soon as may be on the expiration of every second year in accordance with the provisions made in that behalf by Parliament by law.
Simplified_Description: Every Legislative Assembly of every State, unless sooner dissolved, shall continue for five years. The Legislative Council of a State shall not be subject to dissolution, but as nearly as possible one-third of the members thereof shall retire.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: The Legislative Assembly (Vidhan Sabha) has a normal term of five years, but can be dissolved earlier by the Governor.
Its term can be extended during a national emergency.
The Legislative Council (Vidhan Parishad) is a permanent body, not subject to dissolution.
One-third of the members of the Legislative Council retire every two years.
Historical_Context: This article mirrors the provisions for the Union Parliament (Article 83), establishing a system of periodic elections for the lower house and continuity for the upper house at the state level.
Landmark_Cases: Cases concerning the premature dissolution of a State Assembly by the Governor often involve an interpretation of this article along with Article 174.
Related_Articles: Article 174 (Sessions of the State Legislature, prorogation and dissolution)

Title: Qualification for membership of the State Legislature
Original_Description:
A person shall not be qualified to be chosen to fill a seat in the Legislature of a State unless he —

 

(a) is a citizen of India, and makes and subscribes before some person authorised in that behalf by the Election Commission an oath or affirmation according to the form set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule; 

 

(b) is, in the case of a seat in the Legislative Assembly, not less than twenty-five years of age and, in the case of a seat in the Legislative Council, not less than thirty years of age; and

 

(c) possesses such other qualifications as may be prescribed in that behalf by or under any law made by Parliament.
Simplified_Description: A person shall not be qualified to be chosen to fill a seat in the Legislature of a State unless he is a citizen of India, and makes and subscribes before some person authorised in that behalf.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Specifies the eligibility criteria for becoming a member of a State Legislature (MLA or MLC).
A candidate must be a citizen of India.
Minimum age for the Legislative Assembly (Vidhan Sabha) is 25 years.
Minimum age for the Legislative Council (Vidhan Parishad) is 30 years.
Parliament can prescribe other qualifications by law (as done in the Representation of the People Act, 1951).
Historical_Context: These qualifications for state legislators are parallel to those for Members of Parliament, ensuring a baseline of citizenship and maturity for lawmakers at the state level.
Landmark_Cases: This is a straightforward eligibility article, with further details specified in the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

Title: Sessions of the State Legislature, prorogation and dissolution
Original_Description:
(1) The Governor shall from time to time summon the House or each House of the Legislature of the State to meet at such time and place as he thinks fit, but six months shall not intervene between its last sitting in one session and the date appointed for its first sitting in the next session.

 

(2) The Governor may from time to time —

 

(a) prorogue the House or either House;

 

(b) dissolve the Legislative Assembly.
Simplified_Description: The Governor may from time to time summon the House or each House of the Legislature of the State to meet at such time and place as he thinks fit. Six months shall not intervene between its last sitting in one session and the date appointed for its first sitting in the next session.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: The Governor has the power to summon, prorogue, and dissolve the State Legislative Assembly.
The maximum gap between two sessions of the state legislature cannot be more than six months.
The Legislative Council, if it exists, can be prorogued but not dissolved.
Historical_Context: This article gives the Governor powers over the state legislature that are analogous to the President's powers over Parliament. The Governor exercises these powers on the aid and advice of the state's Council of Ministers. However, the Governor's discretion in dissolving the assembly, especially when the government's majority is in question, has been a significant source of constitutional controversy.
Landmark_Cases: Nabam Rebia and Bamang Felix vs Deputy Speaker (2016): The Supreme Court held that the Governor's power to summon the House must be on the aid and advice of the Council of Ministers and cannot be used to undermine a democratically elected government.
Related_Articles: Article 85 (Sessions of Parliament, prorogation and dissolution)
Article 163 (Council of Ministers to aid and advise Governor)

Title: Right of Governor to address and send messages to the House or Houses
Original_Description:
(1) The Governor may address the Legislative Assembly or, in the case of a State having a Legislative Council, either House of the Legislature of the State, or both Houses assembled together, and may for that purpose require the attendance of members.

 

(2) The Governor may send messages to the House or Houses of the Legislature of the State, whether with respect to a Bill then pending in the Legislature or otherwise, and a House to which any message is so sent shall with all convenient despatch consider any matter required by the message to be taken into consideration.
Simplified_Description: The Governor may send messages to the House or Houses of the Legislature of the State, whether with respect to a Bill then pending in the Legislature or otherwise. The Governor may with all convenient despatch consider any matter required by the message to be taken into consideration.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Gives the Governor the right to address the Legislative Assembly, Legislative Council, or a joint sitting.
Gives the Governor the right to send messages to the legislature, concerning a pending bill or any other matter.
Historical_Context: This is a general power of communication between the head of the state and the legislature, similar to Article 86 for the President. It is distinct from the mandatory 'special address' under Article 176. The power to send messages is rarely used in practice.
Landmark_Cases: This is a power-conferring article and is not a common subject of litigation.
Related_Articles: Article 86 (Right of President to address and send messages)

Title: Special address by the Governor
Original_Description:
(1) At the commencement of the first session after each general election to the Legislative Assembly and at the commencement of the first session of each year, the Governor shall address the Legislative Assembly or, in the case of a State having a Legislative Council, both Houses assembled together and inform the Legislature of the causes of its summons.

 

(2) Provision shall be made by the rules regulating the procedure of the House or either House for the allotment of time for discussion of the matters referred to in such address.
Simplified_Description: Governor must inform the Legislature of the causes of its summons. Provision is made by the rules regulating the procedure of the House or either House for the allotment of time for discussion of the matters referred to.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Mandates a 'special address' by the Governor on two occasions: the first session after a general election and the first session of every year.
The address outlines the policies and programs of the state government for the upcoming year.
The address is followed by a 'Motion of Thanks' in the legislature, which is debated and voted upon.
Historical_Context: This is the state-level equivalent of the President's special address under Article 87. The Governor's address is prepared by the state cabinet. Its defeat on a Motion of Thanks is considered a vote of no-confidence in the government and would lead to its resignation.
Landmark_Cases: This is a key procedural article of the state legislature.

Title: Rights of Ministers and Advocate General as respects the Houses
Original_Description: Every Minister and the Advocate-General for a State shall have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of, the Legislative Assembly of the State or, in the case of a State having a Legislative Council, both Houses, and to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of, any committee of the Legislature of which he may be named a member, but shall not, by virtue of this article, be entitled to vote.
Simplified_Description: Every Minister and the Advocate-General for a State shall have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of, the Legislative Assembly of the State.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Grants every Minister and the Advocate-General of the state the right to speak and participate in the proceedings of both Houses of the State Legislature.
This right does not include the right to vote in a House of which they are not a member.
This allows for effective coordination and representation of the government's views in the legislature.
Historical_Context: This provision is analogous to Article 88 for the Union. It is particularly useful in bicameral state legislatures, as it allows a minister from one house to pilot bills and answer questions in the other house, ensuring the smooth flow of government business.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article defining rights of participation.
Related_Articles: Article 88 (Rights of Ministers and Attorney-General as respects Houses)

Title: The Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Legislative Assembly
Original_Description: Every Legislative Assembly of a State shall, as soon as may be, choose two members of the Assembly to be respectively Speaker and Deputy Speaker thereof and, so often as the office of Speaker or Deputy Speaker becomes vacant, the Assembly shall choose another member to be Speaker or Deputy Speaker, as the case may be.
Simplified_Description: Every Legislative Assembly of a State shall, as soon as may be, choose two members of the Assembly to be respectively Speaker and Deputy Speaker thereof. So often as the office of Speaker or Deputy Speaker becomes vacant, the Assembly shall choose another member to be Speaker or deputy Speaker.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Mandates that every State Legislative Assembly (Vidhan Sabha) must elect a Speaker and a Deputy Speaker from among its members.
This election is one of the first items of business for a newly formed Assembly.
Historical_Context: This article establishes the leadership structure of the Legislative Assembly, mirroring the provisions for the Lok Sabha. The Speaker is the presiding officer and principal spokesperson of the Assembly, responsible for maintaining order and decorum.
Landmark_Cases: This is a structural article for state legislatures.
Related_Articles: Article 93 (The Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the House of the People)
Article 182 (The Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Legislative Council)

Title: Vacation and resignation of, and removal from, the offices of Speaker and Deputy Speaker
Original_Description:
A member holding office as Speaker or Deputy Speaker of an Assembly —

 

(a) shall vacate his office if he ceases to be a member of the Assembly;

 

(b) may at any time by writing under his hand addressed, if such member is the Speaker, to the Deputy Speaker, and if such member is the Deputy Speaker, to the Speaker, resign his office; and

 

(c) may be removed from his office by a resolution of the Assembly passed by a majority of all the then members of the Assembly:

 

    Provided that no resolution for the purpose of clause (c) shall be moved unless at least fourteen days' notice has been given of the intention to move the resolution:

 

    Provided further that, whenever the Assembly is dissolved, the Speaker shall not vacate his office until immediately before the first meeting of the Assembly after the dissolution.
Simplified_Description: A member holding office as Speaker or Deputy Speaker of an Assembly —. shall vacate his office if he ceases to be a member of the Assembly. The Speaker may be removed from his office by a resolution of the assembly passed by a majority of all the then members.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Specifies the ways in which the offices of the Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Assembly become vacant.
They vacate the office if they cease to be members of the Assembly.
The Speaker can resign by writing to the Deputy Speaker, and vice versa.
They can be removed by a resolution passed by an 'effective majority' (a majority of all the then members) of the Assembly.
Similar to the Lok Sabha Speaker, the State Assembly Speaker continues in office after dissolution until the first meeting of the new Assembly.
Historical_Context: This article provides for the accountability and orderly transition of the presiding officers of the State Assembly, mirroring the provisions of Article 94 for the Lok Sabha.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article governing the functioning of the State Assembly.
Related_Articles: Article 94 (Vacation and resignation of... Speaker and Deputy Speaker)

Title: Power of the Deputy Speaker or other person to perform the duties of the office of, or to act as, Speaker
Original_Description:
(1) While the office of Speaker is vacant, the duties of the office shall be performed by the Deputy Speaker or, if the office of Deputy Speaker is also vacant, by such member of the Assembly as the Governor may appoint for the purpose.

 

(2) During the absence of the Speaker from any sitting of the Assembly the Deputy Speaker or, if he is also absent, such person as may be determined by the rules of procedure of the Assembly, or, if no such person is present, such other person as may be determined by the Assembly, shall act as Speaker.
Simplified_Description: While the office of Speaker is vacant, the duties of the office shall be performed by the Deputy Speaker or by such member of the Assembly as the Governor may appoint.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: The Deputy Speaker performs the duties of the Speaker when the Speaker's office is vacant.
The Deputy Speaker presides as Speaker during the temporary absence of the Speaker from a sitting.
If the Deputy Speaker's office is also vacant, the Governor can appoint a member of the Assembly to perform the Speaker's duties.
If both are absent from a sitting, a member from the panel of Chairpersons presides as per the rules of the house.
Historical_Context: This article ensures the continuity of the legislative business of the State Assembly, providing a clear line of succession for the presiding officer's duties to prevent any procedural vacuum. It mirrors the provisions for the Lok Sabha under Article 95.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article ensuring the functioning of the State Legislature and is not typically a subject of litigation.
Related_Articles: Article 95 (Similar provision for the Lok Sabha)
Article 184 (Similar provision for the Legislative Council)

Title: The Speaker or the Deputy Speaker not to preside while a resolution for his removal from office is under consideration
Original_Description:
(1) At any sitting of the Legislative Assembly, while any resolution for the removal of the Speaker from his office is under consideration, the Speaker, or while any resolution for the removal of the Deputy Speaker, from his office is under consideration, the Deputy Speaker, shall not, though he is present, preside, and the provisions of clause (2) of article 180 shall apply in relation to every such sitting as they apply in relation to a sitting from which the Speaker or, as the case may be, the Deputy Speaker, is absent.

 

(2) The Speaker shall have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of, the Legislative Assembly while any resolution for his removal from office is under consideration in the Assembly and shall, notwithstanding anything in article 189, be entitled to vote only in the first instance on such resolution or on any other matter during such proceedings but not in the case of an equality of votes.
Simplified_Description: At any sitting of the Legislative Assembly, while any resolution for the removal of the Speaker from his office is under consideration, the Speaker or the Deputy Speaker shall not, though he is present, preside. The Speaker shall have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in, the proceedings.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Prohibits the Speaker or Deputy Speaker from presiding over the Assembly when a resolution for their removal is being considered.
The person facing removal can be present, speak, and participate in the proceedings.
During such proceedings, the Speaker has the right to vote in the first instance like a regular member, but loses the casting vote in case of a tie.
Historical_Context: This provision upholds the principle of natural justice ('nemo judex in causa sua' - no one should be a judge in their own case). It ensures a fair process for the removal of a presiding officer by temporarily removing their special powers and placing them on the same level as other members.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural rule of the State Legislature, analogous to Article 96 for the Lok Sabha.
Related_Articles: Article 96 (Similar provision for the Speaker and Deputy Speaker of Lok Sabha)
Article 179 (Removal from the offices of Speaker and Deputy Speaker)

Title: The Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Legislative Council
Original_Description: The Legislative Council of every State having such Council shall, as soon as may be, choose two members of the Council to be respectively Chairman and Deputy Chairman thereof and, so often as the office of Chairman or Deputy Chairman becomes vacant, the Council shall choose another member to be Chairman or Deputy Chairman, as the case may be.
Simplified_Description: The Legislative Council of every State having such Council shall, as soon as may be, choose two members of the Council to be respectively Chairman and Deputy Chairman thereof. The Council shall choose another member to be Chairman or Deputy Chairman, as the case may be.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Mandates that every State Legislative Council (Vidhan Parishad) must elect a Chairman and a Deputy Chairman.
Both the Chairman and Deputy Chairman are elected from among the members of the Council itself.
Historical_Context: Unlike the Rajya Sabha, where the Vice-President of India is the ex-officio Chairman, the Legislative Council elects its own Chairman from its members. This is because there is no state-level equivalent of a Vice-President. The roles of the Chairman and Deputy Chairman are analogous to those of the Speaker and Deputy Speaker in the Assembly.
Landmark_Cases: This is a structural article for state legislatures with a second house.
Related_Articles: Article 89 (The Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Council of States)
Article 178 (The Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Legislative Assembly)

Title: Vacation and resignation of, and removal from, the offices of Chairman and Deputy Chairman
Original_Description:
A member holding office as Chairman or Deputy Chairman of a Legislative Council —

 

(a) shall vacate his office if he ceases to be a member of the Council;

 

(b) may at any time by writing under his hand addressed, if such member is the Chairman, to the Deputy Chairman, and if such member is the Deputy Chairman, to the Chairman, resign his office; and

 

(c) may be removed from his office by a resolution of the Council passed by a majority of all the then members of the Council:

 

   Provided that no resolution for the purpose of clause (c) shall be moved unless at least fourteen days' notice has been given of the intention to move the resolution.
Simplified_Description: A member holding office as Chairman or Deputy Chairman of a Legislative Council may vacate his office if he ceases to be a member of the Council. A member may be removed from his office by a resolution passed by a majority of all the then members of the council.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Specifies how the offices of Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Legislative Council can become vacant.
The office is vacated if the person ceases to be a member of the Council.
The Chairman can resign by writing to the Deputy Chairman, and vice versa.
They can be removed by a resolution passed by an 'effective majority' (a majority of all the then members) of the Council.
Historical_Context: This article provides the procedures for accountability and transition for the presiding officers of the upper house of a state legislature, mirroring similar provisions for other legislative bodies.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article governing the functioning of the Legislative Council.
Related_Articles: Article 90 (Vacation and resignation of... Deputy Chairman of Rajya Sabha)
Article 179 (Vacation and resignation of... Speaker and Deputy Speaker)

Title: Power of the Deputy Chairman or other person to perform the duties of the office of, or to act as, Chairman
Original_Description:
(1) While the office of Chairman is vacant, the duties of the office shall be performed by the Deputy Chairman or, if the office of Deputy Chairman is also vacant, by such member of the Council as the Governor may appoint for the purpose.

 

(2) During the absence of the Chairman from any sitting of the Council the Deputy Chairman or, if he is also absent, such person as may be determined by the rules of procedure of the Council, or, if no such person is present, such other person as may be determined by the Council, shall act as Chairman.
Simplified_Description: The Chairman of the Council is the person who acts as Chairman when the Chairman is absent. The Deputy Chairman or such other person as may be determined by the rules of procedure shall act as Chairman.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: The Deputy Chairman performs the duties of the Chairman when the Chairman's office is vacant.
The Deputy Chairman presides over the Council during the temporary absence of the Chairman.
If the Deputy Chairman's office is also vacant, the Governor can appoint a member of the Council to perform the Chairman's duties.
If both are absent from a sitting, another member as per the rules of the house will preside.
Historical_Context: This article ensures that the business of the Legislative Council can proceed without interruption, even in the absence or vacancy of its primary presiding officer.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural provision for the internal functioning of the state legislature.
Related_Articles: Article 91 (Similar provision for the Rajya Sabha)
Article 180 (Similar provision for the Legislative Assembly)

Title: The Chairman or the Deputy Chairman not to preside while a resolution for his removal from office is under consideration
Original_Description:
(1) At any sitting of the Legislative Council, while any resolution for the removal of the Chairman from his office is under consideration, the Chairman, or while any resolution for the removal of the Deputy Chairman from his office is under consideration, the Deputy Chairman, shall not, though he is present, preside, and the provisions of clause (2) of article 184 shall apply in relation to every such sitting as they apply in relation to a sitting from which the Chairman or, as the case may be, the Deputy Chairman is absent.

 

(2) The Chairman shall have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of, the Legislative Council while any resolution for his removal from office is under consideration in the Council and shall, notwithstanding anything in article 189, be entitled to vote only in the first instance on such resolution or on any other matter during such proceedings but not in the case of an equality of votes.
Simplified_Description: At any sitting of the Legislative Council, while any resolution for the removal of the Chairman from his office is under consideration, the Chairman or the Deputy Chairman shall not, though he is present, preside.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Prohibits the Chairman or Deputy Chairman from presiding over the Legislative Council when a resolution for their own removal is being considered.
They have the right to be present, speak, and participate in the proceedings.
During such proceedings, they vote in the first instance as a regular member and do not have a casting vote.
Historical_Context: This rule is based on the principles of natural justice and ensures fairness when the conduct of a presiding officer is under scrutiny by the House. It is a standard feature for all legislative bodies in the Indian constitutional scheme.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural rule of the State Legislature.
Related_Articles: Article 92 (Similar provision for the Rajya Sabha)
Article 181 (Similar provision for the Legislative Assembly)

Title: Salaries and allowances of the Speaker and Deputy Speaker and the Chairman and Deputy Chairman
Original_Description: There shall be paid to the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker of the Legislative Assembly, and to the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman of the Legislative Council, such salaries and allowances as may be respectively fixed by the Legislature of the State by law and, until provision in that behalf is so made, such salaries and allowances as are specified in the Second Schedule.
Simplified_Description: There shall be paid to the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker of the Legislative Assembly, and to the Chairman and the deputy Chairman of the legislative council. Such salaries and allowances as are specified in the Second Schedule.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Empowers the State Legislature to determine the salaries and allowances of its presiding officers.
This includes the Speaker, Deputy Speaker, Chairman, and Deputy Chairman.
These salaries are charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State and are not subject to the annual vote of the legislature.
Historical_Context: This provision ensures the financial independence of the presiding officers from the executive. By making their salaries non-votable, the Constitution protects them from political pressures that could be exerted through the annual budget process.
Landmark_Cases: This is a financial and procedural article.
Related_Articles: Article 202(3) (Expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State)

Title: Secretariat of State Legislature
Original_Description:
(1) The House or each House of the Legislature of a State shall have a separate secretarial staff: Provided that nothing in this clause shall, in the case of the Legislature of a State having a Legislative Council, be construed as preventing the creation of posts common to both Houses of such Legislature.

 

(2) The Legislature of a State may by law regulate the recruitment, and the conditions of service of persons appointed, to the secretarial staff of the House or Houses of the Legislature of the State.

 

(3) Until provision is made by the Legislature of the State under clause (2), the Governor may, after consultation with the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly or the Chairman of the Legislative Council, as the case may be, make rules regulating the recruitment, and the conditions of service of persons appointed, to the secretarial staff of the Assembly or the Council, and any rules so made shall have effect subject to the provisions of any law made under the said clause.
Simplified_Description: Each House or each House of the Legislature of a State shall have a separate secretarial staff. Nothing in this clause shall be construed as preventing the creation of posts common to both Houses of such Legislature.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Mandates a separate secretarial staff for each House of the State Legislature.
The State Legislature can regulate the recruitment and service conditions of this staff by law.
Until such a law is made, the Governor makes rules in consultation with the Speaker/Chairman.
Historical_Context: An independent secretariat, operating under the control of the presiding officers, is essential for the autonomy of the legislature. It ensures that the legislature's administrative machinery is not controlled by the state executive, thereby upholding the principle of separation of powers.
Landmark_Cases: This article ensures the administrative independence of the State Legislature.

Title: Oath or affirmation by members
Original_Description: Every member of the Legislative Assembly or the Legislative Council of a State shall, before taking his seat, make and subscribe before the Governor, or some person appointed in that behalf by him, an oath or affirmation according to the form set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule.
Simplified_Description: Every member of the Legislative Assembly or the Legislative Council of a State shall, before taking his seat, make and subscribe before the Governor.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Requires every member of a State Legislature (MLA/MLC) to take an oath or make an affirmation before taking their seat.
The oath is administered by the Governor or a person appointed by them (usually the pro-tem Speaker).
The form of the oath, which includes allegiance to the Constitution, is prescribed in the Third Schedule.
Historical_Context: This is a mandatory and solemn procedure that binds legislators to the Constitution of India. A member cannot participate in the proceedings or vote in the House without completing this formality.
Landmark_Cases: This is a mandatory procedural requirement.
Related_Articles: Article 99 (Oath or affirmation by members of Parliament)
Article 193 (Penalty for sitting and voting before making oath...)

Title: Voting in Houses, power of Houses to act notwithstanding vacancies and quorum
Original_Description:
(1) Save as otherwise provided in this Constitution, all questions at any sitting of a House of the Legislature of a State shall be determined by a majority of votes of the members present and voting, other than the Speaker or Chairman, or person acting as such. The Speaker or Chairman, or person acting as such, shall not vote in the first instance, but shall have and exercise a casting vote in the case of an equality of votes.

 

(2) A House of the Legislature of a State shall have power to act notwithstanding any vacancy in the membership thereof, and any proceedings in the Legislature of a State shall be valid notwithstanding that it is discovered subsequently that some person who was not entitled so to do sat or voted or otherwise took part in the proceedings.

 

(3) Until the Legislature of the State by law otherwise provides, the quorum to constitute a meeting of a House of the Legislature of a State shall be ten members or onetenth of the total number of members of the House, whichever is greater.

 

(4) If at any time during a meeting of the Legislative Assembly or the Legislative Council of a State there is no quorum, it shall be the duty of the Speaker or Chairman, or person acting as such, either to adjourn the House or to suspend the meeting until there is a quorum.
Simplified_Description: The Speaker or Chairman, or person acting as such, shall not vote in the first instance. The quorum to constitute a meeting of a House of the Legislature of a State shall be ten members or onetenth of the total number of members of the House.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Decisions are made by a majority of members present and voting.
The presiding officer (Speaker/Chairman) has a casting vote in case of a tie.
The quorum is ten members or one-tenth of the total membership, whichever is greater.
Proceedings are valid even if there are vacancies in the House's membership.
Historical_Context: This article lays down the standard operating procedures for voting and conducting business in state legislatures, mirroring the rules for Parliament under Article 100. The quorum rule ensures a minimum level of participation for legislative business to be considered valid.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article.

Title: Vacation of seats
Original_Description:
(1) No person shall be a member of both Houses of the Legislature of a State and provision shall be made by the Legislature of the State by law for the vacation by a person who is chosen a member of both Houses of his seat in one house or the other.

 

(2) No person shall be a member of the Legislatures of two or more States specified in the First Schedule and if a person is chosen a member of the Legislatures of two or more such States, then, at the expiration of such period as may be specified in rules1 made by the President, that person's seat in the Legislatures of all such States shall become vacant, unless he has previously resigned his seat in the Legislatures of all but one of the States.

 

(3) If a member of a House of the Legislature of a State — 

 

(a) becomes subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in clause (1) or clause (2) of article 191; or

 

(b) resigns his seat by writing under his hand addressed to the speaker or the Chairman, as the case may be, and his resignation is accepted by the Speaker or the Chairman, as the case may be, 

 

his seat shall thereupon become vacant:

 

   Provided that in the case of any resignation referred to in sub-clause (b), if from information received or otherwise and after making such inquiry as he thinks fit, the Speaker or the Chairman, as the case may be, is satisfied that such resignation is not voluntary or genuine, he shall not accept such resignation. 

 

(4) If for a period of sixty days a member of a House of the Legislature of a State is without permission of the House absent from all meetings thereof, the House may declare his seat vacant:

 

   Provided that in computing the said period of sixty days no account shall be taken of any period during which the House is prorogued or is adjourned for more than four consecutive days.
Simplified_Description: No person shall be a member of both Houses of the Legislature of a State. If a person is chosen a member. of the Legislatures of two or more such States, then, at the. expiration of such period as may be specified in rules1 made by the President, that person's seat in. all such States shall become vacant, unless he has previously resigned his seat in
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Lists the conditions under which a member of a State Legislature's seat becomes vacant.
Prohibits simultaneous membership in both Houses of a state legislature, in the legislatures of two or more states, or in Parliament and a state legislature.
A seat also becomes vacant upon resignation, disqualification, or absence for 60 days without permission.
Historical_Context: This article ensures that legislators devote their attention to a single legislative body and fulfill their duties of attendance and participation. It provides clear rules to prevent individuals from holding multiple legislative offices.
Landmark_Cases: The rules regarding resignation and disqualification are often interpreted in cases before the High Courts and the Supreme Court.

Title: Disqualifications for membership
