Simplified_Description: A person shall be disqualified for being chosen as, and for being, a member of the Legislative Assembly or Legislative Council of a State. A person shall not be deemed to hold an office of profit under the Government of India or any State specified in the First Schedule by reason only that he is a Minister for such State.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Lists the grounds for disqualification of a member of a State Legislature (MLA/MLC).
Grounds include: holding an office of profit, being of unsound mind, being an undischarged insolvent, not being a citizen.
Also includes disqualification under any law made by Parliament (e.g., Representation of the People Act, 1951).
Disqualification on the ground of defection under the Tenth Schedule is also explicitly mentioned.
Historical_Context: This article mirrors Article 102 for Members of Parliament. It sets the legal standards for eligibility to hold legislative office in a state. The addition of the Tenth Schedule (anti-defection law) via the 52nd Amendment Act, 1985, was a major development impacting this article, aimed at curbing political defections.
Landmark_Cases: Kihoto Hollohan vs Zachillhu (1992): Upheld the constitutionality of the Tenth Schedule but held that the Speaker's decision is subject to judicial review.
Lily Thomas vs Union of India (2013): Ruled that legislators are immediately disqualified upon conviction for a criminal offense punishable with two or more years of imprisonment.
Related_Articles: Article 192 (Decision on questions as to disqualifications)

Title: Decision on questions as to disqualifications of members
Original_Description:
(1) If any question arises as to whether a member of a House of the Legislature of a State has become subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in clause (1) of article 191, the question shall be referred for the decision of the Governor and his decision shall be final.

 

(2) Before giving any decision on any such question, the Governor shall obtain the opinion of the Election Commission and shall act according to such opinion.
Simplified_Description: The question of whether a member of a House of the Legislature of a State has become subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in clause (1) of article 191 is referred for the decision of the Governor.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Specifies the authority to decide on the disqualification of an MLA/MLC under Article 191(1).
The decision-making authority is the Governor of the state.
The Governor must obtain the opinion of the Election Commission of India before giving their decision.
The Governor is bound to act according to the Election Commission's opinion.
This process does not apply to disqualification on grounds of defection (Tenth Schedule).
Historical_Context: This article provides a quasi-judicial process for deciding disqualification cases, parallel to Article 103 for MPs. By making the Election Commission's opinion binding on the Governor, the Constitution aims to ensure that the decision is impartial and based on legal and factual determination rather than political considerations.
Landmark_Cases: The role of the Governor and the binding nature of the ECI's opinion have been affirmed in several court judgments.
Related_Articles: Article 103 (Similar provision for Members of Parliament)

Title: Penalty for sitting and voting before making oath or affirmation under article 188 or when not qualified or when disqualified
Original_Description: If a person sits or votes as a member of the Legislative Assembly or the Legislative Council of a State before he has complied with the requirements of article 188, or when he knows that he is not qualified or that he is disqualified for membership thereof, or that he is prohibited from so doing by the provisions of any law made by Parliament or the Legislature of the State, he shall be liable in respect of each day on which he so sits or votes to a penalty of five hundred rupees to be recovered as a debt due to the State.
Simplified_Description: If a person sits or votes as a member of the Legislative Assembly or the Legislative Council of a State before he has complied with the requirements of article 188, he is liable to a penalty of five hundred rupees to be recovered as a debt due to the State.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Imposes a penalty of ₹500 per day for sitting and voting in the State Legislature under certain illegal circumstances.
This applies if a person has not taken the oath or affirmation as required by Article 188.
It also applies if a person participates while knowing they are not qualified or have been disqualified.
Historical_Context: This is a penal provision that acts as a deterrent to ensure compliance with the constitutional requirements for membership in a state legislature. It is the state-level equivalent of Article 104.
Landmark_Cases: This is a penal provision and not frequently litigated.

Title: Powers, privileges, etc, of the Houses of Legislatures and of the members and committees thereof
Original_Description:
(1) Subject to the provisions of this Constitution and to the rules and standing orders regulating the procedure of the Legislature, there shall be freedom of speech in the Legislature of every State.

 

(2) No member of the Legislature of a State shall be liable to any proceedings in any court in respect of anything said or any vote given by him in the Legislature or any committee thereof, and no person shall be so liable in respect of the publication by or under the authority of a House of such a Legislature of any report, paper, votes or proceedings.

 

(3) In other respects, the powers, privileges and immunities of a House of the Legislature of a State, and of the members and the committees of a House of such Legislature, shall be such as may from time to time be defined by the Legislature by law, and, until so defined, shall be those of that House and of its members and committees immediately before the coming into force of section 26 of the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978.

 

(4) The provisions of clauses (1), (2) and (3) shall apply in relation to persons who by virtue of this Constitution have the right to speak in, and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of, a House of the Legislature of a State or any committee thereof as they apply in relation to members of that Legislature.
Simplified_Description: There shall be freedom of speech in the Legislature of every State. No member of a Legislature of a State shall be liable to any proceedings in any court in respect of anything said.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Guarantees freedom of speech for members within the State Legislature.
Provides absolute immunity to members from court proceedings for anything said or any vote cast in the legislature or its committees.
Other powers, privileges, and immunities are to be defined by the State Legislature by law.
This includes the power of the House to punish for breach of privilege or contempt.
Historical_Context: This article mirrors Article 105 and provides state legislators with the same essential privileges as Members of Parliament. These privileges are deemed necessary for them to perform their legislative duties freely and without fear of external interference or legal action.
Landmark_Cases: Keshav Singh's Case (1965): A crucial case that explored the conflict between legislative privileges and fundamental rights, establishing that privileges are subject to the Constitution.

Title: Salaries and allowances of members
Original_Description: Members of the Legislative Assembly and the Legislative Council of a State shall be entitled to receive such salaries and allowances as may from time to time be determined, by the Legislature of the State by law and, until provision in that respect is so made, salaries and allowances at such rates and upon such conditions as were immediately before the commencement of this Constitution applicable in the case of members of the Legislative Assembly of the corresponding Province.
Simplified_Description: Members of the Legislative Assembly and the Legislative Council of a State shall be entitled to receive such salaries and allowances as may from time to time be determined.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Empowers the Legislature of a State to determine the salaries and allowances of its own members (MLAs and MLCs).
This is done by enacting a law.
Historical_Context: This provision gives state legislatures autonomy over the compensation of their members, analogous to Parliament's power under Article 106. This has often been a topic of public debate, especially when legislatures vote to increase their own salaries and allowances.
Landmark_Cases: This is a financial and procedural article.
Related_Articles: Article 106 (Salaries and allowances of members of Parliament)

Title: Provisions as to introduction and passing of Bills
Original_Description:
(1) Subject to the provisions of articles 198 and 207 with respect to Money Bills and other financial Bills, a Bill may originate in either House of the Legislature of a State which has a Legislative Council.

 

(2) Subject to the provisions of articles 197 and 198, a Bill shall not be deemed to have been passed by the Houses of the Legislature of a State having a Legislative Council unless it has been agreed to by both Houses, either without amendment or with such amendments only as are agreed to by both Houses.

 

(3) A Bill pending in the Legislature of a State shall not lapse by reason of the prorogation of the House or Houses thereof.

 

(4) A Bill pending in the Legislative Council of a State which has not been passed by the Legislative Assembly shall not lapse on a dissolution of the Assembly.

 

(5) A Bill which is pending in the Legislative Assembly of a State, or which having been passed by the Legislative Assembly is pending in the Legislative Council, shall lapse on a dissolution of the Assembly.
Simplified_Description: A Bill pending in the Legislature of a State shall not lapse by reason of the prorogation of the House or Houses thereof. The Bill must be agreed to by both Houses, either without amendment or with such amendments only as are agreed to.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: An ordinary bill can be introduced in either House (in a bicameral legislature).
Prorogation of a session does not cause a bill to lapse.
Dissolution of the Legislative Assembly causes any bill pending in the Assembly to lapse.
A bill passed by the Assembly but pending in the Council also lapses upon dissolution of the Assembly.
A bill pending in the Council which has not been passed by the Assembly does not lapse.
Historical_Context: This article sets out the legislative procedure for state legislatures, which is largely similar to the procedure in Parliament. The rules on the lapsing of bills are important for understanding the status of legislation across different sessions and assembly terms.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article central to the state legislative process.

Title: Restriction on powers of Legislative Council as to Bills other than Money Bills
Original_Description:
(1) If after a Bill has been passed by the Legislative Assembly of a State having a Legislative Council and transmitted to the Legislative Council —

 

(a) the Bill is rejected by the Council; or

 

(b) more than three months elapse from the date on which the Bill is laid before the Council without the Bill being passed by it; or

 

(c) the Bill is passed by the Council with amendments to which the Legislative Assembly does not agree;

 

the Legislative Assembly may, subject to the rules regulating its procedure, pass the Bill again in the same or in any subsequent session with or without such amendments, if any, as have been made, suggested or agreed to by the Legislative Council and then transmit the Bill as so passed to the Legislative Council.

 

(2) If after a Bill has been so passed for the second time by the Legislative Assembly and transmitted to the Legislative Council —

 

(a) the Bill is rejected by the Council; or

 

(b) more than one month elapses from the date on which the Bill is laid before the Council without the Bill being passed by it; or

 

(c) the Bill is passed by the Council with amendments to which the Legislative Assembly does not agree;

 

the Bill shall be deemed to have been passed by the Houses of the Legislature of the State in the form in which it was passed by the Legislative Assembly for the second time with such amendments, if any, as have been made or suggested by the Legislative Council and agreed to by the Legislative Assembly.

 

(3) Nothing in this article shall apply to a Money Bill.
Simplified_Description: A Bill is considered to have been passed by the Houses of the Legislature of the State if it is passed for the second time by the Legislative Assembly and transmitted to the Legislative Council. Nothing in this article shall apply to a Money Bill. If a Bill is rejected by the Council for more than three months after it is laid before it, it is deemed to be passed.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Defines the limited powers of the Legislative Council regarding ordinary bills.
A Council can delay a bill passed by the Assembly for a maximum of four months (three months in the first instance, and one month in the second).
The Council can suggest amendments, but the Assembly is not bound to accept them.
Ultimately, the will of the Legislative Assembly prevails; there is no provision for a joint sitting to resolve deadlocks.
This article does not apply to Money Bills.
Historical_Context: This provision establishes the subordinate position of the Legislative Council in relation to the Legislative Assembly. Unlike the Rajya Sabha at the Centre, a State Legislative Council is only a dilatory chamber and cannot permanently block legislation passed by the directly elected house.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article outlining the legislative relationship between the two houses of a state legislature.
Related_Articles: Article 108 (Joint sitting - which does not exist at the state level)

Title: Special procedure in respect of Money Bills
Original_Description:
(1) A Money Bill shall not be introduced in a Legislative Council.

 

(2) After a Money Bill has been passed by the Legislative Assembly of a State having a Legislative Council, it shall be transmitted to the Legislative Council for its recommendations, and the Legislative Council shall within a period of fourteen days from the date of its receipt of the Bill return the Bill to the Legislative Assembly with its recommendations, and the Legislative Assembly may thereupon either accept or reject all or any of the recommendations of the Legislative Council.

 

(3) If the Legislative Assembly accepts any of the recommendations of the Legislative Council, the Money Bill shall be deemed to have been passed by both Houses with the amendments recommended by the Legislative Council and accepted by the Legislative Assembly.

 

(4) If the Legislative Assembly does not accept any of the recommendations of the Legislative Council, the Money Bill shall be deemed to have been passed by both Houses in the form in which it was passed by the Legislative Assembly without any of the amendments recommended by the Legislative Council.

 

(5) If a Money Bill passed by the Legislative Assembly and transmitted to the Legislative Council for its recommendations is not returned to the Legislative Assembly within the said period of fourteen days, it shall be deemed to have been passed by both Houses at the expiration of the said period in the form in which it was passed by the Legislative Assembly.
Simplified_Description: A Money Bill shall not be introduced in a Legislative Council. After a Money Bill has been passed by the Legislative Assembly of a State, it shall be transmitted to the Legislative Council for its recommendations. The Legislative Council shall within a period of fourteen days from the date of its receipt of the Bill return the Bill to the Legislative Assembly with its recommendations.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: A Money Bill can only be introduced in the Legislative Assembly.
The Legislative Council has very limited powers; it can only make recommendations, which the Assembly can accept or reject.
The Council must return the Money Bill within 14 days.
If the bill is not returned within 14 days, it is deemed to have been passed.
The will of the Assembly is supreme in financial matters.
Historical_Context: This article mirrors Article 109 for Parliament, ensuring the financial supremacy of the directly elected house (Legislative Assembly) at the state level. It prevents the upper house from blocking the government's budget or financial legislation.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article central to the state's budget process.
Related_Articles: Article 199 (Definition of “Money Bills” at state level)

Title: Definition of “Money Bills”
Simplified_Description: A Bill is deemed to be a Money Bill if it contains only provisions dealing with all or any of the following matters: imposition, abolition, remission, alteration or regulation of any tax. The decision of the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly of such State thereon shall be final.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Defines a Money Bill at the state level, with provisions similar to Article 110 for the Union (taxation, state government borrowing, appropriation from the Consolidated Fund of the State, etc.).
Declares the decision of the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly as final in certifying a bill as a Money Bill.
The Speaker's certificate is required before the bill is sent to the Legislative Council or the Governor.
Historical_Context: This article provides a clear definition and a final authority (the Speaker) for classifying financial legislation at the state level. Like its Union counterpart, the 'finality' of the Speaker's decision has been debated, with the Supreme Court in the Aadhaar case indicating that this finality is subject to judicial review on certain grounds.
Landmark_Cases: The principles laid down by the Supreme Court in cases concerning Article 110, like the Aadhaar case, would apply by analogy to this article.
Related_Articles: Article 110 (Definition of “Money Bills” at Union level)
Article 198 (Special procedure in respect of Money Bills)

Title: Assent to Bills
Original_Description:
When a Bill has been passed by the Legislative Assembly of a State or, in the case of a State having a Legislative Council, has been passed by both Houses of the Legislature of the State, it shall be presented to the Governor and the Governor shall declare either that he assents to the Bill or that he withholds assent therefrom or that he reserves the Bill for the consideration of the President:

 

   Provided that the Governor may, as soon as possible after the presentation to him of the Bill for assent, return the Bill if it is not a Money Bill together with a message requesting that the House or Houses will reconsider the Bill or any specified provisions thereof and, in particular, will consider the desirability of introducing any such amendments as he may recommend in his message and, when a Bill is so returned, the House or Houses shall reconsider the Bill accordingly, and if the Bill is passed again by the House or Houses with or without amendment and presented to the Governor for assent, the Governor shall not withhold assent therefrom:

 

   Provided further that the Governor shall not assent to, but shall reserve for the consideration of the President, any Bill which in the opinion of the Governor would, if it became law, so derogate from the powers of the High Court as to endanger the position which that Court is by this Constitution designed to fill.
Simplified_Description: When a Bill has been passed by the Legislative Assembly of a State, it shall be presented to the Governor and the Governor shall declare either that he assents to the Bill or that he withholds assent therefrom. The Governor may return the Bill if it is not a Money Bill together with a message requesting that the House or Houses will reconsider the Bill.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Outlines the options available to the Governor when a bill is presented for assent.

The Governor can: (1) give assent, (2) withhold assent (absolute veto), (3) return the bill for reconsideration (suspensive veto, not applicable to Money Bills), or (4) reserve the bill for the consideration of the President.
If the legislature passes the returned bill again, the Governor must give assent.
Reserving a bill for the President is a significant discretionary power.
Historical_Context: The Governor's power to reserve bills for the President's consideration is a key tool of central oversight over state legislation. It is mandatory for the Governor to reserve bills that would derogate the powers of the High Court. In other cases, it is discretionary and has often been a source of friction in Centre-State relations.
Landmark_Cases: The exercise of the Governor's discretion in reserving bills has been discussed in various reports on Centre-State relations, such as the Sarkaria Commission report.

Title: Bills reserved for consideration
Original_Description:
When a Bill is reserved by a Governor for the consideration of the President, the President shall declare either that he assents to the Bill or that he withholds assent therefrom:

 

   Provided that, where the Bill is not a Money Bill, the President may direct the Governor to return the Bill to the House or, as the case may be, the Houses of the Legislature of the State together with such a message as is mentioned in the first proviso to article 200 and, when a Bill is so returned, the House or Houses shall reconsider it accordingly within a period of six months from the date of receipt of such message and, if it is again passed by the House or Houses with or without amendment, it shall be presented again to the President for his consideration.
Simplified_Description: The President may declare either that he assents to the Bill or that he withholds assent therefrom. If the Bill is not a Money Bill, the President may direct the Governor to return the Bill to the House or the Houses of the Legislature.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Describes the procedure once a bill is reserved by the Governor for the President's consideration.
The President can either give assent or withhold assent (absolute veto).
The President can also direct the Governor to return the bill (if it is not a Money Bill) to the state legislature for reconsideration.

If the state legislature passes the bill again, it must be presented again to the President for consideration. The Constitution does not say whether the President is bound to give assent in this case.
Historical_Context: This article gives the Union executive a final say on certain state laws. Unlike the Governor, who must give assent to a reconsidered bill, the President is not explicitly bound to do so. This effectively gives the President an absolute veto over state legislation, which is a significant unitary feature of the Constitution.
Landmark_Cases: This process is a key aspect of Centre-State legislative relations.

Title: Annual financial statement
Simplified_Description: The annual financial statement of the State is to be made every financial year. It is to show the sums required to meet expenditure described by this Constitution. It will distinguish expenditure on revenue account from other expenditure.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Mandates the presentation of the state's 'Annual Financial Statement' (State Budget) before the state legislature each year.
The Governor is responsible for causing it to be laid before the House(s).
The statement must distinguish between expenditure 'charged' on the Consolidated Fund of the State and other expenditure.
Charged expenditure (e.g., salaries of Governor, High Court judges) is non-votable.
Historical_Context: This is the state-level equivalent of Article 112 and establishes the basis for legislative control over state finances. It ensures that the state government is financially accountable to the people's representatives in the Legislative Assembly.
Landmark_Cases: This is a core financial and procedural article for state legislatures.
Related_Articles: Article 112 (Annual financial statement for the Union)

Title: Procedure in Legislature with respect to estimates
Original_Description:
(1) So much of the estimates as relates to expenditure charged upon the Consolidated Fund of a State shall not be submitted to the vote of the Legislative Assembly, but nothing in this clause shall be construed as preventing the discussion in the Legislature of any of those estimates.

 

(2) So much of the said estimates as relates to other expenditure shall be submitted in the form of demands for grants to the Legislative Assembly, and the Legislative Assembly shall have power to assent, or to refuse to assent, to any demand, or to assent to any demand subject to a reduction of the amount specified therein.

 

(3) No demand for a grant shall be made except on the recommendation of the Governor.
Simplified_Description: Nothing in this clause shall be construed as preventing the discussion in the Legislature of any of those estimates. (1) So much of the estimates as relates to expenditure charged upon the Consolidated Fund of a State shall not be submitted to the vote of the Legislative Assembly.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Charged expenditure can be discussed but not voted upon by the Legislative Assembly.
Other expenditure is presented to the Legislative Assembly as 'Demands for Grants'.
The Legislative Assembly can assent, refuse, or reduce a Demand for Grant.
No demand can be made except on the Governor's recommendation.
Historical_Context: This article mirrors Article 113 for the Union, operationalizing the Legislative Assembly's control over the state's purse strings. The power to cut or refuse grants is a powerful tool of accountability.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article for the state budget process.

Title: Appropriation Bills
Original_Description:
(1) As soon as may be after the grants under article 203 have been made by the Assembly, there shall be introduced a Bill to provide for the appropriation out of the Consolidated Fund of the State of all moneys required to meet —

 

(a) the grants so made by the Assembly; and

 

(b) the expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State but not exceeding in any case the amount shown in the statement previously laid before the House or Houses.

 

(2) No amendment shall be proposed to any such Bill in the House or either House of the Legislature of the State which will have the effect of varying the amount or altering the destination of any grant so made or of varying the amount of any expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State, and the decision of the person presiding as to whether an amendment is inadmissible under this clause shall be final.

 

(3) Subject to the provisions of articles 205 and 206, no money shall be withdrawn from the Consolidated Fund of the State except under appropriation made by law passed in accordance with the provisions of this article.
Simplified_Description: Article 203: A Bill to provide for the appropriation out of the Consolidated Fund of the State of all moneys required to meet the requirements of the Assembly. No amendment shall be proposed to any such Bill which will have the effect of varying the amount or altering the destination of any grant so made.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Mandates the introduction of an 'Appropriation Bill' after the Assembly has voted on the Demands for Grants.
This bill provides the legal authority to withdraw money from the Consolidated Fund of the State.
It includes both voted grants and charged expenditure.
No money can be withdrawn from the Fund without the passage of this law.
Historical_Context: Parallel to Article 114 for the Union, this provision ensures that all government expenditure is explicitly authorized by law, reinforcing the principle of legislative control over public finance at the state level.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article for the state budget process.

Title: Supplementary, additional or excess grants
Original_Description:
(1) The Governor shall —

 

(a) if the amount authorised by any law made in accordance with the provisions of article 204 to be expended for a particular service for the current financial year is found to be insufficient for the purposes of that year or when a need has arisen during the current financial year for supplementary or additional expenditure upon some new service not contemplated in the annual financial statement for that year, or

 

(b) if any money has been spent on any service during a financial year in excess of the amount granted for that service and for that year,

 

cause to be laid before the House or the Houses of the Legislature of the State another statement showing the estimated amount of that expenditure or cause to be presented to the Legislative Assembly of the State a demand for such excess, as the case may be.

 

(2) The provisions of articles 202, 203 and 204 shall have effect in relation to any such statement and expenditure or demand and also to any law to be made authorising the appropriation of moneys out of the Consolidated Fund of the State to meet such expenditure or the grant in respect of such demand as they have effect in relation to the annual financial statement and the expenditure mentioned therein or to a demand for a grant and the law to be made for the authorisation of appropriation of moneys out of the Consolidated Fund of the State to meet such expenditure or grant.
Simplified_Description: Governor can order extra money to be spent on a particular service. He can also ask for a grant to meet such an extra expenditure.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Provides for supplementary, additional, or excess grants if the original budget allocation proves insufficient or if unforeseen expenditure arises.
The Governor must cause a statement of such expenditure to be laid before the legislature.
These grants follow the same procedure as the regular budget (Demands for Grants and Appropriation Bill).
Historical_Context: This article provides necessary flexibility in state finances, allowing governments to respond to emergent needs not foreseen at the time of the annual budget, while keeping the process under legislative scrutiny. It is the state-level equivalent of Article 115.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article related to state public finance.

Title: Votes on account, votes of credit and exceptional grants
Simplified_Description: Legislators have power to make any grant in advance in respect of the estimated expenditure for a part of any financial year. They can also make an exceptional grant which forms no part of the current service of anyFinancial year.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Empowers the State Legislative Assembly to make three types of special grants:
1. Vote on Account: An advance grant to cover expenses for a part of the financial year until the budget is fully passed.
2. Vote of Credit: A grant to meet an unforeseen demand (a 'blank cheque').
3. Exceptional Grant: A grant for a special purpose outside the ordinary expenditure of the year.
Historical_Context: This article mirrors Article 116, providing the state legislature with the same financial tools as Parliament to handle routine budgetary transitions (Vote on Account) and extraordinary financial situations (Votes of Credit, Exceptional Grants).
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article related to state public finance.

Title: Special provisions as to financial Bills
Original_Description:
(1) A Bill or amendment making provision for any of the matters specified in sub-clauses (a) to (f) of clause (1) of article 199 shall not be introduced or moved except on the recommendation of the Governor, and a Bill making such provision shall not be introduced in a Legislative Council:

 

   Provided that no recommendation shall be required under this clause for the moving of an amendment making provision for the reduction or abolition of any tax.

 

(2) A Bill or amendment shall not be deemed to make provision for any of the matters aforesaid by reason only that it provides for the imposition of fines or other pecuniary penalties, or for the demand or payment of fees for licences or fees for services rendered, or by reason that it provides for the imposition, abolition, remission, alteration or regulation of any tax by any local authority or body for local purposes.

 

(3) A Bill which, if enacted and brought into operation, would involve expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of a State shall not be passed by a House of the Legislature of the State unless the Governor has recommended to that House the consideration of the Bill.
Simplified_Description: A Bill or amendment making provision for any of the matters specified in sub-clauses (a) to (f) of clause (1) of article 199 shall not be introduced or moved except on the recommendation of the Governor. A Bill which, if enacted and brought into operation, would involve expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of a State.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Defines the procedure for Financial Bills at the state level, similar to Article 117 for the Union.
Financial Bills (Category I), containing matters of Article 199 plus other matters, must be introduced in the Assembly on the Governor's recommendation.
Financial Bills (Category II), involving expenditure from the Consolidated Fund of the State, require the Governor's recommendation for consideration.
Historical_Context: This article ensures executive control (through the Governor's recommendation) over any legislation with financial implications, maintaining fiscal discipline at the state level.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article defining types of financial legislation at the state level.
Related_Articles: Article 199 (Definition of “Money Bills” at state level)

Title: Rules of procedure
Original_Description:
(1) A House of the Legislature of a State may make rules for regulating, subject to the provisions of this Constitution, its procedure and the conduct of its business.

 

(2) Until rules are made under clause (1), the rules of procedure and standing orders in force immediately before the commencement of this Constitution with respect to the Legislature for the corresponding Province shall have effect in relation to the Legislature of the State subject to such modifications and adaptations as may be made therein by the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly, or the Chairman of the Legislative Council, as the case may be.

 

(3) In a State having a Legislative Council the Governor, after consultation with the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly and the Chairman of the Legislative Council, may make rules as to the procedure with respect to communications between the two Houses.
Simplified_Description: The rules of procedure and standing orders in force immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall have effect in relation to the Legislature of the State. The Governor, after consultation with the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly and the Chairman of the legislative Council, may make rules as to the procedure with respect to communications between the two Houses.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Empowers each House of a State Legislature to make its own rules of procedure.
In a bicameral state, the Governor can make rules for communication between the two Houses, in consultation with the Speaker and the Chairman.
Historical_Context: This provision grants autonomy to state legislatures to manage their internal proceedings, parallel to the autonomy given to Parliament under Article 118.
Landmark_Cases: Courts are generally reluctant to interfere with the internal procedural matters of the legislature.
Related_Articles: Article 212 (Courts not to inquire into proceedings of the Legislature)

Title: Regulation by law of procedure in the Legislature of the State in relation to financial business
Original_Description: The Legislature of a State may, for the purpose of the timely completion of financial business, regulate by law the procedure of, and the conduct of business in, the House or Houses of the Legislature of the State in relation to any financial matter or to any Bill for the appropriation of moneys out of the Consolidated Fund of the State, and, if and so far as any provision of any law so made is inconsistent with any rule made by the House or either House of the Legislature of the State under clause (1) of article 208 or with any rule or standing order having effect in relation to the Legislature of the State under clause (2) of that article, such provision shall prevail.
Simplified_Description: The Legislature of a State may regulate by law the procedure of, and the conduct of business in, the House or Houses of the Legislature of the State. This is for the purpose of the timely completion of financial business.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Allows the State Legislature to pass a law to regulate its procedure for financial business.
This is aimed at ensuring the timely completion of budgetary processes.
A law made under this article will override any conflicting rules of procedure made under Article 208.
Historical_Context: This article provides a mechanism to legally streamline the budget process at the state level, ensuring that time-sensitive financial legislation is not delayed. It is the state-level counterpart to Article 119.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article.

Title: Language to be used in the Legislature
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything in Part XVII, but subject to the provisions of article 348, business in the Legislature of a State shall be transacted in the official language or languages of the State or in Hindi or in English: Provided that the Speaker of the Legislative Assembly or Chairman of the Legislative Council, or person acting as such, as the case may be, may permit any member who cannot adequately express himself in any of the languages aforesaid to address the House in his mothertongue.

 

(2) Unless the Legislature of the State by law otherwise provides, this article shall, after the expiration of a period of fifteen years from the commencement of this Constitution, have effect as if the words “or in English” were omitted therefrom:

 

   Provided that in relation to the Legislatures of the States of Himachal Pradesh, Manipur, Meghalaya and Tripura this clause shall have effect as if for the words “fifteen years” occurring therein, the words “twenty-five years” were substituted:

 

   Provided further that in relation to the Legislatures of the States of Arunachal Pradesh, Goa and Mizoram, this clause shall have effect as if for the words “fifteen years” occurring therein, the words “forty years” were substituted.
Simplified_Description: Business in the Legislature of a State shall be transacted in the official language or languages of the State or in Hindi or in English. The Speaker of the Legislative Assembly may permit any member who cannot adequately express himself in any of the languages aforesaid to address the House.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Specifies that business in the State Legislature shall be conducted in the official language(s) of the state, or in Hindi, or in English.
The presiding officer can permit a member to speak in their mother tongue if they are unable to use the official languages.
The continued use of English was originally for 15 years, but this can be extended by state law.
Historical_Context: This provision provides linguistic flexibility in state legislatures, respecting the diverse linguistic landscape of India. It allows states to adopt their own official languages for legislative business while also providing for the use of Hindi and English.
Landmark_Cases: This article governs the internal functioning of state legislatures.
Related_Articles: Article 120 (Language to be used in Parliament)
Article 345 (Official language or languages of a State)

Title: Restriction on discussion in the Legislature
Original_Description: No discussion shall take place in the Legislature of a State with respect to the conduct of any Judge of the Supreme Court or of a High Court in the discharge of his duties.
Simplified_Description: No discussion shall take place in the Legislature of a State with respect to the conduct of any Judge of the Supreme Court or of a High Court.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Prohibits any discussion in a State Legislature regarding the conduct of a Supreme Court or High Court judge in the performance of their judicial duties.
This is an absolute restriction, with no exceptions mentioned (unlike in Parliament, where it is allowed during impeachment proceedings).
Historical_Context: This article is a vital safeguard for judicial independence, protecting judges from political criticism and pressure on the floor of the state legislature. It complements Article 121 and helps maintain the separation of powers.
Landmark_Cases: This provision is a cornerstone of judicial independence and the separation of powers.

Title: Courts not to inquire into proceedings of the Legislature
Original_Description:
(1) The validity of any proceedings in the Legislature of a State shall not be called in question on the ground of any alleged irregularity of procedure.

 

(2) No officer or member of the Legislature of a State in whom powers are vested by or under this Constitution for regulating procedure or the conduct of business, or for maintaining order, in the Legislature shall be subject to the jurisdiction of any court in respect of the exercise by him of those powers.
Simplified_Description: The validity of any proceedings in the Legislature of a State shall not be called in question on the ground of any alleged irregularity of procedure. (1) No officer or member of the Legislature. of a state in whom powers are vested by or under this Constitution. shall be subject to the jurisdiction of any court in respect of the exercise by him of those powers.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Bars courts from questioning the validity of proceedings in the State Legislature on the grounds of procedural irregularity.
Protects the officers and members of the legislature from the jurisdiction of courts in respect of their powers to conduct business.
This ensures the autonomy of the legislature in managing its internal affairs.
Historical_Context: This article, the state-level counterpart of Article 122, upholds the principle of separation of powers. While it grants immunity from judicial review for procedural errors, the Supreme Court has clarified that this does not extend to substantive unconstitutionality or illegality in the proceedings.
Landmark_Cases: The principles from the Raja Ram Pal case (2007) regarding Parliament are applicable here, allowing for judicial review in cases of unconstitutionality, not just procedural flaws.
Related_Articles: Article 194 (Powers and privileges of state legislatures)

Title: Power of Governor to promulgate Ordinances during recess of Legislature
Original_Description:
(1) If at any time, except when the Legislative Assembly of a State is in session, or where there is a Legislative Council in a State, except when both Houses of the Legislature are in session, the Governor is satisfied that circumstances exist which render it necessary for him to take immediate action, he may promulgate such Ordinances as the circumstances appear to him to require:

 

   Provided that the Governor shall not, without instructions from the President, promulgate any such Ordinance if —

 

(a) a Bill containing the same provisions would under this Constitution have required the previous sanction of the President for the introduction thereof into the Legislature; or

 

(b) he would have deemed it necessary to reserve a Bill containing the same provisions for the consideration of the President; or

 

(c) an Act of the Legislature of the State containing the same provisions would under this Constitution have been invalid unless, having been reserved for the consideration of the President, it had received the assent of the President.

 

(2) An Ordinance promulgated under this article shall have the same force and effect as an Act of the Legislature of the State assented to by the Governor, but every such Ordinance —

 

(a) shall be laid before the Legislative Assembly of the State, or where there is a Legislative Council in the State, before both the Houses, and shall cease to operate at the expiration of six weeks from the reassembly of the Legislature, or if before the expiration of that period a resolution disapproving it is passed by the Legislative Assembly and agreed to by the Legislative Council, if any, upon the passing of the resolution or, as the case may be, on the resolution being agreed to by the Council; and

 

(b) may be withdrawn at any time by the Governor.

 

   Explanation — Where the Houses of the Legislature of a State having a Legislative Council are summoned to reassemble on different dates, the period of six weeks shall be reckoned from the later of those dates for the purposes of this clause.

 

(3) If and so far as an Ordinance under this article makes any provision which would not be valid if enacted in an Act of the Legislature of the State assented to by the Governor, it shall be void:

 

   Provided that, for the purposes of the provisions of this Constitution relating to the effect of an Act of the Legislature of a State which is repugnant to an Act of Parliament or an existing law with respect to a matter enumerated in the Concurrent List, an Ordinance promulgated under this article in pursuance of instructions from the President shall be deemed to be an Act of the Legislature of the State which has been reserved for the consideration of the President and assented to by him.
Simplified_Description: The Governor may promulgate such Ordinances as the circumstances appear to him to require. An Ordinance promulgated under this article shall have the same force and effect as an Act of the Legislature of the State assented to by the Governor. Every such Ordinance shall be laid before the Legislative Assembly, or where there is a Legislative Council in the State, before both the Houses.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Gives the Governor the power to issue Ordinances when the state legislature (or at least the Assembly) is not in session.
This power is exercised on the advice of the state Council of Ministers.
An Ordinance has the same force as an Act of the state legislature but is temporary.
It must be laid before the legislature when it reassembles and ceases to operate six weeks after reassembly unless approved or disapproved earlier.
Historical_Context: This is the state-level equivalent of the President's ordinance-making power (Article 123). It is an extraordinary legislative power given to the executive for urgent situations. Its use, and particularly its re-promulgation without legislative approval, has been a subject of significant judicial criticism as a 'fraud on the Constitution'.
Landmark_Cases: D.C. Wadhwa vs State of Bihar (1987): The Supreme Court strongly condemned the repeated re-promulgation of ordinances in Bihar as unconstitutional.
Krishna Kumar Singh vs State of Bihar (2017): Reaffirmed that placing ordinances before the legislature is mandatory and that re-promulgation is a subversion of the democratic process.
Related_Articles: Article 123 (Power of President to promulgate Ordinances)

Title: High Courts for States
Original_Description: There shall be a High Court for each State.
Simplified_Description: There shall be a High Court for each State. There shall be the High Court
Subject: The States
Key_Points: This article simply mandates that there shall be a High Court for each state.
It establishes the High Court as the highest judicial body within a state.
Historical_Context: The institution of High Courts predates the Constitution, with the first ones established in Calcutta, Bombay, and Madras in 1862. This article constitutionalized the existence of High Courts as a fundamental part of India's judicial structure. Article 231 allows for a common High Court for two or more states.
Landmark_Cases: This is a foundational, declaratory article.
Related_Articles: Article 124 (Establishment and constitution of Supreme Court)
Article 215 (High Courts to be courts of record)
Article 231 (Establishment of a common High Court for two or more States)

Title: High Courts to be courts of record
Original_Description: Every High Court shall be a court of record and shall have all the powers of such a court including the power to punish for contempt of itself.
Simplified_Description: Every High Court shall be a court of record and shall have all the powers of such a court including the power to punish for contempt of itself.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Declares every High Court to be a 'court of record'.
As a court of record, its judgments and proceedings are recorded for perpetual memory and have evidentiary value.
It explicitly gives every High Court the constitutional power to punish for 'contempt of itself' and its subordinate courts.
Historical_Context: This provision grants High Courts the same status and inherent powers as the Supreme Court (under Article 129) within their respective jurisdictions. The power to punish for contempt is essential for maintaining the authority and dignity of the entire judicial system within the state.
Landmark_Cases: The scope and limitations of the contempt power of High Courts have been discussed in numerous cases, balancing judicial authority with freedom of speech.
Related_Articles: Article 129 (Supreme Court to be a court of record)

Title: Constitution of High Courts
Original_Description: Every High Court shall consist of a Chief Justice and such other Judges as the President may from time to time deem it necessary to appoint.
Simplified_Description: Every High Court shall consist of a Chief Justice and such other Judges as the President may from time to time deem it necessary to appoint.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Specifies that every High Court consists of a Chief Justice and other judges.
The President determines the number of 'other judges' from time to time.
This means the strength of a High Court is not fixed by the Constitution and can be changed by the President based on the workload.
Historical_Context: This flexible approach to determining the number of judges allows for adjustments based on the evolving needs of each state's judiciary. The process of appointment and the determination of judge strength have been central to the discussions on judicial reforms.
Landmark_Cases: This is a structural article.
Related_Articles: Article 217 (Appointment and conditions of the office of a Judge of a High Court)

Title: Appointment and conditions of the office of a Judge of a High Court
Simplified_Description: Every Judge of a High Court shall be appointed by the President by warrant under his hand and seal after consultation with the Chief Justice of India, the Governor of the State, and, in the case of appointment of a Judge other than the chief justice, the Chief justice of the High Court. A person shall not be qualified for appointment as a judge unless he is a citizen of India and
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Lays down the procedure for the appointment of High Court judges.
Judges are appointed by the President after consultation with the CJI, the State Governor, and (for other judges) the Chief Justice of the High Court.
The retirement age for a High Court judge is 62 years.
Specifies the qualifications: must be a citizen of India and have at least 10 years of experience as a judicial officer or as an advocate of a High Court.
A High Court judge can be removed only by the same impeachment process as a Supreme Court judge.
Historical_Context: The appointment process for High Court judges has evolved in the same way as for Supreme Court judges, with the 'Collegium System' now having primacy. The 15th Amendment Act, 1963, raised the retirement age of High Court judges from 60 to 62 years.
Landmark_Cases: The 'Three Judges Cases' which established the Collegium system (starting with S.P. Gupta vs UoI) are the most important cases related to the interpretation of the 'consultation' process in this article.

Title: Application of certain provisions relating to Supreme Court to High Courts
Original_Description: The provisions of clauses (4) and (5) of article 124 shall apply in relation to a High Court as they apply in relation to the Supreme Court with the substitution of references to the High Court for references to the Supreme Court.
Simplified_Description: The provisions of clauses (4) and (5) of article 124 shall apply in relation to a High Court as they apply to the Supreme Court. The substitution of references to the High Court for references to Supreme Court will be made.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: This article makes the procedure for the removal of a High Court judge the same as that for a Supreme Court judge.
It applies the provisions of Article 124(4) (impeachment process) and 124(5) (Parliament's power to regulate the investigation) to High Court judges.
Historical_Context: By providing the same difficult and stringent removal process for both Supreme Court and High Court judges, the Constitution ensures a high degree of security of tenure for the higher judiciary, which is a cornerstone of its independence.
Landmark_Cases: The impeachment proceedings against judges like V. Ramaswami and Soumitra Sen were conducted under the framework provided by Article 124(4) as applied through this article.
Related_Articles: Article 124 (Establishment and constitution of Supreme Court)
Article 217 (Appointment and conditions of the office of a Judge of a High Court)

Title: Oath or affirmation by Judges of High Courts
Original_Description: Every person appointed to be a Judge of a High Court shall, before he enters upon his office, make and subscribe before the Governor of the State, or some person appointed in that behalf by him, an oath or affirmation according to the form set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule.
Simplified_Description: Every person appointed to be a Judge of a High Court must make and subscribe before the Governor of the State, or some person appointed in that behalf.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Requires every High Court judge to take an oath or make an affirmation before entering office.
The oath is administered by the Governor of the state or a person appointed by the Governor.
The form of the oath is prescribed in the Third Schedule.
Historical_Context: The oath-taking ceremony is a constitutional formality that binds the judge to uphold the Constitution and perform their duties without fear or favor, affection or ill-will.
Landmark_Cases: This is a mandatory procedural requirement.

Title: Restriction on practice after being a permanent Judge
Original_Description:
No person who, after the commencement of this Constitution, has held office as a permanent Judge of a High Court shall plead or act in any court or before any authority in India except the Supreme Court and the other High Courts.

Explanation — In this article, the expression “High Court” does not include a High Court for a State specified in Part B of the First Schedule as it existed before the commencement of the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956.
Simplified_Description: No person who, after the commencement of this Constitution, has held office as a permanent Judge of a High Court shall plead or act in any court or before any authority in India except the Supreme Court and the other High Courts. In this article, the expression ‘High Court’ does not include a high court for a State specified in Part B of the First Schedule.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Restricts a retired permanent judge of a High Court from practicing law.
They are barred from pleading or acting in any court or before any authority in India.
The only exceptions are the Supreme Court and other High Courts (i.e., they cannot practice in the High Court where they were a judge or in any subordinate courts).
Historical_Context: This restriction is intended to prevent any potential conflict of interest and to maintain the dignity of the high office they have held. It ensures that a retired judge cannot use their past position to unduly influence the courts over which they once presided.
Landmark_Cases: This is a rule of professional conduct for retired judges.
Related_Articles: Article 124(7) (Complete bar on practice for retired Supreme Court Judges)

Title: Salaries, etc, of Judges
Original_Description:
(1) There shall be paid to the Judges of each High Court such salaries as may be determined by Parliament by law and, until provision in that behalf is so made, such salaries as are specified in the Second Schedule.

 

(2) Every Judge shall be entitled to such allowances and to such rights in respect of leave of absence and pension as may from time to time be determined by or under law made by Parliament and, until so determined, to such allowances and rights as are specified in the Second Schedule:

 

   Provided that neither the allowances of a Judge nor his rights in respect of leave of absence or pension shall be varied to his disadvantage after his appointment.
Simplified_Description: Every Judge shall be entitled to such allowances and to such rights in respect of leave of absence and pension as may from time to time be determined by or under law made by Parliament.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to determine the salaries, allowances, leave, and pension of High Court judges.
Provides that these cannot be varied to a judge's disadvantage after their appointment.
The salaries and allowances are charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State, while pensions are charged on the Consolidated Fund of India.
Historical_Context: This provision, like Article 125 for Supreme Court judges, is a crucial safeguard for judicial independence. It protects judges from financial coercion by the executive or legislature. The salaries are determined by Parliament to ensure uniformity across all High Courts.
Landmark_Cases: This is a financial and procedural article ensuring judicial independence.
Related_Articles: Article 125 (Salaries, etc., of Supreme Court Judges)
Article 202(3) (Expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State)

Title: Transfer of a Judge from one High Court to another
Original_Description:
(1) The President may, after consultation with the Chief Justice of India, transfer a Judge from one High Court to any other High Court.

 

(2) When a Judge has been or is so transferred, he shall, during the period he serves, after the commencement of the Constitution (Fifteenth Amendment) Act, 1963, as a Judge of the other High Court, be entitled to receive in addition to his salary such compensatory allowance as may be determined by Parliament by law and, until so determined, such compensatory allowance as the President may by order fix.
Simplified_Description: The President may, after consultation with the Chief Justice of India, transfer a Judge from one High Court to any other High Court. When a Judge has been or is so transferred, he shall be entitled to receive in addition to his salary such compensatory allowance as may be determined by Parliament by law.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Gives the President the power to transfer a judge from one High Court to another.
This power must be exercised after consultation with the Chief Justice of India.
A judge who is transferred is entitled to a compensatory allowance.
Historical_Context: The power to transfer judges was intended to be used for administrative reasons and to promote national integration. However, during the Emergency, it was used punitively to transfer judges who had given rulings against the government. This led to major judicial interventions to create safeguards.
Landmark_Cases: S.P. Gupta vs Union of India (1981): The court held that a judge's consent was not required for transfer, but the transfer should be in the public interest and not punitive.

Supreme Court Advocates-on-Record Association vs Union of India (1993): The court gave primacy to the Chief Justice of India in the transfer process, holding that the CJI's recommendation is determinative. It also laid down that the transfer must be in the public interest and the consent of the judge should be obtained.

Title: Appointment of acting Chief Justice
Original_Description: When the office of Chief Justice of a High Court is vacant or when any such Chief Justice is, by reason of absence or otherwise, unable to perform the duties of his office, the duties of the office shall be performed by such one of the other Judges of the Court as the President may appoint for the purpose.
Simplified_Description: The office of Chief Justice of a High Court is vacant or when any such Chief Justice is, by reason of absence or otherwise, unable to perform the duties of his office. The duties of the office shall be performed by such one of the other Judges of the Court as the President may appoint for the purpose.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Allows the President to appoint an acting Chief Justice of a High Court.
This is done when the office of the Chief Justice is vacant, or when the Chief Justice is temporarily unable to perform their duties.
The President appoints one of the other judges of that High Court for the role.
Historical_Context: This provision ensures leadership continuity in the High Courts. It allows for the seamless continuation of the administrative and judicial functions of the Chief Justice during any temporary or permanent vacancy.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article.
Related_Articles: Article 126 (Appointment of acting Chief Justice of India)

Title: Appointment of additional and acting Judges
Original_Description:
(1) If by reason of any temporary increase in the business of a High Court or by reason of arrears of work therein, it appears to the President that the number of the Judges of that Court should be for the time being increased, the President may appoint duly qualified persons to be additional Judges of the Court for such period not exceeding two years as he may specify.

 

(2) When any Judge of a High Court other than the Chief Justice is by reason of absence or for any other reason unable to perform the duties of his office or is appointed to act temporarily as Chief Justice, the President may appoint a duly qualified person to act as a Judge of that Court until the permanent Judge has resumed his duties.

 

(3) No person appointed as an additional or acting Judge of a High Court shall hold office after attaining the age of sixty-two years.
Simplified_Description: President may appoint duly qualified persons to be additional Judges of the Court for such period not exceeding two years as he may specify. No person appointed as an additional or acting Judge of a High Court shall hold office after attaining the age of 60.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Allows the President to appoint temporary judges to a High Court.
Additional Judges: Appointed for a period not exceeding two years to deal with a temporary increase in work or arrears.
Acting Judges: Appointed when a permanent judge is temporarily unable to perform their duties (e.g., acting as Chief Justice).
No such judge can hold office beyond the retirement age of 62.
Historical_Context: This provision was designed to provide flexibility to High Courts to manage their workload. The appointment of additional judges has become a common practice to deal with the large backlog of cases. Often, additional judges are later made permanent.
Landmark_Cases: The appointment process for additional judges follows the same collegium procedure as for permanent judges.

Title: Appointment of retired Judges at sittings of High Courts
Original_Description:
Notwithstanding anything in this Chapter, the Chief Justice of a High Court for any State may at any time, with the previous consent of the President, request any person who has held the office of a Judge of that Court or of any other High Court to sit and act as a Judge of the High Court for that State, and every such person so requested shall, while so sitting and acting, be entitled to such allowances as the President may by order determine and have all the jurisdiction, powers and privileges of, but shall not otherwise be deemed to be, a Judge of that High Court:

 

Provided that nothing in this article shall be deemed to require any such person as aforesaid to sit and act as a Judge of that High Court unless he consents so to do.
Simplified_Description: Chief Justice of a High Court for any State may at any time, with the previous consent of the President, request any person who has held the office of a Judge of that Court or of any other High Court to sit and act as a Judge.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Allows the Chief Justice of a High Court to request a retired High Court judge to sit and act as a judge of that court.
This requires the previous consent of the President and also the consent of the retired judge.
This is a temporary arrangement to help clear the backlog of cases.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 15th Amendment Act, 1963. Like the similar provision for the Supreme Court (Article 128), it provides a mechanism to utilize the experience of retired judges to tackle the persistent problem of judicial arrears in High Courts.
Landmark_Cases: In Lok Prahari vs Union of India (2021), the Supreme Court activated this 'dormant' provision and issued guidelines for the appointment of ad-hoc judges under Article 224A to tackle the backlog of cases in High Courts.
Related_Articles: Article 128 (Attendance of retired Judges at sittings of the Supreme Court)

Title: Jurisdiction of existing High Courts
Original_Description:
Subject to the provisions of this Constitution and to the provisions of any law of the appropriate Legislature made by virtue of powers conferred on that Legislature by this Constitution, the jurisdiction of, and the law administered in, any existing High Court, and the respective powers of the Judges thereof in relation to the administration of justice in the Court, including any power to make rules of Court and to regulate the sittings of the Court and of members thereof sitting alone or in Division Courts, shall be the same as immediately before the commencement of this Constitution:

 

   Provided that any restriction to which the exercise of original jurisdiction by any of the High Courts with respect to any matter concerning the revenue or concerning any act ordered or done in the collection thereof was subject immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall no longer apply to the exercise of such jurisdiction.
Simplified_Description: The jurisdiction of, and the law administered in, any existing High Court, shall be the same as immediately before the commencement of this Constitution. Any restriction to which the exercise of original jurisdiction by any of the High Courts with respect to any matter concerning the revenue or concerning any act ordered or done in the collection thereof was subject immediately before this Constitution shall no longer apply.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: This is a transitional provision that preserved the jurisdiction and powers of the High Courts that were in existence before the Constitution was enacted.
It states that their jurisdiction would continue as it was before 1950, subject to the provisions of the Constitution and any laws made by the appropriate legislature.
It explicitly removed a pre-constitutional restriction on the High Courts' original jurisdiction in revenue matters.
Historical_Context: This article ensured a smooth transition and legal continuity for the higher judiciary. By continuing the pre-existing jurisdiction, it prevented any legal vacuum. The removal of the restriction on revenue matters was a significant step in expanding judicial review over the executive's financial actions.
Landmark_Cases: This article was mainly relevant in the early years of the Constitution to establish the continuity of the High Courts' powers.
Related_Articles: Article 226 (Power of High Courts to issue certain writs)
Article 372 (Continuance in force of existing laws)

Title: Power of High Courts to issue certain writs
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything in article 32, every High Court shall have power, throughout the territories in relation to which it exercises jurisdiction, to issue to any person or authority, including in appropriate cases, any Government, within those territories directions, orders or writs, including writs in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari, or any of them, for the enforcement of any of the rights conferred by Part III and for any other purpose.

 

(2) The power conferred by clause (1) to issue directions, orders or writs to any Government, authority or person may also be exercised by any High Court exercising jurisdiction in relation to the territories within which the cause of action, wholly or in part, arises for the exercise of such power, notwithstanding that the seat of such Government or authority or the residence of such person is not within those territories.

 

(3) Where any party against whom an interim order, whether by way of injunction or stay or in any other manner, is made on, or in any proceedings relating to, a petition under clause (1), without —

 

(a) furnishing to such party copies of such petition and all documents in support of the plea for such interim order; and

 

(b) giving such party an opportunity of being heard,

 

makes an application to the High Court for the vacation of such order and furnishes a copy of such application to the party in whose favour such order has been made or the counsel of such party, the High Court shall dispose of the application within a period of two weeks from the date on which it is received or from the date on which the copy of such application is so furnished, whichever is later, or where the High Court is closed on the last day of that period, before the expiry of the next day afterwards on which the High Court is open; and if the application is not so disposed of, the interim order shall, on the expiry of that period, or, as the case may be, the expiry of the said next day, stand vacated.

 

(4) The power conferred on a High Court by this article shall not be in derogation of the power conferred on the Supreme Court by clause (2) of article 32.
Simplified_Description: Every High Court shall have power to issue to any person or authority, including in appropriate cases, any Government, within those territories directions, orders or writs, including writs in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Empowers every High Court to issue writs of Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Certiorari, and Quo Warranto.
The writ jurisdiction of the High Court is wider than that of the Supreme Court.
High Courts can issue writs not only for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights but also 'for any other purpose' (i.e., for the enforcement of any other legal right).
The power under this article is considered part of the 'basic structure' of the Constitution and cannot be taken away.
Historical_Context: This article is a cornerstone of judicial review in India and makes the High Courts powerful protectors of the rights of individuals. The broad scope of its jurisdiction ('for any other purpose') makes the High Court the first and often the primary forum for citizens to challenge the arbitrary or illegal actions of the administration.
Landmark_Cases: L. Chandra Kumar vs Union of India (1997): The Supreme Court held that the power of judicial review vested in the High Courts under Article 226 and the Supreme Court under Article 32 is an integral and essential feature of the Constitution, constituting part of its basic structure.
Related_Articles: Article 32 (Remedies for enforcement of rights conferred by this Part - SC's writ jurisdiction)

Title: Power of superintendence over all courts by the High Court
Original_Description:
(1) Every High Court shall have superintendence over all courts and tribunals throughout the territories in relation to which it exercises jurisdiction.

 

(2) Without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing provision, the High Court may —

 

(a) call for returns from such courts;

 

(b) make and issue general rules and prescribe forms for regulating the practice and proceedings of such courts; and 

 

(c) prescribe forms in which books, entries and accounts shall be kept by the officers of any such courts.

 

(3) The High Court may also settle tables of fees to be allowed to the sheriff and all clerks and officers of such courts and to attorneys, advocates and pleaders practising therein:

 

   Provided that any rules made, forms prescribed or tables settled under clause (2) or clause (3) shall not be inconsistent with the provision of any law for the time being in force, and shall require the previous approval of the Governor.

 

(4) Nothing in this article shall be deemed to confer on a High Court powers of superintendence over any court or tribunal constituted by or under any law relating to the Armed Forces.
Simplified_Description: Every High Court shall have superintendence over all courts and tribunals throughout the territories in relation to which it exercises jurisdiction. The High Court may also settle tables of fees to be allowed to the sheriff and all clerks and officers of such courts.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Gives every High Court the power of superintendence over all subordinate courts and tribunals within its territorial jurisdiction.
This power is both administrative and judicial.
It includes calling for returns, making rules for practice, prescribing forms for bookkeeping, and settling fees.
This power does not extend to courts or tribunals constituted for the Armed Forces.
Historical_Context: This article establishes the hierarchical structure of the judiciary within a state, with the High Court at its apex. The power of superintendence is broader than the writ jurisdiction under Article 226 and allows the High Court to ensure that subordinate courts function within the bounds of their authority and in a just manner. It is a power of administrative oversight and judicial control.
Landmark_Cases: L. Chandra Kumar vs Union of India (1997): The court clarified that the power of superintendence under Article 227 is also part of the basic structure of the Constitution.
Related_Articles: Article 226 (Power of High Courts to issue certain writs)

Title: Transfer of certain cases to High Court
Original_Description:
If the High Court is satisfied that a case pending in a court subordinate to it involves a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of this Constitution the determination of which is necessary for the disposal of the case, it shall withdraw the case and may — 

 

(a) either dispose of the case itself, or

 

(b) determine the said question of law and return the case to the court from which the case has been so withdrawn together with a copy of its judgment on such question, and the said court shall on receipt thereof proceed to dispose of the case in conformity with such judgment.
Simplified_Description: The High Court can withdraw a case pending in a court subordinate to it. The High Court may then dispose of the case itself or determine the question of law.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Gives the High Court the power to withdraw a case from any subordinate court.
This can be done if the High Court is satisfied that the case involves a 'substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution'.

After withdrawing the case, the High Court can either dispose of the entire case itself or just decide the constitutional question and return the case to the subordinate court for disposal in line with its judgment.
Historical_Context: This provision ensures that important questions of constitutional interpretation are decided authoritatively by the High Court. It prevents subordinate courts, which may lack the requisite expertise, from giving final judgments on complex constitutional issues and ensures consistency in constitutional law within the state.
Landmark_Cases: This is a jurisdictional article that is used when constitutional questions arise in lower court proceedings.
Related_Articles: Article 139A (Transfer of certain cases to the Supreme Court)

Title: Officers and servants and the expenses of High Courts
Original_Description:
(1) Appointments of officers and servants of a High Court shall be made by the Chief Justice of the Court or such other Judge or officer of the Court as he may direct:

 

   Provided that the Governor of the State may by rule require that in such cases as may be specified in the rule no person not already attached to the Court shall be appointed to any office connected with the Court save after consultation with the State Public Service Commission.

 

(2) Subject to the provisions of any law made by the Legislature of the State, the conditions of service of officers and servants of a High Court shall be such as may be prescribed by rules made by the Chief Justice of the Court or by some other Judge or officer of the Court authorised by the Chief Justice to make rules for the purpose:

 

   Provided that the rules made under this clause shall, so far as they relate to salaries, allowances, leave or pensions, require the approval of the Governor of the State.

 

(3) The administrative expenses of a High Court, including all salaries, allowances and pensions payable to or in respect of the officers and servants of the Court, shall be charged upon the Consolidated Fund of the State, and any fees or other moneys taken by the Court shall form part of that Fund.
Simplified_Description: Appointments of officers and servants of a High Court shall be made by the Chief Justice of the Court. The Governor of the State may by rule require that in such cases as may be specified in the rule no person not already attached to the Court should be appointed.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Vests the power to appoint officers and staff of a High Court in its Chief Justice.
The Chief Justice also determines their conditions of service.
However, rules related to salaries, allowances, leave, or pensions require the approval of the Governor.
The administrative expenses of the High Court are charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State, making them non-votable by the legislature.
Historical_Context: This article is a crucial provision for ensuring the independence of the High Courts. By giving the Chief Justice control over the court's administration and staff, and by making its expenses financially secure from legislative votes, the Constitution insulates the High Court from potential pressure or interference from the state executive and legislature. It mirrors Article 146 for the Supreme Court.
