Landmark_Cases: M. Gurumoorthy vs Accountant-General, Assam & Nagaland (1971): The Supreme Court upheld the power of the Chief Justice in matters of appointment and service conditions of the High Court staff, emphasizing the importance of judicial independence.
Related_Articles: Article 146 (Officers and servants and the expenses of the Supreme Court)
Article 202(3) (Expenditure charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State)

Title: Extension of jurisdiction of High Courts to Union territories
Original_Description:
(1) Parliament may by law extend the jurisdiction of a High Court to, or exclude the jurisdiction of a High Court from, any Union territory.

 

(2) Where the High Court of a State exercises jurisdiction in relation to a Union territory, —

 

(a) nothing in this Constitution shall be construed as empowering the Legislature of the State to increase, restrict or abolish that jurisdiction; and

 

(b) the reference in article 227 to the Governor shall, in relation to any rules, forms or tables for subordinate courts in that territory, be construed as a reference to the President.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may by law extend the jurisdiction of a High Court to, or exclude the jurisdiction from, any Union territory.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to extend the jurisdiction of a High Court to a Union Territory (UT).
Parliament can also exclude a UT from a High Court's jurisdiction.
This allows for judicial administration of UTs by the High Court of a neighboring state.
Historical_Context: This provision, along with Article 231, was shaped by the 7th Amendment Act, 1956 (States Reorganisation). It provides a practical and efficient way to provide judicial oversight for Union Territories, which may not be large enough to have their own High Court. For example, the Bombay High Court has jurisdiction over Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu.
Landmark_Cases: This is a structural and procedural article.
Related_Articles: Article 231 (Establishment of a common High Court for two or more States)

Title: Establishment of a common High Court for two or more States
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything contained in the preceding provisions of this Chapter, Parliament may by law establish a common High Court for two or more States or for two or more States and a Union territory.

 

(2) In relation to any such High Court, —

 

(a) the reference in article 217 to the Governor of the State shall be construed as a reference to the Governors of all the States in relation to which the High Court exercises jurisdiction; 

 

(b) the reference in article 227 to the Governor shall, in relation to any rules, forms or tables for subordinate courts, be construed as a reference to the Governor of the State in which the subordinate courts are situate; and

 

(c) the references in articles 219 and 229 to the State shall be construed as a reference to the State in which the High Court has its principal seat:

 

   Provided that if such principal seat is in a Union territory, the references in articles 219 and 229 to the Governor, Public Service Commission, Legislature and Consolidated Fund of the State shall be construed respectively as references to the President, Union Public Service Commission, Parliament and Consolidated Fund of India.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may by law establish a common High Court for two or more States. The reference in article 217 to the Governor of the State shall be construed as a reference to the Governors of all the States in relation to which the High Court exercises jurisdiction.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to establish a common High Court for two or more states.
A common High Court can also be established for two or more states and a Union Territory.
The article specifies how references to the Governor, Legislature, and Consolidated Fund of the 'State' should be interpreted in such cases.
Historical_Context: Introduced by the 7th Amendment Act, 1956, this article was a result of the state reorganization process. It allows for efficient judicial administration, especially for smaller states in a region. For example, the Punjab and Haryana High Court serves both states and the UT of Chandigarh. The Gauhati High Court serves Assam, Nagaland, Mizoram, and Arunachal Pradesh.
Landmark_Cases: This is a structural and procedural article.
Related_Articles: Article 230 (Extension of jurisdiction of High Courts to Union territories)

Title: Appointment of district judges
Original_Description:
(1) Appointments of persons to be, and the posting and promotion of, district judges in any State shall be made by the Governor of the State in consultation with the High Court exercising jurisdiction in relation to such State.

 

(2) A person not already in the service of the Union or of the State shall only be eligible to be appointed a district judge if he has been for not less than seven years an advocate or a pleader and is recommended by the High Court for appointment.
Simplified_Description: A person not already in the service of the Union or of the State shall only be eligible to be appointed a district judge if he has been for not less than seven years an advocate or a pleader and is recommended by the High Court.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Deals with the appointment, posting, and promotion of district judges.
This power is vested in the Governor of the state.
The Governor must exercise this power in consultation with the High Court of that state.
For direct recruitment, a candidate must have been an advocate or a pleader for at least seven years and must be recommended by the High Court.
Historical_Context: This article is crucial for the independence of the subordinate judiciary. By mandating consultation with the High Court and giving it the power of recommendation, the Constitution seeks to minimize executive interference in judicial appointments at the district level, which is the backbone of the justice delivery system.
Landmark_Cases: Chandra Mohan vs State of UP (1966): The Supreme Court held that the appointment of district judges by the Governor can only be made on the recommendation of the High Court, and 'consultation' here implies a binding recommendation.
Related_Articles: Article 234 (Recruitment of persons other than district judges)

Title: Validation of appointments of, and judgments, etc, delivered by, certain district judges
Original_Description:
Notwithstanding any judgment, decree or order of any court, —

 

(a) (i) no appointment of any person already in the judicial service of a State or of any person who has been for not less than seven years an advocate or a pleader, to be a district judge in that State, and

 

(ii) no posting, promotion or transfer of any such person as a district judge,

 

made at any time before the commencement of the Constitution (Twentieth Amendment) Act, 1966, otherwise than in accordance with the provisions of article 233 or article 235 shall be deemed to be illegal or void or ever to have become illegal or void by reason only of the fact that such appointment, posting, promotion or transfer was not made in accordance with the said provisions;

 

(b) no jurisdiction exercised, no judgment, decree, sentence or order passed or made, and no other act or proceeding done or taken, before the commencement of the Constitution (Twentieth Amendment) Act, 1966 by, or before, any person appointed, posted, promoted or transferred as a district judge in any State otherwise than in accordance with the provisions of article 233 or article 235 shall be deemed to be illegal or invalid or ever to have become illegal or invalid by reason only of the fact that such appointment, posting, promotion or transfer was not made in accordance with the said provisions.
Simplified_Description: No appointment, posting, promotion or transfer of any such person as a district judge, made at any time before the commencement of the Constitution (Twentieth Amendment) Act, 1966, otherwise than in accordance with the provisions of article 233 or article 235.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: This is a validation and savings clause.
It retrospectively validated the appointments of certain district judges that were made prior to 1966 and were not in strict accordance with Articles 233 and 235.
It also validated all judgments, decrees, and orders passed by such judges.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 20th Amendment Act, 1966. It was enacted to overcome a Supreme Court judgment (in Chandra Mohan vs State of UP) which had invalidated the appointment of certain district judges in Uttar Pradesh. To prevent administrative chaos and the invalidation of thousands of judgments, this one-time constitutional fix was introduced.
Landmark_Cases: This article itself was the result of the Chandra Mohan vs State of UP (1966) case.

Title: Recruitment of persons other than district judges to the judicial service
Original_Description: Appointments of persons other than district judges to the judicial service of a State shall be made by the Governor of the State in accordance with rules made by him in that behalf after consultation with the State Public Service Commission and with the High Court exercising jurisdiction in relation to such State.
Simplified_Description: Appointments of persons other than district judges to the judicial service of a State shall be made by the Governor of the State in accordance with rules.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Deals with the appointment of judges to the subordinate judiciary, other than district judges (e.g., civil judges, magistrates).
Appointments are made by the Governor.
The process must be in accordance with rules made by the Governor after consulting two bodies: the State Public Service Commission and the State High Court.
Historical_Context: This article lays down the procedure for entry-level appointments to the judicial service. It involves a three-way process between the Governor (executive), the Public Service Commission (recruiting agency), and the High Court (judicial head). Over time, the role of the High Court in this process has been strengthened to ensure judicial independence.
Landmark_Cases: This article is central to the conduct of state judicial service examinations and appointments.

Title: Control over subordinate courts
Original_Description: The control over district courts and courts subordinate thereto including the posting and promotion of, and the grant of leave to, persons belonging to the judicial service of a State and holding any post inferior to the post of district judge shall be vested in the High Court, but nothing in this article shall be construed as taking away from any such person any right of appeal which he may have under the law regulating the conditions of his service or as authorising the High Court to deal with him otherwise than in accordance with the conditions of his service prescribed under such law.
Simplified_Description: The control over district courts and courts subordinate thereto including the posting and promotion of, and the grant of leave to, persons belonging to the judicial service of a State shall be vested in the High Court.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Vests the 'control' over the subordinate judiciary (district courts and below) exclusively in the High Court.
This control includes matters of posting, promotion, and grant of leave for all judicial officers.
It also covers disciplinary control over judicial officers.
Historical_Context: This is a key article for ensuring the independence of the subordinate judiciary from executive interference. By placing control squarely with the High Court, the Constitution ensures that judicial officers can function without fear of punitive transfers or other adverse actions from the executive for their judicial decisions.
Landmark_Cases: High Court of Judicature for Rajasthan vs Ramesh Chand Paliwal (1998): The Supreme Court provided a wide interpretation of the term 'control', stating it includes general superintendence over the working of subordinate courts and disciplinary control over their officers.
Related_Articles: Article 227 (Power of superintendence over all courts by the High Court)

Title: Interpretation
Simplified_Description: The expression "district judge" includes judge of a city civil court, additional district judge, joint district judge. The expression “judicial service” means a service consisting exclusively of persons intended to fill the post of district judge and other civil judicial posts inferior to the post.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Defines the terms 'district judge' and 'judicial service' for the purposes of this chapter.
The definition of 'district judge' is inclusive, covering a wide range of senior judicial posts like sessions judge, additional district judge, etc.
The 'judicial service' is defined to mean the cadre of district judges and other civil judicial posts subordinate to them.
Historical_Context: This interpretation clause provides clarity and a broad scope to the provisions concerning the subordinate judiciary, ensuring that a wide range of senior judicial posts are covered under the protective umbrella of High Court consultation and control.
Landmark_Cases: This definitional article is used to interpret Articles 233, 234, and 235.

Title: Application of the provisions of this Chapter to certain class or classes of magistrates
Original_Description: The Governor may by public notification direct that the foregoing provisions of this Chapter and any rules made thereunder shall with effect from such date as may be fixed by him in that behalf apply in relation to any class or classes of magistrates in the State as they apply in relation to persons appointed to the judicial service of the State subject to such exceptions and modifications as may be specified in the notification.
Simplified_Description: The Governor may by public notification direct that the foregoing provisions of this Chapter and any rules made thereunder shall with effect from such date as may be fixed by him in that behalf. The rules apply in relation to any class or classes of magistrates in the State.
Subject: The States
Key_Points: Allows the Governor to extend the provisions of this Chapter (governing the subordinate judiciary) to any class of magistrates in the state.
This is done through a public notification.
This enables bringing certain executive magistrates under the control of the High Court, thereby separating their judicial functions from their executive ones.
Historical_Context: This article provides a flexible mechanism to further the goal of separating the judiciary from the executive (as mandated by Article 50). By applying the provisions of judicial appointments and control to magistrates, their judicial independence can be enhanced.
Landmark_Cases: This is an enabling provision to further judicial independence.

Title: Application of provisions of Part VI to States in Part B of the First Schedule
Original_Description: Omitted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956, s. 29and Sch. (w.e.f. 1-11-1956).
Simplified_Description: Omitted by the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956, s. 29and Sch.
Subject: Note: 7th Amendment Act, 1956 repealed Part 7
Key_Points: This article and the entire Part VII of the Constitution have been repealed.
Part VII originally dealt with the administration of 'Part B' States.
Historical_Context: The original Constitution classified states into four categories: Part A (former British provinces), Part B (former princely states or unions of princely states), Part C (centrally administered territories), and Part D. The States Reorganisation Act, 1956, and the 7th Amendment Act, 1956, abolished this classification and established two categories: States and Union Territories. As a result, Part VII and Article 238, which dealt with Part B states, became redundant and were repealed.
Landmark_Cases: Not applicable as the article is repealed.

Title: Administration of Union territories
Original_Description:
(1) Save as otherwise provided by Parliament by law, every Union territory shall be administered by the President acting, to such extent as he thinks fit, through an administrator to be appointed by him with such designation as he may specify.

 

(2) Notwithstanding anything contained in Part VI, the President may appoint the Governor of a State as the administrator of an adjoining Union territory, and where a Governor is so appointed, he shall exercise his functions as such administrator independently of his Council of Ministers.
Simplified_Description: Every Union territory shall be administered by the President acting, to such extent as he thinks fit, through an administrator to be appointed by him with such designation as he may specify.
Subject: The Union Territories
Key_Points: Provides for the administration of Union Territories (UTs).
Every UT is administered by the President of India.
The President acts through an Administrator (who may be designated as Lieutenant Governor, Chief Commissioner, etc.).
The President can appoint the Governor of a neighboring state as the Administrator of a UT.
Historical_Context: This article establishes the direct control of the Union government over the Union Territories. UTs are administered centrally to serve various strategic, cultural, or administrative purposes. This framework was established by the 7th Amendment Act, 1956, which reorganized the states and created the category of Union Territories.
Landmark_Cases: Govt. of NCT of Delhi vs Union of India (2018): Although this case focused on Article 239AA, it extensively discussed the constitutional scheme for the administration of Union Territories in general.
Related_Articles: Article 239AA (Special provisions with respect to Delhi)

Title: Creation of local Legislatures or Council of Ministers or both for certain Union territories
Original_Description:
(1) Parliament may by law create for the Union territory of Puducherry —

 

(a) a body, whether elected or partly nominated and partly elected, to function as a Legislature for the Union territory, or

 

(b) a Council of Ministers,

 

or both with such constitution, powers and functions, in each case, as may be specified in the law.

 

(2) Any such law as is referred to in clause (1) shall not be deemed to be an amendment of this Constitution for the purposes of article 368 notwithstanding that it contains any provision which amends or has the effect of amending this Constitution
Simplified_Description: Parliament may by law create for the Union territory of Puducherry — (a) a body, whether elected or partly nominated and partly elected, to function as a Legislature, or (b) a Council of Ministers.
Subject: The Union Territories
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to create a Legislature and/or a Council of Ministers for the Union Territory of Puducherry.
Parliament can specify the constitution, powers, and functions of these bodies by law.
A law made under this article is not considered a constitutional amendment.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 14th Amendment Act, 1962, after the integration of French territories into India. It provides a flexible framework for granting a measure of self-governance to certain Union Territories without according them full statehood. This model was subsequently applied to Delhi through Article 239AA.
Landmark_Cases: This is an enabling article that provided the basis for the Government of Union Territories Act, 1963.
Related_Articles: Article 239AA (Special provisions with respect to Delhi)

Title: Power of administrator to promulgate Ordinances during recess of Legislature
Original_Description:
(1) If at any time, except when the Legislature of the Union territory of Puducherry is in session, the administrator thereof is satisfied that circumstances exist which render it necessary for him to take immediate action, he may promulgate such Ordinances as the circumstances appear to him to require:

 

   Provided that no such Ordinance shall be promulgated by the administrator except after obtaining instructions from the President in that behalf:

 

   Provided further that whenever the said Legislature is dissolved, or its functioning remains suspended on account of any action taken under any such law as is referred to in clause (1) of article 239A, the administrator shall not promulgate any Ordinance during the period of such dissolution or suspension.

 

(2) An Ordinance promulgated under this article in pursuance of instructions from the President shall be deemed to be an Act of the Legislature of the Union territory which has been duly enacted after complying with the provisions in that behalf contained in any such law as is referred to in clause (1) of article 239A, but every such Ordinance —

 

(a) shall be laid before the Legislature of the Union territory and shall cease to operate at the expiration of six weeks from the reassembly of the Legislature or if, before the expiration of that period, a resolution disapproving it is passed by the Legislature, upon the passing of the resolution; and

 

(b) may be withdrawn at any time by the administrator after obtaining instructions from the President in that behalf.

 

(3) If and so far as an Ordinance under this article makes any provision which would not be valid if enacted in an Act of the Legislature of the Union territory made after complying with the provisions in that behalf contained in any such law as is referred to in clause (1) of article 239A, it shall be void.
Simplified_Description: The administrator of Puducherry may promulgate such Ordinances as the circumstances appear to him to require. No such Ordinance shall be promulgated by the administrator except after obtaining instructions from the President in that behalf.
Subject: The Union Territories
Key_Points: Grants the Administrator of Puducherry the power to issue Ordinances when the legislature is not in session.
This power can only be exercised after obtaining instructions from the President.
The ordinance has the same force as an Act of the UT legislature but is temporary in nature.
This power cannot be used when the legislature is dissolved or suspended.
Historical_Context: This article provides the executive of a Union Territory with a legislature (like Puducherry) with emergency legislative powers, similar to those of a Governor of a state under Article 213. However, the requirement of prior instructions from the President underscores the ultimate control of the Union over the UT.
Landmark_Cases: This article is analogous to Articles 123 and 213, and the principles laid down in cases like D.C. Wadhwa would apply.
Related_Articles: Article 239AA (which applies this provision to Delhi)

Title: Special provisions with respect to Delhi
Original_Description:
(1) As from the date of commencement of the Constitution (Sixty-ninth Amendment) Act, 1991, the Union territory of Delhi shall be called the National Capital Territory of Delhi (hereafter in this Part referred to as the National Capital Territory) and the administrator thereof appointed under article 239 shall be designated as the Lieutenant Governor.

 

(2) (a) There shall be a Legislative Assembly for the National Capital Territory and the seats in such Assembly shall be filled by members chosen by direct election from territorial constituencies in the National Capital Territory.

 

(b) The total number of seats in the Legislative Assembly, the number of seats reserved for Scheduled Castes, the division of the National Capital Territory into territorial constituencies (including the basis for such division) and all other matters relating to the functioning of the Legislative Assembly shall be regulated by law made by Parliament.

 

(c) The provisions of articles 324 to 327 and 329 shall apply in relation to the National Capital Territory, the Legislative Assembly of the National Capital Territory and the members thereof as they apply, in relation to a State, the Legislative Assembly of a State and the members thereof respectively; and any reference in articles 326 and 329 to “appropriate Legislature” shall be deemed to be a reference to Parliament.

 

(3) (a) Subject to the provisions of this Constitution, the Legislative Assembly shall have power to make laws for the whole or any part of the National Capital Territory with respect to any of the matters enumerated in the State List or in the Concurrent List in so far as any such matter is applicable to Union territories except matters with respect to Entries 1, 2 and 18 of the State List and Entries 64, 65 and 66 of that List in so far as they relate to the said Entries 1, 2 and 18.

 

(b) Nothing in sub-clause (a) shall derogate from the powers of Parliament under this Constitution to make laws with respect to any matter for a Union territory or any part thereof.

 

(c) If any provision of a law made by the Legislative Assembly with respect to any matter is repugnant to any provision of a law made by Parliament with respect to that matter, whether passed before or after the law made by the Legislative Assembly, or of an earlier law, other than a law made by the Legislative Assembly, then, in either case, the law made by Parliament, or, as the case may be, such earlier law, shall prevail and the law made by the Legislative Assembly shall, to the extent of the repugnancy, be void:

 

   Provided that if any such law made by the Legislative Assembly has been reserved for the consideration of the President and has received his assent, such law shall prevail in the National Capital Territory:

 

   Provided further that nothing in this sub-clause shall prevent Parliament from enacting at any time any law with respect to the same matter including a law adding to, amending, varying or repealing the law so made by the Legislative Assembly.

 

(4) There shall be a Council of Ministers consisting of not more than ten per cent. of the total number of members in the Legislative Assembly, with the Chief Minister at the head to aid and advise the Lieutenant Governor in the exercise of his functions in relation to matters with respect to which the Legislative Assembly has power to make laws, except in so far as he is, by or under any law, required to act in his discretion:

 

Provided that in the case of difference of opinion between the Lieutenant Governor and his Ministers on any matter, the Lieutenant Governor shall refer it to the President for decision and act according to the decision given thereon by the President and pending such decision it shall be competent for the Lieutenant Governor in any case where the matter, in his opinion, is so urgent that it is necessary for him to take immediate action, to take such action or to give such direction in the matter as he deems necessary.

 

(5) The Chief Minister shall be appointed by the President and other Ministers shall be appointed by the President on the advice of the Chief Minister and the Ministers shall hold office during the pleasure of the President.

 

(6) The Council of Ministers shall be collectively responsible to the Legislative Assembly.

 

(7) (a) Parliament may, by law, make provisions for giving effect to, or supplementing the provisions contained in the foregoing clauses and for all matters incidental or consequential thereto.

 

(b) Any such law as is referred to in sub-clause (a) shall not be deemed to be an amendment of this Constitution for the purposes of article 368 notwithstanding that it contains any provision which amends or has the effect of amending, this Constitution.

 

(8) The provisions of article 239B shall, so far as may be, apply in relation to the National Capital Territory, the Lieutenant Governor and the Legislative Assembly, as they apply in relation to the Union territory of Puducherry, the administrator and its Legislature, respectively; and any reference in that article to “clause (1) of article 239A” shall be deemed to be a reference to this article or article 239AB, as the case may be.
Simplified_Description: The Union territory of Delhi shall be called the National Capital Territory of Delhi. The administrator thereof appointed under article 239 shall be designated as the Lieutenant Governor. The seats in such Assembly shall be filled by members chosen by direct election. The Legislative Assembly has power to make laws for the whole or any part of the National Capital Territory. Nothing in sub-clause (a) shall derogate from the powers of Parliament under this Constitution. There shall be a Council of Ministers consisting of not more than ten per cent. of the total number of members in the Legislative Assembly. Chief Minister at the head to aid and advise the Lieutenant Governor in the exercise of his functions. The Chief Minister shall be appointed by the President and other Ministers shall be appointments by the president on the advice of the Chief Minister. The Ministers shall hold office during the pleasure of the President. Parliament may, by law, make provisions for giving effect to, or supplementing the provisions. The provisions of article 239B shall, so far as may be, apply in relation to the National Capital Territory, the Lieutenant Governor and the Legislative Assembly, as they apply to Puducherry. Any reference in that article to “clause (1) of article239A” shall be deemed to be a reference to this article.
Subject: The Union Territories
Key_Points: Grants special status to Delhi as the National Capital Territory (NCT).
Provides for a Legislative Assembly with powers to legislate on most subjects in the State and Concurrent Lists.
Excludes three subjects from the Assembly's legislative competence: Public Order, Police, and Land.
Establishes the office of the Lieutenant Governor (LG) as the Administrator.
Mandates a Council of Ministers to aid and advise the LG, who is generally bound by such advice.
In case of a difference of opinion between the LG and the ministers, the matter is to be referred to the President.
Historical_Context: Inserted by the 69th Amendment Act, 1991, this article provides a unique sui generis constitutional framework for Delhi, balancing the democratic aspirations of its people with the Union's need to control the national capital. The ambiguous relationship and division of power between the elected government and the centrally-appointed LG has been a source of continuous political and legal conflict.
Landmark_Cases: Govt. of NCT of Delhi vs Union of India (2018): A landmark judgment that held that the LG is bound by the aid and advice of the Council of Ministers on all matters except police, public order, and land. It emphasized that the LG cannot act as an obstructionist and must work harmoniously with the elected government.
Related_Articles: Article 239AB (Provision in case of failure of constitutional machinery)

Title: Provision in case of failure of constitutional machinery
Original_Description:
If the President, on receipt of a report from the Lieutenant Governor or otherwise, is satisfied —

 

(a) that a situation has arisen in which the administration of the National Capital Territory cannot be carried on in accordance with the provisions of article 239AA or of any law made in pursuance of that article; or

 

(b) that for the proper administration of the National Capital Territory it is necessary or expedient so to do,

 

the President may by order suspend the operation of any provision of article 239AA or of all or any of the provisions of any law made in pursuance of that article for such period and subject to such conditions as may be specified in such law and make such incidental and consequential provisions as may appear to him to be necessary or expedient for administering the National Capital Territory in accordance with the provisions of article 239 and article 239AA.
Simplified_Description: President may suspend the operation of any provision of article 239AA or of all or any of the provisions of any law made in pursuance of that article for such period and subject to such conditions as may be specified.
Subject: The Union Territories
Key_Points: This is the equivalent of Article 356 (President's Rule) for the National Capital Territory of Delhi.
If the President is satisfied (on a report from the LG or otherwise) that the administration of the NCT cannot be carried on as per Article 239AA, they can intervene.
The President can by order suspend the provisions of Article 239AA and make alternative arrangements for the administration of the territory.
Historical_Context: This provision gives the Union government the power to take over the administration of Delhi in case of a breakdown of the constitutional machinery, similar to its power over states. It reinforces the ultimate control of the Centre over the National Capital Territory.
Landmark_Cases: The principles laid down by the Supreme Court in S.R. Bommai vs Union of India (1994) regarding the misuse of Article 356 would likely be relevant in any challenge to the imposition of President's rule in Delhi under this article.
Related_Articles: Article 356 (Provisions in case of failure of constitutional machinery in States)
Article 239AA (Special provisions with respect to Delhi)

Title: Power of President to make regulations for certain Union territories
Simplified_Description: The President may make regulations for the peace, progress and good government of the Union territory of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands. The President may repeal or amend any Act made by Parliament.
Subject: The Union Territories
Key_Points: Gives the President the power to make regulations for the 'peace, progress and good government' of certain Union Territories.
These include Andaman & Nicobar Islands, Lakshadweep, Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu, and Puducherry.
A regulation made by the President has the same force as an Act of Parliament.
The President's power to make regulations for Puducherry is suspended when its legislature is functioning.
Historical_Context: This article grants plenary legislative powers to the President for UTs that do not have their own legislative bodies. It allows for direct and swift administration of these territories by the Union executive. For UTs with a legislature like Puducherry, this power is activated only when the legislature is dissolved or suspended.
Landmark_Cases: The President's regulatory power under this article is legislative in nature and is not subject to judicial review on the grounds of non-application of mind in the same way an executive order would be.

Title: High Courts for Union territories
Original_Description:
(1) Parliament may by law constitute a High Court for a Union territory or declare any court in any such territory to be a High Court for all or any of the purposes of this Constitution.

 

(2) The provisions of Chapter V of Part VI shall apply in relation to every High Court referred to in clause (1) as they apply in relation to a High Court referred to in article 214 subject to such modifications or exceptions as Parliament may by law provide.

 

(3) Subject to the provisions of this Constitution and to the provisions of any law of the appropriate Legislature made by virtue of powers conferred on that Legislature by or under this Constitution, every High Court exercising jurisdiction immediately before the commencement of the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956, in relation to any Union territory shall continue to exercise such jurisdiction in relation to that territory after such commencement.

 

(4) Nothing in this article derogates from the power of Parliament to extend or exclude the jurisdiction of a High Court for a State to, or from, any Union territory or part thereof.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may by law constitute a High Court for a Union territory. Parliament may also declare any court in any such territory to be a high court for all or any of the purposes of this Constitution.
Subject: The Union Territories
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to establish a High Court for a Union Territory.
Parliament can also declare any existing court in a UT to be a High Court for the purposes of the Constitution.
This is an alternative to extending the jurisdiction of a state's High Court to a UT (under Article 230).
Historical_Context: This article provides the option for a Union Territory to have its own independent High Court. This power has been used to establish the High Court of Delhi. For other UTs, Parliament has generally extended the jurisdiction of neighboring state High Courts.
Landmark_Cases: This is a structural article related to the judiciary.
Related_Articles: Article 230 (Extension of jurisdiction of High Courts to Union territories)

Title: Definitions
Simplified_Description: “Panchayat” means an institution (by whatever name called) of self-government constituted under article 243B, for the rural areas. “Gram Sabha’ means a body consisting of persons registered in the electoral rolls relating to a village.
Subject: The Panchayats
Key_Points: Provides definitions for terms used in Part IX (The Panchayats).
Defines 'Gram Sabha' as the body of all registered voters in a village, forming the foundation of the Panchayati Raj system.
Defines 'Panchayat' as an institution of self-government for rural areas.
Also defines 'district', 'intermediate level', 'panchayat area', and 'village'.
Historical_Context: This article, and the entire Part IX, was inserted by the 73rd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1992. The definitions are crucial for understanding the structure and functioning of the three-tier Panchayati Raj system that the amendment sought to establish across the country.
Landmark_Cases: These definitions are foundational to all litigation related to Panchayati Raj.
Related_Articles: Article 40 (Directive Principle on organisation of village panchayats)

Title: Gram Sabha
Original_Description: A Gram Sabha may exercise such powers and perform such functions at the village level as the Legislature of a State may, by law, provide.
Simplified_Description: A Gram Sabha may exercise such powers and perform such functions at the village level as the Legislature of a State may, by law, provide.
Subject: The Panchayats
Key_Points: Empowers the Gram Sabha (the village assembly of all voters) to exercise powers and perform functions at the village level.
The specific powers and functions are to be determined by the State Legislature through law.
It represents the concept of direct democracy at the grassroots level.
Historical_Context: The 73rd Amendment institutionalized the Gram Sabha as the cornerstone of the Panchayati Raj system. It is envisioned as the primary body of local accountability, through which the villagers can participate in the planning and implementation of development schemes. The extent of its powers varies from state to state depending on the respective state laws.
Landmark_Cases: The functioning and powers of the Gram Sabha, especially under laws like the Forest Rights Act, have been subject to judicial interpretation.

Title: Constitution of Panchayats
Original_Description:
(1) There shall be constituted in every State, Panchayats at the village, intermediate and district levels in accordance with the provisions of this Part.

 

(2) Notwithstanding anything in clause (1), Panchayats at the intermediate level may not be constituted in a State having a population not exceeding twenty lakhs.
Simplified_Description: Panchayats at the village, intermediate and district levels in accordance with the provisions of this Part. Panchayat may not be constituted in State having a population not exceeding twenty lakhs.
Subject: The Panchayats
Key_Points: Mandates the establishment of a three-tier system of Panchayats in every state: village, intermediate (block/taluk), and district levels.
Provides an exception for smaller states with a population not exceeding 20 lakhs, which may choose not to have the intermediate level.
Historical_Context: This article provides the uniform structural framework for Panchayati Raj across India, as envisioned by the 73rd Amendment. Prior to this, the structure and existence of panchayats were dependent on state laws and varied widely. This provision made the three-tier structure a constitutional requirement.
Landmark_Cases: State of U.P. vs Pradhan Sangh Kshettra Samiti (1995): The Supreme Court upheld the constitutional validity of the 73rd Amendment and the provisions relating to the constitution of Panchayats.

Title: Composition of Panchayats
Original_Description:
(1) Subject to the provisions of this Part, the Legislature of a State may, by law, make provisions with respect to the composition of Panchayats:

 

   Provided that the ratio between the population of the territorial area of a Panchayat at any level and the number of seats in such Panchayat to be filled by election shall, so far as practicable, be the same throughout the State.

 

(2) All the seats in a Panchayat shall be filled by persons chosen by direct election from territorial constituencies in the Panchayat area and, for this purpose, each Panchayat area shall be divided into territorial constituencies in such manner that the ratio between the population of each constituency and the number of seats allotted to it shall, so far as practicable, be the same throughout the Panchayat area.

 

(3) The Legislature of a State may, by law, provide for the representation —

 

(a) of the Chairpersons of the Panchayats at the village level, in the Panchayats at the intermediate level or, in the case of a State not having Panchayats at the intermediate level, in the Panchayats at the district level;

 

(b) of the Chairpersons of the Panchayats at the intermediate level, in the Panchayats at the district level;

 

(c) of the members of the House of the People and the members of the Legislative Assembly of the State representing constituencies which comprise wholly or partly a Panchayat area at a level other than the village level, in such Panchayat;

 

(d) of the members of the Council of States and the members of the Legislative Council of the State, where they are registered as electors within —

(i) a Panchayat area at the intermediate level, in Panchayat at the intermediate level;

 

(ii) a Panchayat area at the district level, in Panchayat at the district level.

 

(4) The Chairperson of a Panchayat and other members of a Panchayat whether or not chosen by direct election from territorial constituencies in the Panchayat area shall have the right to vote in the meetings of the Panchayats.

 

(5) The Chairperson of —

 

(a) a panchayat at the village level shall be elected in such manner as the Legislature of a State may, by law, provide; and

 

(b) a Panchayat at the intermediate level or district level shall be elected by, and from amongst, the elected members thereof.
Simplified_Description: The ratio between the population of the territorial area of a Panchayat at any level and the number of seats to be filled by election shall, so far as practicable, be the same throughout the State. (2) All the seats in a Pachayat shall be filled. by persons chosen by direct election from territorial constituencies. (3) The Legislature of a State may
Subject: The Panchayats
Key_Points: Mandates that all seats in a panchayat at all three levels shall be filled by direct election.
Allows State Legislatures to provide for the representation of Chairpersons of lower-level panchayats in the higher-level panchayats.
Also allows for the representation of MPs and MLAs in the intermediate and district level panchayats.

The Chairperson of a village panchayat is elected in a manner determined by the state legislature, while Chairpersons at the intermediate and district levels are elected from among the directly elected members.
Historical_Context: This article ensures the democratic character of Panchayati Raj institutions by mandating direct elections for membership. It also creates a linkage between the different tiers of local government and between local and state/national legislatures.
Landmark_Cases: The manner of election of chairpersons and the role of MPs/MLAs have been subjects of state-level litigation.

Title: Reservation of seats
Original_Description:
(1) Seats shall be reserved for —

 

(a) the Scheduled Castes; and

 

(b) the Scheduled Tribes,

 

in every Panchayat and the number of seats so reserved shall bear, as nearly as may be, the same proportion to the total number of seats to be filled by direct election in that Panchayat as the population of the Scheduled Castes in that Panchayat area or of the Scheduled Tribes in that Panchayat area bears to the total population of that area and such seats may be allotted by rotation to different constituencies in a Panchayat.

 

(2) Not less than one-third of the total number of seats reserved under clause (1) shall be reserved for women belonging to the Scheduled Castes or, as the case may be, the Scheduled Tribes.

 

(3) Not less than one-third (including the number of seats reserved for women belonging to the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes) of the total number of seats to be filled by direct election in every Panchayat shall be reserved for women and such seats may be allotted by rotation to different constituencies in a Panchayat.

 

(4) The offices of the Chairpersons in the Panchayats at the village or any other level shall be reserved for the Scheduled Castes, the Scheduled Tribes and women in such manner as the Legislature of a State may, by law, provide:

 

   Provided that the number of offices of Chairpersons reserved for the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes in the Panchayats at each level in any State shall bear, as nearly as may be, the same proportion to the total number of such offices in the Panchayats at each level as the population of the Scheduled Castes in the State or of the Scheduled Tribes in the State bears to the total population of the State:

 

   Provided further that not less than one-third of the total number of offices of Chairpersons in the Panchayats at each level shall be reserved for women:

 

   Provided also that the number of offices reserved under this clause shall be allotted by rotation to different Panchayats at each level.

 

(5) The reservation of seats under clauses (1) and (2) and the reservation of offices of Chairpersons (other than the reservation for women) under clause (4) shall cease to have effect on the expiration of the period specified in article 334.

 

(6) Nothing in this Part shall prevent the Legislature of a State from making any provision for reservation of seats in any Panchayat or offices of Chairpersons in the Panchayats at any level in favour of backward class of citizens.
Simplified_Description: Seats in every Panchayat shall be reserved for the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes. Seats so reserved shall bear the same proportion to the total number of seats to be filled by direct election. Not less than one-third of the totalnumber of seats reserved under clause (1) shall be Reserved for women.
Subject: The Panchayats
Key_Points: Mandates the reservation of seats for Scheduled Castes (SCs) and Scheduled Tribes (STs) in every Panchayat, in proportion to their population.
Mandates that not less than one-third of the total number of seats shall be reserved for women.
Provides for the reservation of the offices of Chairpersons for SCs, STs, and women.
Allows state legislatures to make provisions for reservation for Backward Classes (OBCs).
Historical_Context: This is a transformative provision of the 73rd Amendment, aimed at ensuring the political empowerment of marginalized communities and women at the grassroots level. The mandatory one-third reservation for women was a revolutionary step that has significantly increased female participation in local governance.
Landmark_Cases: K. Krishna Murthy (Dr.) vs Union of India (2010): The Supreme Court upheld the constitutional validity of reservations for OBCs in panchayat elections, subject to certain conditions, including the 'triple test' to determine the extent of reservation.
Related_Articles: Article 15 (Prohibition of discrimination and special provisions)

Title: Duration of Panchayats, etc
Original_Description:
(1) Every Panchayat, unless sooner dissolved under any law for the time being in force, shall continue for five years from the date appointed for its first meeting and no longer.

 

(2) No amendment of any law for the time being in force shall have the effect of causing dissolution of a Panchayat at any level, which is functioning immediately before such amendment, till the expiration of its duration specified in clause (1).

 

(3) An election to constitute a Panchayat shall be completed —

 

(a) before the expiry of its duration specified in clause (1);

 

(b) before the expiration of a period of six months from the date of its dissolution:

 

   Provided that where the remainder of the period for which the dissolved Panchayat would have continued is less than six months, it shall not be necessary to hold any election under this clause for constituting the Panchayat for such period.

 

(4) A Panchayat constituted upon the dissolution of a Panchayat before the expiration of its duration shall continue only for the remainder of the period for which the dissolved Panchayat would have continued under clause (1) had it not been so dissolved.
Simplified_Description: Every Panchayat, unless sooner dissolved under any law for the time being in force, shall continue for five years from the date appointed for its first meeting.
Subject: The Panchayats
Key_Points: Provides for a fixed five-year term for every Panchayat.
A Panchayat can be dissolved earlier, but it must be given a reasonable opportunity of being heard.
If a Panchayat is dissolved, a fresh election must be held within six months.
A Panchayat reconstituted after dissolution only serves for the remainder of the original term.
Historical_Context: Before the 73rd Amendment, state governments could dissolve panchayats arbitrarily and postpone elections indefinitely. This article provided security of tenure and mandated timely elections, making panchayats stable and durable institutions of self-government.
Landmark_Cases: The Supreme Court has emphasized the importance of timely elections for local bodies as a constitutional mandate.

Title: Disqualifications for membership
Original_Description:
(1) A person shall be disqualified for being chosen as, and for being, a member of a Panchayat —

 

(a) if he is so disqualified by or under any law for the time being in force for the purposes of elections to the Legislature of the State concerned: Provided that no person shall be disqualified on the ground that he is less than twenty-five years of age, if he has attained the age of twenty-one years;

 

(b) if he is so disqualified by or under any law made by the Legislature of the State.

 

(2) If any question arises as to whether a member of a Panchayat has become subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in clause (1), the question shall be referred for the decision of such authority and in such manner as the Legislature of a State may, by law, provide.
Simplified_Description: A person is disqualified for being chosen as, and for being, a member of a Panchayat if he is so disqualified by or under any law for the time being in force for the purposes of elections to the Legislature of the State concerned.
Subject: The Panchayats
Key_Points: Specifies the grounds for disqualification for membership of a Panchayat.
A person is disqualified if they are disqualified under any law applicable to elections for the State Legislature.
It lowers the minimum age for contesting elections to 21 years (as against 25 for the State Assembly).
State legislatures can prescribe additional grounds for disqualification by law.
Historical_Context: This article links the disqualification criteria for panchayat members to those of state legislators, ensuring a basic standard of eligibility. The reduction of the minimum age to 21 was a deliberate step to encourage youth participation in local governance.
Landmark_Cases: State laws imposing disqualifications like a two-child norm or minimum educational qualifications have been challenged and judged by the courts under this article, for instance, in Javed vs State of Haryana (2003).
Related_Articles: Article 191 (Disqualifications for membership of State Legislature)

Title: Powers, authority and responsibilities of Panchayats
Simplified_Description: The Legislature of a State may, by law, endow the Panchayats with such powers and authority as may be necessary to enable them to function as institutions of self-government. Such law may contain provisions for the devolution of powers and responsibilities.
Subject: The Panchayats
Key_Points: Empowers State Legislatures to endow Panchayats with powers and authority.
The objective is to enable them to function as 'institutions of self-government'.
This includes devolution of powers for preparing plans for economic development and social justice.
It also covers the implementation of schemes, including those related to the 29 matters listed in the Eleventh Schedule.
Historical_Context: This is a crucial article that determines the actual functioning and autonomy of panchayats. While the 73rd Amendment created the structure, it left the devolution of powers, functions, and funds to the discretion of the State Legislatures. The extent of devolution varies significantly from state to state, which is a key challenge in the functioning of Panchayati Raj.
Landmark_Cases: This article is at the heart of debates and advocacy for greater devolution of 'Functions, Funds, and Functionaries' (the 3 Fs) to local governments.
Related_Articles: Eleventh Schedule (Lists 29 functional items for Panchayats)

Title: Powers to impose taxes by, and Funds of, the Panchayats
Simplified_Description: The Legislature of a State may, by law, authorise a Panchayat to levy, collect and appropriate such taxes, duties, tolls and fees.
Subject: The Panchayats
Key_Points: Empowers State Legislatures to authorize Panchayats to levy and collect taxes, duties, tolls, and fees.
Allows the State Government to assign its own collected taxes to Panchayats.
Provides for grants-in-aid to Panchayats from the Consolidated Fund of the State.
This article is the basis for the financial empowerment of Panchayats.
Historical_Context: Financial autonomy is critical for the functioning of self-governing institutions. This article enables State Legislatures to create a financial base for Panchayats, allowing them to raise their own resources and receive funds from the state government. The actual extent of financial devolution is determined by the State Finance Commission's recommendations and the state's own laws.
Landmark_Cases: The implementation of this article's provisions is a key area of focus for strengthening local governance.
Related_Articles: Article 243I (Constitution of Finance Commission to review financial position)

Title: Constitution of Finance Commission to review financial position
Simplified_Description: Governor of a State shall constitute a Finance Commission to review the financial position of the Panchayats. The Commission will make recommendations to the Governor as to the principles which should govern the distribution of the net proceeds of the taxes.
Subject: The Panchayats
Key_Points: Mandates the Governor to constitute a State Finance Commission (SFC) every five years.
The primary function of the SFC is to review the financial position of the Panchayats.
It makes recommendations on the principles for the distribution of taxes between the state and panchayats, the assignment of taxes to panchayats, and grants-in-aid.
The Governor must lay the SFC's report and an action-taken memorandum before the State Legislature.
Historical_Context: This article creates a constitutional mechanism, similar to the Union Finance Commission (Article 280), to ensure a predictable and rule-based transfer of funds from the state government to the panchayats. It is a critical institutional safeguard for the financial viability and autonomy of local bodies.
Landmark_Cases: The timely constitution of SFCs and the implementation of their recommendations have been subjects of judicial scrutiny and public advocacy.

Title: Audit of accounts of Panchayats
Original_Description: The Legislature of a State may, by law, make provisions with respect to the maintenance of accounts by the Panchayats and the auditing of such accounts.
Simplified_Description: The Legislature of a State may, by law, make provisions with respect to the maintenance of accounts by the Panchayats and the auditing of such accounts.
Subject: The Panchayats
Key_Points: Empowers the State Legislature to make laws regarding the maintenance and auditing of Panchayat accounts.
This is essential for financial accountability and transparency in local governance.
Historical_Context: This provision ensures that there is a legal framework for financial oversight of Panchayats. Effective auditing helps in preventing corruption, ensuring proper utilization of funds, and building public trust in local institutions.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article related to financial accountability.
Related_Articles: Article 148-151 (Provisions related to the Comptroller and Auditor-General)

Title: Elections to the Panchayats
Original_Description:
(1) The superintendence, direction and control of the preparation of electoral rolls for, and the conduct of, all elections to the Panchayats shall be vested in a State Election Commission consisting of a State Election Commissioner to be appointed by the Governor.

 

(2) Subject to the provisions of any law made by the Legislature of a State, the conditions of service and tenure of office of the State Election Commissioner shall be such as the Governor may by rule determine:

 

   Provided that the State Election Commissioner shall not be removed from his office except in like manner and on the like grounds as a Judge of a High Court and the conditions of service of the State Election Commissioner shall not be varied to his disadvantage after his appointment.

 

(3) The Governor of a State shall, when so requested by the State Election Commission, make available to the State Election Commission such staff as may be necessary for the discharge of the functions conferred on the State Election Commission by clause (1).

 

(4) Subject to the provisions of this Constitution, the Legislature of a State may, by law, make provision with respect to all matters relating to, or in connection with, elections to the Panchayats.
Simplified_Description: The superintendence, direction and control of the preparation of electoral rolls for, and the conduct of, all elections to the Panchayats shall be vested in a State Election Commission. The conditions of service of the State Election Commissioner shall be such as the Governor may by rule determine.
Subject: The Panchayats
Key_Points: Mandates the creation of an independent State Election Commission (SEC) in every state.
The SEC is responsible for the superintendence, direction, and control of all elections to the Panchayats.
The State Election Commissioner is appointed by the Governor.
Provides for security of tenure: the Commissioner can only be removed in the same manner as a High Court judge.
Historical_Context: This article creates an independent constitutional body to conduct free and fair elections for local bodies, mirroring the role of the Election Commission of India (Article 324) for Parliament and state legislatures. This was a crucial step to ensure that panchayat elections are held regularly and impartially, free from the control of the state government.
Landmark_Cases: Kishan Singh Tomar vs Municipal Corporation of the City of Ahmedabad (2006): The Supreme Court held that the powers of the State Election Commission are akin to the Election Commission of India and that state governments are obligated to cooperate with it to ensure timely elections.

Title: Application to Union territories
Original_Description:
The provisions of this Part shall apply to the Union territories and shall, in their application to a Union territory, have effect as if the references to the Governor of a State were references to the Administrator of the Union territory appointed under article 239 and references to the Legislature or the Legislative Assembly of a State were references, in relation to a Union territory having a Legislative Assembly, to that Legislative Assembly:

 

   Provided that the President may, by public notification, direct that the provisions of this Part shall apply to any Union territory or part thereof subject to such exceptions and modifications as he may specify in the notification.
Simplified_Description: The provisions of this Part shall apply to the Union territories and shall, in their application to a Union territory, have effect as if the references to Governor of a State were references to the Administrator of the Union territory appointed under article 239. Provided that the President may, by public notification, direct that the provisions of this Partshall apply to any Union territory or part thereof.
Subject: The Panchayats
Key_Points: Applies the provisions of Part IX (The Panchayats) to Union Territories.
References to the Governor are to be read as references to the Administrator of the UT.
Gives the President the power to direct that the provisions of this Part shall apply to a UT with certain exceptions and modifications.
Historical_Context: This article extends the Panchayati Raj system to Union Territories, promoting grassroots democracy in these centrally administered areas. It also provides the flexibility for the President to adapt the provisions to the specific administrative context of each UT.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article for applying Part IX to UTs.

Title: Part not to apply to certain areas
Original_Description:
(1) Nothing in this Part shall apply to the Scheduled Areas referred to in clause (1), and the tribal areas referred to in clause (2), of article 244.

 

(2) Nothing in this Part shall apply to —

 

(a) the States of Nagaland, Meghalaya and Mizoram; 

 

(b) the hill areas in the State of Manipur for which District Councils exist under any law for the time being in force.

 

(3) Nothing in this Part —

 

(a) relating to Panchayats at the district level shall apply to the hill areas of the District of Darjeeling in the State of West Bengal for which Darjeeling Gorkha Hill Council exists under any law for the time being in force;

 

(b) shall be construed to affect the functions and powers of the Darjeeling Gorkha Hill Council constituted under such law.

 

(3A) Nothing in article 243D, relating to reservation of seats for the Scheduled Castes, shall apply to the State of Arunachal Pradesh. 

 

(4) Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, —

 

(a) the Legislature of a State referred to in subclause (a) of clause (2) may, by law, extend this part to that State, except the areas, if any, referred to in clause (1), if the Legislative Assembly of that State passes a resolution to that effect by a majority of the total membership of that House and by a majority of not less than two-thirds of the members of that House present and voting;

 

(b) Parliament may, by law, extend the provisions of this Part to the Scheduled Areas and the tribal areas referred to in clause (1) subject to such exceptions and modifications as may be specified in such law, and no such law shall be deemed to be an amendment of this Constitution for the purposes of article 368.
Simplified_Description: Nothing in this Part shall apply to the Scheduled Areas and tribal areas referred to in clause (2), of article 244. Nothing in article 243D, relating to reservation of seats for the. Scheduled Castes, shallapply to the State of Arunachal Pradesh. No such law shall be deemed to be an amendment of this Constitution.
Subject: The Panchayats
Key_Points: Specifies areas where Part IX (The Panchayats) does not automatically apply.
This includes Scheduled Areas and Tribal Areas under Article 244.
It also excludes the states of Nagaland, Meghalaya, and Mizoram, as well as certain hill areas of Manipur and Darjeeling.
Empowers Parliament to extend the provisions of this Part to Scheduled and Tribal areas with modifications.
Historical_Context: This article recognizes that the tribal areas and certain states in the North-East have their own traditional systems of local governance and self-government. A uniform application of the Panchayati Raj system was deemed inappropriate. This led to the enactment of the Panchayats (Extension to Scheduled Areas) Act, 1996 (PESA), which extended Part IX to Scheduled Areas with modifications to recognize the powers of the Gram Sabha and traditional customs.
Landmark_Cases: Cases related to the implementation of the PESA Act fall under the ambit of this article.
Related_Articles: Article 244 (Administration of Scheduled Areas and Tribal Areas)

Title: Continuance of existing laws and Panchayats
Original_Description:
Notwithstanding anything in this Part, any provision of any law relating to Panchayats in force in a State immediately before the commencement of the Constitution (Seventy-third Amendment) Act, 1992, which is inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall continue to be in force until amended or repealed by a competent Legislature or other competent authority or until the expiration of one year from such commencement, whichever is earlier:

 

   Provided that all the Panchayats existing immediately before such commencement shall continue till the expiration of their duration, unless sooner dissolved by a resolution passed to that effect by the Legislative Assembly of that State or, in the case of a State having a Legislative Council, by each House of the Legislature of that State.
Simplified_Description: Any law relating to Panchayats in force in a State immediately before the commencement of the Constitution (Seventy-third Amendment) Act, 1992, shall continue to be in force until amended or repealed.
Subject: The Panchayats
Key_Points: This is a transitional provision.
It provided that all existing state laws on Panchayats that were inconsistent with the new Part IX would continue for a maximum of one year.
States were required to amend their laws to bring them in conformity with the 73rd Amendment within this one-year period.
Existing panchayats were allowed to continue for their full term unless dissolved sooner by the state legislature.
Historical_Context: This article ensured a smooth transition to the new constitutional framework for Panchayati Raj. It gave state governments a one-year window (from April 24, 1993, to April 23, 1994) to pass new Panchayati Raj Acts or amend existing ones to align them with the mandatory provisions of the 73rd Amendment.
Landmark_Cases: This was a transitional article with relevance for a limited period after the 73rd Amendment came into force.
Related_Articles: Article 372 (Continuance in force of existing laws)

Title: Bar to interference by courts in electoral matters
Simplified_Description: No election to any Panchayat shall be called in question except by an election petition presented to such authority and in such manner as is provided for by or under any law made by the Legislature of a State. The validity of any law relating to the delimitation of constituencies or the allotment of seats to such constituencies, made or purporting to be made under article 243K,
Subject: The Panchayats
Key_Points: Places a bar on judicial interference in certain electoral matters related to Panchayats.
The validity of laws related to delimitation of constituencies and allotment of seats cannot be questioned in any court.
An election to a Panchayat can only be challenged through an election petition presented to an authority prescribed by state law.
This bars courts from interfering in the electoral process once it has started.
Historical_Context: This article mirrors the provisions of Article 329 for Parliament and State Legislature elections. It is intended to ensure that electoral processes are conducted smoothly and without interruption. The remedy for any grievance is not to stop the election but to file an election petition after the results are declared.
Landmark_Cases: Kishan Singh Tomar vs Municipal Corporation of the City of Ahmedabad (2006): While interpreting the parallel provision for municipalities, the SC affirmed this principle but also stated that the bar does not prevent High Courts from intervening under Article 226 in extraordinary cases where the election is not being conducted at all.
Related_Articles: Article 329 (Bar to interference by courts in electoral matters)

Title: Definitions
Simplified_Description: “Metropolitan area” means an area having a population of ten lakhs or more. “Population’ means the population as ascertained at the last preceding census of which the relevant figures have been published.
Subject: The Municipalities
Key_Points: Provides definitions for terms used in Part IX-A (The Municipalities).
Defines 'Municipality' as an institution of self-government for urban areas.
Defines 'Metropolitan area' as an area with a population of 10 lakhs or more.
Also defines 'Committee', 'district', 'Municipal area', and 'Panchayat' for the purpose of this part.
Historical_Context: This article, and the entire Part IX-A, was inserted by the 74th Constitutional Amendment Act, 1992. These definitions are essential for understanding the structure and different types of Urban Local Bodies (ULBs) that the amendment established.
Landmark_Cases: These definitions are foundational to all litigation related to urban local governance.

Title: Constitution of Municipalities
Original_Description:
(1) There shall be constituted in every State, —

 

(a) a Nagar Panchayat (by whatever name called) for a transitional area, that is to say, an area in transition from a rural area to an urban area;

 

(b) a Municipal Council for a smaller urban area; and

 

(c) a Municipal Corporation for a larger urban area, in accordance with the provisions of this Part:

 

   Provided that a Municipality under this clause may not be constituted in such urban area or part thereof as the Governor may, having regard to the size of the area and the municipal services being provided or proposed to be provided by an industrial establishment in that area and such other factors as he may deem fit, by public notification, specify to be an industrial township.

 

(2) In this article, “a transitional area”, “a smaller urban area” or “a larger urban area” means such area as the Governor may, having regard to the population of the area, the density of the population therein, the revenue generated for local administration, the percentage of employment in non-agricultural activities, the economic importance or such other factors as he may deem fit, specify by public notification for the purposes of this Part
Simplified_Description: A Nagar Panchayat (by whatever name called) for a transitional area, that is to say, an area in transition from a rural area to an urban area. A Municipal Council for a smaller urban area; and a Municipal Corporation for a larger urban area, in accordance with the provisions of this Part. A Municipality under this clause may not be constituted in such urban
Subject: The Municipalities
Key_Points: Mandates the constitution of a three-tier system of urban local bodies.
A Nagar Panchayat for a transitional area (an area in transition from rural to urban).
A Municipal Council for a smaller urban area.
A Municipal Corporation for a larger urban area.
The Governor specifies these areas based on factors like population, revenue, and economic importance.
Historical_Context: The 74th Amendment brought constitutional uniformity to the structure of urban local governance. Prior to this, the creation and structure of municipalities were entirely at the discretion of state governments. This article made the three-tier structure a constitutional requirement, strengthening urban self-government.
Landmark_Cases: This is a foundational structural article for urban local bodies.

Title: Composition of Municipalities
Simplified_Description: All seats in a Municipality shall be filled by persons chosen by direct election from the territorial constituencies in the Municipal area. For this purpose each Municipal area shall be divided into territorial constituencies to be known as wards.
Subject: The Municipalities
Key_Points: Mandates that all seats in a Municipality shall be filled by direct election.
The municipal area is to be divided into territorial constituencies called 'wards'.
Allows State Legislatures to provide for the representation of persons with special knowledge, MPs, and MLAs in the Municipality (though they may not have the right to vote).
Historical_Context: This article ensures that urban local bodies are democratically elected representative bodies. It establishes the principle of direct election from wards as the basis of municipal governance, ensuring accountability to local citizens.
Landmark_Cases: This is a structural article defining the democratic composition of municipalities.

Title: Constitution and composition of Wards Committees, etc
Original_Description:
(1) There shall be constituted Wards Committees, consisting of one or more wards, within the territorial area of a Municipality having a population of three lakhs or more.

 

(2) The Legislature of a State may, by law, make provision with respect to —

 

(a) the composition and the territorial area of a Wards Committee;

 

(b) the manner in which the seats in a Wards Committee shall be filled.

 

(3) A member of a Municipality representing a ward within the territorial area of the Wards Committee shall be a member of that Committee.

 

(4) Where a Wards Committee consists of —

 

(a) one ward, the member representing that ward in the Municipality; or

 

(b) two or more wards, one of the members representing such wards in the Municipality elected by the members of the Wards Committee, shall be the Chairperson of that Committee.

 

(5) Nothing in this article shall be deemed to prevent the Legislature of a State from making any provision for the constitution of Committees in addition to the Wards Committees.
Simplified_Description: There shall be constituted Wards Committees, consisting of one or more wards, within the territorial area of a Municipality having a population of three lakhs or more. The Legislature of a State may, by law, make provision with respect to — (a) the composition and the territorial areas of a Wards Committee; and (b) the manner in which the seats in a W
Subject: The Municipalities
Key_Points: Mandates the constitution of Wards Committees in all municipalities with a population of three lakhs or more.
A Wards Committee consists of one or more wards.
The State Legislature is empowered to make laws regarding the composition, territorial area, and manner of filling seats in these committees.
Historical_Context: The concept of Wards Committees was introduced by the 74th Amendment to bring governance even closer to the people in larger cities. They are meant to be a sub-municipal structure to deal with local issues at the ward level, enhancing citizen participation and accountability.
Landmark_Cases: The effectiveness and functioning of Wards Committees vary widely across different cities and states.

Title: Reservation of seats
Original_Description:
(1) Seats shall be reserved for the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes in every Municipality and the number of seats so reserved shall bear, as nearly as may be, the same proportion to the total number of seats to be filled by direct election in that Municipality as the population of the Scheduled Castes in the Municipal area or of the Scheduled Tribes in the Municipal area bears to the total population of that area and such seats may be allotted by rotation to different constituencies in a Municipality.

 

(2) Not less than one-third of the total number of seats reserved under clause (1) shall be reserved for women belonging to the Scheduled Castes or, as the case may be, the Scheduled Tribes.

 

(3) Not less than one-third (including the number of seats reserved for women belonging to the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes) of the total number of seats to be filled by direct election in every Municipality shall be reserved for women and such seats may be allotted by rotation to different constituencies in a Municipality.

 

(4) The offices of Chairpersons in the Municipalities shall be reserved for the Scheduled Castes, the Scheduled Tribes and women in such manner as the Legislature of a State may, by law, provide.

 

(5) The reservation of seats under clauses (1) and (2) and the reservation of offices of Chairpersons (other than the reservation for women) under clause (4) shall cease to have effect on the expiration of the period specified in article 334.

 

(6) Nothing in this Part shall prevent the Legislature of a State from making any provision for reservation of seats in any Municipality or offices of Chairpersons in the Municipalities in favour of backward class of citizens.
Simplified_Description: Seats reserved for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes in every Municipality. Not less than one-third of the total number of seats reserved under clause (1) shall be reserved for women. The offices of Chairpersons in the Municipalities shall also be reserved.
Subject: The Municipalities
Key_Points: Mandates reservation of seats for Scheduled Castes (SCs) and Scheduled Tribes (STs) in every Municipality, in proportion to their population.
Mandates that not less than one-third of the total seats must be reserved for women.
Provides for the reservation of the offices of Chairpersons for SCs, STs, and women.
Allows state legislatures to make reservation provisions for Backward Classes (OBCs).
Historical_Context: This article is the urban counterpart to Article 243D for panchayats. It was a landmark provision of the 74th Amendment that constitutionally guaranteed political representation for marginalized groups and women in urban local governance, aiming to make city councils more inclusive and representative.
Landmark_Cases: K. Krishna Murthy (Dr.) vs Union of India (2010): Upheld the constitutionality of reservations for OBCs in municipal elections, subject to the 'triple test' criteria.
Related_Articles: Article 15 (Prohibition of discrimination and special provisions)

Title: Duration of Municipalities, etc
Original_Description:
(1) Every Municipality, unless sooner dissolved under any law for the time being in force, shall continue for five years from the date appointed for its first meeting and no longer:

 

   Provided that a Municipality shall be given a reasonable opportunity of being heard before its dissolution.

 

(2) No amendment of any law for the time being in force shall have the effect of causing dissolution of a Municipality at any level, which is functioning immediately before such amendment, till the expiration of its duration specified in clause (1). 

 

(3) An election to constitute a Municipality shall be completed, —

 

(a) before the expiry of its duration specified in clause (1);

 

(b) before the expiration of a period of six months from the date of its dissolution:
