   Provided that where the remainder of the period for which the dissolved Municipality would have continued is less than six months, it shall not be necessary to hold any election under this clause for constituting the Municipality for such period.

 

(4) A Municipality constituted upon the dissolution of a Municipality before the expiration of its duration shall continue only for the remainder of the period for which the dissolved Municipality would have continued under clause (1) had it not been so dissolved.
Simplified_Description: Every Municipality, unless sooner dissolved under any law for the time being in force, shall continue for five years from the date appointed for its first meeting and no longer. Provided that a Municipality shall be given a reasonable opportunity of being heard before its dissolution.
Subject: The Municipalities
Key_Points: Provides for a fixed five-year term for every Municipality.
A Municipality must be given a reasonable opportunity to be heard before it is dissolved.
If a Municipality is dissolved, fresh elections must be held within six months.
A Municipality reconstituted after a mid-term dissolution will only serve for the remainder of the original five-year period.
Historical_Context: This article provided crucial security of tenure for urban local bodies. Before the 74th Amendment, state governments frequently superseded municipalities for long periods, undermining local democracy. This provision made regular, timely elections a constitutional compulsion.
Landmark_Cases: This article has been instrumental in ensuring the regularity of municipal elections across the country.

Title: Disqualifications for membership
Original_Description:
(1) A person shall be disqualified for being chosen as, and for being, a member of a Municipality —

 

(a) if he is so disqualified by or under any law for the time being in force for the purposes of elections to the Legislature of the State concerned:

 

   Provided that no person shall be disqualified on the ground that he is less than twenty-five years of age, if he has attained the age of twenty-one years;

 

(b) if he is so disqualified by or under any law made by the Legislature of the State.

 

(2) If any question arises as to whether a member of a Municipality has become subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in clause (1), the question shall be referred for the decision of such authority and in such manner as the Legislature of a State may, by law, provide.
Simplified_Description: A person shall be disqualified for being chosen as, and for being, a member of a Municipality. If he is so disqualified by or under any law for the time being in force for the purposes of elections to the Legislature of the State concerned.
Subject: The Municipalities
Key_Points: Specifies the disqualification criteria for membership of a Municipality.
It links the disqualifications to those applicable for elections to the State Legislature.
It sets the minimum age for contesting municipal elections at 21 years.
State legislatures can prescribe additional disqualifications by law.
Historical_Context: Similar to Article 243F for panchayats, this article sets the eligibility standards for candidates in urban local elections, aligning them with state-level norms while also lowering the age barrier to encourage youth participation.
Landmark_Cases: State laws passed under this article, prescribing conditions like a two-child norm or minimum educational qualifications, have been a subject of litigation.
Related_Articles: Article 191 (Disqualifications for membership of State Legislature)

Title: Powers, authority and responsibilities of Municipalities, etc
Simplified_Description: The Legislature of a State may, by law, endow Municipalities with such powers and authority as may be necessary to enable them to function as institutions of self-government. Such law may contain provisions for the devolution of powers and responsibilities upon Municipalities.
Subject: The Municipalities
Key_Points: Empowers State Legislatures to give powers and authority to Municipalities.
The aim is to enable them to function as 'institutions of self-government'.
This includes powers related to preparing plans for economic development and social justice.
It also covers the implementation of schemes related to the 18 matters listed in the Twelfth Schedule.
Historical_Context: This article is the cornerstone for the functional autonomy of urban local bodies. However, like its rural counterpart (Article 243G), it leaves the actual devolution of powers to the discretion of state legislatures. The limited and often reluctant transfer of functions, funds, and functionaries from state governments remains a major challenge for effective urban governance.
Landmark_Cases: This article is central to the ongoing debate about empowering city governments in India.
Related_Articles: Twelfth Schedule (Lists 18 functional items for Municipalities)

Title: Power to impose taxes by, and Funds of, the Municipalities
Simplified_Description: The Legislature of a State may authorise a Municipality to levy, collect and appropriate such taxes, duties, tolls and fees in accordance with such procedure and subject to such limits.
Subject: The Municipalities
Key_Points: Empowers State Legislatures to authorize Municipalities to levy and collect taxes, duties, tolls, and fees (e.g., property tax).
Allows the State Government to assign its own collected taxes to Municipalities.
Provides for grants-in-aid to Municipalities from the Consolidated Fund of the State.
Historical_Context: Financial independence is critical for urban local bodies to deliver civic services. This article provides the constitutional basis for municipalities to raise their own revenue and receive funds from the state. The recommendations of the State Finance Commission are meant to guide this process of financial devolution.
Landmark_Cases: The scope of municipal taxation powers is a frequent subject of litigation.

Title: Finance Commission
Simplified_Description: The Finance Commission constituted under article 243-I shall also review the financial position of the Municipalities. The Governor shall cause every recommendation made by the Commission together with an explanatory memorandum as to the action taken thereon to be laid before the Legislature of the State.
Subject: The Municipalities
Key_Points: Mandates that the State Finance Commission (SFC), constituted under Article 243-I for panchayats, shall also review the financial position of the Municipalities.
The SFC will make recommendations on the distribution of taxes between the state and municipalities, assignment of taxes, and grants-in-aid.
This creates a single, unified body to look at the financial needs of both rural and urban local bodies.
Historical_Context: By tasking the same State Finance Commission with reviewing the finances of both panchayats and municipalities, the Constitution provides for an integrated approach to local government finance. The goal is to ensure a stable and predictable flow of funds to urban local bodies based on objective criteria.
Landmark_Cases: The functioning of SFCs and the implementation of their recommendations are crucial for the financial health of cities.
Related_Articles: Article 243I (Constitution of Finance Commission for Panchayats)

Title: Audit of accounts of Municipalities
Original_Description: The Legislature of a State may, by law, make provisions with respect to the maintenance of accounts by the Municipalities and the auditing of such accounts.
Simplified_Description: The Legislature of a State may, by law, make provisions with respect to the maintenance of accounts by the Municipalities and the auditing of such accounts.
Subject: The Municipalities
Key_Points: Empowers the State Legislature to make laws regarding the maintenance and auditing of the accounts of Municipalities.
This is essential for ensuring financial discipline, transparency, and accountability in urban local governance.
Historical_Context: This provision is the urban counterpart to Article 243J for panchayats. It provides the legal basis for state-level audit mechanisms to oversee the financial operations of municipalities, which handle significant public funds.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article related to financial accountability.

Title: Elections to the Municipalities
Original_Description:
(1) The superintendence, direction and control of the preparation of electoral rolls for, and the conduct of, all elections to the Municipalities shall be vested in the State Election Commission referred to in article 243K.

 

(2) Subject to the provisions of this Constitution, the Legislature of a State may, by law, make provision with respect to all matters relating to, or in connection with, elections to the Municipalities.
Simplified_Description: The superintendence, direction and control of the preparation of electoral rolls for, and the conduct of, all elections to the Municipalities shall be vested in the State Election Commission referred to in article 243K.
Subject: The Municipalities
Key_Points: Vests the responsibility for conducting all elections to Municipalities in the State Election Commission (SEC).
The same SEC constituted under Article 243K for panchayat elections is responsible for municipal elections.
This includes the preparation of electoral rolls and the conduct of elections.
Historical_Context: This article ensures that municipal elections are conducted by an independent constitutional body, free from the control of the state executive. It makes the State Election Commission the single authority for all local body elections in a state, ensuring uniformity and impartiality.
Landmark_Cases: Kishan Singh Tomar vs Municipal Corporation of the City of Ahmedabad (2006): The Supreme Court affirmed the independence of the SEC and the constitutional mandate to hold timely municipal elections.

Title: Application to Union territories
Original_Description:
The provisions of this Part shall apply to the Union territories and shall, in their application to a Union territory, have effect as if the references to the Governor of a State were references to the Administrator of the Union territory appointed under article 239 and references to the Legislature or the Legislative Assembly of a State were references in relation to a Union territory having a Legislative Assembly, to that Legislative Assembly:

 

   Provided that the President may, by public notification, direct that the provisions of this Part shall apply to any Union territory or part thereof subject to such exceptions and modifications as he may specify in the notification.
Simplified_Description: The provisions of this Part shall apply to the Union territories and shall, in their application to a Union territory, have effect as if the references to the Governor of a State were references to an Administrator of the Union territory appointed under article 239. Provided that the President may, by public notification, direct that the provisions of this Partshall apply to any Union territory or part thereof.
Subject: The Municipalities
Key_Points: Applies the provisions of Part IX-A (The Municipalities) to Union Territories.
Gives the President the power to apply these provisions with such exceptions and modifications as necessary for a particular UT.
Historical_Context: This article extends the constitutional framework for urban local self-government to the Union Territories, ensuring that the principles of the 74th Amendment are also implemented in centrally administered urban areas.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article.
Related_Articles: Article 243L (Application of Panchayat provisions to UTs)

Title: Part not to apply to certain areas
Original_Description:
(1) Nothing in this Part shall apply to the Scheduled Areas referred to in clause (1), and the tribal areas referred to in clause (2), of article 244.

 

(2) Nothing in this Part shall be construed to affect the functions and powers of the Darjeeling Gorkha Hill Council constituted under any law for the time being in force for the hill areas of the district of Darjeeling in the State of West Bengal.

 

(3) Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, Parliament may, by law, extend the provisions of this Part to the Scheduled Areas and the tribal areas referred to in clause (1) subject to such exceptions and modifications as may be specified in such law, and no such law shall be deemed to be an amendment of this Constitution for the purposes of article 368.
Simplified_Description: Nothing in this Part shall be construed to affect the functions and powers of the Darjeeling Gorkha Hill Council. Parliament may extend the provisions of this Part to the Scheduled Areas and the tribal areas referred to in clause (1) subject to such exceptions and modifications.
Subject: The Municipalities
Key_Points: Specifies areas where Part IX-A (The Municipalities) does not automatically apply.
This includes Scheduled Areas and Tribal Areas under Article 244, which have their own governance structures.
It also protected the functions and powers of the Darjeeling Gorkha Hill Council.
Parliament is empowered to extend these provisions to Scheduled and Tribal areas with modifications.
Historical_Context: Similar to Article 243M for panchayats, this article acknowledges the special governance arrangements in tribal areas and certain other specified regions. It prevents a uniform model of urban governance from being imposed on areas with distinct administrative and cultural contexts.
Landmark_Cases: The governance structures in these excluded areas are a complex mix of traditional and modern institutions.
Related_Articles: Article 243M (Part not to apply to certain areas - for Panchayats)
Article 244 (Administration of Scheduled Areas and Tribal Areas)

Title: Committee for district planning
Simplified_Description: A State may make provision with respect to the composition of the District Planning Committees. The Chairperson of every District Planning Committee shall forward the development plan, as recommended by such Committee, to the Government of the State.
Subject: The Municipalities
Key_Points: Mandates the constitution of a District Planning Committee (DPC) in every state at the district level.
The DPC's primary function is to consolidate the development plans prepared by both Panchayats and Municipalities within the district.
It prepares a draft development plan for the district as a whole.
Not less than four-fifths of the DPC members must be elected from among the elected members of the district panchayat and municipalities.
Historical_Context: The 74th Amendment introduced the DPC as a critical institution for integrated and decentralized planning. It is designed to bridge the rural-urban divide in planning by creating a single platform where representatives of both panchayats and municipalities can come together to create a holistic development plan for the entire district.
Landmark_Cases: The effective functioning of DPCs remains a challenge in many states, and their role is a key topic in the discourse on decentralized governance.

Title: Committee for Metropolitan planning
Simplified_Description: A State may, by law, make provision with respect to the composition of the Metropolitan Planning Committees. Two-thirds of the members of such Committee shall be elected by, and from amongst, the elected members of the Municipalities and Chairpersons of the Panchayats in the Metropolitan area.
Subject: The Municipalities
Key_Points: Mandates the constitution of a Metropolitan Planning Committee (MPC) in every metropolitan area (population of 10 lakhs or more).
The MPC's function is to prepare a draft development plan for the entire metropolitan area.
It must consolidate plans prepared by the Municipalities and Panchayats within the area.
Not less than two-thirds of the MPC members must be elected from among the elected members of the municipalities and chairpersons of the panchayats in the area.
Historical_Context: The 74th Amendment Act, 1992, introduced the MPC to address the planning challenges of large urban agglomerations that often span multiple municipalities and rural areas. It aims to ensure integrated, region-wide planning for infrastructure, land use, and environmental conservation in major urban centres.
Landmark_Cases: The functioning and empowerment of MPCs are critical issues in urban planning and governance, though they have not been the subject of major Supreme Court litigation.

Title: Continuance of existing laws and Municipalities
Original_Description:
Notwithstanding anything in this Part, any provision of any law relating to Municipalities in force in a State immediately before the commencement of the Constitution (Seventy-fourth Amendment) Act, 1992, which is inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall continue to be in force until amended or repealed by a competent Legislature or other competent authority or until the expiration of one year from such commencement, whichever is earlier:

 

   Provided that all the Municipalities existing immediately before such commencement shall continue till the expiration of their duration, unless sooner dissolved by a resolution passed to that effect by the Legislative Assembly of that State or, in the case of a State having a Legislative Council, by each House of the Legislature of that State.
Simplified_Description: Any law relating to Municipalities in force in a State immediately before the commencement of the Constitution (Seventy-fourth Amendment) Act, 1992, which is inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall continue to be in force.
Subject: The Municipalities
Key_Points: This is a transitional provision related to the 74th Amendment.
It stipulated that all existing state laws on municipalities inconsistent with the new Part IX-A would continue for a maximum of one year.
It required states to amend their municipal laws to conform with the 74th Amendment within one year of its commencement.
Existing municipalities were allowed to complete their term unless dissolved earlier.
Historical_Context: This article provided a one-year grace period (from June 1, 1993, to May 31, 1994) for state governments to align their urban local body legislation with the new constitutional framework, ensuring a smooth transition to the new system of municipal governance.
Landmark_Cases: This was a transitional article with relevance for a limited period after the 74th Amendment came into force.

Title: Bar to interference by courts in electoral matters
Simplified_Description: The validity of any law relating to the delimitation of constituencies or the allotment of seats to such constituencies, made or purporting to be made under article 243ZA shall not be called in question in any court. No election to any Municipality shall be call in question except by an election petition presented to such authority.
Subject: The Municipalities
Key_Points: Bars courts from interfering in certain electoral matters related to municipalities.
The validity of laws on delimitation and seat allotment cannot be challenged in court.
An election to a municipality can only be challenged through an election petition after the election is over.
This prevents judicial intervention during the electoral process.
Historical_Context: Mirroring the provisions for Parliament, State Legislatures, and Panchayats, this article aims to ensure that municipal elections are completed without being hindered by litigation. The proper legal remedy for electoral grievances is an election petition, not a writ petition to stop the process midway.
Landmark_Cases: Kishan Singh Tomar vs Municipal Corporation of the City of Ahmedabad (2006): The Supreme Court clarified that while courts cannot interfere in the election process once started, they can intervene to direct the State Election Commission to conduct elections if they are not being held on time.
Related_Articles: Article 329 (Bar to interference by courts in electoral matters of Parliament/State Legislatures)

Title: Definitions
Simplified_Description: "Board" means the governing body of a co-operative society. "Office bearer" means a President, Vice-President, Chairperson or Vice-Chairperson. "State Act" means any law made by the Legislature of a State.
Subject: Co-operative Societies
Key_Points: Provides definitions for terms used in Part IX-B (The Co-operative Societies).
Defines 'co-operative society', 'board', 'office bearer', 'multi-State co-operative society', and other relevant terms.
Historical_Context: This article, and the entire Part IX-B, was added by the 97th Constitutional Amendment Act, 2011. The amendment was aimed at promoting and professionalizing co-operative societies by giving them a constitutional status and setting out principles for their democratic and autonomous functioning.
Landmark_Cases: Union of India vs Rajendra N. Shah (2021): The Supreme Court struck down certain provisions of Part IX-B, holding that the amendment required ratification by state legislatures as 'co-operative societies' is a State List subject, and this procedure was not followed.
Related_Articles: Article 19(1)(c) (which includes the right to form co-operative societies)
Article 43B (DPSP for promotion of co-operative societies)

Title: Incorporation of co-operative societies
Original_Description: Subject to the provisions of this Part, the Legislature of a State may, by law, make provisions with respect to the incorporation, regulation and winding up of co-operative societies based on the principles of voluntary formation, democratic membercontrol, member-economic participation and autonomous functioning.
Simplified_Description: State may, by law, make provisions with respect to the incorporation, regulation and winding up of co-operative societies.
Subject: Co-operative Societies
Key_Points: Empowers State Legislatures to make laws for the incorporation, regulation, and winding up of co-operative societies.
Mandates that such laws must be based on principles of voluntary formation, democratic member control, member economic participation, and autonomous functioning.
Historical_Context: This provision was introduced by the 97th Amendment to provide a constitutional guideline for state laws governing co-operatives, aiming to free them from excessive government control and promote them as genuine, member-driven democratic enterprises.
Landmark_Cases: The Supreme Court's judgment in Union of India vs Rajendra N. Shah (2021) impacted the applicability of this part on state-level co-operative societies, as the required state ratification was not obtained for the amendment.

Title: Number and term of members of board and its office bearers
Original_Description:
(1) The board shall consist of such number of directors as may be provided by the Legislature of a State, by law:

 

Provided that the maximum number of directors of a co-operative society shall not exceed twenty-one:

 

Provided further that the Legislature of a State shall, by law, provide for the reservation of one seat for the Scheduled Castes or the Scheduled Tribes and two seats for women on board of every co-operative society consisting of individuals as members and having members from such class of category of persons.

 

(2) The term of office of elected members of the board and its office bearers shall be five years from the date of election and the term of office bearers shall be coterminous with the term of the board:Provided that the board may fill a casual vacancy on the board by nomination out of the same class of members in respect of which the casual vacancy has arisen, if the term of office of the board is less than half of its original term.

 

(3) The Legislature of a State shall, by law, make provisions for co-option of persons to be members of the board having experience in the field of banking, management, finance or specialisation in any other field relating to the objects and activities undertaken by the co-operative society, as members of the board of such society:

 

Provided that the number of such co-opted members shall not exceed two in addition to twenty-one directors specified in the first proviso to clause (1):

 

Provided further that such co-opted members shall not have the right to vote in any election of the cooperative society in their capacity as such member or to be eligible to be elected as office bearers of the board:

 

Provided also that the functional directors of a co-operative society shall also be the members of the board and such members shall be excluded for the purpose of counting the total number of directors specified in the first proviso to clause (1).
Simplified_Description: The maximum number of directors of a co-operative society shall not exceed twenty-one. The board may fill a casual vacancy on the board by nomination out of the same class of members in respect of which the casual vacancy has arisen.
Subject: Co-operative Societies
Key_Points: Sets the maximum number of directors on the board of a co-operative society at twenty-one.
Mandates a fixed five-year term for elected members of the board and its office bearers.
Requires state laws to provide for the reservation of one seat for SCs/STs and two seats for women on the board of certain co-operatives.
Historical_Context: Part of the 97th Amendment, this article aimed to bring uniformity and democratic principles to the governance structure of co-operative societies, preventing indefinitely long terms for office bearers and ensuring representation for women and marginalized communities.
Landmark_Cases: This provision was one of the parts of the 97th Amendment that the Supreme Court found to be invalid for want of state ratification in the Union of India vs Rajendra N. Shah (2021) case, in its application to state co-operative societies.

Title: Election of members of board
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything contained in any law made by the Legislature of a State, the election of a board shall be conducted before the expiry of the term of the board so as to ensure that the newly elected members of the board assume office immediately on the expiry of the term of the office of members of the outgoing board.

 

(2) The superintendence, direction and control of the preparation of electoral rolls for, and the conduct of, all elections to a co-operative society shall vest in such an authority or body, as may be provided by the Legislature of a State, by law:

 

Provided that the Legislature of a State may, by law, provide for the procedure and guidelines for the conduct of such elections.
Simplified_Description: The superintendence, direction and control of the preparation of electoral rolls for, and the conduct of, all elections to a co-operative society shall vest in such an authority or body, as may be provided by the Legislature of a State.
Subject: Co-operative Societies
Key_Points: Mandates that elections to the board of a co-operative society must be conducted before the expiry of the current board's term.
Vests the responsibility for conducting these elections in an authority or body as provided by state law.
Historical_Context: A key objective of the 97th Amendment was to ensure regular and timely elections in co-operative societies, which were often plagued by indefinite postponements and the appointment of administrators by the government. This article aimed to secure the democratic functioning of these bodies.
Landmark_Cases: This provision was also affected by the Supreme Court's 2021 judgment on the 97th Amendment.
Related_Articles: Article 243ZJ (Number and term of members of board)

Title: Supersession and suspension of board and interim management
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything contained in any law for the time being in force, no board shall be superseded or kept under supersession for a period exceeding six months:

 

Provided that the board may be superseded or kept under suspension in a case—

 

(i) of its persistent default; or

 

(ii) of negligence in the performance of its duties; or

 

(iii) the board has committed any act prejudicial to the interests of the co-operative society or its members; or

 

(iv) there is stalemate in the constitution or functions of the board; or (v) the authority or body as provided by the Legislature of a State, by law, under clause (2) of article 243ZK, has failed to conduct elections in accordance with the provisions of the State Act:

 

Provided further that the board of any such co-operative society shall not be superseded or kept under suspension where there is no Government shareholding or loan or financial assistance or any guarantee by the Government:

 

Provided also that in case of a co-operative society carrying on the business of banking, the provisions of the Banking Regulation Act, 1949 shall also apply:

 

Provided also that in case of a co-operative society, other than a multi- State co-operative society, carrying on the business of banking, the provisions of this clause shall have the effect as if for the words ―six months‖, the words "one year" had been substituted.

 

(2) In case of supersession of a board, the administrator appointed to manage the affairs of such cooperative society shall arrange for conduct of elections within the period specified in clause (1) and hand over the management to the elected board.

 

(3) The Legislature of a State may, by law, make provisions for the conditions of service of the administrator.
Simplified_Description: No board shall be superseded or kept under supersession for a period exceeding six months. The board of any such co-operative society shall not be superseding or keeping under suspension where there is no Government shareholding or loan.
Subject: Co-operative Societies
Key_Points: Restricts the power of the government to supersede (dissolve) the elected board of a co-operative society.
Supersession is not allowed for a period exceeding six months.
Specifies the grounds on which a board can be superseded, such as persistent default or negligence.
An administrator appointed during supersession must arrange for elections within the six-month period.
Historical_Context: This provision was a direct response to the widespread practice of state governments superseding elected boards of co-operatives for long periods and appointing their own administrators, which undermined their autonomy. The 97th Amendment sought to severely curtail this power.
Landmark_Cases: This was another key provision of Part IX-B that the Supreme Court held would not apply to state co-operative societies due to the lack of ratification.
Related_Articles: Article 243ZJ, 243ZK (dealing with board's term and elections)

Title: Audit of accounts of co-operative societies
Original_Description:
(1) The Legislature of a State may, by law, make provisions with respect to the maintenance of accounts by the co-operative societies and the auditing of such accounts at least once in each financial year. 

 

(2) The Legislature of a State shall, by law, lay down the minimum qualifications and experience of auditors and auditing firms that shall be eligible for auditing accounts of the co-operative societies.

 

(3) Every co-operative society shall cause to be audited by an auditor or auditing firms referred to in clause (2) appointed by the general body of the co-operative society:

 

Provided that such auditors or auditing firms shall be appointed from a panel approved by a State Government or an authority authorised by the State Government in this behalf.

 

(4) The accounts of every co-operative society shall be audited within six months of the close of the financial year to which such accounts relate.

 

(5) The audit report of the accounts of an apex co-operative society, as may be defined by the State Act, shall be laid before the State Legislature in the manner, as may be provided by the State Legislature, by law.
Simplified_Description: The Legislature of a State may, by law, make provisions with respect to the maintenance of accounts by the co-operative societies and the auditing of such accounts at least once in each financial year. The accounts of every co- operative society shall be audited within six months of the close of the financial year to which such accounts relate.
Subject: Co-operative Societies
Key_Points: Requires state laws to provide for the maintenance of accounts by co-operatives and their audit at least once a year.
The audit must be completed within six months of the close of the financial year.
State law is to lay down the minimum qualifications for auditors.
Historical_Context: The 97th Amendment introduced this article to promote financial discipline, transparency, and accountability in the functioning of co-operative societies.
Landmark_Cases: This provision was also affected by the Supreme Court's 2021 judgment on the 97th Amendment.
Related_Articles: Article 243ZP (Returns to be filed by co-operatives)

Title: Convening of general body meetings
Original_Description: The Legislature of a State may, by law, make provisions that the annual general body meeting of every co-operative society shall be convened within a period of six months of close of the financial year to transact the business as may be provided in such law.
Simplified_Description: State law states that every co-operative society must hold an annual general body meeting within six months of the close of the financial year.
Subject: Co-operative Societies
Key_Points: Mandates that state laws should ensure that every co-operative society holds its annual general body meeting.
The meeting must be convened within six months of the close of the financial year.
Historical_Context: This provision was introduced by the 97th Amendment to ensure that the supreme authority of a co-operative, the general body of its members, meets regularly to review its functioning, approve accounts, and hold the elected board accountable.
Landmark_Cases: This provision was also affected by the Supreme Court's 2021 judgment on the 97th Amendment.
Related_Articles: Article 243ZO (Right of a member to get information)

Title: Right of a member to get information
Original_Description:
(1) The Legislature of a State may, by law, provide for access to every member of a co-operative society to the books, information and accounts of the cooperative society kept in regular transaction of its business with such members.

 

(2) The Legislature of a State may, by law, make provisions to ensure the participation of members of the management of the co-operative society providing minimum requirement of attending meetings by the members and utilising the minimum level of services as may be provided in such law.

 

(3) The Legislature of a State may, by law, provide for co-operative education and training for its members.
Simplified_Description: The Legislature of a State may, by law, provide for access to every member of a co-operative society to the books, information and accounts of the cooperative society kept in regular transaction of its business with such members. A State may make provisions to ensure the participation of members of the management.
Subject: Co-operative Societies
Key_Points: Directs state legislatures to make laws to give members of a co-operative society access to its books, accounts, and information.
Also directs states to make provisions for co-operative education and training for members.
Historical_Context: Introduced by the 97th Amendment, this article aims to empower the members of a co-operative society by ensuring their right to information about its functioning. This promotes transparency and strengthens member control over the management.
Landmark_Cases: This provision was also affected by the Supreme Court's 2021 judgment on the 97th Amendment.
Related_Articles: Article 19(1)(a) (Right to freedom of speech and expression, which includes the right to information)

Title: Returns
Simplified_Description: Every co-operative society shall file returns within six months of the close of every financial year to the authority designated by the State Government.
Subject: Co-operative Societies
Key_Points: Mandates every co-operative society to file annual returns within six months of the close of the financial year.
The returns should include an annual report, audited accounts, and other specified information.
The returns are to be filed with an authority designated by the state government.
Historical_Context: This provision of the 97th Amendment aims to ensure regulatory oversight and create a public record of the activities and financial health of co-operative societies, thereby enhancing accountability.
Landmark_Cases: This provision was also affected by the Supreme Court's 2021 judgment on the 97th Amendment.

Title: Offences and Penalties
Simplified_Description: A law made by the Legislature of a State under clause (1) shall include the commission of the following act or omission as offences. (a) a co-operative society or an officer or member thereof wilfully makes a false return or furnishes false information. (b) any person wilfully or without any reasonable excuse disobeys any summons, requisition or lawful written order
Subject: Co-operative Societies
Key_Points: Empowers state legislatures to make laws specifying offences and penalties related to co-operative societies.
Lists certain acts that must be included as offences, such as wilfully making a false return, disobeying summons, and adopting corrupt practices during elections.
Historical_Context: This part of the 97th Amendment provides a framework for state laws to create a deterrent against mismanagement and malpractices in co-operative societies, thereby protecting the interests of the members and the public.
Landmark_Cases: This provision was also affected by the Supreme Court's 2021 judgment on the 97th Amendment.
Related_Articles: This article provides the penal framework for Part IX-B.

Title: Application to multi-State co-operative societies
Original_Description: The provisions of this Part shall apply to the multi-State co-operative societies subject to the modification that any reference to "Legislature of a State", "State Act" or State Government" shall be construed as a reference to "Parliament", "Central Act" or "the Central Government" respectively.
Simplified_Description: The provisions of this Part shall apply to the multi-State co-operative societies subject to the modification that any reference to "Legislature of a State", "State Act" or State Government" shall be construed as "Parliament", "Central Act
Subject: Co-operative Societies
Key_Points: Applies the provisions of Part IX-B to multi-State co-operative societies.
For multi-State co-operatives, references to 'State Legislature' are to be read as 'Parliament', and 'State Government' as 'Central Government'.
Historical_Context: While state-level co-operatives are a state subject, multi-State co-operatives (which operate in more than one state) are a Union subject. The 97th Amendment aimed to reform both. The Supreme Court in 2021, while striking down the part of the amendment concerning state co-operatives, upheld its validity for multi-State co-operative societies.
Landmark_Cases: Union of India vs Rajendra N. Shah (2021): This judgment is directly relevant as it upheld the validity of Part IX-B in relation to multi-State co-operative societies.

Title: Application to Union territories
Original_Description:
The provisions of this Part shall apply to the Union territories and shall, in their application to a Union territory, having no Legislative Assembly as if the references to the Legislature of a State were a reference to the administrator thereof appointed under article 239 and, in relation to a Union territory having a Legislative Assembly, to that Legislative Assembly:

 

Provided that the President may, by notification in the Official Gazette, direct that the provisions of this Part shall not apply to any Union territory or part thereof as he may specify in the notification.
Simplified_Description: The provisions of this Part shall apply to the Union territories and shall, in their application to a Union territory, having no Legislative Assembly as if the references to the Legislature of a State were a reference to the administrator thereof appointed under article 239. Provided that the President may, by notification in the Official Gazette, direct that the provisions ofthis Part shall not apply to any Union territory.
Subject: Co-operative Societies
Key_Points: Applies the provisions of Part IX-B to Union Territories.
Gives the President the power to direct that these provisions shall not apply to a particular UT or part thereof.
Historical_Context: This article extends the constitutional framework for co-operative societies, as introduced by the 97th Amendment, to the Union Territories, while providing flexibility for the President to make exceptions as needed for specific UTs.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article.

Title: Continuance of existing laws
Original_Description: Notwithstanding anything in this Part, any provision of any law relating to co-operative societies in force in a State immediately before the commencement of the Constitution (Ninety-seventh Amendment) Act, 2011, which is inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall continue to be in force until amended or repealed by a competent Legislature or other competent authority or until the expiration of one year from such commencement, whichever is less.
Simplified_Description: Any provision of any law relating to co-operative societies in force in a State immediately before the commencement of the Constitution (Ninety-seventh Amendment) Act, 2011, which is inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall continue to be in force.
Subject: Co-operative Societies
Key_Points: This is a transitional provision for the 97th Amendment.
It provided a one-year window for existing laws on co-operative societies to be brought into conformity with the new constitutional provisions.
Inconsistent laws would cease to have effect after one year from the commencement of the amendment.
Historical_Context: Similar to the transitional provisions for Panchayats and Municipalities, this article was intended to ensure a smooth transition by giving state legislatures time to amend their existing co-operative laws to align with the new constitutional mandate of Part IX-B.
Landmark_Cases: This article was relevant for the one-year period following the commencement of the 97th Amendment in 2012.

Title: Administration of Scheduled Areas and Tribal Areas
Original_Description:
(1) The provisions of the Fifth Schedule shall apply to the administration and control of the Scheduled Areas and Scheduled Tribes in any State other than the States of Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura and Mizoram.

 

(2) The provisions of the Sixth Schedule shall apply to the administration of the tribal areas in the States of Assam Meghalaya, Tripura and Mizoram.
Simplified_Description: The provisions of the Fifth Schedule shall apply to the administration and control of the Scheduled Areas and Scheduled Tribes in any State other than the States of Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura and Mizoram.
Subject: Scheduled and Tribal Areas
Key_Points: Provides for a special system of administration for certain designated 'Scheduled Areas' and 'Tribal Areas'.
Applies the provisions of the Fifth Schedule to Scheduled Areas in various states across India (except four northeastern states).
Applies the provisions of the Sixth Schedule to the Tribal Areas in the states of Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram.
This creates two different schemes for the administration of tribal areas.
Historical_Context: The framers recognized the need to protect the distinct culture, customs, and land rights of the tribal population from exploitation. This article, along with the Fifth and Sixth Schedules, creates a protective legal and administrative framework. The Sixth Schedule provides for a higher degree of autonomy through the creation of Autonomous District Councils.
Landmark_Cases: Samatha vs State of Andhra Pradesh (1997): A landmark judgment that interpreted the Fifth Schedule to protect tribal lands from being transferred to non-tribals for private mining operations.
Related_Articles: Article 243M, 243ZC (Exclusion of these areas from Part IX and IX-A)

Title: Formation of an autonomous State comprising certain tribal areas in Assam and creation of local Legislature or Council of Ministers or both therefor
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, Parliament may, by law, form within the State of Assam an autonomous State (comprising whether wholly or in part) all or any of the tribal areas specified in Part I of the table appended to paragraph 20 of the Sixth Schedule and create therefor —

 

(a) a body, whether elected or partly nominated and partly elected, to function as a Legislature for the autonomous State, or

 

(b) a Council of Ministers,

 

or both with such constitution, powers and functions, in each case, as may be specified in the law.

 

(2) Any such law as is referred to in clause (1) may, in particular, —

 

(a) specify the matters enumerated in the State List or the Concurrent List with respect to which the Legislature of the autonomous State shall have power to make laws for the whole or any part thereof, whether to the exclusion of the Legislature of the State of Assam or otherwise;

 

(b) define the matters with respect to which the executive power of the autonomous State shall extend;

 

(c) provide that any tax levied by the State of Assam shall be assigned to the autonomous State in so far as the proceeds thereof are attributable to the autonomous State;

 

(d) provide that any reference to a State in any article of this Constitution shall be construed as including a reference to the autonomous State; and

 

(e) make such supplemental, incidental and consequential provisions as may be deemed necessary.

 

(3) An amendment of any such law as aforesaid in so far as such amendment relates to any of the matters specified in sub-clause (a) or sub-clause (b) of clause (2) shall have no effect unless the amendment is passed in each House of Parliament by not less than two-thirds of the members present and voting.

 

(4) Any such law as is referred to in this article shall not be deemed to be an amendment of this Constitution for the purposes of article 368 notwithstanding that it contains any provision which amends or has the effect of amending this Constitution.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may, by law, form within the State of Assam an autonomous State (comprising whether wholly or in part) all or any of the tribal areas specified in Part I of the table.
Subject: Scheduled and Tribal Areas
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to create an 'autonomous state' within the State of Assam.
This autonomous state can comprise some or all of the tribal areas specified in the Sixth Schedule.
Parliament can create a local Legislature or a Council of Ministers, or both, for such an autonomous state.
This is a special provision applicable only to Assam.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 22nd Amendment Act, 1969. It was a response to the political aspirations of the tribal communities in the hill areas of Assam. The provision was used to create the autonomous state of Meghalaya in 1970, which was later granted full statehood in 1972. It provides a constitutional mechanism for granting a higher degree of autonomy than available under the Sixth Schedule.
Landmark_Cases: This is a special power-conferring article that has been used in the past for state formation in the North-East.
Related_Articles: Article 244 (Administration of Scheduled Areas and Tribal Areas)

Title: Extent of laws made by Parliament and by the Legislatures of States
Original_Description:
(1) Subject to the provisions of this Constitution, Parliament may make laws for the whole or any part of the territory of India, and the Legislature of a State may make laws for the whole or any part of the State.

 

(2) No law made by Parliament shall be deemed to be invalid on the ground that it would have extra-territorial operation.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may make laws for the whole or any part of the territory of India. No law made by Parliament shall be deemed to be invalid on the ground that it would have extra-territorial operation.
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: Defines the territorial limits of the legislative powers of Parliament and State Legislatures.
Parliament can legislate for the entire territory of India or any part of it.
A State Legislature can legislate for the whole state or any part of it.
Laws made by Parliament can have extra-territorial application (apply to Indian citizens and their property anywhere in the world).
State laws generally cannot have extra-territorial operation, unless there is a sufficient 'nexus' or connection between the state and the subject of the law.
Historical_Context: This is the first article of Part XI, which deals with Union-State relations. It establishes the foundational principle of legislative jurisdiction based on territory, a fundamental aspect of a federal structure.
Landmark_Cases: Wallace Bros. & Co. Ltd. vs Commissioner of Income Tax (1948): The Privy Council, in a pre-constitution case, established the doctrine of 'territorial nexus', which holds that a state can legislate on an extra-territorial object if there is a sufficient connection between the state and that object.

Title: Subject-matter of laws made by Parliament and by the Legislatures of States
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything in clauses (2) and (3), Parliament has exclusive power to make laws with respect to any of the matters enumerated in List I in the Seventh Schedule (in this Constitution referred to as the “Union List”).

 

(2) Notwithstanding anything in clause (3), Parliament, and, subject to clause (1), the Legislature of any State also, have power to make laws with respect to any of the matters enumerated in List III in the Seventh Schedule (in this Constitution referred to as the “Concurrent List”).

 

(3) Subject to clauses (1) and (2), the Legislature of any State has exclusive power to make laws for such State or any part thereof with respect to any of the matters enumerated in List II in the Seventh Schedule (in this Constitution referred to as the “State List”).

 

(4) Parliament has power to make laws with respect to any matter for any part of the territory of India not included in a State notwithstanding that such matter is a matter enumerated in the State List.
Simplified_Description: Parliament has exclusive power to make laws with respect to any of the matters enumerated in List I in the Seventh Schedule (in this Constitution referred to as the “Union List”).
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: Distributes legislative power between the Union and the States based on subject matter.
It establishes the three lists of the Seventh Schedule:
List I (Union List): Parliament has exclusive power (e.g., Defence, Foreign Affairs, Currency).
List II (State List): State Legislatures have exclusive power (e.g., Public Order, Police, Health).
List III (Concurrent List): Both Parliament and State Legislatures can make laws (e.g., Education, Forests, Criminal Law).
Historical_Context: This article is the bedrock of India's legislative federalism. The detailed three-fold distribution of subjects, adopted from the Government of India Act, 1935, is a unique feature designed to minimize jurisdictional conflicts. In case of any conflict between the lists, the Union List prevails over the Concurrent and State Lists, and the Concurrent List prevails over the State List.
Landmark_Cases: State of Bombay vs F.N. Balsara (1951): The Supreme Court applied the 'Doctrine of Pith and Substance' to determine the true nature of a law when it seems to transgress into the other legislature's domain.
Gujarat University vs Krishna Ranganath Mudholkar (1963): Dealt with conflicts between Union and State laws on the subject of education.

Title: Special provision with respect to goods and services tax
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything contained in articles 246 and 254, Parliament, and, subject to clause (2), the Legislature of every State, have power to make laws with respect to goods and services tax imposed by the Union or by such State.

(2) Parliament has exclusive power to make laws with respect to goods and services tax where the supply of goods, or of services, or both takes place in the course of inter-State trade or commerce.

Explanation.—The provisions of this article, shall, in respect of goods and services tax referred to in clause (5) of article 279A, take effect from the date recommended by the Goods and Services Tax Council.]
Simplified_Description: Parliament has exclusive power to make laws with respect to goods and services tax where the supply of goods, or of services, or both takes place in the course of inter-State trade or commerce.
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: Gives concurrent power to both Parliament and State Legislatures to make laws on Goods and Services Tax (GST).
Gives Parliament the exclusive power to make laws on GST for inter-state trade and commerce (IGST).
This article overrides the traditional separation of powers in Articles 246 and 254 for the purpose of GST.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 101st Constitutional Amendment Act, 2016, which introduced the GST regime. GST replaced a multitude of indirect taxes levied by the Centre and states. Article 246A created a unique concurrent power for both levels of government to legislate on this single tax, a fundamental shift in Indian fiscal federalism.
Landmark_Cases: Union of India vs Mohit Minerals Pvt. Ltd. (2022): The Supreme Court held that the recommendations of the GST Council are not binding on the Union and State legislatures, emphasizing the importance of cooperative federalism.
Related_Articles: Article 269A (Levy and collection of GST in course of inter-State trade)

Title: Power of Parliament to provide for the establishment of certain additional courts
Original_Description: Notwithstanding anything in this Chapter, Parliament may by law provide for the establishment of any additional courts for the better administration of laws made by Parliament or of any existing laws with respect to a matter enumerated in the Union List.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may by law provide for the establishment of any additional courts for the better administration of laws made by Parliament.
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to establish additional courts.
The purpose of these courts is the better administration of laws made by Parliament or laws related to subjects in the Union List.
Historical_Context: This article provides the constitutional basis for Parliament to create specialized courts or tribunals to deal with matters falling under its legislative competence. This allows for the creation of expert judicial bodies to handle specific areas of law, supplementing the work of the regular judiciary.
Landmark_Cases: This is a power-conferring article.

Title: Residuary powers of legislation
Original_Description:
(1) Parliament has exclusive power to make any law with respect to any matter not enumerated in the Concurrent List or State List.

 

(2) Such power shall include the power of making any law imposing a tax not mentioned in either of those Lists.
Simplified_Description: Parliament has exclusive power to make any law with respect to any matter not enumerated in the Concurrent List or State List. Such power shall include the power of making any law imposing a tax.
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: Vests the 'residuary powers' of legislation exclusively with the Parliament.
This means that if a subject matter is not mentioned in any of the three lists (Union, State, or Concurrent), only Parliament has the power to make a law on it.
This includes the power to impose a tax not mentioned in any list.
Historical_Context: This provision reflects the strong-centre bias of the Indian federation. Unlike other federations like the USA, where residuary powers are with the states, the Indian Constitution allocates them to the Union. This ensures that the central legislature has the authority to legislate on any new subject that may emerge in the future.
Landmark_Cases: Union of India vs H.S. Dhillon (1972): The Supreme Court upheld Parliament's power to enact the wealth tax on agricultural land by relying on its residuary powers under this article.

Title: Power of Parliament to legislate with respect to a matter in the State List in the national interest
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything in the foregoing provisions of this Chapter, if the Council of States has declared by resolution supported by not less than twothirds of the members present and voting that it is necessary or expedient in the national interest that Parliament should make laws with respect to any matter enumerated in the State List specified in the resolution, it shall be lawful for Parliament to make laws for the whole or any part of the territory of India with respect to that matter while the resolution remains in force.

 

(2) A resolution passed under clause (1) shall remain in force for such period not exceeding one year as may be specified therein:

 

   Provided that, if and so often as a resolution approving the continuance in force of any such resolution is passed in the manner provided in clause (1), such resolution shall continue in force for a further period of one year from the date on which under this clause it would otherwise have ceased to be in force.

 

(3) A law made by Parliament which Parliament would not but for the passing of a resolution under clause (1) have been competent to make shall, to the extent of the incompetency, cease to have effect on the expiration of a period of six months after the resolution has ceased to be in force, except as respects things done or omitted to be done before the expiration of the said period.
Simplified_Description: A resolution passed under clause (1) shall remain in force for such period not exceeding one year as may be specified therein. If and so often as a resolution approving the continuance in force of any such resolution is passed, such resolution shall continue in force. A law made by Parliament which Parliament would not but for the passing of a resolution under clause(1) have been competent to
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: Allows Parliament to make laws on a subject in the State List.
This can only be done if the Rajya Sabha passes a resolution declaring it necessary in the 'national interest'.
The resolution must be supported by a special majority of two-thirds of the members present and voting.
Such a resolution is valid for one year at a time but can be renewed.
The law made by Parliament ceases to have effect six months after the resolution expires.
Historical_Context: This is a significant provision that allows the Union to encroach upon the legislative domain of the states under specific circumstances. The requirement of a resolution by the Rajya Sabha (the Council of States) is a key federal safeguard, as it signifies the consent of the representatives of the states themselves for this temporary centralization of power.
Landmark_Cases: This is a power-conferring article that highlights the flexible nature of Indian federalism.
Related_Articles: Article 250 (Parliament's power to legislate on State List during emergency)

Title: Power of Parliament to legislate with respect to any matter in the State List if a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything in this Chapter, Parliament shall, while a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation, have power to make laws for the whole or any part of the territory of India with respect to any of the matters enumerated in the State List.

 

(2) A law made by Parliament which Parliament would not but for the issue of a Proclamation of Emergency have been competent to make shall, to the extent of the incompetency, cease to have effect on the expiration of a period of six months after the Proclamation has ceased to operate, except as respects things done or omitted to be done before the expiration of the said period.
Simplified_Description: While a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation, Parliament has power to make laws for the whole or any part of the territory of India.
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to legislate on any subject in the State List during a National Emergency (under Article 352).
This power extends to the whole of India or any part of it.
The laws made under this provision become inoperative six months after the emergency has ceased to operate.
Historical_Context: This provision transforms the Indian federal system into a unitary one during a national emergency. It allows the central government to assume supreme legislative power to deal with the crisis, overriding the normal distribution of powers between the Union and the States.
Landmark_Cases: This is a key emergency provision.

Title: Inconsistency between laws made by Parliament under articles 249 and 250 and laws made by the Legislatures of States
Original_Description: Nothing in articles 249 and 250 shall restrict the power of the Legislature of a State to make any law which under this Constitution it has power to make, but if any provision of a law made by the Legislature of a State is repugnant to any provision of a law made by Parliament which Parliament has under either of the said articles power to make, the law made by Parliament, whether passed before or after the law made by the Legislature of the State, shall prevail, and the law made by the Legislature of the State shall to the extent of the repugnancy, but so long only as the law made by Parliament continues to have effect, be inoperative.
Simplified_Description: Nothing in articles 249 and 250 shall restrict the power of the Legislature of a State to make any law which under this Constitution it has power to make. If any provision of a law made by a State is repugnant to any provision made by Parliament, that law will prevail. Law made by Legislature of the State shall to the extent of the repugnancy, be inoperative
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: Deals with inconsistency between a law made by Parliament (under Art 249 or 250) and a law made by a State Legislature on the same State List subject.
It clarifies that the law made by Parliament will prevail.
The state law is not completely void but becomes 'inoperative' to the extent of its repugnancy, for as long as the parliamentary law is in force.
Historical_Context: This article establishes a clear rule of precedence for the temporary and extraordinary situations covered by Articles 249 and 250. It reinforces the supremacy of Parliament's law when it is legislating on a state subject in the national interest or during an emergency.
Landmark_Cases: This is a rule of interpretation to resolve legislative conflicts.
Related_Articles: Article 249 (Parliament's power on state list in national interest)
Article 250 (Parliament's power on state list during emergency)

Title: Power of Parliament to legislate for two or more States by consent and adoption of such legislation by
Original_Description:
(1) If it appears to the Legislatures of two or more States to be desirable that any of the matters with respect to which Parliament has no power to make laws for the States except as provided in articles 249 and 250 should be regulated in such States by Parliament by law, and if resolutions to that effect are passed by all the Houses of the Legislatures of those States, it shall be lawful for Parliament to pass an Act for regulating that matter accordingly, and any Act so passed shall apply to such States and to any other State by which it is adopted afterwards by resolution passed in that behalf by the House or, where there are two Houses, by each of the Houses of the Legislature of that State.

 

(2) Any Act so passed by Parliament may be amended or repealed by an Act of Parliament passed or adopted in like manner but shall not, as respects any State to which it applies, be amended or repealed by an Act of the Legislature of that State.
Simplified_Description: Parliament has no power to make laws for the States except as provided in articles 249 and 250. If it appears to the Legislatures of two or more States to be desirable, it shall be lawful for Parliament to pass an Act for regulating that matter.
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: Allows Parliament to make a law on a State List subject if two or more states pass resolutions requesting it.
Such a law will apply only to the states that made the request.
Other states can adopt the same law later by passing a similar resolution.
Only Parliament can amend or repeal such a law, not the state legislatures.
Historical_Context: This is a mechanism for achieving uniformity in legislation on state subjects when desired by the states themselves, without having to amend the Constitution. It is a feature of cooperative federalism. Several laws have been passed under this provision, such as the Prize Competition Act, 1955, and the Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972.
Landmark_Cases: This is a power-conferring article.

Title: Legislation for giving effect to international agreements
Original_Description: Notwithstanding anything in the foregoing provisions of this Chapter, Parliament has power to make any law for the whole or any part of the territory of India for implementing any treaty, agreement or convention with any other country or countries or any decision made at any international conference, association or other body
Simplified_Description: Parliament has power to make any law for the whole or any part of the territory of India for implementing any treaty, agreement or convention.
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: Gives Parliament the power to make laws on any subject (including those in the State List) to implement international treaties, agreements, or conventions.
This power overrides the normal distribution of legislative powers between the Union and the States.
It enables the central government to fulfill its international obligations.
Historical_Context: In international law, the national government is responsible for fulfilling the country's treaty obligations. This article ensures that the Indian Parliament has the necessary legislative power to do so, even if the subject matter of the treaty falls within the legislative domain of the states. This provision has been used to enact laws on subjects like environment (e.g., Environment Protection Act, 1986) and intellectual property.
Landmark_Cases: The enactment of laws to comply with WTO obligations and various international environmental conventions relies on the power derived from this article.
Related_Articles: Article 51 (Promotion of international peace and security)

Title: Inconsistency between laws made by Parliament and laws made by the Legislatures of States
Original_Description:
(1) If any provision of a law made by the Legislature of a State is repugnant to any provision of a law made by Parliament which Parliament is competent to enact, or to any provision of an existing law with respect to one of the matters enumerated in the Concurrent List, then, subject to the provisions of clause (2), the law made by Parliament, whether passed before or after the law made by the Legislature of such State, or, as the case may be, the existing law, shall prevail and the law made by the Legislature of the State shall, to the extent of the repugnancy, be void.

 

(2) Where a law made by the Legislature of a State with respect to one of the matters enumerated in the Concurrent List contains any provision repugnant to the provisions of an earlier law made by Parliament or an existing law with respect to that matter, then, the law so made by the Legislature of such State shall, if it has been reserved for the consideration of the President and has received his assent, prevail in that State:

 

   Provided that nothing in this clause shall prevent Parliament from enacting at any time any law with respect to the same matter including a law adding to, amending, varying or repealing the law so made by the Legislature of the State.
Simplified_Description: If a law made by the Legislature of a State contains any provision repugnant to the provisions of an earlier law, then the law so made by such State shall prevail in that State. Nothing in this clause shall prevent Parliament from enacting at any time any law with respect to the same matter.
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: Establishes the 'Doctrine of Repugnancy' for laws on the Concurrent List.
If a state law conflicts with a central law on a concurrent subject, the central law prevails.
The state law, to the extent of the conflict (repugnancy), becomes void.

Exception: If the state law was reserved for and has received the President's assent, it will prevail in that state. However, Parliament can still override this state law by enacting a later law on the same subject.
Historical_Context: This article provides a clear rule to resolve conflicts that are bound to arise in the Concurrent List, where both levels of government have legislative competence. It establishes the ultimate supremacy of Parliament in the concurrent field, a key unitary feature of the Indian Constitution.
Landmark_Cases: M. Karunanidhi vs Union of India (1979): The Supreme Court laid down the conditions for when a state law can be considered 'repugnant' to a central law.
Zaverbhai Amaidas vs State of Bombay (1954): Dealt with the issue of implied repeal and repugnancy in the concurrent field.

Title: Requirements as to recommendations and previous sanctions to be regarded as matters of procedure only
Simplified_Description: No Act of Parliament or of the Legislature of a State shall be invalid by reason only that some recommendation or previous sanction required by this Constitution was not given, if assent to that Act was given.
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: This is a 'curing' provision.
It states that a law will not be considered invalid merely because the required prior recommendation or sanction (from the President or Governor) was not obtained.
This is valid only if the bill subsequently receives the assent of that very authority (President or Governor).
It treats the lack of prior sanction as a procedural irregularity that can be cured by subsequent assent.
Historical_Context: This article is designed to prevent laws from being struck down on purely technical or procedural grounds, especially when the authority whose prior sanction was needed has ultimately given their assent to the final Act. It prioritizes the substance of the legislative act over a procedural lapse.
Landmark_Cases: This procedural article is sometimes invoked to save legislation from being invalidated on technical grounds.
Related_Articles: Article 304 (Bills restricting trade requiring prior sanction)

Title: Obligation of States and the Union
Original_Description: The executive power of every State shall be so exercised as to ensure compliance with the laws made by Parliament and any existing laws which apply in that State, and the executive power of the Union shall extend to the giving of such directions to a State as may appear to the Government of India to be necessary for that purpose.
Simplified_Description: The executive power of every State shall be so exercised as to ensure compliance with the laws made by Parliament and any existing laws which apply in that State. Executive power of the Union shall extend to the giving of such directions to a State as may appear to be necessary for that purpose.
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: Imposes an obligation on every state government to exercise its executive power in a way that ensures compliance with laws made by Parliament.
Empowers the Union executive to give directions to a state government as necessary to ensure such compliance.
This establishes the supremacy of Union laws in the executive sphere.
Historical_Context: This article provides the constitutional basis for the Union's administrative control over the states. It ensures that state governments, which are responsible for implementing most laws (including central laws), do so effectively. Failure to comply with such directions can have serious consequences, potentially leading to the imposition of President's Rule under Article 365.
Landmark_Cases: The scope of this power and its implications for federalism were extensively discussed in S.R. Bommai vs Union of India (1994).
Related_Articles: Article 257 (Control of the Union over States in certain cases)
Article 365 (Effect of failure to comply with directions given by the Union)

Title: Control of the Union over States in certain cases
Original_Description:
(1) The executive power of every State shall be so exercised as not to impede or prejudice the exercise of the executive power of the Union, and the executive power of the Union shall extend to the giving of such directions to a State as may appear to the Government of India to be necessary for that purpose.

 

(2) The executive power of the Union shall also extend to the giving of directions to a State as to the construction and maintenance of means of communication declared in the direction to be of national or military importance:

 

   Provided that nothing in this clause shall be taken as restricting the power of Parliament to declare highways or waterways to be national highways or national waterways or the power of the Union with respect to the highways or waterways so declared or the power of the Union to construct and maintain means of communication as part of its functions with respect to naval, military and air force works.

 

(3) The executive power of the Union shall also extend to the giving of directions to a State as to the measures to be taken for the protection of the railways within the State.

 

(4) Where in carrying out any direction given to a State under clause (2) as to the construction or maintenance of any means of communication or under clause (3) as to the measures to be taken for the protection of any railway, costs have been incurred in excess of those which would have been incurred in the discharge of the normal duties of the State if such direction had not been given, there shall be paid by the Government of India to the State such sum as may be agreed, or, in default of agreement, as may be determined by an arbitrator appointed by the Chief Justice of India, in respect of the extra costs so incurred by the State.
Simplified_Description: Executive power of every State shall be so exercised as not to impede or prejudice the exercise of the executive power of the Union. Power of Union to give directions to a State as to the construction and maintenance of means of communication of national or military importance.
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: Obligates state governments not to impede or prejudice the executive power of the Union.
Empowers the Union executive to give directions to states in specific matters:
Construction and maintenance of communications of national or military importance.
Measures for the protection of railways within the state.
The Union is required to pay for the extra costs incurred by the state in carrying out these directions.
Historical_Context: This article further elaborates on the administrative control of the Union over the states. It is aimed at ensuring that national interests, particularly in strategic areas like communications and railways, are not hampered by the actions or inactions of state governments.
Landmark_Cases: This article defines specific areas of Union's administrative control over states.
Related_Articles: Article 256 (Obligation of States and the Union)
Article 365 (Effect of failure to comply with directions)

Title: Power of the Union to confer powers, etc, on States in certain cases
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, the President may, with the consent of the Government of a State, entrust either conditionally or unconditionally to that Government or to its officers functions in relation to any matter to which the executive power of the Union extends.

 

(2) A law made by Parliament which applies in any State may, notwithstanding that it relates to a matter with respect to which the Legislature of the State has no power to make laws, confer powers and impose duties, or authorise the conferring of powers and the imposition of duties, upon the State or officers and authorities thereof.

 

(3) Where by virtue of this article powers and duties have been conferred or imposed upon a State or officers or authorities thereof, there shall be paid by the Government of India to the State such sum as may be agreed, or, in default of agreement, as may be determined by an arbitrator appointed by the Chief Justice of India, in respect of any extra costs of administration incurred by the State in connection with the exercise of those powers and duties.
Simplified_Description: The President may entrust either conditionally or unconditionally to that Government or to its officers functions in relation to any matter to which the executive power of the Union extends.
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: Allows for the delegation of the Union's executive functions to a state government.
Delegation by President: The President can entrust Union functions to a state government, but only with the consent of that state government.
Delegation by Parliament: A law made by Parliament can confer powers and impose duties on a state government or its officers, even without the state's consent.
When functions are delegated, the Union must pay the state for any extra costs of administration.
Historical_Context: This article facilitates cooperative federalism and administrative efficiency. It allows the central government to use the administrative machinery of the states to implement its own functions, which is often more practical and effective. It provides for both consensual and statutory delegation of powers.
Landmark_Cases: This article provides the framework for administrative delegation between the Union and states.
Related_Articles: Article 258A (Power of the States to entrust functions to the Union)

Title: Power of the States to entrust functions to the Union
Original_Description: Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, the Governor of a State may, with the consent of the Government of India, entrust either conditionally or unconditionally to that Government or to its officers functions in relation to any matter to which the executive power of the State extends.
Simplified_Description: The Governor of a State may entrust either conditionally or unconditionally to that Government or to its officers functions in relation to any matter to which the executive power of the State extends.
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: Allows a state government to delegate its executive functions to the Union government.
This can only be done with the consent of the Government of India.
The delegation is done by the Governor.
