This is the reverse of the delegation provided for in Article 258.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 7th Amendment Act, 1956. It creates a reciprocal arrangement for the delegation of functions, allowing states to entrust their executive powers to the Centre when it is administratively convenient or necessary. This further promotes inter-governmental cooperation.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article facilitating cooperative federalism.
Related_Articles: Article 258 (Power of the Union to confer powers on States)

Title: Jurisdiction of the Union in relation to territories outside India
Original_Description: The Government of India may by agreement with the Government of any territory not being part of the territory of India undertake any executive, legislative or judicial functions vested in the Government of such territory, but every such agreement shall be subject to, and governed by, any law relating to the exercise of foreign jurisdiction for the time being in force.
Simplified_Description: The Government of India may by agreement with the Government of any territory not being part of the territory of India undertake any executive, legislative or judicial functions. Every such agreement shall be subject to, and governed by, any law relating to the exercise of foreign jurisdiction.
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: Empowers the Government of India to undertake executive, legislative, or judicial functions of a foreign territory.
This can only be done through an agreement with the government of that territory.
Any such exercise of power is governed by laws related to foreign jurisdiction.
Historical_Context: This article was designed to provide a legal framework for India to administer territories outside its borders by agreement, possibly in a protectorate or trust capacity. It is based on the British Foreign Jurisdiction Act and has not been significantly used in practice.
Landmark_Cases: This is an enabling provision related to foreign relations.

Title: Public acts, records and judicial proceedings
Original_Description:
(1) Full faith and credit shall be given throughout the territory of India to public acts, records and judicial proceedings of the Union and of every State.

 

(2) The manner in which and the conditions under which the acts, records and proceedings referred to in clause (1) shall be proved and the effect thereof determined shall be as provided by law made by Parliament.

 

(3) Final judgments or orders delivered or passed by civil courts in any part of the territory of India shall be capable of execution anywhere within that territory according to law.
Simplified_Description: Full faith and credit shall be given throughout the territory of India to public acts, records and judicial proceedings of the Union and of every State. Final judgments or orders delivered or passed by civil courts in any part of India shall be capable of execution anywhere within that territory.
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: This is the 'Full Faith and Credit' clause of the Constitution.
It mandates that public acts (like laws), records, and judicial proceedings of the Centre and every state must be given full faith and credit throughout India.
Final judgments of civil courts in any part of India are executable anywhere else in the country.
Parliament can make laws to prescribe the manner in which these acts and records are to be proved and their effect determined.
Historical_Context: This provision is crucial for the unity and integrity of the nation's legal and administrative framework. It ensures that a person does not have to re-litigate a civil case in another state and that the official acts and records of one state are respected in another, facilitating inter-state commerce and movement.
Landmark_Cases: This principle is fundamental to the execution of decrees and the recognition of official documents across state borders.
Related_Articles: This article promotes judicial and administrative unity across states.

Title: Adjudication of disputes relating to waters of interState rivers or river valleys
Original_Description:
(1) Parliament may by law provide for the adjudication of any dispute or complaint with respect to the use, distribution or control of the waters of, or in, any inter-State river or river valley.

 

(2) Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, Parliament may by law provide that neither the Supreme Court nor any other court shall exercise jurisdiction in respect of any such dispute or complaint as is referred to in clause (1).
Simplified_Description: Parliament may by law provide for the adjudication of any dispute or complaint with respect to the use, distribution or control of the waters of, or in, any inter-State river or river valley.
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to create a mechanism for adjudicating inter-state river water disputes.
Allows Parliament to exclude the jurisdiction of all courts, including the Supreme Court, over such disputes.
This power is an exception to the Supreme Court's original jurisdiction under Article 131.
Historical_Context: The framers recognized that inter-state river water disputes are highly technical and politically sensitive, and may not be suitable for regular court proceedings. This article allows for the creation of specialized expert tribunals. Under this article, Parliament has enacted the Inter-State Water Disputes Act, 1956, and several tribunals (e.g., for Cauvery, Narmada, Krishna rivers) have been constituted.
Landmark_Cases: State of Karnataka vs Union of India & Anr (2017) (Cauvery Dispute): The Supreme Court clarified that while it cannot act as a tribunal itself, its power of judicial review under Article 136 to hear appeals from the tribunal's award is not completely ousted. It can intervene to ensure the tribunal acts within the law.
Related_Articles: Article 131 (Original jurisdiction of the Supreme Court)

Title: Provisions with respect to an inter-State Council
Original_Description:
If at any time it appears to the President that the public interests would be served by the establishment of a Council charged with the duty of —

 

(a) inquiring into and advising upon disputes which may have arisen between States;

 

(b) investigating and discussing subjects in which some or all of the States, or the Union and one or more of the States, have a common interest; or

 

(c) making recommendations upon any such subject and, in particular, recommendations for the better co-ordination of policy and action with respect to that subject, it shall be lawful for the President by order to establish such a Council, and to define the nature of the duties to be performed by it and its organisation and procedure.
Simplified_Description: The Council is charged with the duty of inquiring into and advising upon disputes which may have arisen between States. If at any time it appears to the President that the public interests would be served by the establishment of a Council it shall be lawful for the President to establish such a Council.
Subject: Relation between Union & States
Key_Points: Empowers the President to establish an Inter-State Council.
The Council's role is to inquire into and advise upon disputes between states, investigate subjects of common interest, and make recommendations for better policy coordination.
The Council is an advisory body to promote cooperative federalism.
Historical_Context: Although the provision existed since the inception of the Constitution, the Inter-State Council was established for the first time only in 1990 on the recommendation of the Sarkaria Commission on Centre-State Relations. It is a forum for dialogue and discussion between the Centre and the states, headed by the Prime Minister.
Landmark_Cases: This article provides the constitutional basis for a key institution of cooperative federalism.

Title: Interpretation
Original_Description: In this Part, “Finance Commission” means a Finance Commission constituted under article 280.
Simplified_Description: "Finance Commission" means a Finance Commission constituted under article 280. In this Part, “
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: This is a definitional article for Part XII.
It clarifies that any reference to the 'Finance Commission' in this Part refers to the one constituted under Article 280.
Historical_Context: This article serves as an introductory definition for Part XII, which deals with the complex financial relations between the Union and the States, a core aspect of fiscal federalism.
Landmark_Cases: This is a purely definitional article.

Title: Taxes not to be imposed save by authority of law
Original_Description: No tax shall be levied or collected except by authority of law.
Simplified_Description: No tax shall be levied or collected except by authority of law. No tax should be levied
Subject: Finance, Property,Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Establishes a fundamental principle of the rule of law in fiscal matters.
No tax can be levied or collected without the authority of a validly enacted law.
This means the executive cannot impose taxes on its own; it requires the sanction of the legislature (Parliament or a State Legislature).
Historical_Context: This article is a bulwark against arbitrary taxation, a principle derived from the English Magna Carta ('no taxation without representation'). While it is not a Fundamental Right, it is a crucial constitutional right that protects citizens and businesses from arbitrary financial demands by the government.
Landmark_Cases: This principle is the foundation of all tax law and litigation in India. Any tax imposed through a government notification or rule without a clear legislative backing can be challenged under this article.

Title: Consolidated Funds and public accounts of India and of the States
Original_Description:
(1) Subject to the provisions of article 267 and to the provisions of this Chapter with respect to the assignment of the whole or part of the net proceeds of certain taxes and duties to States, all revenues received by the Government of India, all loans raised by that Government by the issue of treasury bills, loans or ways and means advances and all moneys received by that Government in repayment of loans shall form one consolidated fund to be entitled “the Consolidated Fund of India”, and all revenues received by the Government of a State, all loans raised by that Government by the issue of treasury bills, loans or ways and means advances and all moneys received by that Government in repayment of loans shall form one consolidated fund to be entitled “the Consolidated Fund of the State”.

 

(2) All other public moneys received by or on behalf of the Government of India or the Government of a State shall be credited to the public account of India or the public account of the State, as the case may be.

 

(3) No moneys out of the Consolidated Fund of India or the Consolidated Fund of a State shall be appropriated except in accordance with law and for the purposes and in the manner provided in this Constitution.
Simplified_Description: All revenues received by the Government of India, all loans raised by that Government by the issue of treasury bills, loans or ways and means advances and all moneys received by that government in repayment of loans shall form one consolidated fund to be entitled “the Consolidated Fund of India” All other public moneyys received. by or on behalf of the Government or the
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Creates the Consolidated Fund of India and the Consolidated Fund of each State.
All government revenues (like taxes) and loans are credited to this fund.
No money can be withdrawn from this fund except through an 'appropriation made by law' (i.e., after passing the Appropriation Bill in the legislature).
Also creates the Public Account of India and of each State, where other public moneys (like provident fund deposits, small savings) are held.
Withdrawals from the Public Account do not require parliamentary appropriation.
Historical_Context: This article establishes the primary accounts for all government transactions and reinforces legislative control over public money. The distinction between the Consolidated Fund and the Public Account is crucial; the government acts as a banker for money in the Public Account and must repay it, whereas money in the Consolidated Fund is government revenue.
Landmark_Cases: This is a fundamental article governing public finance.

Title: Contingency Fund
Original_Description:
(1) Parliament may by law establish a Contingency Fund in the nature of an imprest to be entitled “the Contingency Fund of India” into which shall be paid from time to time such sums as may be determined by such law, and the said Fund shall be placed at the disposal of the President to enable advances to be made by him out of such Fund for the purposes of meeting unforeseen expenditure pending authorisation of such expenditure by Parliament by law under article 115 or article 116.

 

(2) The Legislature of a State may by law establish a Contingency Fund in the nature of an imprest to be entitled “the Contingency Fund of the State” into which shall be paid from time to time such sums as may be determined by such law, and the said Fund shall be placed at the disposal of the Governor of the State to enable advances to be made by him out of such Fund for the purposes of meeting unforeseen expenditure pending authorisation of such expenditure by the Legislature of the State by law under article 205 or article 206.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may by law establish a Contingency Fund in the nature of an imprest to be entitled “the Contingencies Fund of India” into which shall be paid from time to time such sums as may be determined by such law. The said Fund shall be placed at the disposal of the President to enable advances to be made by him out of such Fund for the
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Allows Parliament to establish a Contingency Fund of India, which is placed at the disposal of the President.
Similarly, allows State Legislatures to establish a Contingency Fund of the State, placed at the disposal of the Governor.
This fund is used to meet unforeseen or urgent expenditure.
Any expenditure from this fund must subsequently be approved by the legislature, and the amount withdrawn must be returned to the fund.
Historical_Context: The Contingency Fund acts as an imprest account for the executive to deal with emergencies and natural disasters when the legislature is not in session to approve the expenditure. It provides the necessary financial flexibility for urgent situations while ensuring eventual legislative oversight.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article related to public finance.

Title: Duties levied by the Union but collected and appropriated by the States
Original_Description:
(1) Such stamp duties and such duties of excise on medicinal and toilet preparations as are mentioned in the Union List shall be levied by the Government of India but shall be collected,—

 

(a) in the case where such duties are leviable within any Union territory, by the Government of India, and

 

(b) in other cases, by the States within which such duties are respectively leviable.

 

(2) The proceeds in any financial year of any such duty leviable within any State shall not form part of the Consolidated Fund of India, but shall be assigned to that State.
Simplified_Description: Stamp duties and such duties of excise on medicinal and toilet preparations as are mentioned in the Union List shall be levied by the Government of India.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Deals with taxes that are levied by the Union but collected and kept by the states.
Examples include stamp duties on bills of exchange, cheques, etc., and excise duties on medicinal and toilet preparations mentioned in the Union List.
The revenue from these duties goes directly to the state where they are collected and does not form part of the Consolidated Fund of India.
Historical_Context: This article is part of the scheme of distribution of financial resources between the Centre and the states. It assigns certain revenue sources to the states for their administrative convenience, even though the power to legislate and fix the rate of the tax lies with the Centre. Note: The relevance of this article has changed significantly after the introduction of GST.
Landmark_Cases: This is a fiscal federalism article.

Title: Service tax levied by Union and collected and appropriated by the Union and the States
Original_Description:
(1) Taxes on services shall be levied by the Government of India and such tax shall be collected and appropriated by the Government of India and the States in the manner provided in clause (2).

 

(2) The proceeds in any financial year of any such tax levied in accordance with the provisions of clause (1) shall be —

 

(a) collected by the Government of India and the States;

 

(b) appropriated by the Government of India and the States,

 

in accordance with such principles of collection and appropriation as may be formulated by Parliament by law.
Simplified_Description: Taxes on services shall be levied by the Government of India. Such tax shall be collected and appropriated by the government of India and the States.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: This article, which dealt with Service Tax, has been repealed.
It provided for service tax to be levied by the Union and collected and appropriated by both the Union and the States.
Service tax has been subsumed into the Goods and Services Tax (GST).
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 88th Amendment Act, 2003, to provide a constitutional basis for the levy of tax on services. It remained inoperative for a long time. With the introduction of GST, which covers both goods and services, this article became redundant and was repealed by the 101st Amendment Act, 2016.
Landmark_Cases: Not applicable as the article is repealed.

Title: Taxes levied and collected by the Union but assigned to the States
Original_Description:
(1) Taxes on the sale or purchase of goods and taxes on the consignment of goods shall be levied and collected by the Government of India but shall be assigned and shall be deemed to have been assigned to the States on or after the 1st day of April, 1996 in the manner provided in clause (2).

 

Explanation. — For the purposes of this clause, —

 

(a) the expression “taxes on the sale or purchase of goods” shall mean taxes on sale or purchase of goods other than newspapers, where such sale or purchase takes place in the course of inter-State trade or commerce;

 

(b) the expression “taxes on the consignment of goods” shall mean taxes on the consignment of goods (whether the consignment is to the person making it or to any other person), where such consignment takes place in the course of inter-State trade or commerce.

 

(2) The net proceeds in any financial year of any such tax, except in so far as those proceeds represent proceeds attributable to Union territories, shall not form part of the Consolidated Fund of India, but shall be assigned to the States within which that tax is leviable in that year, and shall be distributed among those States in accordance with such principles of distribution as may be formulated by Parliament by law. 

 

(3) Parliament may by law formulate principles for determining when a sale or purchase of, or consignment of, goods] takes place in the course of inter-State trade or commerce.
Simplified_Description: Taxes on the sale or purchase of goods and taxes on the consignment of goods shall be levied and collected by the Government of India. The net proceeds in any financial year of any such tax shall not form part of the Consolidated Fund of India, but shall be assigned to the States.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Deals with taxes that are levied and collected by the Union, but the entire proceeds are assigned to the states.
Originally, this included taxes on the inter-state sale or purchase of goods (Central Sales Tax) and taxes on the consignment of goods.
The revenue does not go to the Consolidated Fund of India but is distributed among states based on principles formulated by Parliament.
Historical_Context: This was a key article governing inter-state trade taxation. The Central Sales Tax (CST) was a major source of revenue governed by this article. With the advent of GST, CST has been largely subsumed, and the nature of inter-state taxation is now governed by Article 269A (IGST), significantly altering the relevance of this article.
Landmark_Cases: This article was central to all litigation concerning Central Sales Tax.

Title: Levy and collection of goods and services tax in course of inter-State trade or commerce
Original_Description:
(1) Goods and services tax on supplies in the course of inter-State trade or commerce shall be levied and collected by the Government of India and such tax shall be apportioned between the Union and the States in the manner as may be provided by Parliament by law on the recommendations of the Goods and Services Tax Council.

 

Explanation.—For the purposes of this clause, supply of goods, or of services, or both in the course of import into the territory of India shall be deemed to be supply of goods, or of services, or both in the course of inter-State trade or commerce.

 

(2) The amount apportioned to a State under clause (1) shall not form part of the Consolidated Fund of India.

 

(3) Where an amount collected as tax levied under clause (1) has been used for payment of the tax levied by a State under article 246A, such amount shall not form part of the Consolidated Fund of India.

 

(4) Where an amount collected as tax levied by a State under article 246A has been used for payment of the tax levied under clause (1), such amount shall not form part of the Consolidated Fund of the State.

 

(5) Parliament may, by law, formulate the principles for determining the place of supply, and when a supply of goods, or of services, or both takes place in the course of inter-State trade or commerce.
Simplified_Description: Goods and services tax on supplies in the course of inter-State trade or commerce shall be levied and collected by the Government of India. Such tax shall be apportioned between the Union and the States in the manner as may be provided by Parliament by law.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Deals with Integrated GST (IGST) levied on inter-state trade and commerce.
IGST is levied and collected by the Government of India.
The collected tax is then apportioned between the Union and the States.
The manner of apportionment is determined by Parliament based on the recommendations of the GST Council.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 101st Amendment Act, 2016, and is the heart of the GST system for inter-state transactions. IGST is designed to ensure a seamless flow of tax credit across state borders. The GST Council plays a crucial role in recommending how this tax is shared, making it a key institution of fiscal federalism.
Landmark_Cases: Union of India vs Mohit Minerals Pvt. Ltd. (2022): While not directly on this article, it clarified the recommendatory nature of the GST Council's decisions, which are central to the apportionment mentioned here.

Title: Taxes levied and distributed between the Union and the States
Original_Description:
(1) All taxes and duties referred to in the Union List, except the duties and taxes referred to in articles 268 and 269, respectively, surcharge on taxes and duties referred to in article 271 and any cess levied for specific purposes under any law made by Parliament shall be levied and collected by the Government of India and shall be distributed between the Union and the States in the manner provided in clause (2).

 

 

(2) Such percentage, as may be prescribed, of the net proceeds of any such tax or duty in any financial year shall not form part of the Consolidated Fund of India, but shall be assigned to the States within which that tax or duty is leviable in that year, and shall be distributed among those States in such manner and from such time as may be prescribed in the manner provided in clause (3).

 

(3) In this article, “prescribed” means, —

 

(i) until a Finance Commission has been constituted, prescribed by the President by order, and

 

(ii) after a Finance Commission has been constituted, prescribed by the President by order after considering the recommendations of the Finance Commission.
Simplified_Description: All taxes and duties referred to in the Union List shall be collected by the Government of India and distributed between the Union and the States. Such percentage, as may be prescribed, of the net proceeds of any such tax or duty in any financial year shall not form part of the Consolidated Fund of India.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Deals with the 'divisible pool' of taxes.
It states that most major taxes levied by the Union (like income tax, corporation tax, etc.) are to be collected by the Centre and then distributed between the Union and the States.
The percentage of the net proceeds to be distributed and the manner of distribution among states is 'prescribed' by the President based on the recommendations of the Finance Commission.
Historical_Context: This article is the cornerstone of India's system of fiscal transfers. It was introduced by the 80th Amendment Act, 2000, which fundamentally changed the system from tax-by-tax sharing to a single divisible pool of central taxes. This provides greater flexibility and stability in revenue sharing, with the Finance Commission acting as the arbiter.
Landmark_Cases: This is a fundamental article of fiscal federalism, operationalized through the periodic reports of the Finance Commission.

Title: Surcharge on certain duties and taxes for purposes of the Union
Original_Description: Notwithstanding anything in articles 269 and 270, Parliament may at any time increase any of the duties or taxes referred to in those articles by a surcharge for purposes of the Union and the whole proceeds of any such surcharge shall form part of the Consolidated Fund of India.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may at any time increase any of the duties or taxes referred to in those articles by a surcharge for purposes of the Union. The whole proceeds of any such surcharge shall form part of the Consolidated Fund of India.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to levy a 'surcharge' on any of the taxes mentioned in Articles 269 and 270.
The entire proceeds from such a surcharge go exclusively to the Union.
This revenue is not part of the divisible pool and does not have to be shared with the states.
Historical_Context: This provision gives the central government an elastic source of revenue for its specific needs. The use of surcharges (and cesses) has been a point of contention in fiscal federalism, as states argue that it allows the Centre to raise revenues outside the shareable pool, thereby reducing the funds available for devolution.
Landmark_Cases: The increasing use of surcharges and cesses by the Union government has been criticized by various Finance Commissions and state governments.
Related_Articles: Article 269, 270 (Taxes that are shared with states)

Title: Grants in lieu of export duty on jute and jute products
Original_Description:
(1) There shall be charged on the Consolidated Fund of India in each year as grants-in-aid of the revenues of the States of Assam, Bihar, Orissa and West Bengal, in lieu of assignment of any share of the net proceeds in each year of export duty on jute and jute products to those States, such sums as may be prescribed.

 

(2) The sums so prescribed shall continue to be charged on the Consolidated Fund of India so long as any export duty on jute or jute products continues to be levied by the Government of India or until the expiration of ten years from the commencement of this Constitution whichever is earlier.

 

(3) In this article, the expression “prescribed” has the same meaning as in article 270.
Simplified_Description: The sums so prescribed shall continue to be charged on the Consolidated Fund of India so long as any export duty on jute or jute products continues to be levied by the Government of India.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Provided for grants-in-aid to the states of Assam, Bihar, Orissa, and West Bengal.
These grants were in lieu of their share in the export duty on jute and jute products.
This provision was to remain in effect for ten years from the commencement of the Constitution or until the export duty was levied, whichever was earlier.
Historical_Context: Before the Constitution, some provinces received a share of the export duty on jute. This article was a transitional arrangement to compensate these specific states for the loss of that revenue source under the new constitutional scheme. As the ten-year period has long expired, this article is now obsolete.
Landmark_Cases: This was a transitional financial provision and is no longer operative.
Related_Articles: Article 275 (Grants from the Union to certain States)

Title: Prior recommendation of President required to Bills affecting taxation in which States are interested
Original_Description:
(1) No Bill or amendment which imposes or varies any tax or duty in which States are interested, or which varies the meaning of the expression “agricultural income” as defined for the purposes of the enactments relating to Indian income-tax, or which affects the principles on which under any of the foregoing provisions of this Chapter moneys are or may be distributable to States, or which imposes any such surcharge for the purposes of the Union as is mentioned in the foregoing provisions of this Chapter, shall be introduced or moved in either House of Parliament except on the recommendation of the President.

 

(2) In this article, the expression “tax or duty in which States are interested” means —

 

(a) a tax or duty the whole or part of the net proceeds whereof are assigned to any State; or

 

(b) a tax or duty by reference to the net proceeds whereof sums are for the time being payable out of the Consolidated Fund of India to any State.
Simplified_Description: No Bill or amendment which imposes or varies any tax or duty in which States are interested, or which varies the meaning of the expression “agricultural income” as defined for the purposes of the enactments relating to Indian income-tax, shall be introduced.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Requires the prior recommendation of the President for the introduction of any bill in Parliament that affects taxation in which states have an interest.
This includes any bill that imposes or varies a tax whose proceeds are shared with states.
It also applies to bills that affect the principles of revenue distribution to the states.
Historical_Context: This article is a procedural safeguard to protect the financial interests of the states. Since the President acts on the advice of the Union Council of Ministers, it essentially ensures that the Union executive has considered the implications for states before any such financial legislation is introduced in Parliament. It also provides an opportunity for the Finance Commission's views to be considered.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural safeguard in fiscal federalism.
Related_Articles: Article 270 (Taxes distributed between Union and States)

Title: Grants from the Union to certain States
Original_Description:
(1) Such sums as Parliament may by law provide shall be charged on the Consolidated Fund of India in each year as grants-in-aid of the revenues of such States as Parliament may determine to be in need of assistance, and different sums may be fixed for different States:

 

   Provided that there shall be paid out of the Consolidated Fund of India as grants-in-aid of the revenues of a State such capital and recurring sums as may be necessary to enable that State to meet the costs of such schemes of development as may be undertaken by the State with the approval of the Government of India for the purpose of promoting the welfare of the Scheduled Tribes in that State or raising the level of administration of the Scheduled Areas therein to that of the administration of the rest of the areas of that State:

 

   Provided further that there shall be paid out of the Consolidated Fund of India as grants-in-aid of the revenues of the State of Assam sums, capital and recurring, equivalent to —

 

(a) the average excess of expenditure over the revenues during the two years immediately preceding the commencement of this Constitution in respect of the administration of the tribal areas specified in Part I of the table appended to paragraph 20 of the Sixth Schedule; and

 

(b) the costs of such schemes of development as may be undertaken by that State with the approval of the Government of India for the purpose of raising the level of administration of the said areas to that of the administration of the rest of the areas of that State.

 

(1A) On and from the formation of the autonomous State under article 244A, —

 

(i) any sums payable under clause (a) of the second proviso to clause (1) shall, if the autonomous State comprises all the tribal areas referred to therein, be paid to the autonomous State, and, if the autonomous State comprises only some of those tribal areas, be apportioned between the State of Assam and the autonomous State as the President may, by order, specify;

 

 

(ii) there shall be paid out of the Consolidated Fund of India as grants-in-aid of the revenues of the autonomous State sums, capital and recurring, equivalent to the costs of such schemes of development as may be undertaken by the autonomous State with the approval of the Government of India for the purpose of raising the level of administration of that State to that of the administration of the rest of the State of Assam.

 

(2) Until provision is made by Parliament under clause (1), the powers conferred on Parliament under that clause shall be exercisable by the President by order and any order made by the President under this clause shall have effect subject to any provision so made by Parliament:

 

   Provided that after a Finance Commission has been constituted no order shall be made under this clause by the President except after considering the recommendations of the Finance Commission.
Simplified_Description: Constitution provides for grants-in-aid of the revenues of such States as Parliament may determine to be in need of assistance. Different sums may be fixed for different States.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Authorizes Parliament to provide 'grants-in-aid' to states that are in need of financial assistance.
These are known as statutory grants and are made based on the recommendations of the Finance Commission.
The amount can vary from state to state depending on their needs.
It specifically mandates grants for promoting the welfare of Scheduled Tribes and for raising the administrative level of Scheduled Areas.
Historical_Context: This article is a key instrument of fiscal federalism, designed to correct vertical and horizontal fiscal imbalances. It enables the Centre, which has greater revenue-raising powers, to transfer resources to states to help them meet their expenditure needs. The recommendations of the Finance Commission (under Article 280) provide an objective basis for these grants.
Landmark_Cases: This is a fiscal federalism article, and its application is guided by the reports of the successive Finance Commissions.

Title: Taxes on professions, trades, callings and employments
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything in article 246, no law of the Legislature of a State relating to taxes for the benefit of the State or of a municipality, district board, local board or other local authority therein in respect of professions, trades, callings or employments shall be invalid on the ground that it relates to a tax on income.

 

(2) The total amount payable in respect of any one person to the State or to any one municipality, district board, local board or other local authority in the State by way of taxes on professions, trades, callings and employments shall not exceed 1 [two thousand and five hundred rupees] per annum.

 

(3) The power of the Legislature of a State to make laws as aforesaid with respect to taxes on professions, trades, callings and employments shall not be construed as limiting in any way the power of Parliament to make laws with respect to taxes on income accruing from or arising out of professions, trades, callings and employments.
Simplified_Description: No law of the Legislature of a State relating to taxes for the benefit of the State or of a municipality, district board, local board or other local authority therein in respect of professions, trades, callings or employments shall be invalid on the ground that it relates to a tax on income.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Empowers a State Legislature to impose a tax on professions, trades, callings, and employments (Professional Tax).
Clarifies that this tax is not invalid even if it appears to be a tax on income (which is a Union subject).
Sets a ceiling on the amount of professional tax that can be levied on any one person. The current ceiling is ₹2,500 per year.
Historical_Context: This article carves out a specific taxation power for the states and local bodies. The ceiling on the tax has been increased over the years through constitutional amendments. Many states have been demanding a further increase in this ceiling to augment their revenues.
Landmark_Cases: This article provides a clear, though limited, source of revenue for state and local governments.

Title: Savings
Original_Description: Any taxes, duties, cesses or fees which, immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, were being lawfully levied by the Government of any State or by any municipality or other local authority or body for the purposes of the State, municipality, district or other local area may, notwithstanding that those taxes, duties, cesses or fees are mentioned in the Union List, continue to be levied and to be applied to the same purposes until provision to the contrary is made by Parliament by law.
Simplified_Description: Any taxes, duties, cesses or fees which, immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, were being lawfully levied by the Government of any State or by any municipality or other local authority or body may continue to be levied and to be applied to the same purposes.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: This is a 'savings' or transitional provision.
It allowed states and local authorities to continue levying any taxes that they were lawfully levying before the Constitution came into force.
This continuance was permitted even if the tax now fell under the Union List in the new constitutional scheme.
This arrangement would only continue until Parliament made a law to the contrary.
Historical_Context: This article was designed to prevent a disruption in the financial resources of states and local bodies during the transition to the new constitutional framework. It ensured that existing sources of revenue were not suddenly cut off just because the distribution of taxation powers had changed.
Landmark_Cases: This was a transitional provision whose relevance has diminished over time as Parliament has enacted laws covering most subjects.
Related_Articles: Article 372 (Continuance in force of existing laws)

Title: Calculation of “net proceeds”, etc
Original_Description:
(1) In the foregoing provisions of this Chapter, “net proceeds” means in relation to any tax or duty the proceeds thereof reduced by the cost of collection, and for the purposes of those provisions the net proceeds of any tax or duty, or of any part of any tax or duty, in or attributable to any area shall be ascertained and certified by the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India, whose certificate shall be final.

 

(2) Subject as aforesaid, and to any other express provision of this Chapter, a law made by Parliament or an order of the President may, in any case where under this Part the proceeds of any duty or tax are, or may be, assigned to any State, provide for the manner in which the proceeds are to be calculated, for the time from or at which and the manner in which any payments are to be made, for the making of adjustments between one financial year and another, and for any other incidental or ancillary matters.
Simplified_Description: Net proceeds means in relation to any tax or duty the proceeds thereof reduced by the cost of collection. The Comptroller and Auditor-General of India's certificate shall be final. A law made by Parliament or an order of the President may, in any case, provide for the manner in which the proceeds are to be calculated.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Defines 'net proceeds' of a tax as the gross proceeds minus the cost of collection.
Designates the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India (CAG) as the authority to ascertain and certify the net proceeds.
The certificate issued by the CAG is final and cannot be questioned.
Historical_Context: Since many central taxes are shared with the states based on their 'net proceeds', this article provides a clear, impartial, and final mechanism for calculating this amount. By entrusting this function to the independent constitutional authority of the CAG, it prevents any disputes between the Centre and the states over the calculation of the divisible pool of taxes.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article underpinning the mechanism of fiscal federalism.
Related_Articles: Article 270 (Taxes levied and distributed between the Union and the States)

Title: Finance Commission
Simplified_Description: The President shall, within two years from the commencement of this Constitution and thereafter at the expiration of every fifth year or at such earlier time as the President considers necessary, by order constitute a Finance Commission. The Commission shall consist of a Chairman and four other members to be appointed by the President.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Mandates the President to constitute a Finance Commission every five years, or earlier if necessary.
The Commission's primary role is to make recommendations on the distribution of financial resources between the Union and the States.
Key recommendations include the vertical devolution (share of states in central taxes) and horizontal devolution (allocation of funds among different states).
It also recommends the principles for grants-in-aid and measures to augment the resources of local bodies (Panchayats and Municipalities).
Historical_Context: The Finance Commission is a quasi-judicial body and a cornerstone of Indian fiscal federalism. It was created to address the vertical and horizontal fiscal imbalances inherent in the constitutional scheme. Its recommendations, while not legally binding on the government, are given great weight and form the basis of fiscal transfers from the Centre to the states for a five-year period.
Landmark_Cases: The recommendations of successive Finance Commissions are pivotal documents in the evolution of Centre-State financial relations.

Title: Recommendations of the Finance Commission
Original_Description: The President shall cause every recommendation made by the Finance Commission under the provisions of this Constitution together with an explanatory memorandum as to the action taken thereon to be laid before each House of Parliament.
Simplified_Description: The President shall cause every recommendation made by the Finance Commission under the provisions of this Constitution together with an explanatory memorandum to be laid before each House of Parliament.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Requires the President to lay the report of the Finance Commission before both Houses of Parliament.
The report must be accompanied by an 'explanatory memorandum' detailing the action taken by the government on the Commission's recommendations.
This ensures transparency and accountability in the process of implementing the Commission's advice.
Historical_Context: This article ensures that the Finance Commission's recommendations and the government's response are subject to parliamentary scrutiny. While the government is not legally bound to accept the recommendations, it is politically accountable to Parliament for its decisions, and the explanatory memorandum forces it to justify any deviation from the Commission's advice.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article ensuring accountability in fiscal federalism.

Title: Expenditure defrayable by the Union or a State out of its revenues
Original_Description: The Union or a State may make any grants for any public purpose, notwithstanding that the purpose is not one with respect to which Parliament or the Legislature of the State, as the case may be, may make laws.
Simplified_Description: The Union or a State may make any grants for any public purpose, notwithstanding that the purpose is not one with respect to which Parliament or the Legislature of the State, as the case may be, may make laws.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Allows the Union and the States to make grants for any 'public purpose'.
This power exists even if the purpose is a subject on which that legislature cannot make laws.
These are known as discretionary grants, as they are not based on the recommendations of the Finance Commission.
Historical_Context: While Article 275 deals with statutory grants based on the Finance Commission's recommendations, Article 282 provides flexibility for the Union (and states) to provide funds for various schemes and purposes as they see fit. A significant portion of central assistance to states for implementing centrally sponsored schemes is routed through these discretionary grants, which has been a point of contention in federal relations.
Landmark_Cases: The scope of 'public purpose' is very wide and is generally left to the discretion of the government.

Title: Custody, etc, of Consolidated Funds, Contingency Funds and moneys credited to the public accounts
Original_Description:
(1) The custody of the Consolidated Fund of India and the Contingency Fund of India, the payment of moneys into such Funds, the withdrawal of moneys therefrom, the custody of public moneys other than those credited to such Funds received by or on behalf of the Government of India, their payment into the public account of India and the withdrawal of moneys from such account and all other matters connected with or ancillary to matters aforesaid shall be regulated by law made by Parliament, and, until provision in that behalf is so made, shall be regulated by rules made by the President.

 

(2) The custody of the Consolidated Fund of a State and the Contingency Fund of a State, the payment of moneys into such Funds, the withdrawal of moneys therefrom, the custody of public moneys other than those credited to such Funds received by or on behalf of the Government of the State, their payment into the public account of the State and the withdrawal of moneys from such account and all other matters connected with or ancillary to matters aforesaid shall be regulated by law made by the Legislature of the State, and, until provision in that behalf is so made, shall be regulated by rules made by the Governor of the State.
Simplified_Description: Custody of the Consolidated Fund of India and the Contingency Fund. Payment of moneys into such Funds, the withdrawal ofmoneys therefrom. Custody of public money other than those credited to such Funds received by or on behalf of Government of India.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Provides for the regulation of the custody and operation of various government funds.
At the Union level, Parliament makes the law, and until then, the President makes the rules.
At the State level, the State Legislature makes the law, and until then, the Governor makes the rules.
This covers the Consolidated Fund, the Contingency Fund, and the Public Account.
Historical_Context: This article establishes the legal framework for the day-to-day management of public money, including deposits, withdrawals, and custody. It ensures that the handling of all government funds is governed by either legislative acts or, in their absence, by rules made by the head of the executive.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article governing public financial management.

Title: Custody of suitors’ deposits and other moneys received by public servants and courts
Original_Description:
All moneys received by or deposited with —

 

(a) any officer employed in connection with the affairs of the Union or of a State in his capacity as such, other than revenues or public moneys raised or received by the Government of India or the Government of the State, as the case may be, or

 

(b) any court within the territory of India to the credit of any cause, matter, account or persons, shall be paid into the public account of India or the public account of State, as the case may be.
Simplified_Description: All moneys received by or deposited with the Government of India or the State shall be paid into the public account of India.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Specifies that certain types of money received by public servants or courts must be deposited into the Public Account of India or the State.
This includes money deposited with a court in connection with a case (suitors' deposits) and money received by a government officer that is not government revenue.
This money does not belong to the government but is held by it in trust.
Historical_Context: This article provides for the safe custody of money that the government or the judiciary holds on behalf of others. By placing it in the Public Account, it is kept separate from government revenues in the Consolidated Fund and can be returned to the rightful owners without needing legislative appropriation.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article related to public finance.

Title: Exemption of property of the Union from State taxation
Original_Description:
(1) The property of the Union shall, save in so far as Parliament may by law otherwise provide, be exempt from all taxes imposed by a State or by any authority within a State.

 

(2) Nothing in clause (1) shall, until Parliament by law otherwise provides, prevent any authority within a State from levying any tax on any property of the Union to which such property was immediately before the commencement of this Constitution liable or treated as liable, so long as that tax continues to be levied in that State.
Simplified_Description: The property of the Union shall be exempt from all taxes imposed by a State or by any authority within a State. Nothing in clause (1) shall, until Parliament by law otherwise provides, prevent a State from levying any tax on any property.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Provides for inter-governmental tax immunity.
The property of the Union Government is exempt from all taxes imposed by a state or any local authority within a state.
Parliament can, by law, remove this exemption for any specific property.
A pre-constitutional tax on Union property could continue to be levied until Parliament provides otherwise.
Historical_Context: This article is based on the principle of federal immunity, which prevents one level of government from taxing the property of another, as this could impede their sovereign functions. This provision ensures the smooth functioning of Union government properties (like railways, post offices, defence establishments) located within states.
Landmark_Cases: Sea Customs Act case (1963): The Supreme Court held that this immunity applies only to property taxes and not to indirect taxes like customs duties.
Related_Articles: Article 289 (Exemption of property and income of a State from Union taxation)

Title: Restrictions as to imposition of tax on the sale or purchase of goods
Original_Description:
(1) No law of a State shall impose, or authorise the imposition of, a tax on the sale or purchase of goods where such sale or purchase takes place —

 

(a) outside the State; or

 

(b) in the course of the import of the goods into, or export of the goods out of, the territory of India.

 

(2) Parliament may by law formulate principles for determining when a sale or purchase of goods takes place in any of the ways mentioned in clause (1).

 

(3) Any law of a State shall, in so far as it imposes, or authorises the imposition of, —

 

(a) a tax on the sale or purchase of goods declared by Parliament by law to be of special importance in inter-State trade or commerce; or

 

(b) a tax on the sale or purchase of goods, being a tax of the nature referred to in sub-clause (b), subclause (c) or sub-clause (d) of clause (29A) of article 366,

 

be subject to such restrictions and conditions in regard to the system of levy, rates and other incidents of the tax as Parliament may by law specify.
Simplified_Description: No law of a State shall impose, or authorise the imposition of, a tax on the sale or purchase of goods outside the State. The tax must be of special importance in inter-State trade or commerce.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Places certain restrictions on the power of states to levy taxes on the sale or purchase of goods.
A state cannot tax a sale that takes place outside the state.
A state cannot tax a sale that is in the course of import into or export out of India.
Parliament can by law declare certain goods to be of 'special importance' in inter-state trade and can impose restrictions on how states tax them.
Historical_Context: This article was crucial for maintaining the free flow of inter-state trade and commerce and preventing multiple taxation of the same transaction by different states. It aims to clearly demarcate the taxing powers of states in the context of inter-state and international trade. The introduction of GST has significantly changed the landscape of sales taxation, and this article's relevance has been altered accordingly.
Landmark_Cases: State of Travancore-Cochin vs Shanmugha Vilas Cashew Nut Factory (1953): The Supreme Court interpreted the meaning of 'in the course of import or export'.
Related_Articles: Article 301 (Freedom of trade, commerce and intercourse)

Title: Exemption from taxes on electricity
Original_Description:
Save in so far as Parliament may by law otherwise provide, no law of a State shall impose, or authorise the imposition of, a tax on the consumption or sale of electricity (whether produced by a Government or other persons) which is —

 

(a) consumed by the Government of India, or sold to the Government of India for consumption by that Government; or

 

(b) consumed in the construction, maintenance or operation of any railway by the Government of India or a railway company operating that railway, or sold to that Government or any such railway company for consumption in the construction, maintenance or operation of any railway,

 

and any such law imposing, or authorising the imposition of, a tax on the sale of electricity shall secure that the price of electricity sold to the Government of India for consumption by that Government, or to any such railway company as aforesaid for consumption in the construction, maintenance or operation of any railway, shall be less by the amount of the tax than the price charged to other consumers of a substantial quantity of electricity.
Simplified_Description: No law of a State shall impose, or authorise the imposition of, a tax on the consumption or sale of electricity. The price of electricity sold to the Government of India for consumption by that Government, or to any such railway company as aforesaid for consumption in the construction, maintenance or operation of any railway, shall be less by the amount of the tax than the price charged to
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Restricts states from imposing a tax on the consumption or sale of electricity in certain cases.
Electricity consumed by the Government of India is exempt.
Electricity consumed in the operation of railways by the Government of India is also exempt.
Parliament can by law remove this exemption.
Historical_Context: This is another provision based on the principle of inter-governmental tax immunity. It ensures that the functions of the Union government and essential national services like railways are not burdened by state taxes on electricity.
Landmark_Cases: This is a specific fiscal provision related to federal relations.

Title: Exemption from taxation by States in respect of water or electricity in certain cases
Original_Description:
(1) Save in so far as the President may by order otherwise provide, no law of a State in force immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall impose, or authorise the imposition of, a tax in respect of any water or electricity stored, generated, consumed, distributed or sold by any authority established by any existing law or any law made by Parliament for regulating or developing any inter-State river or river-valley.

 

   Explanation. — The expression “law of a State in force” in this clause shall include a law of a State passed or made before the commencement of this Constitution and not previously repealed, notwithstanding that it or parts of it may not be then in operation either at all or in particular areas.

 

(2) The Legislature of a State may by law impose, or authorise the imposition of, any such tax as is mentioned in clause (1), but no such law shall have any effect unless it has, after having been reserved for the consideration of the President, received his assent; and if any such law provides for the fixation of the rates and other incidents of such tax by means of rules or orders to be made under the law by any authority, the law shall provide for the previous consent of the President being obtained to the making of any such rule or order.
Simplified_Description: No law of a State in force immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall impose, or authorise the imposition of, a tax in respect of any water or electricity stored, generated, consumed, distributed or sold. No such law shall have any effect unless it has been reserved for the consideration of the President, and received his assent.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Restricts states from taxing water or electricity generated, stored, or distributed by an authority established by Parliament for regulating an inter-state river.
A state can pass a law to impose such a tax, but it will have no effect unless it has received the President's assent.
This gives the Union government control over the taxation of inter-state river valley projects.
Historical_Context: This article was designed to protect major inter-state river valley projects (like the Damodar Valley Corporation), which are of national importance, from being subjected to taxation by the states in which they are located. It ensures that the benefits of such projects are not undermined by local taxation.
Landmark_Cases: This is a specific fiscal provision related to federal relations.
Related_Articles: Article 262 (Adjudication of disputes relating to waters of interState rivers)

Title: Exemption of property and income of a State from Union taxation
Original_Description:
(1) The property and income of a State shall be exempt from Union taxation.

 

(2) Nothing in clause (1) shall prevent the Union from imposing, or authorising the imposition of, any tax to such extent, if any, as Parliament may by law provide in respect of a trade or business of any kind carried on by, or on behalf of, the Government of a State, or any operations connected therewith, or any property used or occupied for the purposes of such trade or business, or any income accruing or arising in connection therewith.

 

(3) Nothing in clause (2) shall apply to any trade or business, or to any class of trade or business, which Parliament may by law declare to be incidental to the ordinary functions of Government.
Simplified_Description: Property and income of a State shall be exempt from Union taxation. Nothing in clause (1) shall prevent the Union from imposing, or authorising the imposition of, any tax to such extent, if any, as Parliament may by law provide.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Provides that the property and income of a State are exempt from Union taxation.
This is the reciprocal immunity to the one granted to the Union under Article 285.

However, this immunity is not absolute. Parliament can by law authorize the Union to tax any trade or business carried on by a state government, unless that business is declared by Parliament to be incidental to the ordinary functions of government.
Historical_Context: This article upholds the principle of mutual tax immunity in a federal system. The exception for commercial activities of a state ensures a level playing field and prevents state-run businesses from having an unfair tax advantage over private businesses. This distinction between a state's sovereign functions and its commercial functions is key.
Landmark_Cases: Sea Customs Act case (1963): The Supreme Court held that the immunity does not extend to indirect taxes like customs duties. So, if a state imports goods, it is liable to pay customs duty.
Related_Articles: Article 285 (Exemption of property of the Union from State taxation)

Title: Adjustment in respect of certain expenses and pensions
Original_Description:
Where under the provisions of this Constitution the expenses of any court or Commission, or the pension payable to or in respect of a person who has served before the commencement of this Constitution under the Crown in India or after such commencement in connection with the affairs of the Union or of a State, are charged on the Consolidated Fund of India or the Consolidated Fund of a State, then, if —

 

(a) in the case of a charge on the Consolidated Fund of India, the court or Commission serves any of the separate needs of a State, or the person has served wholly or in part in connection with the affairs of a State; or

 

(b) in the case of a charge on the Consolidated Fund of a State, the court or Commission serves any of the separate needs of the Union or another State, or the person has served wholly or in part in connection with the affairs of the Union or another State,

 

there shall be charged on and paid out of the Consolidated Fund of the State or, as the case may be, the Consolidated Fund of India or the Consolidated Fund of the other State, such contribution in respect of the expenses or pension as may be agreed, or as may in default of agreement be determined by an arbitrator to be appointed by the Chief Justice of India.
Simplified_Description: The expenses of any court or Commission, or the pension payable to or in respect of a person who has served before the commencement of this Constitution under the Crown in India, are charged on the Consolidated Fund of India. The expenses or pension as may be agreed, or as may in default of agreement be determined by an arbitrator to be appointed by the Chief Justice of India, will
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Provides for a mechanism of financial adjustment between the Union and the States.
If a court or commission whose expenses are charged on the Consolidated Fund of India also serves the needs of a state, that state must contribute to the expenses.
Conversely, if a state body serves the needs of the Union or another state, the Union or that other state must contribute.
The amount of contribution is to be settled by agreement, or failing that, by an arbitrator appointed by the Chief Justice of India.
Historical_Context: This is an accounting and adjustment provision designed to ensure that the costs of shared services and pensions for officials who have served both the Centre and states are shared equitably between the respective governments.
Landmark_Cases: This is a financial adjustment article.

Title: Annual payment to certain Devaswom Funds
Original_Description: A sum of forty-six lakhs and fifty thousand rupees shall be charged on, and paid out of, the Consolidated Fund of the State of Kerala every year to the Travancore Devaswom Fund; and a sum of thirteen lakhs and fifty thousand rupees shall be charged on, and paid out of, the Consolidated Fund of the State of Tamil Nadu every year to the Devaswom Fund established in that State for the maintenance of Hindu temples and shrines in the territories transferred to that State on the 1st day of November, 1956, from the State of Travancore-Cochin.
Simplified_Description: A sum of forty-six lakhs and fifty thousand rupees shall be charged on, and paid out of, the Consolidated Fund of the State of Kerala every year to the Travancore Devaswom Fund.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Mandates specific annual payments from the Consolidated Funds of Kerala and Tamil Nadu.
A fixed sum is to be paid to the Travancore Devaswom Fund by Kerala.
A fixed sum is to be paid by Tamil Nadu to the Devaswom Fund for maintenance of Hindu temples in territories transferred from Travancore-Cochin.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 7th Amendment Act, 1956. It constitutionalized an obligation that arose from the covenant entered into by the ruler of the princely state of Travancore-Cochin at the time of its integration with India. The ruler had dedicated revenues for the maintenance of temples, and this provision ensured the continuance of that financial support after the reorganization of states.
Landmark_Cases: This is a specific financial provision with a historical basis.

Title: Borrowing by the Government of India
Original_Description: The executive power of the Union extends to borrowing upon the security of the Consolidated Fund of India within such limits, if any, as may from time to time be fixed by Parliament by law and to the giving of guarantees within such limits, if any, as may be so fixed.
Simplified_Description: The executive power of the Union extends to borrowing upon the security of the Consolidated Fund of India within such limits, if any.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Empowers the Union executive (Government of India) to borrow money.
The borrowing is done on the security of the Consolidated Fund of India.
Parliament has the power to fix limits on the government's borrowing and the guarantees it can give.
This power extends to borrowing within India and from abroad.
Historical_Context: This article provides the constitutional authority for the government's borrowing program, which is essential for managing the budget deficit and financing public expenditure. Although Parliament has the power to set borrowing limits through legislation (like a Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act), it has not yet set an absolute ceiling on government debt.
Landmark_Cases: This is a foundational article for public debt management.

Title: Borrowing by States
Original_Description:
(1) Subject to the provisions of this article, the executive power of a State extends to borrowing within the territory of India upon the security of the Consolidated Fund of the State within such limits, if any, as may from time to time be fixed by the Legislature of such State by law and to the giving of guarantees within such limits, if any, as may be so fixed.

 

(2) The Government of India may, subject to such conditions as may be laid down by or under any law made by Parliament, make loans to any State or, so long as any limits fixed under article 292 are not exceeded, give guarantees in respect of loans raised by any State, and any sums required for the purpose of making such loans shall be charged on the Consolidated Fund of India.

 

(3) A State may not without the consent of the Government of India raise any loan if there is still outstanding any part of a loan which has been made to the State by the Government of India or by its predecessor Government, or in respect of which a guarantee has been given by the Government of India or by its predecessor Government.

 

(4) A consent under clause (3) may be granted subject to such conditions, if any, as the Government of India may think fit to impose.
Simplified_Description: Executive power of a State extends to borrowing within the territory of India upon the security of the Consolidated Fund of the State. Government of India may, subject to such conditions as may be laid down by or under any law made by Parliament, make loans to any State.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Empowers a state government to borrow money on the security of its Consolidated Fund.
The State Legislature can fix borrowing limits for the state government.
A state's borrowing power is restricted: it can only borrow within the territory of India.
Crucially, a state cannot raise a fresh loan without the consent of the Central Government if it has any outstanding loans from the Centre.
Historical_Context: This article places significant restrictions on the borrowing powers of the states, giving the Union government substantial control over state finances. Since virtually all states are indebted to the Centre, they effectively need the Centre's permission for all their borrowing. This provision has been a major point of debate in the discourse on state autonomy and fiscal federalism.
Landmark_Cases: The interpretation of 'loan' and the conditions the Centre can impose under clause (4) are critical for Centre-State financial relations.
Related_Articles: Article 292 (Borrowing by the Government of India)

Title: Succession to property, assets, rights, liabilities and obligations in certain cases
Original_Description:
As from the commencement of this Constitution —

 

(a) all property and assets which immediately before such commencement were vested in His Majesty for the purposes of the Government of the Dominion of India and all property and assets which immediately before such commencement were vested in His Majesty for the purposes of the Government of each Governor’s Province shall vest respectively in the Union and the corresponding State, and

 

(b) all rights, liabilities and obligations of the Government of the Dominion of India and of the Government of each Governor’s Province, whether arising out of any contract or otherwise, shall be the rights, liabilities and obligations respectively of the Government of India and the Government of each corresponding State,

 

subject to any adjustment made or to be made by reason of the creation before the commencement of this Constitution of the Dominion of Pakistan or of the Provinces of West Bengal, East Bengal, West Punjab and East Punjab.
Simplified_Description: All property and assets which immediately before such commencement were vested in His Majesty for the purposes of the Government of the Dominion of India shall vest respectively in the Union and the corresponding State, and all rights, liabilities and obligations.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: This is a succession provision.
It deals with the transfer of property, assets, rights, liabilities, and obligations from the pre-Constitution governments to the new governments under the Constitution.
Property and assets of the Dominion of India vested in the Union.
Property and assets of the Governor's Provinces vested in the corresponding States.
Rights and liabilities were similarly transferred.
Historical_Context: This article ensured a smooth and orderly transition of legal and financial personality from the British Indian government to the Government of the Republic of India and its constituent states. It prevented a legal vacuum and ensured that existing government contracts, debts, and properties were properly accounted for.
Landmark_Cases: This was a key article in early litigation concerning pre-independence claims against the government.

Title: Succession to property, assets, rights, liabilities and obligations in other cases
Original_Description:
(1) As from the commencement of this Constitution —

 

(a) all property and assets which immediately before such commencement were vested in any Indian State corresponding to a State specified in Part B of the First Schedule shall vest in the Union, if the purposes for which such property and assets were held immediately before such commencement will thereafter be purposes of the Union relating to any of the matters enumerated in the Union List, and

 

(b) all rights, liabilities and obligations of the Government of any Indian State corresponding to a State specified in Part B of the First Schedule, whether arising out of any contract or otherwise, shall be the rights, liabilities and obligations of the Government of India, if the purposes for which such rights were acquired or liabilities or obligations were incurred before such commencement will thereafter be purposes of the Government of India relating to any of the matters enumerated in the Union List,

 

subject to any agreement entered into in that behalf by the Government of India with the Government of that State.

 

(2) Subject as aforesaid, the Government of each State specified in Part B of the First Schedule shall, as from the commencement of this Constitution, be the successor of the Government of the corresponding Indian State as regards all property and assets and all rights, liabilities and obligations, whether arising out of any contract or otherwise, other than those referred to in clause (1).
Simplified_Description: From the commencement of this Constitution, all property and assets which immediately before such commencement were vested in any Indian State corresponding to a State specified in Part B of the First Schedule shall vest in the Union. All rights, liabilities and obligations of the Government of India, whether arising out of any contract or otherwise, shall be the rights and liabilities of the government of India.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: This is another succession provision, specifically for the former Indian Princely States.
Property and assets of a princely state related to Union List subjects (e.g., defence, railways) vested in the Union.
All other property, assets, rights, and liabilities of the princely state were succeeded to by the new corresponding State (the Part B states).
This succession was subject to any agreements made between the Government of India and the government of that state.
Historical_Context: This article dealt with the complex task of integrating the assets and liabilities of over 500 princely states into the new constitutional structure. It provided a legal framework for the division of these assets and liabilities between the Union and the newly formed states.
Landmark_Cases: Cases involving claims and liabilities of the former princely states often involved an interpretation of this article.

Title: Property accruing by escheat or lapse or as bona vacantia
Original_Description:
Subject as hereinafter provided, any property in the territory of India which, if this Constitution had not come into operation, would have accrued to His Majesty or, as the case may be, to the Ruler of an Indian State by escheat or lapse, or as bona vacantia for want of a rightful owner, shall, if it is property situate in a State, vest in such State, and shall, in any other case, vest in the Union:

 

   Provided that any property which at the date when it would have so accrued to His Majesty or to the Ruler of an Indian State was in the possession or under the control of the Government of India or the Government of a State shall, according as the purposes for which it was then used or held were purposes of the Union or of a State, vest in the Union or in that State.

 

   Explanation. — In this article, the expressions “Ruler” and “Indian State” have the same meanings as in article 363.
Simplified_Description: Any property in the territory of India which, if this Constitution had not come into operation, would have accrued to His Majesty or, as the case may be, to the Ruler of an Indian State by escheat or lapse, shall, if it is property situate in a State, vest in such State.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Deals with property that has no legal owner.
Such property vests in the government through the doctrines of 'escheat', 'lapse', or 'bona vacantia' (vacant goods).
If the property is located within a state, it vests in the state government.
In all other cases (e.g., within a Union Territory), it vests in the Union government.
Historical_Context: This article establishes the state as the ultimate heir to all ownerless property. It is a common feature of sovereign power. This prevents property from falling into a legal limbo and allows the state to take control of it for public benefit.
Landmark_Cases: This principle is applied in cases where a person dies without leaving any legal heirs or a will.
Related_Articles: This is a standalone provision regarding state rights over property.

Title: Things of value within territorial waters or continental shelf and resources of the exclusive economic zone to vest in the Union
Original_Description:
(1) All lands, minerals and other things of value underlying the ocean within the territorial waters, or the continental shelf, or the exclusive economic zone, of India shall vest in the Union and be held for the purposes of the Union.

 

(2) All other resources of the exclusive economic zone of India shall also vest in the Union and be held for the purposes of the Union.

 

(3) The limits of the territorial waters, the continental shelf, the exclusive economic zone, and other maritime zones, of India shall be such as may be specified, from time to time, by or under any law made by Parliament.
Simplified_Description: All lands, minerals and other things of value underlying the ocean within the territorial waters, or the continental shelf, of India shall vest in the Union and be held for the purposes of the Union.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Vests all lands, minerals, and other things of value in India's territorial waters, continental shelf, and Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) in the Union Government.
This gives the central government ownership and control over all offshore resources.
Parliament is empowered to specify the limits of these maritime zones.
Historical_Context: This article asserts the sovereign rights of the Union over its maritime resources, in line with international maritime law (like the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea - UNCLOS). It was amended by the 40th Amendment Act, 1976, to explicitly include the 'continental shelf' and 'exclusive economic zone', reflecting developments in international law.
Landmark_Cases: This article forms the constitutional basis for all central laws governing offshore mining, oil exploration, and fishing.
