Related_Articles: Article 246 and Union List (which gives Parliament power to legislate on these areas)

Title: Power to carry on trade, etc
Original_Description:
The executive power of the Union and of each State shall extend to the carrying on of any trade or business and to the acquisition, holding and disposal of property and the making of contracts for any purpose: Provided that —

 

(a) the said executive power of the Union shall, in so far as such trade or business or such purpose is not one with respect to which Parliament may make laws, be subject in each State to legislation by the State; and

 

(b) the said executive power of each State shall, in so far as such trade or business or such purpose is not one with respect to which the State Legislature may make laws, be subject to legislation by Parliament.
Simplified_Description: The executive power of the Union and of each State shall extend to the carrying on of any trade or business and to the acquisition, holding and disposal of property.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Grants both the Union and State governments the power to carry on any trade or business.
This power also includes the acquisition, holding, and disposal of property, and the making of contracts for any purpose.
The exercise of this power is subject to the legislative competence of the respective government.
Historical_Context: This article was substituted by the 7th Amendment Act, 1956. It provides the constitutional basis for the government to enter into commercial activities and establish Public Sector Undertakings (PSUs). It clarifies that the executive power of the government is not limited to purely governmental functions but extends to business and trade as well.
Landmark_Cases: This article has been cited to uphold the government's power to create state monopolies and engage in commercial enterprises.
Related_Articles: Article 19(6) (which allows the state to create monopolies)

Title: Contracts
Original_Description:
(1) All contracts made in the exercise of the executive power of the Union or of a State shall be expressed to be made by the President, or by the Governor of the State, as the case may be, and all such contracts and all assurances of property made in the exercise of that power shall be executed on behalf of the President or the Governor by such persons and in such manner as he may direct or authorise.

 

(2) Neither the President nor the Governor shall be personally liable in respect of any contract or assurance made or executed for the purposes of this Constitution, or for the purposes of any enactment relating to the Government of India heretofore in force, nor shall any person making or executing any such contract or assurance on behalf of any of them be personally liable in respect thereof.
Simplified_Description: All contracts made in the exercise of the executive power of the Union or of a State shall be expressed to be made by the President. Neither the President nor the Governor shall be personally liable in respect of any contract or assurance made or executed for the purposes of this Constitution.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Prescribes the formal procedure for making government contracts.
All contracts by the Union must be expressed in the name of the President.
All contracts by a State must be expressed in the name of the Governor.
The contract must be executed by a person authorized by the President or Governor.
It provides personal immunity to the President and the Governor, as well as the executing officer, from any liability arising from the contract.
Historical_Context: This article lays down mandatory requirements for the validity of a government contract. The purpose is to protect the government from unauthorized contracts and to ensure that contracts are made in a proper manner. Failure to comply with these formal requirements can render a contract unenforceable against the government.
Landmark_Cases: State of Bihar vs M/s Karam Chand Thapar & Brothers Ltd. (1962): The Supreme Court held that the provisions of this article are mandatory and a contract that does not comply with them is void.

Title: Suits and proceedings
Original_Description:
(1) The Government of India may sue or be sued by the name of the Union of India and the Government of a State may sue or be sued by the name of the State and may, subject to any provisions which may be made by Act of Parliament or of the Legislature of such State enacted by virtue of powers conferred by this Constitution, sue or be sued in relation to their respective affairs in the like cases as the Dominion of India and the corresponding Provinces or the corresponding Indian States might have sued or been sued if this Constitution had not been enacted. 

 

(2) If at the commencement of this Constitution —

 

(a) any legal proceedings are pending to which the Dominion of India is a party, the Union of India shall be deemed to be substituted for the Dominion in those proceedings; and (

 

b) any legal proceedings are pending to which a Province or an Indian State is a party, the corresponding State shall be deemed to be substituted for the Province or the Indian State in those proceedings.
Simplified_Description: The Government of India may sue or be sued by the name of the Union of India. The Government of a State may sued or be sue by theName of the State. If at the commencement of this Constitution the Dominion of India is a party to legal proceedings, the Union shall be deemed to be substituted for the Dominion in those proceedings.
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Provides for the legal personality of the government.
The Government of India can sue and be sued in the name of the 'Union of India'.
A State Government can sue and be sued in the name of the 'State'.
It establishes the legal liability of the government, stating that it can be sued in the same cases as the Dominion of India and the Provinces could have been before the Constitution.
Historical_Context: This article establishes the principle of government liability, meaning the state is not above the law and can be brought to court like any other legal entity. It continues the legal liability that existed in the pre-Constitution era. This is the basis for all suits filed by or against the government, including for breach of contract and for torts (civil wrongs) committed by its servants.
Landmark_Cases: State of Rajasthan vs Vidyawati (1962): The Supreme Court held the state liable for the tortious acts of its employees committed in the course of their employment, moving away from the old doctrine of sovereign immunity.

Title: Persons not to be deprived of property save by authority of law
Original_Description: No person shall be deprived of his property save by authority of law.
Simplified_Description: No person shall be deprived of his property save by authority of law. No person shall have his property
Subject: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
Key_Points: Guarantees the Right to Property as a constitutional right, not a fundamental right.
It provides that no person can be deprived of their property except by the 'authority of law'.
This means the government can acquire property only by enacting a valid law.
Unlike a fundamental right, its violation cannot be directly challenged in the Supreme Court under Article 32.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 44th Amendment Act, 1978. The same amendment repealed Article 19(1)(f) and Article 31, which had made the Right to Property a Fundamental Right. This was a landmark change, aimed at making it easier for the government to pursue land reforms and other socio-economic policies without facing extensive legal challenges based on the fundamental right to property.
Landmark_Cases: K.T. Plantation Pvt. Ltd. vs. State of Karnataka (2011): The Supreme Court held that the 'law' under Article 300A must be just, fair, and reasonable. It also interpreted the right to property as a human right.

Vidhya Devi v. State of Himachal Pradesh (2020): The court affirmed that the state cannot dispossess a citizen of their property without following the due process of law and that the state cannot claim adverse possession.
Related_Articles: Article 265 (Taxes not to be imposed save by authority of law)

Title: Freedom of trade, commerce and intercourse
Original_Description: Subject to the other provisions of this Part, trade, commerce and intercourse throughout the territory of India shall be free.
Simplified_Description: Trade and commerce throughout the territory of India shall be free. Subject to the other provisions of this Part, trade, commerce and intercourse throughout
Subject: Trade, Commerce and Intercourse within the territory of India
Key_Points: Guarantees the freedom of trade, commerce, and intercourse throughout the territory of India.
The aim is to create a single, unified economic market and remove inter-state barriers.
This freedom is not absolute and is subject to the restrictions laid down in Articles 302 to 305.
Historical_Context: The framers of the Constitution wanted to ensure that provincial and local interests did not hinder the economic unity of the nation. This article is designed to prevent states from creating protectionist policies that would obstruct the free movement of goods and services across state borders, thereby promoting a common market.
Landmark_Cases: Atiabari Tea Co. vs State of Assam (1961): The Supreme Court held that any law (including a tax law) that directly and immediately restricts or impedes the free flow of trade and commerce violates Article 301.

Automobile Transport (Rajasthan) Ltd. vs State of Rajasthan (1962): The court clarified that regulatory measures or compensatory taxes (e.g., road tax for using state highways) are not considered restrictions and are permissible.
Related_Articles: Article 19(1)(g) (Right to practice any profession, trade or business)

Title: Power of Parliament to impose restrictions on trade, commerce and intercourse
Original_Description: Parliament may by law impose such restrictions on the freedom of trade, commerce or intercourse between one State and another or within any part of the territory of India as may be required in the public interest.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may by law impose such restrictions on the freedom of trade, commerce or intercourse between one State and another or within any part of the territory of India.
Subject: Trade, Commerce and Intercourse within the territory of India
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to impose restrictions on the freedom of trade, commerce, and intercourse guaranteed under Article 301.
Such restrictions can be imposed on both inter-state and intra-state trade.
The only condition is that the restrictions must be 'required in the public interest'.
Historical_Context: This article provides the necessary power to the central legislature to regulate the economy in the national interest. While Article 301 guarantees freedom, Article 302 provides the power to regulate it. The judgment of what constitutes 'public interest' is left to the Parliament, subject to judicial review.
Landmark_Cases: The interpretation of 'public interest' in this context has been a subject of judicial scrutiny in cases challenging parliamentary restrictions on trade.
Related_Articles: Article 303 (Restrictions on the legislative powers of the Union and of the States)

Title: Restrictions on the legislative powers of the Union and of the States with regard to trade and commerce
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything in article 302, neither Parliament nor the Legislature of a State shall have power to make any law giving, or authorising the giving of, any preference to one State over another, or making, or authorising the making of, any discrimination between one State and another, by virtue of any entry relating to trade and commerce in any of the Lists in the Seventh Schedule.

 

(2) Nothing in clause (1) shall prevent Parliament from making any law giving, or authorising the giving of, any preference or making, or authorising the making of, any discrimination if it is declared by such law that it is necessary to do so for the purpose of dealing with a situation arising from scarcity of goods in any part of the territory of India.
Simplified_Description: Neither Parliament nor the Legislature of a State shall have power to make any law giving, or authorising the giving of, any preference to one State over another.
Subject: Trade, Commerce and Intercourse within the territory of India
Key_Points: Prohibits both Parliament and State Legislatures from making laws that give preference to one state over another or discriminate between states in matters of trade and commerce.
This is a non-discrimination clause to ensure a level playing field for all states.
An exception is made for Parliament, which can make a discriminatory law if it is necessary to deal with a scarcity of goods in any part of India.
Historical_Context: This article further strengthens the idea of a unified Indian market. It prevents economic Balkanization by disallowing both the Centre and the states from playing favorites. The exception for scarcity of goods is a pragmatic provision to allow the central government to manage regional crises, for example, by directing the movement of food grains to a famine-affected area.
Landmark_Cases: This article acts as a check on the powers granted under Article 302.
Related_Articles: Article 302 (Power of Parliament to impose restrictions)

Title: Restrictions on trade, commerce and intercourse among States
Original_Description:
Notwithstanding anything in article 301 or article 303, the Legislature of a State may by law —

 

(a) impose on goods imported from other States 1 [or the Union territories] any tax to which similar goods manufactured or produced in that State are subject, so, however, as not to discriminate between goods so imported and goods so manufactured or produced; and

 

(b) impose such reasonable restrictions on the freedom of trade, commerce or intercourse with or within that State as may be required in the public interest:

 

   Provided that no Bill or amendment for the purposes of clause (b) shall be introduced or moved in the Legislature of a State without the previous sanction of the President
Simplified_Description: A State may by law impose on goods imported from other States 1 [or the Union territories] any tax to which similar goods manufactured or produced in that State are subject. A State may impose such reasonable restrictions on the freedom of trade, commerce or intercourse with or within that State as may be required in the public interest.
Subject: Trade, Commerce and Intercourse within the territory of India
Key_Points: Allows State Legislatures to impose certain restrictions on the freedom of trade and commerce.
Clause (a) permits a state to impose a non-discriminatory tax on goods imported from other states, if a similar tax is levied on goods produced within the state.
Clause (b) permits a state to impose 'reasonable restrictions' on trade in the public interest, but any bill for this purpose requires the prior sanction of the President.
Historical_Context: This article gives states some power to regulate trade and commerce within their borders, balancing the freedom under Article 301. Clause (a) prevents states from creating tax barriers against goods from other states. Clause (b) allows states to impose restrictions (e.g., for public health or safety), but the requirement of prior Presidential sanction acts as a central check to prevent misuse.
Landmark_Cases: The distinction between a non-discriminatory 'compensatory tax' and a discriminatory 'restriction' has been a key issue in cases under this article.

Title: Saving of existing laws and laws providing for State monopolies
Original_Description: Nothing in articles 301 and 303 shall affect the provisions of any existing law except in so far as the President may by order otherwise direct; and nothing in article 301 shall affect the operation of any law made before the commencement of the Constitution (Fourth Amendment) Act, 1955, in so far as it relates to, or prevent Parliament or the Legislature of a State from making any law relating to, any such matter as is referred to in subclause (ii) of clause (6) of article 19.
Simplified_Description: Nothing in articles 301 and 303 shall affect the provisions of any existing law except in so far as the President may by order otherwise direct. Nothing in article 301 shall. affect the operation of any law made before the commencement of the Constitution (Fourth Amendment) Act, 1955.
Subject: Trade, Commerce and Intercourse within the territory of India
Key_Points: This is a 'saving' clause.
It protects existing laws (in force before the Constitution) from being invalidated by Articles 301 and 303.
It also clarifies that the freedom of trade under Article 301 does not prevent the state from creating monopolies in any trade or business (as allowed under Article 19(6)).
Historical_Context: This article was included to ensure legal continuity and to explicitly protect the government's power to nationalize certain industries or create state monopolies (e.g., in sectors like railways, atomic energy, etc.) without it being challenged as a violation of the freedom of trade.
Landmark_Cases: This article is invoked to defend the legality of state monopolies.

Title: Appointment of authority for carrying out the purposes of articles 301 to 304
Original_Description: Parliament may by law appoint such authority as it considers appropriate for carrying out the purposes of articles 301, 302, 303 and 304, and confer on the authority so appointed such powers and such duties as it thinks necessary.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may by law appoint such authority as it considers appropriate for carrying out the purposes of articles 301, 302, 303 and 304. It may confer on the authority so appointed such powers and such duties as it thinks necessary.
Subject: Trade, Commerce and Intercourse within the territory of India
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to appoint an authority to enforce the provisions of Articles 301 to 304.
Parliament can confer necessary powers and duties on this authority.
This authority would act as a regulator for inter-state trade and commerce.
Historical_Context: The framers envisioned a body, perhaps similar to the Inter-State Commerce Commission in the USA, to deal with the complex issues of inter-state trade. However, Parliament has not yet enacted a law to create such an authority. These functions are currently handled by various government departments and regulatory bodies.
Landmark_Cases: This is an enabling provision that has not yet been acted upon by Parliament.

Title: Interpretation
Original_Description: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, the expression “State” does not include the State of Jammu and Kashmir.
Simplified_Description: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, the expression “State” does not include the State of Jammu and Kashmir
Subject: Services under the Union and States
Key_Points: Provided a specific definition of 'State' for the purposes of Part XIV (Services).
It excluded the State of Jammu and Kashmir, which had its own separate provisions for public services.
This article has become redundant after the abrogation of Article 370.
Historical_Context: This was another provision reflecting the special status of Jammu and Kashmir under Article 370. Since all-India services and other Union service rules did not automatically apply to J&K, it was excluded from the general definition in this part. Following the reorganization of J&K in 2019, this article is no longer operative.
Landmark_Cases: This was a definitional clause linked to Article 370.
Related_Articles: Article 370 (Temporary provisions with respect to the State of Jammu and Kashmir)

Title: Recruitment and conditions of service of persons serving the Union or a State
Original_Description:
Subject to the provisions of this Constitution, Acts of the appropriate Legislature may regulate the recruitment, and conditions of service of persons appointed, to public services and posts in connection with the affairs of the Union or of any State:

 

   Provided that it shall be competent for the President or such person as he may direct in the case of services and posts in connection with the affairs of the Union, and for the Governor of a State or such person as he may direct in the case of services and posts in connection with the affairs of the State, to make rules regulating the recruitment, and the conditions of service of persons appointed, to such services and posts until provision in that behalf is made by or under an Act of the appropriate Legislature under this article, and any rules so made shall have effect subject to the provisions of any such Act.
Simplified_Description: An Act of the appropriate Legislature may regulate the recruitment, and conditions of service of persons appointed, to public services and posts.
Subject: Services under the Union and States
Key_Points: Empowers the Parliament and State Legislatures to regulate the recruitment and conditions of service for public servants.
Until such a law is made, the President (for Union services) and the Governor (for State services) have the power to make rules for the same.
These rules made by the executive are temporary and will be superseded by any law made by the legislature.
Historical_Context: This article provides the legal framework for public employment. In practice, most of the service conditions for government employees are governed by the rules made by the President or the Governor under the proviso to this article, as comprehensive legislative acts covering all aspects of service are less common.
Landmark_Cases: Roshan Lal Tandon vs Union of India (1967): The Supreme Court held that once appointed, a government servant acquires a status, and their rights and obligations are determined by statutory rules, not by contract.
Related_Articles: Article 311 (Dismissal, removal or reduction in rank)

Title: Tenure of office of persons serving the Union or a State
Original_Description:
(1) Except as expressly provided by this Constitution, every person who is a member of a defence service or of a civil service of the Union or of an all-India service or holds any post connected with defence or any civil post under the Union holds office during the pleasure of the President, and every person who is a member of a civil service of a State or holds any civil post under a State holds office during the pleasure of the Governor of the State.

 

(2) Notwithstanding that a person holding a civil post under the Union or a State holds office during the pleasure of the President or, as the case may be, of the Governor of the State, any contract under which a person, not being a member of a defence service or of an all-India service or of a civil service of the Union or a State, is appointed under this Constitution to hold such a post may, if the President or the Governor, as the case may be, deems it necessary in order to secure the services of a person having special qualifications, provide for the payment to him of compensation, if before the expiration of an agreed period that post is abolished or he is, for reasons not connected with any misconduct on his part, required to vacate that post.
Simplified_Description: Every person who is a member of a defence service or of a civil service of the Union or of an all-India service or holds any post connected with defence or any civil post under the Union holds office during the pleasure of the President.
Subject: Services under the Union and States
Key_Points: Establishes the 'Doctrine of Pleasure'.
Public servants of the Union (civil and defence) hold office during the pleasure of the President.
Public servants of a State hold office during the pleasure of the Governor.
This means that their services can be terminated at any time by the respective authority.
However, this doctrine is not absolute and is subject to the procedural safeguards provided in Article 311.
Historical_Context: This doctrine is borrowed from the English common law, where a civil servant holds office at the pleasure of the Crown. In India, the framers adopted this principle but made it subject to constitutional restrictions (Article 311) to provide security of tenure to civil servants and protect them from arbitrary dismissal.
Landmark_Cases: Union of India vs Tulsiram Patel (1985): The Supreme Court extensively discussed the Doctrine of Pleasure and its limitations, holding that it is subject to the provisions of Article 311 but not to Fundamental Rights.
Related_Articles: Article 311 (Dismissal, removal or reduction in rank)

Title: Dismissal, removal or reduction in rank of persons employed in civil capacities under the Union or a State
Original_Description:
(1) No person who is a member of a civil service of the Union or an all-India service or a civil service of a State or holds a civil post under the Union or a State shall be dismissed or removed by an authority subordinate to that by which he was appointed.

 

(2) No such person as aforesaid shall be dismissed or removed or reduced in rank except after an inquiry in which he has been informed of the charges against him and given a reasonable opportunity of being heard in respect of those charges:

 

   Provided that where it is proposed after such inquiry, to impose upon him any such penalty, such penalty may be imposed on the basis of the evidence adduced during such inquiry and it shall not be necessary to give such person any opportunity of making representation on the penalty proposed:

 

   Provided further that this clause shall not apply — 

 

(a) where a person is dismissed or removed or reduced in rank on the ground of conduct which has led to his conviction on a criminal charge; or

 

(b) where the authority empowered to dismiss or remove a person or to reduce him in rank is satisfied that for some reason, to be recorded by that authority in writing, it is not reasonably practicable to hold such inquiry; or

 

(c) where the President or the Governor, as the case may be, is satisfied that in the interest of the security of the State it is not expedient to hold such inquiry.

 

(3) If, in respect of any such person as aforesaid, a question arises whether it is reasonably practicable to hold such inquiry as is referred to in clause (2), the decision thereon of the authority empowered to dismiss or remove such person or to reduce him in rank shall be final.
Simplified_Description: No person who is a member of a. civil service of the Union or an all-India service or a civil service. of a State or holds a civil post under the. Union or a State shall be dismissed or removed by an authority subordinate to. that by which he was appointed.
Subject: Services under the Union and States
Key_Points: Provides two crucial safeguards to civil servants against arbitrary dismissal or removal.
1. A civil servant cannot be dismissed or removed by an authority subordinate to the one that appointed them.
2. A civil servant cannot be dismissed, removed, or reduced in rank without a formal inquiry where they are informed of the charges and given a reasonable opportunity to be heard.
These safeguards are not available to members of the defence services.
There are exceptions where an inquiry may not be held (e.g., conviction on a criminal charge).
Historical_Context: This article is a vital protection for civil servants, acting as a major exception to the 'Doctrine of Pleasure' under Article 310. It provides security of tenure and ensures that civil servants can perform their duties impartially without fear of arbitrary disciplinary action. It embodies the principles of natural justice within the framework of administrative law.
Landmark_Cases: Khem Chand vs Union of India (1958): The Supreme Court detailed what constitutes a 'reasonable opportunity of being heard'.
Union of India vs Tulsiram Patel (1985): The court explained the scope of the exceptions under clause (2), where an inquiry can be dispensed with.

Title: All-India services
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything in Chapter VI of Part VI or Part XI, if the Council of States has declared by resolution supported by not less than two-thirds of the members present and voting that it is necessary or expedient in the national interest so to do, Parliament may by law provide for the creation of one or more all India services (including an all-India judicial service) common to the Union and the States, and, subject to the other provisions of this Chapter, regulate the recruitment, and the conditions of service of persons appointed, to any such service.

 

(2) The services known at the commencement of this Constitution as the Indian Administrative Service and the Indian Police Service shall be deemed to be services created by Parliament under this article.

 

(3) The all-India judicial service referred to in clause (1) shall not include any post inferior to that of a district judge as defined in article 236.

 

(4) The law providing for the creation of the all-India judicial service aforesaid may contain such provisions for the amendment of Chapter VI of Part VI as may be necessary for giving effect to the provisions of that law and no such law shall be deemed to be an amendment of this Constitution for the purposes of article 368.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may by law provide for the creation of one or more all India services (including an all-India judicial service) common to the Union and the States. The services known at the commencement of this Constitution as the Indian Administrative Service and the Indian Police Service shall be deemed to be services created by Parliament under this article.
Subject: Services under the Union and States
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to create one or more All-India Services (AIS) common to the Union and the States.
The process must be initiated by the Rajya Sabha, which needs to pass a resolution supported by a two-thirds majority, declaring that such a service is necessary in the national interest.
The Indian Administrative Service (IAS) and the Indian Police Service (IPS) are recognized as services created under this article.
The provision also allows for the creation of an All-India Judicial Service.
Historical_Context: The All-India Services are a unique feature of Indian federalism. They are recruited and trained by the Centre, but their members serve in different state cadres, providing a vital link between the Union and state administrations. The special role given to the Rajya Sabha (Council of States) in creating new AIS is a federal safeguard, as it requires the consent of the states' representatives.
Landmark_Cases: The nature and role of AIS in the federal structure have been a subject of administrative and political debate, particularly regarding the control of state governments over AIS officers.

Title: Power of Parliament to vary or revoke conditions of service of officers of certain services
Original_Description:
(1) Parliament may by law —

 

(a) vary or revoke, whether prospectively or retrospectively, the conditions of services as respects remuneration, leave and pension and the rights as respects disciplinary matters of persons who, having been appointed by the Secretary of State or Secretary of State in Council to a civil service of the Crown in India before the commencement of this Constitution, continue on and after the commencement of the Constitution (Twenty-eighth Amendment) Act, 1972, to serve under the Government of India or of a State in any service or post;

 

(b) vary or revoke, whether prospectively or retrospectively, the conditions of service as respects pension of persons who, having been appointed by the Secretary of State or Secretary of State in Council to a civil service of the Crown in India before the commencement of this Constitution, retired or otherwise ceased to be in service at any time before the commencement of the Constitution (Twentyeighth Amendment) Act, 1972:

 

   Provided that in the case of any such person who is holding or has held the office of the Chief Justice or other Judge of the Supreme Court or a High Court, the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India, the Chairman or other member of the Union or a State Public Service Commission or the Chief Election Commissioner, nothing in sub-clause (a) or sub-clause (b) shall be construed as empowering Parliament to vary or revoke, after his appointment to such post, the conditions of his service to his disadvantage except in so far as such conditions of service are applicable to him by reason of his being a person appointed by the Secretary of State or Secretary of State in Council to a civil service of the Crown in India.

 

(2) Except to the extent provided for by Parliament by law under this article, nothing in this article shall affect the power of any Legislature or other authority under any other provision of this Constitution to regulate the conditions of service of persons referred to in clause (1).

 

(3) Neither the Supreme Court nor any other court shall have jurisdiction in —

 

(a) any dispute arising out of any provision of, or any endorsement on, any covenant, agreement or other similar instrument which was entered into or executed by any person referred to in clause (1), or arising out of any letter issued to such person, in relation to his appointment to any civil service of the Crown in India or his continuance in service under the Government of the Dominion of India or a Province thereof;

 

(b) any dispute in respect of any right, liability or obligation under article 314 as originally enacted.

 

(4) The provisions of this article shall have effect notwithstanding anything in article 314 as originally enacted or in any other provision of this Constitution.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may by law vary or revoke, whether prospectively or retrospectively, the conditions of services as respects remuneration, leave and pension of persons who, having been appointed by the Secretary of State, continue to serve under the Government of India or of a State.
Subject: Services under the Union and States
Key_Points: Empowered Parliament to vary or revoke the service conditions of the officers of the Indian Civil Service (ICS).
This applied to ICS officers who were appointed by the British Secretary of State and continued to serve the Government of India after independence.
This power could be exercised retrospectively.
Historical_Context: The original Constitution (in the now-repealed Article 314) had guaranteed the pre-independence service conditions of ICS officers. This was seen as a colonial legacy and an anomaly. The 28th Amendment Act, 1972, repealed Article 314 and inserted this new article, giving Parliament the power to alter these special privileges.
Landmark_Cases: This article was enacted to close a specific chapter of the colonial civil service legacy.
Related_Articles: This article is of historical importance.

Title: Transitional provisions
Original_Description: Until other provision is made in this behalf under this Constitution, all the laws in force immediately before the commencement of this Constitution and applicable to any public service or any post which continues to exist after the commencement of this Constitution, as an allIndia service or as service or post under the Union or a State shall continue in force so far as consistent with the provisions of this Constitution.
Simplified_Description: Until other provision is made in this behalf under this Constitution, all the laws in force immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall continue in force so far as consistent with the provisions of this constitution.
Subject: Services under the Union and States
Key_Points: This is a transitional provision.
It ensured that all laws governing public services that were in force before the Constitution's commencement would continue to be in force.
This was to remain effective until new provisions were made under the Constitution, and as long as the old laws were consistent with the new Constitution.
Historical_Context: This article ensured continuity in the administration of public services during the transition from the colonial era to the new republic. It prevented a legal vacuum in service rules and regulations.
Landmark_Cases: This article was primarily relevant in the early years of the Constitution.
Related_Articles: Article 372 (Continuance in force of existing laws)

Title: Public Service Commissions for the Union and for the States
Original_Description:
(1) Subject to the provisions of this article, there shall be a Public Service Commission for the Union and a Public Service Commission for each State.

 

(2) Two or more States may agree that there shall be one Public Service Commission for that group of States, and if a resolution to that effect is passed by the House or, where there are two Houses, by each House of the Legislature of each of those States, Parliament may by law provide for the appointment of a Joint State Public Service Commission (referred to in this Chapter as Joint Commission) to serve the needs of those States.

 

(3) Any such law as aforesaid may contain such incidental and consequential provisions as may be necessary or desirable for giving effect to the purposes of the law.

 

(4) The Public Service Commission for the Union, if requested so to do by the Governor of a State, may, with the approval of the President, agree to serve all or any of the needs of the State.

 

(5) References in this Constitution to the Union Public Service Commission or a State Public Service Commission shall, unless the context otherwise requires, be construed as references to the Commission serving the needs of the Union or, as the case may be, the State as respects the particular matter in question.
Simplified_Description: There shall be a Public Service Commission for the Union and a Public service Commission for each State. Two or more States may agree that there shall be one Public service commission for that group.
Subject: Services under the Union and States
Key_Points: Mandates the establishment of a Public Service Commission for the Union (UPSC) and a Public Service Commission for each State (SPSC).
Allows for the creation of a Joint Public Service Commission (JPSC) for two or more states if they agree to it.
The UPSC can also serve the needs of a state if the Governor requests and the President approves.
Historical_Context: The Public Service Commissions are independent constitutional bodies created to ensure merit-based recruitment to public services and to advise the government on service matters. Their creation was a continuation and strengthening of the model from the Government of India Act, 1935, aimed at insulating recruitment from political influence and patronage.
Landmark_Cases: The independence and functions of the PSCs have been upheld in numerous judgments.
Related_Articles: Article 316 (Appointment and term of office of members)

Title: Appointment and term of office of members
Original_Description:
(1) The Chairman and other members of a Public Service Commission shall be appointed, in the case of the Union Commission or a Joint Commission, by the President, and in the case of a State Commission, by the Governor of the State:

 

    Provided that as nearly as may be one-half of the members of every Public Service Commission shall be persons who at the dates of their respective appointments have held office for at least ten years either under the Government of India or under the Government of a State, and in computing the said period of ten years any period before the commencement of this Constitution during which a person has held office under the Crown in India or under the Government of an Indian State shall be included.

 

(1A) If the office of the Chairman of the Commission becomes vacant or if any such Chairman is by reason of absence or for any other reason unable to perform the duties of his office, those duties shall, until some person appointed under clause (1) to the vacant office has entered on the duties thereof or, as the case may be, until the Chairman has resumed his duties, be performed by such one of the other members of the Commission as the President, in the case of the Union Commission or a Joint Commission, and the Governor of the State in the case of a State Commission, may appoint for the purpose.

 

(2) A member of a Public Service Commission shall hold office for a term of six years from the date on which he enters upon his office or until he attains, in the case of the Union Commission, the age of sixty-five years, and in the case of a State Commission or a Joint Commission, the age of sixty-two years, whichever is earlier:

 

   Provided that —

 

(a) a member of a Public Service Commission may, by writing under his hand addressed, in the case of the Union Commission or a Joint Commission, to the President, and in the case of a State Commission, to the Governor of the State, resign his office;

 

(b) a member of a Public Service Commission may be removed from his office in the manner provided in clause (1) or clause (3) of article 317.

 

(3) A person who holds office as a member of a Public Service Commission shall, on the expiration of his term of office, be ineligible for re-appointment to that office.
Simplified_Description: The Chairman and other members of a Public Service Commission shall be appointed, in the case of the Union Commission or a Joint Commission, by the President, and by the Governor of the State. A member of a public service commission shall hold office for a term of six years from the date on which he enters upon his office.
Subject: Services under the Union and States
Key_Points: The Chairman and members of the UPSC are appointed by the President.
The Chairman and members of an SPSC are appointed by the Governor.
The term of office is six years or until the age of 65 (for UPSC) or 62 (for SPSC), whichever is earlier.
At least one-half of the members should be persons with a minimum of ten years of government service experience.
Historical_Context: This article lays down the composition and tenure of the Public Service Commissions. The fixed tenure and high retirement age are designed to ensure the independence and impartiality of the members, allowing them to function without fear or favor.
Landmark_Cases: The appointment process and the eligibility criteria have been subject to judicial interpretation in various cases.
Related_Articles: Article 317 (Removal and suspension of a member)

Title: Removal and suspension of a member of a Public Service Commission
Original_Description:
(1) Subject to the provisions of clause (3), the Chairman or any other member of a Public Service Commission shall only be removed from his office by order of the President on the ground of misbehaviour after the Supreme Court, on reference being made to it by the President, has, on inquiry held in accordance with the procedure prescribed in that behalf under article 145, reported that the Chairman or such other member, as the case may be, ought on any such ground to be removed.

 

(2) The President, in the case of the Union Commission or a Joint Commission, and the Governor in the case of a State Commission, may suspend from office the Chairman or any other member of the Commission in respect of whom a reference has been made to the Supreme Court under clause (1) until the President has passed orders on receipt of the report of the Supreme Court on such reference.

 

(3) Notwithstanding anything in clause (1), the President may by order remove from office the Chairman or any other member of a Public Service Commission if the Chairman or such other member, as the case may be, —

 

(a) is adjudged an insolvent; or

 

(b) engages during his term of office in any paid employment outside the duties of his office; or

 

(c) is, in the opinion of the President, unfit to continue in office by reason of infirmity of mind or body.

 

(4) If the Chairman or any other member of a Public Service Commission is or becomes in any way concerned or interested in any contract or agreement made by or on behalf of the Government of India or the Government of a State or participates in any way in the profit thereof or in any benefit or emolument arising therefrom otherwise than as a member and in common with the other members of an incorporated company, he shall, for the purposes of clause (1), be deemed to be guilty of misbehaviour.
Simplified_Description: The Chairman or any other member of a Public Service Commission shall only be removed from his office by order of the President on the ground of misbehaviour after the Supreme Court has reported that the Chairman or such other member, as the case may be, ought to be removed.
Subject: Services under the Union and States
Key_Points: Provides a secure procedure for the removal of a member of a PSC.
The Chairman or a member can only be removed by the President on the ground of 'misbehaviour'.
The President must first refer the matter to the Supreme Court for an inquiry.
The President can remove the member only if the Supreme Court, after inquiry, recommends their removal.
The President can suspend the member while the inquiry is pending.
The President can also remove a member on other grounds like insolvency, engaging in paid employment, or infirmity of mind/body.
Historical_Context: This stringent removal process is a crucial safeguard for the independence of the Public Service Commissions. By making the removal process subject to a judicial inquiry by the Supreme Court, the Constitution protects the members from arbitrary or politically motivated removal by the executive.
Landmark_Cases: This procedure ensures a high degree of security of tenure for PSC members.

Title: Power to make regulations as to conditions of service of members and staff of the Commission
Original_Description:
In the case of the Union Commission or a Joint Commission, the President and, in the case of a State Commission, the Governor of the State may by regulations —

 

(a) determine the number of members of the Commission and their conditions of service; and

 

(b) make provision with respect to the number of members of the staff of the Commission and their conditions of service:

 

   Provided that the conditions of service of a member of a Public Service Commission shall not be varied to his disadvantage after his appointment.
Simplified_Description: The President and, in the case of a State Commission, the Governor of the State may determine the number of members of the Commission and their conditions of service.
Subject: Services under the Union and States
Key_Points: Empowers the President (for UPSC) and the Governor (for SPSC) to make regulations.
These regulations determine the number of members, their conditions of service, and the service conditions of the Commission's staff.
A crucial proviso states that the conditions of service of a member cannot be changed to their disadvantage after their appointment.
Historical_Context: This article gives the executive the power to frame the service rules for the PSCs while providing an important safeguard for the independence of the members. The proviso ensures that the executive cannot use its rule-making power to penalize or influence a serving member by altering their service conditions adversely.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural and power-conferring article.

Title: Prohibition as to the holding of offices by members of Commission on ceasing to be such members
Simplified_Description: On ceasing to hold office, the Chairman of the Union Public Service Commission shall be ineligible for further employment either under the Government of India or under a State.
Subject: Services under the Union and States
Key_Points: Imposes restrictions on the post-retirement employment of members of Public Service Commissions.
The Chairman of the UPSC is ineligible for any further government employment.
The Chairman of an SPSC is eligible for appointment to the UPSC (as Chairman or member) or as Chairman of another SPSC, but not for any other government employment.
A member of the UPSC (other than Chairman) can become the Chairman of the UPSC or an SPSC.
A member of an SPSC (other than Chairman) can become the Chairman or a member of the UPSC, or the Chairman of that or any other SPSC.
Historical_Context: These restrictions are designed to safeguard the independence and impartiality of the Public Service Commissions. By barring members from future government employment, the Constitution seeks to eliminate the possibility of them favoring the government during their tenure in the hope of securing a future appointment.
Landmark_Cases: This article is a key provision ensuring the integrity of the PSCs.

Title: Power to extend functions of Public Service Commissions
Original_Description: An Act made by Parliament or, as the case may be, the Legislature of a State may provide for the exercise of additional functions by the Union Public Service Commission or the State Public Service Commission as respects the services of the Union or the State and also as respects the services of any local authority or other body corporate constituted by law or of any public institution.
Simplified_Description: An Act made by Parliament or, as the case may be, the Legislature of a State may provide for the exercise of additional functions by the Union Public Service Commission.
Subject: Services under the Union and States
Key_Points: Allows the functions of the Public Service Commissions to be extended.
Parliament can confer additional functions on the UPSC.
A State Legislature can confer additional functions on the SPSC.
These additional functions can relate to the services of a local authority, a public institution, or a body corporate constituted by law.
Historical_Context: This article provides flexibility, allowing the legislature to entrust the PSCs with recruitment for bodies other than the government's own civil services. This enables public sector undertakings, universities, and other autonomous bodies to utilize the expertise and impartiality of the PSCs for their recruitment processes.
Landmark_Cases: This is an enabling provision.

Title: Expenses of Public Service Commissions
Original_Description: The expenses of the Union or a State Public Service Commission, including any salaries, allowances and pensions payable to or in respect of the members or staff of the Commission, shall be charged on the Consolidated Fund of India or, as the case may be, the Consolidated Fund of the State.
Simplified_Description: The expenses of the Union or a State Public Service Commission, including any salaries, allowances and pensions payable to or in respect of the members or staff of the Commission, shall be charged on the Consolidated Fund of India.
Subject: Services under the Union and States
Key_Points: Provides that all expenses of the UPSC and SPSCs are 'charged' upon the Consolidated Fund.
Expenses of the UPSC are charged on the Consolidated Fund of India.
Expenses of an SPSC are charged on the Consolidated Fund of the State.
This means their budget is not subject to the annual vote of the legislature.
Historical_Context: This is a critical provision for ensuring the financial autonomy and independence of the Public Service Commissions. By making their expenses non-votable, the Constitution protects them from being starved of funds or being subjected to financial pressure by the political executive.
Landmark_Cases: This is a key article for the independence of the PSCs.

Title: Reports of Public Service Commissions
Original_Description:
(1) It shall be the duty of the Union Commission to present annually to the President a report as to the work done by the Commission and on receipt of such report the President shall cause a copy thereof together with a memorandum explaining, as respects the cases, if any, where the advice of the Commission was not accepted, the reasons for such non-acceptance to be laid before each House of Parliament.

 

(2) It shall be the duty of a State Commission to present annually to the Governor of the State a report as to the work done by the Commission, and it shall be the duty of a Joint Commission to present annually to the Governor of each of the States the needs of which are served by the Joint Commission a report as to the work done by the Commission in relation to that State, and in either case the Governor, shall, on receipt of such report, cause a copy thereof together with a memorandum explaining, as respects the cases, if any, where the advice of the Commission was not accepted, the reasons for such non-acceptance to be laid before the Legislature of the State.
Simplified_Description: It is the duty of the Union Commission to present annually to the President a report as to the work done by the Commission. The President shall cause a copy thereof together with a memorandum explaining, as respects the cases, if any, where the advice of the Commission was not accepted, the reasons for such non-acceptance.
Subject: Services under the Union and States
Key_Points: Mandates the UPSC to submit an annual report on its work to the President.
Mandates the SPSC to submit an annual report to the Governor.
The President/Governor must lay this report before the Parliament/State Legislature.
The report must be accompanied by a memorandum explaining the cases, if any, where the advice of the Commission was not accepted by the government and the reasons for such non-acceptance.
Historical_Context: This article ensures the accountability of both the Public Service Commissions and the government. The annual report allows the legislature to scrutinize the functioning of the PSC. The memorandum on non-acceptance of advice makes the government accountable to the legislature for overriding the recommendations of the independent recruiting body.
Landmark_Cases: This is a key accountability mechanism in the constitutional scheme.

Title: Administrative tribunals
Simplified_Description: Parliament may, by law, provide for the adjudication or trial by administrative tribunals of disputes and complaints with respect to recruitment and conditions of service.
Subject: Tribunals
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to establish Administrative Tribunals.
These tribunals adjudicate disputes related to the recruitment and service conditions of public servants.
Parliament can provide for a Central Administrative Tribunal (CAT) and State Administrative Tribunals (SATs).
The law can exclude the jurisdiction of all courts (except the Supreme Court's jurisdiction under Article 136) over these matters.
Historical_Context: This article, along with Part XIV-A, was inserted by the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976. The objective was to provide speedy and specialized justice for service-related disputes and to reduce the burden on High Courts. The Administrative Tribunals Act, 1985, was enacted under this provision.
Landmark_Cases: L. Chandra Kumar vs Union of India (1997): In a landmark judgment, the Supreme Court struck down the provision that excluded the jurisdiction of High Courts (under Articles 226/227) over these tribunals. It held that appeals from tribunals must lie before the divisional bench of the High Court, as judicial review is a basic feature of the Constitution.

Title: Tribunals for other matters
Simplified_Description: The appropriate Legislature may, by law, provide for the adjudication or trial by tribunals of any disputes, complaints, or offences. The matters referred to in clause (1) are the following: levy, assessment, collection and enforcement of any tax, foreign exchange, import and export across customs frontiers.
Subject: Tribunals
Key_Points: Empowers the 'appropriate legislature' (Parliament or State Legislature) to establish tribunals for a wide range of other matters.
The specified matters include taxation, foreign exchange, industrial and labor disputes, land reforms, elections, rent control, etc.
The law creating such tribunals can exclude the jurisdiction of all courts except the Supreme Court.
Historical_Context: Also inserted by the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976, this article allowed for the creation of a parallel system of justice outside the traditional courts for various specialized subjects. This has led to the establishment of numerous tribunals, such as the National Green Tribunal, the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, and the National Company Law Tribunal.
Landmark_Cases: L. Chandra Kumar vs Union of India (1997): The ruling in this case, which made tribunal decisions subject to the High Court's jurisdiction, applies to tribunals under Article 323B as well.

Title: Superintendence, direction and control of elections to be vested in an Election Commission
Original_Description:
(1) The superintendence, direction and control of the preparation of the electoral rolls for, and the conduct of, all elections to Parliament and to the Legislature of every State and of elections to the offices of President and Vice-President held under this Constitution shall be vested in a Commission (referred to in this Constitution as the Election Commission).

 

(2) The Election Commission shall consist of the Chief Election Commissioner and such number of other Election Commissioners, if any, as the President may from time to time fix and the appointment of the Chief Election Commissioner and other Election Commissioners shall, subject to the provisions of any law made in that behalf by Parliament, be made by the President.

 

(3) When any other Election Commissioner is so appointed the Chief Election Commissioner shall act as the Chairman of the Election Commission.

 

(4) Before each general election to the House of the People and to the Legislative Assembly of each State, and before the first general election and thereafter before each biennial election to the Legislative Council of each State having such Council, the President may also appoint after consultation with the Election Commission such Regional Commissioners as he may consider necessary to assist the Election Commission in the performance of the functions conferred on the Commission by clause (1).

 

(5) Subject to the provisions of any law made by Parliament, the conditions of service and tenure of office of the Election Commissioners and the Regional Commissioners shall be such as the President may by rule determine: 

 

   Provided that the Chief Election Commissioner shall not be removed from his office except in like manner and on the like grounds as a Judge of the Supreme Court and the conditions of service of the Chief Election Commissioner shall not be varied to his disadvantage after his appointment:

 

   Provided further that any other Election Commissioner or a Regional Commissioner shall not be removed from office except on the recommendation of the Chief Election Commissioner.

 

(6) The President, or the Governor of a State, shall, when so requested by the Election Commission, make available to the Election Commission or to a Regional Commissioner such staff as may be necessary for the discharge of the functions conferred on the Election Commission by clause (1).
Simplified_Description: The superintendence, direction and control of the preparation of the electoral rolls for, and the conduct of, all elections to Parliament and to the Legislature of every State shall be vested in a Commission. The Election Commission shall consist of the Chief Election Commissioner and such number of other Election Commissioners, if any, as the President may fix.
Subject: Elections
Key_Points: Establishes the Election Commission of India (ECI).
Vests the ECI with the power of superintendence, direction, and control over all elections to Parliament, State Legislatures, and the offices of the President and Vice-President.
The ECI consists of the Chief Election Commissioner (CEC) and other Election Commissioners (ECs), appointed by the President.
The CEC has security of tenure and can only be removed in the same manner as a Supreme Court judge.
Historical_Context: The Constituent Assembly created the ECI as a powerful, independent body to ensure free and fair elections, which are the bedrock of democracy. The powers of the ECI were asserted most strongly during the tenure of T.N. Seshan in the 1990s, establishing its authority in practice. The appointment process has been a subject of debate, leading to recent judicial and legislative developments.
Landmark_Cases: T.N. Seshan vs Union of India (1995): The Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of a multi-member Election Commission and held that the CEC and ECs have equal powers.

Anoop Baranwal vs Union of India (2023): The Court directed that the appointment of the CEC and ECs be done on the advice of a committee comprising the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition in Lok Sabha, and the Chief Justice of India (this was subsequently altered by a parliamentary Act).
Related_Articles: Article 325 (No ineligibility for inclusion in electoral rolls on grounds of religion, race, caste or sex)
Article 326 (Elections to be on the basis of adult suffrage)

Title: No person to be ineligible for inclusion in, or to claim to be included in a special, electoral roll on grounds of religion, race, caste or sex
Original_Description: There shall be one general electoral roll for every territorial constituency for election to either House of Parliament or to the House or either House of the Legislature of a State and no person shall be ineligible for inclusion in any such roll or claim to be included in any special electoral roll for any such constituency on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex or any of them.
Simplified_Description: No person shall be ineligible for inclusion in any such roll or claim to be included in any special electoral roll for any such constituency on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex or any of them.
Subject: Elections
Key_Points: Mandates a 'general electoral roll' for every constituency.
Prohibits the preparation of separate electoral rolls for any group.
States that no person can be considered ineligible to be a voter on the grounds of religion, race, caste, or sex.
Historical_Context: This is a crucial provision that abolished the British-era practice of 'separate electorates', where different religious communities voted for their own candidates. By establishing a common, general electoral roll, the Constitution laid the foundation for a secular and inclusive democracy where all citizens vote as one electorate.
Landmark_Cases: This principle of a universal, non-discriminatory electoral roll is a cornerstone of Indian democracy.
Related_Articles: Article 326 (Elections to be on the basis of adult suffrage)

Title: Elections to the House of the People and to the Legislative Assemblies of States to be on the basis of adult suffrage
Original_Description: The elections to the House of the People and to the Legislative Assembly of every State shall be on the basis of adult suffrage; that is to say, every person who is a citizen of India and who is not less than  [eighteen years] of age on such date as may be fixed in that behalf by or under any law made by the appropriate Legislature and is not otherwise disqualified under this Constitution or any law made by the appropriate Legislature on the ground of non-residence, unsoundness of mind, crime or corrupt or illegal practice, shall be entitled to be registered as a voter at any such election.
Simplified_Description: The elections to the House of the People and to the Legislative Assembly of every State shall be on the basis of adult suffrage. Every person who is a citizen of India and who is not less than  [eighteen years] of age on such date as may be fixed.
Subject: Elections
Key_Points: Establishes the principle of 'Universal Adult Suffrage' for elections to the Lok Sabha and State Legislative Assemblies.
Every citizen of India who is 18 years of age or older is entitled to be a voter.
This right is subject to disqualifications prescribed by the Constitution or law on grounds like non-residence, unsoundness of mind, crime, or corrupt practices.
Historical_Context: The adoption of universal adult suffrage from the very beginning of the Republic was a radical and visionary act of faith in the democratic wisdom of the Indian people, at a time when many Western democracies still had property or educational qualifications for voting. The voting age was lowered from 21 to 18 by the 61st Constitutional Amendment Act, 1988.
Landmark_Cases: This article is the constitutional foundation of the right to vote in India.
Related_Articles: Article 325 (No person to be ineligible for inclusion in electoral roll)

Title: Power of Parliament to make provision with respect to elections to Legislatures
Original_Description: Subject to the provisions of this Constitution, Parliament may from time to time by law make provision with respect to all matters relating to, or in connection with, elections to either House of Parliament or to the House or either House of the Legislature of a State including the preparation of electoral rolls, the delimitation of constituencies and all other matters necessary for securing the due constitution of such House or Houses.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may from time to time by law make provision with respect to all matters relating to, or in connection with, elections to either House of Parliament or to the House of the Legislature.
Subject: Elections
Key_Points: Gives Parliament the power to make laws on all matters related to elections.
This includes elections to both Parliament and State Legislatures.
The scope is wide, covering preparation of electoral rolls, delimitation of constituencies, and all other necessary matters.
This power is subject to the provisions of the Constitution.
Historical_Context: This article provides the constitutional authority for Parliament to enact a comprehensive legal framework for the conduct of elections. The most important laws enacted under this article are the Representation of the People Act, 1950 (which deals with electoral rolls and qualifications of voters) and the Representation of the People Act, 1951 (which deals with the conduct of elections, disqualifications, corrupt practices, etc.).
Landmark_Cases: The constitutionality of various provisions of the Representation of the People Acts has been challenged and interpreted by the courts in numerous election-related cases.

Title: Power of Legislature of a State to make provision with respect to elections to such Legislature
Original_Description: Subject to the provisions of this Constitution and in so far as provision in that behalf is not made by Parliament, the Legislature of a State may from time to time by law make provision with respect to all matters relating to, or in connection with, the elections to the House or either House of the Legislature of the State including the preparation of electoral rolls and all other matters necessary for securing the due constitution of such House or Houses.
Simplified_Description: The Legislature of a State may from time to time by law make provision with respect to all matters relating to, or in connection with, the elections to the House or either House of the Legislature of the State.
Subject: Elections
Key_Points: Gives State Legislatures the power to make laws on matters related to their own elections.
This power is subject to two conditions: it must be consistent with the Constitution, and it applies only to matters on which Parliament has not already made a law.
This is a residual power for states in electoral matters.
Historical_Context: While Parliament has the primary power to legislate on electoral matters for uniformity (under Article 327), this article gives states a limited power to legislate on aspects not covered by central law. In practice, since Parliament has enacted comprehensive laws (Representation of the People Acts), the scope for state legislation under this article is very limited.
Landmark_Cases: This article defines the limited legislative competence of states in electoral matters.

Title: Bar to interference by courts in electoral matters
Simplified_Description: The validity of any law relating to the delimitation of constituencies or the allotment of seats to such constituencies, made or purporting to be made under article 327 or article 328, shall not be called in question in any court. No election to either House of Parliament or to the House of the Legislature of a State shall be call in question except by an election petition.
Subject: Elections
Key_Points: Places an explicit bar on interference by courts in certain electoral matters.
Clause (a) provides that the validity of any law on delimitation of constituencies cannot be questioned in any court.
Clause (b) states that an election can only be challenged by filing an 'election petition' after the election is over, and not through any other means.
This effectively bars courts from intervening in the election process once it has commenced.
Historical_Context: This article is designed to ensure that the electoral process, which is time-bound, is not derailed or delayed by litigation. It provides for a specific, post-election remedy (the election petition) as the sole mechanism for resolving electoral disputes, thereby ensuring the finality and stability of election results.
Landmark_Cases: N.P. Ponnuswami vs Returning Officer, Namakkal (1952): The Supreme Court gave a wide interpretation to the bar in clause (b), holding that once the election process has started, courts cannot interfere.
Related_Articles: Article 243O, 243ZG (Similar bars for Panchayat and Municipality elections)

Title: Reservation of seats for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes in the House of the People
Original_Description:
(1) Seats shall be reserved in the House of the People for —

 

(a) the Scheduled Castes;

 

(b) the Scheduled Tribes except the Scheduled Tribes in the autonomous districts of Assam; and

 

(c) the Scheduled Tribes in the autonomous districts of Assam.

 

(2) The number of seats reserved in any State or Union territory for the Scheduled Castes or the Scheduled Tribes under clause (1) shall bear, as nearly as may be, the same proportion to the total number of seats allotted to that State 2 [or Union territory] in the House of the People as the population of the Scheduled Castes in the State or Union territory or of the Scheduled Tribes in the State or Union territory or part of the State or Union territory, as the case may be, in respect of which seats are so reserved, bears to the total population of the State or Union territory.

 

(3) Notwithstanding anything contained in clause (2), the number of seats reserved in the House of the People for the Scheduled Tribes in the autonomous districts of Assam shall bear to the total number of seats allotted to that State a proportion not less than the population of the Scheduled Tribes in the said autonomous districts bears to the total population of the State.

 

Explanation —In this article and in article 332, the expression “population” means the population as ascertained at the last preceding census of which the relevant figures have been published:

 

    Provided that the reference in this Explanation to the last preceding census of which the relevant figures have been published shall, until the relevant figures for the first census taken after the year 2026 have been published, be construed as a reference to the 2001 census.
Simplified_Description: The number of seats reserved in any State or Union territory shall bear the same proportion to the total number. of seats allotted to that State 2 [or Union territory] in the House of the People as the population of the Scheduled Castes in the State. Seats reserved for Scheduled Tribes in Assam shall bear a proportion not less than the total population of that State.
Subject: Special Provisions relating to certain classes
Key_Points: Mandates the reservation of seats for Scheduled Castes (SCs) and Scheduled Tribes (STs) in the Lok Sabha (House of the People).
The number of seats reserved in a state or UT is to be in proportion to the population of SCs/STs in that state/UT.
This is a form of political reservation to ensure representation for these communities.
Historical_Context: This was a crucial measure adopted by the Constituent Assembly to ensure that historically marginalized and disadvantaged communities (SCs and STs) get adequate representation in the country's highest law-making body. This provision was originally intended for a limited period but has been extended successively by constitutional amendments. As per Article 334, this reservation is currently set to last until 2030.
Landmark_Cases: The principle of political reservation is a foundational aspect of India's affirmative action policy.
Related_Articles: Article 332 (Reservation of seats for SCs and STs in State Assemblies)
Article 334 (Period for which reservation is to have effect)

Title: Representation of the Anglo-Indian Community in the House of the People
Original_Description: Notwithstanding anything in article 81, the President may, if he is of opinion that the Anglo-Indian community is not adequately represented in the House of the People, nominate not more than two members of that community to the House of the People.
Simplified_Description: The President may, if he is of opinion that the Anglo-Indian community is not adequately represented, nominate not more than two members of that community.
Subject: Special Provisions relating to certain classes
Key_Points: Empowered the President to nominate up to two members from the Anglo-Indian community to the Lok Sabha.
This was a discretionary power, to be used if the President felt the community was not adequately represented through the election process.
This provision is no longer in effect.
Historical_Context: This special provision was made to ensure the representation of the small but distinct Anglo-Indian community. Like the reservation for SCs/STs, this was for a temporary period and was extended regularly. However, the 104th Constitutional Amendment Act, 2019, did not extend the reservation for Anglo-Indians, and thus this provision ceased to have effect from January 25, 2020.
Landmark_Cases: This article is now of historical importance.
Related_Articles: Article 334 (Period for which reservation is to have effect)

Title: Reservation of seats for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes in the Legislative Assemblies of the States
Original_Description:
(1) Seats shall be reserved for the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes, except the Scheduled Tribes in the autonomous districts of Assam, in the Legislative Assembly of every State.

 

(2) Seats shall be reserved also for the autonomous districts in the Legislative Assembly of the State of Assam.

 

(3) The number of seats reserved for the Scheduled Castes or the Scheduled Tribes in the Legislative Assembly of any State under clause (1) shall bear, as nearly as may be, the same proportion to the total number of seats in the Assembly as the population of the Scheduled Castes in the State or of the Scheduled Tribes in the State or part of the State, as the case may be, in respect of which seats are so reserved, bears to the total population of the State.

 

(3A) Notwithstanding anything contained in clause (3), until the taking effect, under article 170, of the readjustment, on the basis of the first census after the year 2026, of the number of seats in the Legislative Assemblies of the States of Arunachal Pradesh, Meghalaya, Mizoram and Nagaland, the seats which shall be reserved for the Scheduled Tribes in the Legislative Assembly of any such State shall be,—

 

(a) if all the seats in the Legislative Assembly of such State in existence on the date of coming into force of the Constitution (Fifty-seventh Amendment) Act, 1987 (hereafter in this clause referred to as the existing Assembly) are held by members of the Scheduled Tribes, all the seats except one;

 

(b) in any other case, such number of seats as bears to the total number of seats, a proportion not less than the number (as on the said date) of members belonging to the Scheduled Tribes in the existing Assembly bears to the total number of seats in the existing Assembly.

 

(3B) Notwithstanding anything contained in clause (3), until the re-adjustment, under article 170, takes effect on the basis of the first census after the year 2026, of the number of seats in the Legislative Assembly of the State of Tripura, the seats which shall be reserved for the Scheduled Tribes in the Legislative Assembly shall be, such number of seats as bears to the total number of seats, a proportion not less than the number, as on the date of coming into force of the Constitution (Seventysecond Amendment) Act, 1992, of members belonging to the Scheduled Tribes in the Legislative Assembly in existence on the said date bears to the total number of seats in that Assembly.

 

(4) The number of seats reserved for an autonomous district in the Legislative Assembly of the State of Assam shall bear to the total number of seats in that Assembly a proportion not less than the population of the district bears to the total population of the State.

 

(5) The constituencies for the seats reserved for any autonomous district of Assam shall not comprise any area outside that district.

 

(6) No person who is not a member of a Scheduled Tribe of any autonomous district of the State of Assam shall be eligible for election to the Legislative Assembly of the State from any constituency of that district

 

     Provided that for elections to the Legislative Assembly of the State of Assam, the representation of the Scheduled Tribes and non-Scheduled Tribes in the constituencies included in the Bodoland Territorial Areas District, so notified, and existing prior to the constitution of Bodoland Territorial Areas District, shall be maintained.
Simplified_Description: Seats shall be reserved for Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes in the autonomous districts of Assam, in the Legislative Assembly of every State. Seats will be reserved also for the Autonomous districts in the Legislative Assembly of the State of Assam.
Subject: Special Provisions relating to certain classes
Key_Points: Mandates the reservation of seats for Scheduled Castes (SCs) and Scheduled Tribes (STs) in the Legislative Assembly of every state.
The number of seats reserved is to be in proportion to the population of SCs/STs in that state.
This ensures political representation for these communities at the state level.
Historical_Context: This is the state-level counterpart to Article 330. It extends the principle of political reservation for SCs and STs to the state legislatures, ensuring their voice in state-level governance. This reservation has also been extended periodically along with the Lok Sabha reservations.
Landmark_Cases: This is a foundational article for state-level political representation.
Related_Articles: Article 330 (Reservation of seats for SCs and STs in the Lok Sabha)
Article 334 (Period for which reservation is to have effect)

Title: Representation of the Anglo-Indian community in the Legislative Assemblies of the States
