Original_Description: Notwithstanding anything in article 170, the Governor of a State may, if he is of opinion that the Anglo-Indian community needs representation in the Legislative Assembly of the State and is not adequately represented therein, nominate one member of that community to the Assembly.
Simplified_Description: The Governor of a State may, if he is of opinion that the Anglo-Indian community needs representation in the Legislative Assembly, nominate one member of that community to the Assembly.
Subject: Special Provisions relating to certain classes
Key_Points: Empowered the Governor of a state to nominate one member from the Anglo-Indian community to the State Legislative Assembly.
This was a discretionary power, to be used if the Governor felt the community was not adequately represented.
This provision is no longer in effect.
Historical_Context: This was the state-level counterpart to Article 331. This provision was also not extended by the 104th Constitutional Amendment Act, 2019, and ceased to have effect from January 25, 2020.
Landmark_Cases: This article is now of historical importance.
Related_Articles: Article 331 (Similar provision for the Lok Sabha)
Article 334 (Period for which reservation is to have effect)

Title: Reservation of seats and special representation to cease after certain period
Original_Description:
Notwithstanding anything in the foregoing provisions of this Part, the provisions of this Constitution relating to —

 

(a) the reservation of seats for the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes in the House of the People and in the Legislative Assemblies of the States; and

 

(b) the representation of the Anglo-Indian community in the House of the People and in the Legislative Assemblies of the States by nomination,

 

shall cease to have effect on the expiration of a period of eighty years in respect of clause (a) and seventy years in respect of clause (b) from the commencement of this Constitution:

 

    Provided that nothing in this article shall affect any representation in the House of the People or in the Legislative Assembly of a State until the dissolution of the then existing House or Assembly, as the case may be.
Simplified_Description: The reservation of seats for Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes in the House of the People and in the Legislative Assemblies of the States shall cease to have effect on the expiration of a period of eighty years in respect of clause (a) and seventy years inrespect of clause(b) from the commencement of this Constitution.
Subject: Special Provisions relating to certain classes
Key_Points: Specifies the time limit for the political reservations for SCs, STs, and the Anglo-Indian community.
Originally, this period was set for ten years.
It has been extended every ten years through constitutional amendments.
The 104th Amendment Act, 2019, extended the reservation for SCs and STs for another ten years (up to 2030) but did not extend it for the Anglo-Indian community.
Historical_Context: The initial ten-year sunset clause reflected the hope that the social and economic conditions of the marginalized communities would improve sufficiently to make reservations unnecessary. However, successive governments have found it necessary to continue these provisions to ensure continued political representation. The discontinuation of the Anglo-Indian nomination reflects a view that the community is no longer in need of this special provision.
Landmark_Cases: The constitutional amendments extending the reservation period under this article have all been passed by Parliament.

Title: Claims of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes to services and posts
Original_Description:
The claims of the members of the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes shall be taken into consideration, consistently with the maintenance of efficiency of administration, in the making of appointments to services and posts in connection with the affairs of the Union or of a State:

 

     Provided that nothing in this article shall prevent in making of any provision in favour of the members of the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes for relaxation in qualifying marks in any examination or lowering the standards of evaluation, for reservation in matters of promotion to any class or classes of services or posts in connection with the affairs of the Union or of a State.
Simplified_Description: The claims of the members of the Scheduled Castes and the. Scheduled Tribes shall be taken into consideration, consistently with the maintenance of efficiency of administration, in the. making of appointments to services and posts in connection with the affairs of the Union.
Subject: Special Provisions relating to certain classes
Key_Points: Mandates that the claims of SCs and STs shall be considered in making appointments to public services and posts.
This consideration must be consistent with the 'maintenance of efficiency of administration'.
A proviso allows for relaxation of qualifying marks or standards of evaluation for SCs/STs in matters of reservation and promotion.
Historical_Context: This article provides the constitutional basis for reservations in government jobs (under Articles 16(4) and 16(4A)). The phrase 'consistently with the maintenance of efficiency of administration' has been a subject of intense debate. Opponents of reservation have cited it to argue against affirmative action, while proponents argue that efficiency is not compromised. The proviso, added by the 82nd Amendment Act, 2000, clarified that relaxations in standards are permissible.
Landmark_Cases: M. Nagaraj vs Union of India (2006): The Supreme Court held that any policy for reservation in promotions for SCs/STs must satisfy the conditions of backwardness, inadequate representation, and overall administrative efficiency.

Jarnail Singh vs Lachhmi Narain Gupta (2018): The court modified the Nagaraj judgment by holding that the state does not need to collect quantifiable data on the backwardness of SCs/STs but must apply the creamy layer principle to them in promotions.
Related_Articles: Article 16 (Equality of opportunity in public employment)
Article 46 (DPSP to promote interests of weaker sections)

Title: Special provision for Anglo-Indian community in certain services
Original_Description:
(1) During the first two years after the commencement of this Constitution, appointments of members of the Anglo-Indian community to posts in the railway, customs, postal and telegraph services of the Union shall be made on the same basis as immediately before the fifteenth day of August, 1947.

 

During every succeeding period of two years, the number of posts reserved for the members of the said community in the said services shall, as nearly as possible, be less by ten per cent. than the numbers so reserved during the immediately preceding period of two years:

 

     Provided that at the end of ten years from the commencement of this Constitution all such reservations shall cease.

 

(2) Nothing in clause (1) shall bar the appointment of members of the Anglo-Indian community to posts other than, or in addition to, those reserved for the community under that clause if such members are found qualified for appointment on merit as compared with the members of other communities.
Simplified_Description: appointments of members of the Anglo-Indian community to posts in the railway, customs, postal and telegraph services of the Union.
Subject: Special Provisions relating to certain classes
Key_Points: Provided for special reservations for the Anglo-Indian community in certain Union services like railways, customs, and postal services.
This was a transitional provision.
The reservations were to be progressively reduced every two years and were to cease completely after ten years from the commencement of the Constitution.
Historical_Context: The Anglo-Indian community had significant representation in certain services during the British era. This article was a temporary measure to ensure that their employment opportunities were not abruptly cut off after independence. As the ten-year period has long passed, this article is now obsolete.
Landmark_Cases: This was a transitional provision and is no longer operative.
Related_Articles: This is a historical provision with no current applicability.

Title: Special provision with respect to educational grants for the benefit of Anglo-Indian community
Original_Description:
During the first three financial years after the commencement of this Constitution, the same grants, if any, shall be made by the Union and by each State for the benefit of the Anglo-Indian community in respect of education as were made in the financial year ending on the thirty-first day of March, 1948.

 

During every succeeding period of three years the grants may be less by ten per cent. than those for the immediately preceding period of three years :

 

     Provided that at the end of ten years from the commencement of this Constitution such grants, to the extent to which they are a special concession to the AngloIndian community, shall cease:

 

     Provided further that no educational institution shall be entitled to receive any grant under this article unless at least forty per cent. of the annual admissions therein are made available to members of communities other than the Anglo-Indian community.
Simplified_Description: During the first three financial years after the commencement of this Constitution, the same grants, if any, shall be made by the Union and by each State for the benefit of the Anglo-Indian community in respect of education. The grants may be less by ten per cent. than those for the immediately preceding period of three years.
Subject: Special Provisions relating to certain classes
Key_Points: Provided for special educational grants from the Union and States for the benefit of the Anglo-Indian community.
This was a transitional provision.
The grants were to be progressively reduced every three years and were to cease completely after ten years from the commencement of the Constitution.
Historical_Context: This was another temporary safeguard for the Anglo-Indian community, ensuring the continuity of educational grants for their institutions for a limited period after independence. This article is now obsolete.
Landmark_Cases: This was a transitional provision and is no longer operative.
Related_Articles: This is a historical provision with no current applicability.

Title: National Commission for Scheduled Castes
Simplified_Description: The National Commission for the Scheduled Castes will have the power to regulate its own procedure. The Commission will have all the powers of a civil court trying a suit and in particular in respect of the following matters.
Subject: Special Provisions relating to certain classes
Key_Points: Establishes a constitutional body, the National Commission for Scheduled Castes (NCSC).
The Commission's duty is to investigate and monitor all matters relating to the constitutional safeguards for Scheduled Castes.
It has the power to inquire into specific complaints regarding the deprivation of rights of SCs.
The Commission has the powers of a civil court while investigating any matter.
It submits an annual report to the President, which is then laid before Parliament.
Historical_Context: Originally, Article 338 provided for a single Special Officer for SCs and STs. The 65th Amendment Act, 1990, replaced the officer with a multi-member National Commission for SCs and STs. Later, the 89th Amendment Act, 2003, bifurcated this body, creating the NCSC under Article 338 and a separate National Commission for Scheduled Tribes (NCST) under Article 338A. This was done to give focused attention to the distinct issues faced by each community.
Landmark_Cases: The reports and recommendations of the NCSC are significant in shaping government policy and are often cited in litigation concerning the rights of Scheduled Castes.

Title: National Commission for Scheduled Tribes
Simplified_Description: There shall be a Commission for the Scheduled Tribes. The Commission shall have the power to regulate its own procedure. The Union and every State Government shall consult the Commission on all major policy matters.
Subject: Special Provisions relating to certain classes
Key_Points: Establishes a constitutional body, the National Commission for Scheduled Tribes (NCST).
The Commission's functions are parallel to those of the NCSC, but focused exclusively on the Scheduled Tribes.
It investigates safeguards, inquires into complaints, and participates in the planning process for the development of STs.
It also has the powers of a civil court and submits an annual report to the President.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 89th Amendment Act, 2003. It was created by bifurcating the erstwhile combined National Commission for SCs and STs. This was done in recognition of the fact that the issues and challenges faced by Scheduled Tribes are often distinct from those of Scheduled Castes and require specialized attention.
Landmark_Cases: The NCST plays a crucial role in matters related to tribal rights, land alienation, and implementation of laws like the Forest Rights Act, 2006.

Title: Control of the Union over the administration of Scheduled Areas and the welfare of Scheduled Tribes
Original_Description:
(1) The President may at any time and shall, at the expiration of ten years from the commencement of this Constitution by order appoint a Commission to report on the administration of the Scheduled Areas and the welfare of the Scheduled Tribes in the States .

 

  The order may define the composition, powers and procedure of the Commission and may contain such incidental or ancillary provisions as the President may consider necessary or desirable.

 

(2) The executive power of the Union shall extend to the giving of directions to a State as to the drawing up and execution of schemes specified in the direction to be essential for the welfare of the Scheduled Tribes in the State.
Simplified_Description: The President may at any time and shall, at the expiration of ten years from the commencement of this Constitution by order appoint a Commission to report on the administration of the Scheduled Areas. The order may define the composition, powers and procedure of the Commission.
Subject: Special Provisions relating to certain classes
Key_Points: Empowers the President to appoint a Commission to report on the administration of Scheduled Areas and the welfare of Scheduled Tribes.
The first such commission was mandatory within ten years of the Constitution's commencement.
Gives the Union executive the power to give directions to states regarding the implementation of welfare schemes for Scheduled Tribes.
Historical_Context: This article provides for Union oversight and control over the administration of tribal welfare, which is a matter of national importance. It ensures that the central government can guide and direct state governments to ensure that welfare schemes are properly implemented. The first such commission was appointed in 1960 under the chairmanship of U.N. Dhebar.
Landmark_Cases: This is an administrative and power-conferring article.
Related_Articles: Article 244 (Administration of Scheduled Areas and Tribal Areas)

Title: Appointment of a Commission to investigate the conditions of backward classes
Original_Description:
(1) The President may by order appoint a Commission consisting of such persons as he thinks fit to investigate the conditions of socially and educationally backward classes within the territory of India and the difficulties under which they labour and to make recommendations as to the steps that should be taken by the Union or any State to remove such difficulties and to improve their condition and as to the grants that should be made for the purpose by the Union or any State and the conditions subject to which such grants should be made, and the order appointing such Commission shall define the procedure to be followed by the Commission.

 

(2) A Commission so appointed shall investigate the matters referred to them and present to the President a report setting out the facts as found by them and making such recommendations as they think proper.

 

(3) The President shall cause a copy of the report so presented together with a memorandum explaining the action taken thereon to be laid before each House of Parliament.
Simplified_Description: The President may by order appoint a Commission consisting of such persons as he thinks fit to investigate the conditions of socially and educationally backward classes. The order appointing such Commission shall define the procedure to be followed by the Commission.
Subject: Special Provisions relating to certain classes
Key_Points: Empowers the President to appoint a Commission to investigate the conditions of 'socially and educationally backward classes' (SEBCs), also known as Other Backward Classes (OBCs).
The Commission is tasked with identifying these classes, investigating their conditions, and recommending steps for their upliftment.
The President must lay the Commission's report before Parliament along with a memorandum explaining the action taken.
Historical_Context: This article is the constitutional basis for identifying OBCs and creating policies for them. Two major commissions have been appointed under this article: the First Backward Classes Commission (Kaka Kalelkar Commission) in 1953, and the Second Backward Classes Commission (B.P. Mandal Commission) in 1979. The recommendations of the Mandal Commission, implemented in 1990, led to the introduction of reservations for OBCs in central government jobs.
Landmark_Cases: Indra Sawhney vs Union of India (1992) ('Mandal Case'): The Supreme Court upheld the implementation of the Mandal Commission's recommendations for 27% reservation for OBCs in government jobs, laying down several principles like the 50% ceiling and the 'creamy layer' concept.
Related_Articles: Article 15(4), 16(4) (Enabling provisions for making special provisions for backward classes)

Title: Scheduled Castes
Original_Description:
(1) The President 2 [may with respect to any State 3 [or Union territory], and where it is a State, after consultation with the Governor thereof, by public notification, specify the castes, races or tribes or parts of or groups within castes, races or tribes which shall for the purposes of this Constitution be deemed to be Scheduled Castes in relation to that State 2[or Union territory, as the case may be.

 

(2) Parliament may by law include in or exclude from the list of Scheduled Castes specified in a notification issued under clause (1) any caste, race or tribe or part of or group within any caste, race or tribe, but save as aforesaid a notification issued under the said clause shall not be varied by any subsequent notification.
Simplified_Description: The President 2 [may] with respect to any State 3 [or Union territory], and where it is a State, after consultation with the Governor thereof, by public notification. Parliament may by law include in or exclude from the list of Scheduled Castes specified in a notification.
Subject: Special Provisions relating to certain classes
Key_Points: Defines the procedure for specifying which castes are to be deemed 'Scheduled Castes' (SCs).
The President, after consulting the Governor of a state, issues a public notification specifying the list of SCs for that state.
Once this list is notified, any inclusion or exclusion from it can only be done by an Act of Parliament.
The initial Presidential notification cannot be modified by any subsequent notification.
Historical_Context: This article provides a clear and authoritative procedure for the identification of Scheduled Castes. The power is centralized to ensure a uniform and objective process. The initial lists were largely based on the 'Depressed Classes' list of the Government of India Act, 1935. The requirement of a parliamentary act for any modification makes the process robust and subject to legislative scrutiny.
Landmark_Cases: State of Kerala vs N.M. Thomas (1976): The Supreme Court has held that the list of Scheduled Castes is final and cannot be altered by courts or state governments.

Title: Scheduled Tribes
Original_Description:
(1) The President may with respect to any State or Union territory, and where it is a State 4, after consultation with the Governor thereof, by public notification6 , specify the tribes or tribal communities or parts of or groups within tribes or tribal communities which shall for the purposes of this Constitution be deemed to be Scheduled Tribes in relation to that State or Union territory, as the case may be.

 

(2) Parliament may by law include in or exclude from the list of Scheduled Tribes specified in a notification issued under clause (1) any tribe or tribal community or part of or group within any tribe or tribal community, but save as aforesaid a notification issued under the said clause shall not be varied by any subsequent notification.
Simplified_Description: The President may with respect to any State or Union territory, and where it is a State 4, after consultation with the Governor thereof, by public notification6 , specify the tribes or tribal communities. Parliament may by law include in or exclude from the list of Scheduled Tribes.
Subject: Special Provisions relating to certain classes
Key_Points: Defines the procedure for specifying which tribes or tribal communities are to be deemed 'Scheduled Tribes' (STs).
The procedure is identical to that for Scheduled Castes under Article 341.
The President, after consulting the Governor, issues the initial notification.
Any subsequent modification (inclusion or exclusion) can only be done by an Act of Parliament.
Historical_Context: This article provides the authoritative mechanism for the identification of Scheduled Tribes. This process is crucial as inclusion in the ST list makes the community eligible for the various safeguards and benefits provided under the Constitution, including political reservations and special development programs.
Landmark_Cases: Courts have repeatedly held that they do not have the power to declare any tribe as a Scheduled Tribe; this power is vested exclusively with the President and Parliament as per this article.

Title: Official language of the Union
Original_Description:
(1) The official language of the Union shall be Hindi in Devanagari script.

The form of numerals to be used for the official purposes of the Union shall be the international form of Indian numerals.

 

(2) Notwithstanding anything in clause (1), for a period of fifteen years from the commencement of this Constitution, the English language shall continue to be used for all the official purposes of the Union for which it was being used immediately before such commencement:

 

   Provided that the President may, during the said period, by order authorise the use of the Hindi language in addition to the English language and of the Devanagari form of numerals in addition to the international form of Indian numerals for any of the official purposes of the Union.

 

(3) Notwithstanding anything in this article, Parliament may by law provide for the use, after the said period of fifteen years, of —

 

(a) the English language, or

 

(b) the Devanagari form of numerals,

 

for such purposes as may be specified in the law.
Simplified_Description: The official language of the Union shall be Hindi in Devanagari script. The form of numerals to be used for the official purposes of the union shall be the international form of Indian numerals. For a period of fifteen years from the commencement of this Constitution, the English language shall continue to beused for all official purposes.
Subject: Official Languages
Key_Points: Declares Hindi in Devanagari script as the official language of the Union.
Specifies the use of the international form of Indian numerals for official purposes.
Provided for the continued use of English for all official purposes of the Union for an initial period of 15 years.
Empowers Parliament to provide for the use of English even after the 15-year period.
Historical_Context: The choice of official language was one of the most contentious issues in the Constituent Assembly. This article represents a compromise. While Hindi was adopted as the official language, the continuation of English was guaranteed for 15 years to accommodate non-Hindi speaking regions. The Official Languages Act, 1963, enacted by Parliament under clause (3), provided for the indefinite continuation of English as an associate official language, following widespread protests in southern states.
Landmark_Cases: This article and the Official Languages Act form the legal basis of India's language policy.
Related_Articles: Article 344 (Commission and Committee of Parliament on official language)
Article 351 (Directive for development of the Hindi language)

Title: Commission and Committee of Parliament on official language
Simplified_Description: The President shall, at the expiration of five years from the commencement of this Constitution, by order constitute a Commission which shall consist of a Chairman and such other members representing the different languages specified in the Eighth Schedule. The Commission shall have due regard to the industrial, cultural and scientific advancement of India.
Subject: Official Languages
Key_Points: Provided for the constitution of a Commission on Official Language by the President, five years after the Constitution's commencement and again after ten years.
The Commission's duty was to make recommendations on the progressive use of Hindi, restrictions on the use of English, and other language-related issues.
Mandated the creation of a Joint Parliamentary Committee (JPC) to examine the Commission's recommendations and report to the President.
Historical_Context: This article provided a mechanism to periodically review the progress of Hindi and the status of English as the official language. The first Official Language Commission was appointed in 1955 under B.G. Kher, and the JPC was constituted in 1957. Based on their recommendations, the Official Languages Act, 1963 was eventually passed.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article related to the implementation of the official language policy.

Title: Official language or languages of a State
Original_Description:
Subject to the provisions of articles 346 and 347, the Legislature of a State may by law adopt any one or more of the languages in use in the State or Hindi as the language or languages to be used for all or any of the official purposes of that State:

 

   Provided that, until the Legislature of the State otherwise provides by law, the English language shall continue to be used for those official purposes within the State for which it was being used immediately before the commencement of this Constitution.
Simplified_Description: Provided that, until the Legislature of the State otherwise provides by law, the English language shall continue to be used for those official purposes within the State for which it was being used immediately before the commencement of this Constitution.
Subject: Official Languages
Key_Points: Empowers the legislature of a state to adopt one or more languages in use in that state, or Hindi, as its official language(s).
Until the state legislature decides otherwise, English would continue to be used for official purposes within the state.
This gives states the freedom to choose their own official language based on their linguistic demographics.
Historical_Context: Recognizing India's linguistic diversity, this article grants autonomy to states in the matter of official language. As a result, different states have adopted different official languages. For example, Karnataka has adopted Kannada, Tamil Nadu has adopted Tamil, while some states in the North have adopted Hindi.
Landmark_Cases: This article is the basis for state-level official language acts.
Related_Articles: Article 346, 347 (Relating to inter-state communication and special provisions)

Title: Official language for communication between one State and another or between a State and the Union
Original_Description:
The language for the time being authorised for use in the Union for official purposes shall be the official language for communication between one State and another State and between a State and the Union:

 

   Provided that if two or more States agree that the Hindi language should be the official language for communication between such States, that language may be used for such communication.
Simplified_Description: The language for the time being authorised for use in the Union for official purposes shall be the official language for communication between one State and another State and between a State and the Union.Provided that if two or more States agree that the Hindi language should be theOfficial language.
Subject: Official Languages
Key_Points: Specifies the language for inter-governmental communication.
The official language of the Union (currently English and Hindi) is the language for communication between the Union and a state, and between different states.
It provides that two or more states can agree to use Hindi for communication among themselves.
Historical_Context: This article provides a practical solution for communication in a multi-lingual federal system. By default, it designates the language of the Union (English or Hindi) as the link language, ensuring that all state governments can communicate with the Centre and with each other in a common language.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article for inter-governmental communication.

Title: Special provision relating to language spoken by a section of the population of a State
Original_Description: On a demand being made in that behalf the President may, if he is satisfied that a substantial proportion of the population of a State desire the use of any language spoken by them to be recognised by that State, direct that such language shall also be officially recognised throughout that State or any part thereof for such purpose as he may specify.
Simplified_Description: The President may, if he is satisfied that a substantial proportion of the population of a State desire the use of any language spoken by them to be recognised by that State, direct that such language shall also be officially recognised.
Subject: Official Languages
Key_Points: Empowers the President to direct a state to officially recognize a language.
This can be done if a 'substantial proportion' of the population of that state demands the recognition of their language.
The recognition can be for the whole state or a part of it, and for specific purposes.
Historical_Context: This is a safeguard for linguistic minorities within a state. If a state adopts an official language that is not the mother tongue of a significant minority, this article allows that minority group to appeal to the President for the official recognition of their language for certain purposes (e.g., in local administration, schools).
Landmark_Cases: This provision acts as a protective measure for linguistic minorities.

Title: Language to be used in the Supreme Court and in the High Courts and for Acts, Bills, etc
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything in the foregoing provisions of this Part, until Parliament by law otherwise provides —

 

(a) all proceedings in the Supreme Court and in every High Court,

 

(b) the authoritative texts —

 

(i) of all Bills to be introduced or amendments thereto to be moved in either House of Parliament or in the House or either House of the Legislature of a State,

 

(ii) of all Acts passed by Parliament or the Legislature of a State and of all Ordinances promulgated by the President or the Governor of a State, and

 

(iii) of all orders, rules, regulations and bye-laws issued under this Constitution or under any law made by Parliament or the Legislature of a State,

 

shall be in the English language.

 

(2) Notwithstanding anything in sub-clause (a) of clause (1), the Governor of a State may, with the previous consent of the President, authorise the use of the Hindi language, or any other language used for any official purposes of the State, in proceedings in the High Court having its principal seat in that State: Provided that nothing in this clause shall apply to any judgment, decree or order passed or made by such High Court.

 

(3) Notwithstanding anything in sub-clause (b) of clause (1), where the Legislature of a State has prescribed any language other than the English language for use in Bills introduced in, or Acts passed by, the Legislature of the State or in Ordinances promulgated by the Governor of the State or in any order, rule, regulation or bye-law referred to in paragraph (iii) of that sub-clause, a translation of the same in the English language published under the authority of the Governor of the State in the Official Gazette of that State shall be deemed to be the authoritative text thereof in the English language under this article.
Simplified_Description: Until Parliament by law otherwise provides, all proceedings in the Supreme Court and in every High Court, shall be in the English language. The Governor of a State may authorise the use of the Hindi language, or any other language used for any official purposes of the State.
Subject: Official Languages
Key_Points: Mandates that English shall be the language for all proceedings in the Supreme Court and every High Court.
Also states that the authoritative texts of all Bills, Acts, Ordinances, Rules, and Regulations at both the Union and State levels shall be in English.

A Governor can, with the prior consent of the President, authorize the use of Hindi or the state's official language in the proceedings of the High Court, but this does not apply to judgments, decrees, and orders.
If a state uses another language for its Acts and Bills, an official English translation must be published, which will be deemed the authoritative text.
Historical_Context: This provision was adopted to ensure uniformity, clarity, and continuity in the legal and judicial system across the country, as the entire body of pre-existing law and legal precedent was in English. While there are provisions for using other languages, English remains the authoritative language of the law and the higher judiciary.
Landmark_Cases: This article has been the subject of debates regarding the use of regional languages in High Courts, but its provisions currently remain in force.

Title: Special procedure for enactment of certain laws relating to language
Original_Description: During the period of fifteen years from the commencement of this Constitution, no Bill or amendment making provision for the language to be used for any of the purposes mentioned in clause (1) of article 348 shall be introduced or moved in either House of Parliament without the previous sanction of the President, and the President shall not give his sanction to the introduction of any such Bill or the moving of any such amendment except after he has taken into consideration the recommendations of the Commission constituted under clause (1) of article 344 and the report of the Committee constituted under clause (4) of that article.
Simplified_Description: No Bill or amendment making provision for the language to be used for any of the purposes mentioned in clause (1) of article 348 shall be introduced or moved in either House of Parliament without the previous sanction of the President. The President shall not give his sanction to the introduction of any such Bill or the moving of anySuch amendment except after he has taken into consideration the recommendations of the Commission
Subject: Official Languages
Key_Points: This was a transitional provision.
It stipulated a special procedure for any law seeking to change the language used in the judiciary and for legal texts (as per Article 348) during the first 15 years of the Constitution.
Such a bill required the prior sanction of the President, who in turn had to consider the recommendations of the Official Language Commission and the Parliamentary Committee.
Historical_Context: This article was designed as a safeguard to ensure that any change to the language of the judiciary and the law during the initial 15-year period was made after careful consideration and expert advice. As the 15-year period has long passed, this article is now obsolete.
Landmark_Cases: This was a transitional provision and is no longer operative.
Related_Articles: Article 344 (Commission and Committee on official language)

Title: Language to be used in representations for redress of grievances
Original_Description: Every person shall be entitled to submit a representation for the redress of any grievance to any officer or authority of the Union or a State in any of the languages used in the Union or in the State, as the case may be.
Simplified_Description: Every person shall be entitled to submit a representation for the redress of any grievance to any officer or authority of the Union or a State in any of the languages used.
Subject: Official Languages
Key_Points: Guarantees the right of every person to submit a representation for the redress of grievances to any government authority.
The representation can be made in any of the languages used in the Union or in the state.
This means a person cannot be forced to submit a petition or representation only in the official language.
Historical_Context: This is a practical and important right that ensures access to justice and administration for all citizens, regardless of their knowledge of the official language. It protects linguistic minorities and ensures that language is not a barrier to seeking redress from the government.
Landmark_Cases: This article protects the linguistic rights of individuals in their dealings with the government.

Title: Facilities for instruction in mother-tongue at primary stage
Original_Description: It shall be the endeavour of every State and of every local authority within the State to provide adequate facilities for instruction in the mother-tongue at the primary stage of education to children belonging to linguistic minority groups; and the President may issue such directions to any State as he considers necessary or proper for securing the provision of such facilities.
Simplified_Description: It shall be the endeavour of every State and of every local authority within the State to provide adequate facilities for instruction in the mother-tongue at the primary stage of education.
Subject: Official Languages
Key_Points: Directs every state and local authority to provide adequate facilities for primary education in the mother tongue.
This is specifically for children belonging to linguistic minority groups.
The President can issue directions to any state to ensure the provision of these facilities.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 7th Amendment Act, 1956, based on the recommendations of the States Reorganisation Commission. It is a crucial safeguard for linguistic minorities, aiming to protect their languages and cultures by ensuring that children can receive their foundational education in their mother tongue.
Landmark_Cases: This provision is a key principle in education policy, though its implementation varies across states.

Title: Special Officer for linguistic minorities
Original_Description:
(1) There shall be a Special Officer for linguistic minorities to be appointed by the President.

 

(2) It shall be the duty of the Special Officer to investigate all matters relating to the safeguards provided for linguistic minorities under this Constitution and report to the President upon those matters at such intervals as the President may direct, and the President shall cause all such reports to be laid before each House of Parliament, and sent to the Governments of the States concerned.
Simplified_Description: There shall be a Special Officer for linguistic minorities to be appointed by the President. (2) It shall be the duty of the Special Officer to investigate all matters relating to the safeguards provided for linguistic minority under this Constitution.
Subject: Official Languages
Key_Points: Mandates the appointment of a 'Special Officer for linguistic minorities' by the President.
This officer is also known as the Commissioner for Linguistic Minorities.
Their duty is to investigate all matters related to the constitutional safeguards for linguistic minorities.
The Commissioner submits reports to the President, which are then laid before Parliament and sent to the concerned state governments.
Historical_Context: This article was also inserted by the 7th Amendment Act, 1956, to provide an institutional mechanism for monitoring the implementation of safeguards for linguistic minorities. The office of the Commissioner for Linguistic Minorities acts as a watchdog for the rights of these communities.
Landmark_Cases: The reports of the Commissioner for Linguistic Minorities are important documents that highlight the issues faced by these communities.

Title: Directive for development of the Hindi language
Original_Description: It shall be the duty of the Union to promote the spread of the Hindi language, to develop it so that it may serve as a medium of expression for all the elements of the composite culture of India and to secure its enrichment by assimilating without interfering with its genius, the forms, style and expressions used in Hindustani and in the other languages of India specified in the Eighth Schedule, and by drawing, wherever necessary or desirable, for its vocabulary, primarily on Sanskrit and secondarily on other languages.
Simplified_Description: It shall be the duty of the Union to promote the spread of the Hindi language. The language is primarily based on Sanskrit and secondarily on other languages.
Subject: Official Languages
Key_Points: This is a directive, not a mandatory provision.
It lays down the duty of the Union to promote the spread and development of the Hindi language.
The goal is to develop Hindi as a medium of expression for India's composite culture.
It directs that Hindi should be enriched by assimilating vocabulary from Hindustani and other languages of the Eighth Schedule, while drawing primarily on Sanskrit.
Historical_Context: This article represents the aspirational aspect of the language compromise in the Constituent Assembly. It envisions Hindi not as a language to be imposed, but as one to be developed and enriched into a truly national link language that reflects the diversity of India. It guides the language promotion policies of the Union government.
Landmark_Cases: This is a directive and guides the official language policy of the Union.

Title: Proclamation of Emergency
Original_Description:
(1) If the President is satisfied that a grave emergency exists whereby the security of India or of any part of the territory thereof is threatened, whether by war or external aggression or armed rebellion, he may, by Proclamation, make a declaration to that effect in respect of the whole of India or of such part of the territory thereof as may be specified in the Proclamation.

 

   Explanation. — A Proclamation of Emergency declaring that the security of India or any part of the territory thereof is threatened by war or by external aggression or by armed rebellion may be made before the actual occurrence of war or of any such aggression or rebellion, if the President is satisfied that there is imminent danger thereof. 

 

(2) A Proclamation issued under clause (1) may be varied or revoked by a subsequent Proclamation.

 

(3) The President shall not issue a Proclamation under clause (1) or a Proclamation varying such Proclamation unless the decision of the Union Cabinet (that is to say, the Council consisting of the Prime Minister and other Ministers of Cabinet rank appointed under article 75) that such a Proclamation may be issued has been communicated to him in writing.

 

(4) Every Proclamation issued under this article shall be laid before each House of Parliament and shall, except where it is a Proclamation revoking a previous Proclamation, cease to operate at the expiration of one month unless before the expiration of that period it has been approved by resolutions of both Houses of Parliament:

 

   Provided that if any such Proclamation (not being a Proclamation revoking a previous Proclamation) is issued at a time when the House of the People has been dissolved, or the dissolution of the House of the People takes place during the period of one month referred to in this clause, and if a resolution approving the Proclamation has been passed by the Council of States, but no resolution with respect to such Proclamation has been passed by the House of the People before the expiration of that period, the Proclamation shall cease to operate at the expiration of thirty days from the date on which the House of the People first sits after its reconstitution, unless before the expiration of the said period of thirty days a resolution approving the Proclamation has been also passed by the House of the People.

 

(5) A Proclamation so approved shall, unless revoked, cease to operate on the expiration of a period of six months from the date of the passing of the second of the resolutions approving the Proclamation under clause (4):

 

   Provided that if and so often as a resolution approving the continuance in force of such a Proclamation is passed by both Houses of Parliament the Proclamation shall, unless revoked, continue in force for a further period of six months from the date on which it would otherwise have ceased to operate under this clause:

 

   Provided further that if the dissolution of the House of the People takes place during any such period of six months and a resolution approving the continuance in force of such Proclamation has been passed by the Council of States but no resolution with respect to the continuance in force of such Proclamation has been passed by the House of the People during the said period, the Proclamation shall cease to operate at the expiration of thirty days from the date on which the House of the People first sits after its reconstitution unless before the expiration of the said period of thirty days, a resolution approving the continuance in force of the Proclamation has been also passed by the House of the People.

 

(6) For the purposes of clauses (4) and (5), a resolution may be passed by either House of Parliament only by a majority of the total membership of that House and by a majority of not less than two-thirds of the Members of that House present and voting.

 

(7) Notwithstanding anything contained in the foregoing clauses, the President shall revoke a Proclamation issued under clause (1) or a Proclamation varying such Proclamation if the House of the People passes a resolution disapproving, or, as the case may be, disapproving the continuance in force of, such Proclamation.

 

(8) Where a notice in writing signed by not less than one-tenth of the total number of members of the House of the People has been given, of their intention to move a resolution for disapproving, or, as the case may be, for disapproving the continuance in force of, a Proclamation issued under clause (1) or a Proclamation varying such Proclamation, —

 

(a) to the Speaker, if the House is in session; or

 

(b) to the President, if the House is not in session,

 

a special sitting of the House shall be held within fourteen days from the date on which such notice is received by the Speaker, or, as the case may be, by the President, for the purpose of considering such resolution.

 

(9) The power conferred on the President by this article shall include the power to issue different Proclamations on different grounds, being war or external aggression or armed rebellion or imminent danger of war or external aggression or armed rebellion, whether or not there is a Proclamation already issued by the President under clause (1) and such Proclamation is in operation.
Simplified_Description: A Proclamation of Emergency declaring that the security of India or any part of the territory thereof is threatened by war or by external aggression or by armed rebellion may be made before the actual occurrence of war or of any such aggression or rebellion. A Proclamation issued under clause (1) may be varied or revoked by a subsequent Proclamation. Every Proclamation issued under this article shall be laid before each House of Parliament and shall, except where it is a Proclamation revoking a previous Proclamation, cease to operate at the expiration of one month. A Proclamation so approved by both Houses of Parliament will be allowed to continue. The Proclamation. shall, unless revoked, cease to operate on the expiration of a period of six months from the date of the passing of the second of the resolutions approving the Proclamation under clause (4): Provided that if and so often as a resolution approving the continuance in force of such a Proclamation is passed by both Houses of Parliament. A resolution may be passed by either House of Parliament only by a majority of the total membership of that House. The President shall revoke a Proclamation issued under clause (1) if the House of the People passes a resolution disapproving, or, as the case may be, disapproving the continuance in force of, such Proclamation. The power conferred on the President by this article shall include the power to issue different Proclamations on different grounds, being war or external aggression or armed rebellion or imminent danger of war. (9) The Proclamation already issued by the President under clause (1) is in operation.
Subject: Emergency Provisions
Key_Points: Allows the President to declare a National Emergency.
Grounds for emergency are: war, external aggression, or armed rebellion.
The President must have a written recommendation from the Union Cabinet.
The proclamation must be approved by both Houses of Parliament by a special majority within one month.
Once approved, it continues for six months and can be extended indefinitely with parliamentary approval every six months.
During a national emergency, the federal structure can become unitary, and fundamental rights can be suspended.
Historical_Context: This is a powerful and extraordinary provision. A national emergency was declared in 1962 (China war), 1971 (Pakistan war), and 1975 (on grounds of 'internal disturbance'). The 1975 emergency was highly controversial and led to the 44th Amendment Act, 1978, which introduced several safeguards to prevent its misuse. Key changes included replacing 'internal disturbance' with 'armed rebellion', making Cabinet's written advice mandatory, and requiring a special majority for parliamentary approval.
Landmark_Cases: Minerva Mills vs Union of India (1980): The Supreme Court held that the proclamation of a national emergency is subject to judicial review on the ground of mala fides or if it is based on wholly extraneous and irrelevant grounds.

Title: Effect of Proclamation of Emergency
Original_Description:
While a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation, then —

 

(a) notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, the executive power of the Union shall extend to the giving of directions to any State as to the manner in which the executive power thereof is to be exercised;

 

(b) the power of Parliament to make laws with respect to any matter shall include power to make laws conferring powers and imposing duties, or authorising the conferring of powers and the imposition of duties, upon the Union or officers and authorities of the Union as respects that matter, notwithstanding that it is one which is not enumerated in the Union List:

 

   Provided that where a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation only in any part of the territory of India, —

 

(i) the executive power of the Union to give directions under clause (a), and

 

(ii) the power of Parliament to make laws under clause (b),

 

shall also extend to any State other than a State in which or in any part of which the Proclamation of Emergency is in operation if and in so far as the security of India or any part of the territory thereof is threatened by activities in or in relation to the part of the territory of India in which the Proclamation of Emergency is in operation.
Simplified_Description: While a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation, the executive power of the Union shall extend to the giving of directions to any State. The power of Parliament to make laws with respect to any matter shall include the power to authorise the conferring of powers and the imposition of duties.
Subject: Emergency Provisions
Key_Points: Describes the effect of a National Emergency on Centre-State relations.
Executive effect: The Union executive can give directions to any state on any matter.
Legislative effect: Parliament gets the power to make laws on subjects in the State List.
This effectively converts the federal structure into a unitary one for the duration of the emergency.
Historical_Context: This article outlines the mechanism by which the central government assumes overriding powers during a national emergency. It allows for a swift and unified response to a national crisis by centralizing administrative and legislative authority, temporarily suspending the normal division of powers.
Landmark_Cases: This article defines the powers of the Union during an emergency.
Related_Articles: Article 250 (Parliament's power to legislate on State List during emergency)

Title: Application of provisions relating to distribution of revenues while a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation
Original_Description:
(1) The President may, while a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation, by order direct that all or any of the provisions of articles 268 to 279 shall for such period, not extending in any case beyond the expiration of the financial year in which such Proclamation ceases to operate, as may be specified in the order, have effect subject to such exceptions or modifications as he thinks fit.

 

(2) Every order made under clause (1) shall, as soon as may be after it is made, be laid before each House of Parliament.
Simplified_Description: The President may, while a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation, by order direct that all or any of the provisions of articles 268 to 279 shall for such period, not extending beyond the expiration of the financial year in which such Proclamation ceases to operate.
Subject: Emergency Provisions
Key_Points: Allows the President to modify the constitutional provisions related to the distribution of revenues between the Union and the States.
This power is available while a National Emergency is in operation.
Any such order must be laid before both Houses of Parliament.
Historical_Context: This provision gives the Union financial control during an emergency. It allows the President to alter the financial arrangements (like the sharing of taxes) to redirect resources towards managing the national crisis. This further strengthens the central government's position during an emergency.
Landmark_Cases: This is a financial provision related to emergencies.

Title: Duty of the Union to protect States against external aggression and internal disturbance
Original_Description: It shall be the duty of the Union to protect every State against external aggression and internal disturbance and to ensure that the Government of every State is carried on in accordance with the provisions of this Constitution
Simplified_Description: It shall be the duty of the Union to protect every State against external aggression and internal disturbance. The Government of every State is carried on in accordance with the provisions of this Constitution.
Subject: Emergency Provisions
Key_Points: Imposes a duty on the Union government to do two things:
1. Protect every state from external aggression and internal disturbance.
2. Ensure that the government of every state is carried on in accordance with the provisions of the Constitution.
This article provides the justification for the Union's intervention in a state's affairs, particularly through the use of Article 356.
Historical_Context: This article establishes the role of the Union as a guardian of the states and the constitutional order. While seemingly protective, the duty to ensure that the state government is functioning according to the Constitution is the basis on which the controversial power of President's Rule (Article 356) is invoked.
Landmark_Cases: S.R. Bommai vs Union of India (1994): The Supreme Court extensively discussed this article as providing the rationale for the imposition of President's Rule, while also laying down strict limits to prevent its misuse.

Title: Provisions in case of failure of constitutional machinery in States
Original_Description:
(1) If the President, on receipt of a report from the Governor of a State or otherwise, is satisfied that a situation has arisen in which the Government of the State cannot be carried on in accordance with the provisions of this Constitution, the President may by Proclamation —

 

(a) assume to himself all or any of the functions of the Government of the State and all or any of the powers vested in or exercisable by the Governor or any body or authority in the State other than the Legislature of the State;

 

(b) declare that the powers of the Legislature of the State shall be exercisable by or under the authority of Parliament;

 

(c) make such incidental and consequential provisions as appear to the President to be necessary or desirable for giving effect to the objects of the Proclamation, including provisions for suspending in whole or in part the operation of any provisions of this Constitution relating to any body or authority in the State:

 

   Provided that nothing in this clause shall authorise the President to assume to himself any of the powers vested in or exercisable by a High Court, or to suspend in whole or in part the operation of any provision of this Constitution relating to High Courts.

 

(2) Any such Proclamation may be revoked or varied by a subsequent Proclamation.

 

(3) Every Proclamation under this article shall be laid before each House of Parliament and shall, except where it is a Proclamation revoking a previous Proclamation, cease to operate at the expiration of two months unless before the expiration of that period it has been approved by resolutions of both Houses of Parliament:

 

   Provided that if any such Proclamation (not being a Proclamation revoking a previous Proclamation) is issued at a time when the House of the People is dissolved or the dissolution of the House of the People takes place during the period of two months referred to in this clause, and if a resolution approving the Proclamation has been passed by the Council of States, but no resolution with respect to such Proclamation has been passed by the House of the People before the expiration of that period, the Proclamation shall cease to operate at the expiration of thirty days from the date on which the House of the People first sits after its reconstitution unless before the expiration of the said period of thirty days a resolution approving the Proclamation has been also passed by the House of the People.

 

(4) A Proclamation so approved shall, unless revoked, cease to operate on the expiration of a period of six months from the date of issue of the Proclamation:

 

   Provided that if and so often as a resolution approving the continuance in force of such a Proclamation is passed by both Houses of Parliament, the Proclamation shall, unless revoked, continue in force for a further period of six months from the date on which under this clause it would otherwise have ceased to operate, but no such Proclamation shall in any case remain in force for more than three years:

 

   Provided further that if the dissolution of the House of the People takes place during any such period of six months and a resolution approving the continuance in force of such Proclamation has been passed by the Council of States, but no resolution with respect to the continuance in force of such Proclamation has been passed by the House of the People during the said period, the Proclamation shall cease to operate at the expiration of thirty days from the date on which the House of the People first sits after its reconstitution unless before the expiration of the said period of thirty days a resolution approving the continuance in force of the Proclamation has been also passed by the House of the People:

 

   Provided also that in the case of the Proclamation issued under clause (1) on the 11th day of May, 1987 with respect to the State of Punjab, the reference in the first proviso to this clause to “three years” shall be construed as a reference to five years.

 

(5) Notwithstanding anything contained in clause (4), a resolution with respect to the continuance in force of a Proclamation approved under clause (3) for any period beyond the expiration of one year from the date of issue of such Proclamation shall not be passed by either House of Parliament unless —

 

(a) a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation, in the whole of India or, as the case may be, in the whole or any part of the State, at the time of the passing of such resolution, and

 

(b) the Election Commission certifies that the continuance in force of the Proclamation approved under clause (3) during the period specified in such resolution is necessary on account of difficulties in holding general elections to the Legislative Assembly of the State concerned:

 

   Provided that nothing in this clause shall apply to the Proclamation issued under clause (1) on the 11th day of May, 1987 with respect to the State of Punjab.
Simplified_Description: The President may by Proclamation assume to himself all or any of the functions of the Government of the State. Every Proclamation under this article shall be laid before each House of Parliament and shall cease to operate at the expiration of two months unless before that period it has been approved by both Houses of Parliament.
Subject: Emergency Provisions
Key_Points: Empowers the President to impose 'President's Rule' in a state.
This can be done if the President is satisfied that there is a failure of the constitutional machinery in the state.
The state government is dismissed, and the State Assembly is either suspended or dissolved.
The executive power of the state is assumed by the President, and the legislative power by Parliament.
The proclamation must be approved by Parliament within two months.
It can last for a maximum of three years with parliamentary approval every six months.
Historical_Context: This is arguably the most controversial article of the Constitution. Intended as a last resort to restore constitutional order in a state, it has been widely criticized for its frequent misuse by central governments to dismiss politically inconvenient state governments. The scope of this article was significantly curtailed by the Supreme Court's Bommai judgment.
Landmark_Cases: State of Rajasthan vs Union of India (1977): The Court initially took a restrictive view on judicial review of this power.

S.R. Bommai vs Union of India (1994): A landmark judgment that established that the imposition of President's Rule is subject to judicial review. It held that the majority of a government should be tested on the floor of the House and that the power cannot be used for mala fide reasons.
Related_Articles: Article 355 (Duty of the Union to protect States)
Article 365 (Effect of failure to comply with directions)

Title: Exercise of legislative powers under Proclamation issued under article 356
Simplified_Description: Proclamation issued under clause (1) of article 356. It declares that the powers of the Legislature of the State shall be exercisable by or under the authority of Parliament.
Subject: Emergency Provisions
Key_Points: Specifies how the legislative power of a state is exercised during President's Rule.
Parliament can make laws for the state.
Parliament can delegate this law-making power to the President or any other authority specified by it.
Laws made by Parliament or the President for the state during this period are known as 'President's Acts'.
These laws continue to be in force even after President's Rule ends, until they are repealed or altered by the state legislature.
Historical_Context: This article provides the mechanism for the Union to legislate for a state when its own legislature is not functioning. The delegation of this power to the President is for administrative convenience, allowing laws to be made for the state even when Parliament is not in session.
Landmark_Cases: This is a procedural article detailing legislative functions during President's Rule.

Title: Suspension of provisions of article 19 during emergencies
Original_Description:
(1) While a Proclamation of Emergency declaring that the security of India or any part of the territory thereof is threatened by war or by external aggression is in operation, nothing in article 19 shall restrict the power of the State as defined in Part III to make any law or to take any executive action which the State would but for the provisions contained in that Part be competent to make or to take, but any law so made shall, to the extent of the incompetency, cease to have effect as soon as the Proclamation ceases to operate, except as respects things done or omitted to be done before the law so ceases to have effect:

 

   Provided that where such Proclamation of Emergency is in operation only in any part of the territory of India, any such law may be made, or any such executive action may be taken, under this article in relation to or in any State or Union territory in which or in any part of which the Proclamation of Emergency is not in operation, if and in so far as the security of India or any part of the territory thereof is threatened by activities in or in relation to the part of the territory of India in which the Proclamation of Emergency is in operation.

 

(2) Nothing in clause (1) shall apply —

 

(a) to any law which does not contain a recital to the effect that such law is in relation to the Proclamation of Emergency in operation when it is made; or

 

(b) to any executive action taken otherwise than under a law containing such a recital.
Simplified_Description: While a Proclamation of Emergency declaring that the security of India or any part of the territory thereof is threatened by war or by external aggression is in operation, nothing in article 19 shall restrict the power of the State as defined in Part III.
Subject: Emergency Provisions
Key_Points: Provides for the automatic suspension of the six fundamental freedoms under Article 19 when a National Emergency is declared.
This automatic suspension happens only when the emergency is declared on the grounds of 'war' or 'external aggression', not 'armed rebellion'.
During this period, the state can make any law or take any executive action that abridges the rights under Article 19.
Such laws become void as soon as the emergency ceases to operate.
Historical_Context: The 44th Amendment Act, 1978, introduced significant changes to this article. Before the amendment, Article 19 was suspended even during an emergency declared on grounds of 'internal disturbance'. The amendment restricted the automatic suspension only to emergencies arising from war or external aggression, providing a crucial safeguard against the misuse of emergency powers to suppress internal dissent.
Landmark_Cases: The interpretation of this article was central to cases during the 1962 and 1971 emergencies.
Related_Articles: Article 19 (Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech, etc)
Article 359 (Suspension of the enforcement of other rights)

Title: Suspension of the enforcement of the rights conferred by Part III during emergencies
Original_Description:
(1) Where a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation, the President may by order declare that the right to move any court for the enforcement of such of the rights conferred by Part III (except articles 20 and 21) as may be mentioned in the order and all proceedings pending in any court for the enforcement of the rights so mentioned shall remain suspended for the period during which the Proclamation is in force or for such shorter period as may be specified in the order.

 

(1A) While an order made under clause (1) mentioning any of the rights conferred by Part III (except articles 20 and 21) is in operation, nothing in that Part conferring those rights shall restrict the power of the State as defined in the said Part to make any law or to take any executive action which the State would but for the provisions contained in that Part be competent to make or to take, but any law so made shall, to the extent of the incompetency, cease to have effect as soon as the order aforesaid ceases to operate, except as respects things done or omitted to be done before the law so ceases to have effect:

 

   Provided that where a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation only in any part of the territory of India, any such law may be made, or any such executive action may be taken, under this article in relation to or in any State or Union territory in which or in any part of which the Proclamation of Emergency is not in operation, if and in so far as the security of India or any part of the territory thereof is threatened by activities in or in relation to the part of the territory of India in which the Proclamation of Emergency is in operation.

 

(1B) Nothing in clause (1A) shall apply —

 

(a) to any law which does not contain a recital to the effect that such law is in relation to the Proclamation of Emergency in operation when it is made; or

 

(b) to any executive action taken otherwise than under a law containing such a recital.(

 

(2) An order made as aforesaid may extend to the whole or any part of the territory of India:

 

   Provided that where a Proclamation of Emergency is in operation only in a part of the territory of India, any such order shall not extend to any other part of the territory of India unless the President, being satisfied that the security of India or any part of the territory thereof is threatened by activities in or in relation to the part of the territory of India in which the Proclamation of Emergency is in operation, considers such extension to be necessary. 

 

(3) Every order made under clause (1) shall, as soon as may be after it is made, be laid before each House of Parliament.
Simplified_Description: The President may by order declare that the right to move any court for the enforcement of such of the rights conferred by Part III (except articles 20 and 21) as may be mentioned in the order. Nothing in that Part conferring those rights shall restrict the power of the State as defined in the said Part.
Subject: Emergency Provisions
Key_Points: Authorizes the President to suspend the right to move any court for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights during a National Emergency.
Unlike Article 358, this is not an automatic suspension; it requires a specific Presidential Order.
The President can specify which Fundamental Rights (their enforcement) are to be suspended.
The rights under Articles 20 and 21 (protection in respect of conviction and right to life and personal liberty) can never be suspended.
The suspension applies only to the enforcement of the rights, not the rights themselves.
Historical_Context: This article gives the executive wide powers to curtail fundamental rights during an emergency. The infamous ADM Jabalpur case during the 1975 Emergency saw the Supreme Court rule that even the right to life could be suspended. This was corrected by the 44th Amendment Act, 1978, which explicitly protected Articles 20 and 21 from being suspended under any circumstances, a landmark safeguard for individual liberty.
Landmark_Cases: ADM Jabalpur vs Shivkant Shukla (1976) (The Habeas Corpus case): A now-overruled judgment where the Supreme Court held that during an emergency, the right to move a court for habeas corpus against illegal detention was suspended.
The 44th Amendment was a direct legislative response to overturn the effect of this judgment.

Title: Provisions as to financial emergency
Simplified_Description: The President may by a Proclamation make a declaration to that effect. A Proclamation issued under clause (1) — (a) may be revoked or varied by a subsequent Proclamation; (b) shall be laid before each House of Parliament; (c) shall cease to operate at the expiration of two months.
Subject: Emergency Provisions
Key_Points: Empowers the President to declare a Financial Emergency.
This can be done if the financial stability or credit of India (or any part of it) is threatened.
The proclamation must be approved by Parliament with a simple majority within two months.
During a financial emergency, the Union can give financial directions to the states.
The President can direct the reduction of salaries and allowances of all government employees, including judges of the Supreme Court and High Courts.
Historical_Context: This article was included as a measure to deal with a severe national economic crisis. It grants the central government sweeping powers to enforce fiscal discipline across the country. To date, a financial emergency has never been declared in India.
Landmark_Cases: As this article has never been invoked, there is no case law on it.

Title: Protection of President and Governors and Rajpramukhs
Original_Description:
(1) The President, or the Governor or Rajpramukh of a State, shall not be answerable to any court for the exercise and performance of the powers and duties of his office or for any act done or purporting to be done by him in the exercise and performance of those powers and duties:

 

   Provided that the conduct of the President may be brought under review by any court, tribunal or body appointed or designated by either House of Parliament for the investigation of a charge under article 61:

 

   Provided further that nothing in this clause shall be construed as restricting the right of any person to bring appropriate proceedings against the Government of India or the Government of a State.

 

(2) No criminal proceedings whatsoever shall be instituted or continued against the President, or the Governor of a State, in any court during his term of office.

 

(3) No process for the arrest or imprisonment of the President, or the Governor of a State, shall issue from any court during his term of office.

 

(4) No civil proceedings in which relief is claimed against the President, or the Governor of a State, shall be instituted during his term of office in any court in respect of any act done or purporting to be done by him in his personal capacity, whether before or after he entered upon his office as President, or as Governor of such State, until the expiration of two months next after notice in writing has been delivered to the President or the Governor, as the case may be, or left at his office stating the nature of the proceedings, the cause of action therefor, the name, description and place of residence of the party by whom such proceedings are to be instituted and the relief which he claims.
Simplified_Description: The President, or the Governor or Rajpramukh of a State, shall not be answerable to any court for the exercise and performance of the powers and duties of his office or for any act done or purporting to be done by him. Provided that the conduct of the President may be brought under review by any court, tribunal or body appointed or designated by either House of
Subject: Miscellaneous
Key_Points: Provides personal immunity to the President and Governors from legal proceedings.
They are not answerable to any court for the exercise of their official powers and duties.
Complete immunity from criminal proceedings during their term of office.
No process for arrest or imprisonment can be issued against them during their term.
Civil proceedings can be instituted against them for personal acts only after giving two months' prior notice.
Historical_Context: This article is designed to protect the dignity and independence of the highest constitutional offices of the Union and the States. It ensures that the President and Governors can perform their official duties without fear of politically motivated or vexatious litigation. The immunity is for their term of office and does not apply to their actions after they demit office.
Landmark_Cases: The scope of this immunity has been tested in courts, which have held that while the President/Governor is personally immune, their actions can be challenged and the government can be held responsible for them.
Related_Articles: Article 14 (Equality before law - this is an exception to it)

Title: Protection of publication of proceedings of Parliament and State Legislatures
Original_Description:
(1) No person shall be liable to any proceedings, civil or criminal, in any court in respect of the publication in a newspaper of a substantially true report of any proceedings of either House of Parliament or the Legislative Assembly, or, as the case may be, either House of the Legislature, of a State, unless the publication is proved to have been made with malice:

 

   Provided that nothing in this clause shall apply to the publication of any report of the proceedings of a secret sitting of either House of Parliament or the Legislative Assembly, or, as the case may be, either House of the Legislature, of a State.

 

(2) Clause (1) shall apply in relation to reports or matters broadcast by means of wireless telegraphy as part of any programme or service provided by means of a broadcasting station as it applies in relation to reports or matters published in a newspaper.

 

   Explanation. — In this article, “newspaper” includes a news agency report containing material for publication in a newspaper .
Simplified_Description: No person shall be liable to any proceedings, civil or criminal, in any court in respect of the publication in a newspaper of a substantially true report of any proceedings of either House of Parliament or the Legislative Assembly.
Subject: Miscellaneous
Key_Points: Provides legal immunity to persons (including the media) for publishing a 'substantially true report' of the proceedings of Parliament or a State Legislature.
This protection covers both civil and criminal proceedings (e.g., defamation).
The immunity does not apply if the publication is proved to have been made with malice.
It also does not apply to the publication of proceedings of a secret sitting.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 44th Amendment Act, 1978. It gives constitutional protection to media freedom in reporting on legislative proceedings, which is essential for transparency and public accountability. It was enacted to undo the restrictions placed on the media during the Emergency.
Landmark_Cases: This article is a key safeguard for freedom of the press.

Title: Disqualification for appointment on remunerative political post
Original_Description:
