A member of a House belonging to any political party who is disqualified for being a member of the House under paragraph 2 of the Tenth Schedule shall also be disqualified to hold any remunerative political post for duration of the period commencing from the date of his disqualification till the date on which the term of his office as such member would expire or till the date on which he contests an election to a House and is declared elected, whichever is earlier.

 

Explanation. — For the purposes of this article, —

 

(a) the expression “House” has the meaning assigned to it in clause (a) of paragraph 1 of the Tenth Schedule; 

 

(b) the expression “remunerative political post” means any office —

 

(i) under the Government of India or the Government of a State where the salary or remuneration for such office is paid out of the public revenue of the Government of India or the Government of the State, as the case may be; or

 

(ii) under a body, whether incorporated or not, which is wholly or partially owned by the Government of India or the Government of a State and the salary or remuneration for such office is paid by such body,

 

except where such salary or remuneration paid is compensatory in nature.
Simplified_Description: A member of a House belonging to any political party who is disqualified for being a member of the House under paragraph 2 of the Tenth Schedule shall also be disqualified to hold any remunerative political post. The term of his office as such member would expire or till the date on which he contests an election to a House and is declared elected.
Subject: Miscellaneous
Key_Points: Adds a further disqualification for a legislator who is disqualified under the anti-defection law (Tenth Schedule).
Such a disqualified member is also barred from holding any 'remunerative political post' for the duration of their disqualification.
'Remunerative political post' is defined as an office under the government or a government-owned body for which a salary is paid.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 91st Amendment Act, 2003, which also limited the size of ministries. The purpose was to strengthen the anti-defection law by closing a loophole. It prevents a disqualified defector from being immediately rewarded with a lucrative post like the chairmanship of a public sector undertaking.
Landmark_Cases: This article strengthens the anti-defection law.

Title: Bar to interference by courts in disputes arising out of certain treaties, agreements, etc
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution but subject to the provisions of article 143, neither the Supreme Court nor any other court shall have jurisdiction in any dispute arising out of any provision of a treaty, agreement, covenant, engagement, sanad or other similar instrument which was entered into or executed before the commencement of this Constitution by any Ruler of an Indian State and to which the Government of the Dominion of India or any of its predecessor Governments was a party and which has or has been continued in operation after such commencement, or in any dispute in respect of any right accruing under or any liability or obligation arising out of any of the provisions of this Constitution relating to any such treaty, agreement, covenant, engagement, sanad or other similar instrument.

 

(2) In this article —

 

(a) “Indian State” means any territory recognised before the commencement of this Constitution by His Majesty or the Government of the Dominion of India as being such a State; and

 

(b) “Ruler” includes the Prince, Chief or other person recognised before such commencement by His Majesty or the Government of the Dominion of India as the Ruler of any Indian State.
Simplified_Description: Neither the Supreme Court nor any other court shall have jurisdiction in any dispute arising out of any provision of a treaty, agreement, covenant, engagement, sanad or other similar instrument. “Indian State” means any territory recognised before the commencement of this Constitution.
Subject: Miscellaneous
Key_Points: Bars the jurisdiction of all courts, including the Supreme Court, over disputes arising from pre-Constitution treaties, agreements, and covenants entered into by the rulers of the former princely states.
This ouster of jurisdiction applies to disputes where the Government of India was a party.
The only exception is the advisory jurisdiction of the Supreme Court under Article 143.
Historical_Context: This article was included to treat the integration of the princely states and the agreements made with their rulers as political acts, keeping them outside the purview of ordinary legal challenges. It was intended to give finality to the political settlements made during the unification of India. The abolition of privy purses by the 26th Amendment was a major event related to this provision.
Landmark_Cases: Madhav Rao Scindia vs Union of India (1971) (Privy Purses case): The Supreme Court initially struck down the presidential order derecognizing the rulers but this was later overturned by the 26th Constitutional Amendment.
Related_Articles: Article 143 (Advisory jurisdiction of the Supreme Court)

Title: Recognition granted to Rulers of Indian States to cease and privy purses to be abolished
Simplified_Description: A person who, at any time before the commencement of the Constitution (Twenty-sixth Amendment) Act, 1971, was recognised by the President as the Ruler of an Indian State or the successor of such ruler shall, on and from such commencement, cease to be recognised as such Ruler. The Ruler or any other person shall not be paid any sum as privy purse.
Subject: Miscellaneous
Key_Points: Abolished the recognition of the rulers of the former princely states.
Abolished the 'privy purse', which was a tax-free payment made annually by the Government of India to the former rulers and their successors.
Extinguished all rights, liabilities, and obligations related to the privy purse.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 26th Amendment Act, 1971. The system of privy purses and special privileges for former rulers was seen as contrary to the principles of an egalitarian and democratic republic. After a failed attempt to abolish them by an executive order (which was struck down by the Supreme Court in the Madhav Rao Scindia case), the government passed this constitutional amendment to achieve its objective.
Landmark_Cases: Madhav Rao Scindia vs Union of India (1971) is the key case preceding this amendment.

Title: Special provisions as to major ports and aerodromes
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, the President may by public notification direct that as from such date as may be specified in the notification —

 

(a) any law made by Parliament or by the Legislature of a State shall not apply to any major port or aerodrome or shall apply thereto subject to such exceptions or modifications as may be specified in the notification, or

 

(b) any existing law shall cease to have effect in any major port or aerodrome except as respects things done or omitted to be done before the said date, or shall in its application to such port or aerodrome have effect subject to such exceptions or modifications as may be specified in the notification.

 

(2) In this article —

 

(a) “major port” means a port declared to be a major port by or under any law made by Parliament or any existing law and includes all areas for the time being included within the limits of such port;

 

(b) “aerodrome” means aerodrome as defined for the purposes of the enactments relating to airways, aircraft and air navigation.
Simplified_Description: President may by public notification direct that any law made by Parliament or by the Legislature of a State shall not apply to any major port or aerodrome.
Subject: Miscellaneous
Key_Points: Gives the President the power to make special provisions for major ports and aerodromes.
The President can direct, by public notification, that any law of Parliament or a State Legislature will not apply to a major port or aerodrome, or will apply with certain modifications.
This power can also be used to modify the application of existing laws.
Historical_Context: This article recognizes the special status and national importance of major ports and aerodromes, which are crucial hubs for trade, commerce, and national security. It allows the Union executive to create a uniform and specialized legal regime for these areas, overriding general state or central laws if necessary for their efficient functioning and development.
Landmark_Cases: This is an administrative power-conferring article.
Related_Articles: Union List (which lists major ports and airways as Union subjects)

Title: Effect of failure to comply with, or to give effect to, directions given by the Union
Original_Description: Where any State has failed to comply with, or to give effect to, any directions given in the exercise of the executive power of the Union under any of the provisions of this Constitution, it shall be lawful for the President to hold that a situation has arisen in which the Government of the State cannot be carried on in accordance with the provisions of this Constitution.
Simplified_Description: The President may hold that a situation has arisen in which the Government of the State cannot be carried on in accordance with the provisions of this Constitution.
Subject: Miscellaneous
Key_Points: Provides for a consequence if a state fails to comply with directions given by the Union government.
If a state fails to comply, the President can deem that a situation has arisen where the government of the state cannot be carried on in accordance with the Constitution.
This effectively becomes a ground for the imposition of President's Rule under Article 356.
Historical_Context: This article is a powerful tool that backs the Union's administrative directions to the states (under Articles 256 and 257) with a serious sanction. It is a significant unitary feature of the Constitution, providing a constitutional basis for the President to act against a non-compliant state government.
Landmark_Cases: S.R. Bommai vs Union of India (1994): The Supreme Court discussed this article as one of the grounds for invoking President's Rule, while cautioning that it should not be used for trivial reasons and must be based on a deliberate and serious failure by the state.

Title: Definitions
Simplified_Description: In this Constitution, unless the context otherwise requires, the following expressions have the meanings hereby respectively assigned to them. “agricultural income” means agricultural income as defined for the purposes of the enactments relating to Indian income-tax; “an Anglo-Indian’ means a person whose father or any of his other male progenitors in the male line is or No provision exists for taking the tax so paid into account in computing for the purposes of Indian income-tax. “Debt” includes any liability in respect of any obligation to repay capital sums by way of annuities and any liability under any guarantee. “existing law” means any law, Ordinance, order, bye-law, rule or regulation passed or made before the commencement of this Constitution. “Federal Court’ means the Federal Court constituted under the Government of India Act, 1935; “goods” includes all materials, commodities, and articles; (13) “guarantee” “Proclamation of Emergency” means a Proclamation issued under clause (1) of article 352. “Ruler’ means the Prince, Chief or other person who, at any time before the commencement of the Constitution (Twenty-sixth Amendment) Act, 1971, was recognised as the Ruler of an Indian State. “Scheduled Tribes” means such tribes or tribal communities or parts of or groups within such tribes. “securities” includes stock; (27) “sub-clause’ means a sub-Clause of the clause in which the expression occurs; (28) ‘taxation’ includes the imposition of any tax or impost “Union territory” means any Union territory specified in the First Schedule and includes any other territory comprised within the territory of India but not specified in that Schedule. A tax on the transfer of the right to use any goods for any purpose (whether or not for a specified period) for cash.
Subject: Miscellaneous
Key_Points: This is a major interpretation clause, providing definitions for 30 key terms used throughout the Constitution.

Some important definitions include: 'agricultural income', 'Anglo-Indian', 'corporation tax', 'existing law', 'goods', 'High Court', 'Ruler', 'Scheduled Castes', 'Scheduled Tribes', 'tax on income', and 'Union territory'.
Clause (29A) was added later to provide an expansive definition of 'tax on the sale or purchase of goods' to cover things like works contracts, hire-purchase, and leases.
Historical_Context: A definition clause is essential in any complex legal document to ensure clarity and consistency. Many of the definitions in this article are crucial for understanding the division of powers, financial provisions, and special provisions of the Constitution. Clause (29A), added by the 46th Amendment, 1982, was a significant change made to overcome a Supreme Court judgment (Gannon Dunkerley) and expand the states' power to levy sales tax.
Landmark_Cases: State of Madras vs Gannon Dunkerley & Co. (1958): This case led to the insertion of clause (29A) in Article 366.
The definitions in this article are frequently cited in a vast range of constitutional cases.
Related_Articles: The various articles where the defined terms are used.

Title: Interpretation
Original_Description:
(1) Unless the context otherwise requires, the General Clauses Act, 1897, shall, subject to any adaptations and modifications that may be made therein under article 372, apply for the interpretation of this Constitution as it applies for the interpretation of an Act of the Legislature of the Dominion of India.

(2) Any reference in this Constitution to Acts or laws of, or made by, Parliament, or to Acts or laws of, or made by, the Legislature of a State, shall be construed as including a reference to an Ordinance made by the President or, to an Ordinance made by a Governor, as the case may be.

(3) For the purposes of this Constitution “foreign State” means any State other than India:

Provided that, subject to the provisions of any law made by Parliament, the President may by order declare any State not to be a foreign State for such purposes as may be specified in the order.
Simplified_Description: The General Clauses Act, 1897, shall apply for the interpretation of this Constitution as it applies to an Act of the Legislature of the Dominion of India. “Foreign State” means any State other than India.
Subject: Miscellaneous
Key_Points: Provides rules for the interpretation of the Constitution.
It states that the General Clauses Act, 1897, should be used for interpretation, just as it is for other central acts.
It clarifies that any reference to an Act of a legislature also includes a reference to an Ordinance promulgated by the President or a Governor.
Defines 'foreign State' as any State other than India, but gives the President the power to declare any state not to be a foreign state for specific purposes.
Historical_Context: This article provides a standard legal framework for interpreting the Constitution, ensuring consistency with other laws. The power of the President to declare a state as 'not foreign' was used to accommodate India's relationship with Commonwealth countries and other nations with which it had special ties.
Landmark_Cases: This article is a tool for interpretation and is cited by courts in a wide variety of constitutional cases to define terms and apply principles of statutory interpretation.

Title: Power of Parliament to amend the Constitution and procedure therefor
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, Parliament may in exercise of its constituent power amend by way of addition, variation or repeal any provision of this Constitution in accordance with the procedure laid down in this article.

 

(2) An amendment of this Constitution may be initiated only by the introduction of a Bill for the purpose in either House of Parliament, and when the Bill is passed in each House by a majority of the total membership of that House and by a majority of not less than two-thirds of the members of that House present and voting, it shall be presented to the President who shall give his assent to the Bill and thereupon] the Constitution shall stand amended in accordance with the terms of the Bill:

 

   Provided that if such amendment seeks to make any change in —

 

(a) article 54, article 55, article 73, article 162 or article 241, or

 

(b) Chapter IV of Part V, Chapter V of Part VI, or Chapter I of Part XI, or

 

(c) any of the Lists in the Seventh Schedule, or

 

(d) the representation of States in Parliament, or

 

(e) the provisions of this article,

 

the amendment shall also require to be ratified by the Legislatures of not less than one-half of the States by resolutions to that effect passed by those Legislatures before the Bill making provision for such amendment is presented to the President for assent.

 

(3) Nothing in article 13 shall apply to any amendment made under this article.

 

(4) No amendment of this Constitution (including the provisions of Part III) made or purporting to have been made under this article [whether before or after the commencement of section 55 of the Constitution (Fortysecond Amendment) Act, 1976] shall be called in question in any court on any ground.

 

(5) For the removal of doubts, it is hereby declared that there shall be no limitation whatever on the constituent power of Parliament to amend by way of addition, variation or repeal the provisions of this Constitution under this article.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may in exercise of its constituent power amend by way of addition, variation or repeal any provision of this Constitution in accordance with the procedure laid down in this article. Amendment may be initiated only by the introduction of a Bill for the purpose in either House of Parliament.
Subject: Amendment of the Constitution
Key_Points: Grants 'constituent power' to the Parliament to amend the Constitution.
An amendment can be initiated only in Parliament, not in state legislatures.
Most provisions require a 'special majority' for amendment: a majority of the total membership of the House AND a majority of two-thirds of the members present and voting.
Provisions affecting the federal structure require a special majority plus ratification by at least half of the state legislatures.
There is no provision for a joint sitting to pass a constitutional amendment bill.
Historical_Context: This article has been the most litigated provision of the Constitution. The central question has been the scope of Parliament's amending power. A series of confrontations between Parliament and the Judiciary over amendments affecting fundamental rights (especially the right to property) culminated in the Kesavananda Bharati case.
Landmark_Cases: Shankari Prasad vs Union of India (1951): Held that Parliament's power to amend under Article 368 includes the power to amend Fundamental Rights.
Golaknath vs State of Punjab (1967): Overruled Shankari Prasad, stating that Fundamental Rights are 'transcendental and immutable' and cannot be amended.

Kesavananda Bharati vs State of Kerala (1973): Overruled Golaknath and established the 'Basic Structure Doctrine', holding that Parliament can amend any part of the Constitution, including Fundamental Rights, but cannot alter its 'basic structure'.
Minerva Mills vs Union of India (1980): Reaffirmed the Basic Structure Doctrine and struck down clauses added by the 42nd Amendment that had tried to give Parliament unlimited amending power.

Title: Temporary power to Parliament to make laws with respect to certain matters in the State List as if they were matters in the Concurrent List
Simplified_Description: Parliament shall, during a period of five years from the commencement of this Constitution, have power to make laws with respect to the following matters. These matters include cotton and woollen textiles, cotton seed, paper (including newsprint), food-stuffs, coal (including coke and derivatives of coal), iron, steel and mica.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: This was a temporary provision.
For the first five years of the Constitution, it gave Parliament concurrent power to legislate on certain subjects that were otherwise in the State List.
These subjects included trade and commerce in essential goods like cotton, foodstuffs, coal, iron, and steel.
Historical_Context: This article was included to ensure that the central government had adequate power to regulate the economy and ensure the supply of essential commodities during the initial years of the Republic, when the country was still facing post-partition economic challenges. As the five-year period has long expired, this article is now obsolete.
Landmark_Cases: This was a transitional provision and is no longer operative.
Related_Articles: This is a historical provision with no current applicability.

Title: Temporary provisions with respect to the State of Jammu and Kashmir
Original_Description: Article 370, which granted special autonomy to the state of Jammu and Kashmir, was abrogated on August 5, 2019. This marked a significant constitutional change, as the state was reorganized into two Union Territories: Jammu & Kashmir (with a legislative assembly) and Ladakh (without a legislative assembly). The special provisions and autonomy previously enjoyed by Jammu and Kashmir under this article are no longer applicable, ensuring uniform application of the Indian Constitution across the entire region.
Simplified_Description: Article 370, which granted special autonomy to the state of Jammu and Kashmir, was abrogated on August 5, 2019. This marked a significant constitutional change, as the state was reorganized into two Union Territories: Jammu & Kashmir (with a legislative assembly) and Ladakh.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: Originally a 'temporary provision', it granted special autonomous status to the State of Jammu & Kashmir (J&K).
It limited the legislative power of the Indian Parliament over J&K to the subjects of Defence, Foreign Affairs, and Communications.
It allowed J&K to have its own Constitution.
The provisions of this article were rendered inoperative on August 5, 2019, through a Presidential Order (C.O. 272).
Historical_Context: Article 370 was incorporated into the Constitution to accommodate the special conditions under which the princely state of Jammu and Kashmir acceded to India in 1947. For over 70 years, it defined the unique relationship between the state and the Union. Its abrogation in 2019 was a momentous and controversial event, leading to the full application of the Indian Constitution to the region and the reorganization of the state into two Union Territories.
Landmark_Cases: Sampat Prakash vs State of J&K (1970): The Supreme Court upheld the power of the President to issue orders modifying the application of constitutional provisions to J&K.

In Re: Article 370 of the Constitution (2023): A Constitution Bench of the Supreme Court unanimously upheld the President's 2019 orders that abrogated the special status of Jammu & Kashmir under Article 370.

Title: Special provision with respect to the States of Maharashtra and Gujarat
Original_Description:
(2) Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, the President may by order made with respect to the State of Maharashtra or Gujarat], provide for any special responsibility of the Governor for —

 

(a) the establishment of separate development boards for Vidarbha, Marathwada, and the rest of Maharashtra or, as the case may be, Saurashtra, Kutch and the rest of Gujarat with the provision that a report on the working of each of these boards will be placed each year before the State Legislative Assembly;

 

(b) the equitable allocation of funds for developmental expenditure over the said areas, subject to the requirements of the State as a whole; and

 

(c) an equitable arrangement providing adequate facilities for technical education and vocational training, and adequate opportunities for employment in services under the control of the State Government, in respect of all the said areas, subject to the requirements of the State as a whole.
Simplified_Description: The President may by order made with respect to the State of Maharashtra or Gujarat], provide for any special responsibility of the Governor for the establishment of separate development boards for Vidarbha, Marathwada, and the rest of Maharashtra.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: Provides for special responsibilities of the Governor of Maharashtra and Gujarat.
This is for the establishment of separate development boards for specific regions: Vidarbha and Marathwada in Maharashtra; and Saurashtra and Kutch in Gujarat.
The purpose is to ensure equitable allocation of development funds and opportunities for these regions.
Historical_Context: This article was introduced after the bifurcation of the state of Bombay into Maharashtra and Gujarat in 1960. It was designed to address the developmental aspirations and concerns of backward regions within these new states, ensuring that they receive adequate attention and resources.
Landmark_Cases: This article provides the framework for regional development boards in these states.
Related_Articles: Articles 371A to 371J (Special provisions for other states)

Title: Special provision with respect to the State of Nagaland
Simplified_Description: No Act of Parliament in respect of religious or social practices of the Nagas. Governor of Nagaland has special responsibility with respect to law and order. The President on receipt of a report from the Governor or otherwise is satisfied that it is no longer necessary for the Governor to have special responsibility. done by the Governor shall not be called in question on the ground that he ought or ought not to have acted in the exercise of his individual judgment. Constitution provides for composition of regional council and the manner in which the members of the regional council shall be chosen. The Deputy Commissioner of the Tuensang district shall be the Chairman ex officio. Tuensang district shall be carried on by the Governor. No Act of the Legislature of Nagaland shall apply to Tuensang. Governor may repeal or amend with retrospective effect, if necessary, any Act of Parliament. One of the members representing the Tuensang district in the Legislative Assembly of Nagaland shall be appointed Minister for Tuensangs affairs by the Governor. The final decision on all matters relating to the TuENSang district shall be made by the governor in his discretion. In this article, the Kohima, Mokokchung and Tuensang districts shall have the same meanings as in the State of Nagaland Act, 1962. If any difficulty arises in giving effect to any of the foregoing provisions, the President may by order do anything (including any adaptation or modification of any other article) which appears to be necessary.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: Provides extensive special provisions for Nagaland to protect its unique culture and customs.
No Act of Parliament concerning Naga religious or social practices, customary law, or ownership of land and resources applies to Nagaland unless the state's Legislative Assembly so decides.
Assigns a special responsibility to the Governor with respect to law and order in the state.
Provided for special administrative arrangements for the Tuensang district for a period of time.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 13th Amendment Act, 1962, which created the state of Nagaland. It was the result of a political agreement (the 16-Point Agreement) between the Government of India and the Naga People's Convention, aimed at ending the Naga insurgency and protecting the distinct identity of the Naga people. It is a key example of asymmetric federalism.
Landmark_Cases: This article is central to the legal and political framework governing Nagaland.

Title: Special provision with respect to the State of Assam
Original_Description: Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, the President may, by order made with respect to the State of Assam, provide for the constitution and functions of a committee of the Legislative Assembly of the State consisting of members of that Assembly elected from the tribal areas specified in 2 [Part I] of the table appended to paragraph 20 of the Sixth Schedule and such number of other members of that Assembly as may be specified in the order and for the modifications to be made in the rules of procedure of that Assembly for the constitution and proper functioning of such committee.
Simplified_Description: The President may, by order made with respect to the State of Assam, provide for the constitution and functions of a committee.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: Allows the President to provide for the creation of a special committee within the Assam Legislative Assembly.
This committee is to consist of members elected from the Tribal Areas of Assam (as specified in the Sixth Schedule).
The President's order can also specify the functions of this committee.
Historical_Context: Inserted by the 22nd Amendment Act, 1969, this article was part of the reorganisation of Assam. It aimed to provide a legislative forum for the tribal areas of Assam within the state assembly, ensuring that their specific interests and concerns were addressed in the state's legislative process.
Landmark_Cases: This is an administrative provision for the Assam Legislature.
Related_Articles: Article 244A (Formation of an autonomous State within Assam)

Title: Special provision with respect to the State of Manipur
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, the President may, by order made with respect to the State of Manipur, provide for the constitution and functions of a committee of the Legislative Assembly of the State consisting of members of that Assembly elected from the Hill Areas of that State, for the modifications to be made in the rules of business of the Government and in the rules of procedure of the Legislative Assembly of the State and for any special responsibility of the Governor in order to secure the proper functioning of such committee.

 

(2) The Governor shall annually, or whenever so required by the President, make a report to the President regarding the administration of the Hill Areas in the State of Manipur and the executive power of the Union shall extend to the giving of directions to the State as to the administration of the said areas.

 

   Explanation.—In this article, the expression “Hill Areas” means such areas as the President may, by order, declare to be Hill areas.
Simplified_Description: The President may, by order made with respect to the State of Manipur, provide for the constitution and functions of a committee of the Legislative Assembly of the State. The Governor shall annually, or whenever so required by the President, make a report to the President regarding the administration of the Hill Areas.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: Allows the President to provide for the creation of a committee in the Manipur Legislative Assembly.
This committee is to consist of members elected from the Hill Areas of the state.
Assigns a special responsibility to the Governor to ensure the proper functioning of this committee.
The Governor must submit an annual report to the President on the administration of the Hill Areas.
Historical_Context: Inserted by the 27th Amendment Act, 1971, this article was designed to protect the interests of the tribal communities residing in the Hill Areas of Manipur. It provides a mechanism for their representation and involvement in the governance of the state, recognising the distinct geography and demographics of the region.
Landmark_Cases: This article is central to the administration of the Hill Areas of Manipur.
Related_Articles: This is a specific provision for Manipur.

Title: Special provisions with respect to the State of Andhra Pradesh
Original_Description:
(1) The President may by order made with respect to the State of Andhra Pradesh provide, having regard to the requirements of the State as a whole, for equitable opportunities and facilities for the people belonging to different parts of the State, in the matter of public employment and in the matter of education, and different provisions may be made for various parts of the State.

 

(2) An order made under clause (1) may, in particular, —

 

(a) require the State Government to organise any class or classes of posts in a civil service of, or any class or classes of civil posts under, the State into different local cadres for different parts of the State and allot in accordance with such principles and procedure as may be specified in the order the persons holding such posts to the local cadres so organised;

 

(b) specify any part or parts of the State which shall be regarded as the local area —

 

(i) for direct recruitment to posts in any local cadre (whether organised in pursuance of an order under this article or constituted otherwise) under the State Government;

 

(ii) for direct recruitment to posts in any cadre under any local authority within the State; and

 

(iii) for the purposes of admission to any University within the State or to any other educational institution which is subject to the control of the State Government;

 

(c) specify the extent to which, the manner in which and the conditions subject to which, preference or reservation shall be given or made —

 

(i) in the matter of direct recruitment to posts in any such cadre referred to in sub-clause (b) as may be specified in this behalf in the order; 

 

(ii) in the matter of admission to any such University or other educational institution referred to in sub-clause (b) as may be specified in this behalf in the order,

 

to or in favour of candidates who have resided or studied for any period specified in the order in the local area in respect of such cadre, University or other educational institution, as the case may be.

 

(3) The President may, by order, provide for the constitution of an Administrative Tribunal for the State of Andhra Pradesh to exercise such jurisdiction, powers and authority [including any jurisdiction, power and authority which immediately before the commencement of the Constitution (Thirty-second Amendment) Act, 1973, was exercisable by any court (other than the Supreme Court) or by any tribunal or other authority] as may be specified in the order with respect to the following matters, namely: —

 

(a) appointment, allotment or promotion to such class or classes of posts in any civil service of the State, or to such class or classes of civil posts under the State, or to such class or classes of posts under the control of any local authority within the State, as may be specified in the order;

 

(b) seniority of persons appointed, allotted or promoted to such class or classes of posts in any civil service of the State, or to such class or classes of civil posts under the State, or to such class or classes of posts under the control of any local authority within the State, as may be specified in the order;

 

(c) such other conditions of service of persons appointed, allotted or promoted to such class or classes of posts in any civil service of the State or to such class or classes of civil posts under the State or to such class or classes of posts under the control of any local authority within the State, as may be specified in the order. 

 

(4) An order made under clause (3) may —

 

(a) authorise the Administrative Tribunal to receive representations for the redress of grievances relating to any matter within its jurisdiction as the President may specify in the order and to make such orders thereon as the Administrative Tribunal deems fit;

 

(b) contain such provisions with respect to the powers and authorities and procedure of the Administrative Tribunal (including provisions with respect to the powers of the Administrative Tribunal to punish for contempt of itself) as the President may deem necessary;

 

(c) provide for the transfer to the Administrative Tribunal of such classes of proceedings, being proceedings relating to matters within its jurisdiction and pending before any court (other than the Supreme Court) or tribunal or other authority immediately before the commencement of such order, as may be specified in the order;

 

(d) contain such supplemental, incidental and consequential provisions (including provisions as to fees and as to limitation, evidence or for the application of any law for the time being in force subject to any exceptions or modifications) as the President may deem necessary.

 

(5) The Order of the Administrative Tribunal finally disposing of any case shall become effective upon its confirmation by the State Government or on the expiry of three months from the date on which the order is made, whichever is earlier:

 

   Provided that the State Government may, by special order made in writing and for reasons to be specified therein, modify or annul any order of the Administrative Tribunal before it becomes effective and in such a case, the order of the Administrative Tribunal shall have effect only in such modified form or be of no effect, as the case may be.

 

(6) Every special order made by the State Government under the proviso to clause (5) shall be laid, as soon as may be after it is made, before both Houses of the State Legislature.

 

(7) The High Court for the State shall not have any powers of superintendence over the Administrative Tribunal and no court (other than the Supreme Court) or tribunal shall exercise any jurisdiction, power or authority in respect of any matter subject to the jurisdiction, power or authority of, or in relation to, the Administrative Tribunal.

 

(8) If the President is satisfied that the continued existence of the Administrative Tribunal is not necessary, the President may by order abolish the Administrative Tribunal and make such provisions in such order as he may deem fit for the transfer and disposal of cases pending before the Tribunal immediately before such abolition.

 

(9) Notwithstanding any judgment, decree or order of any court, tribunal or other authority, —

 

(a) no appointment, posting, promotion or transfer of any person —

 

(i) made before the 1st day of November, 1956, to any post under the Government of, or any local authority within, the State of Hyderabad as it existed before that date; or

 

(ii) made before the commencement of the Constitution (Thirty-second Amendment) Act, 1973, to any post under the Government of, or any local or other authority within, the State of Andhra Pradesh; and 

 

(b) no action taken or thing done by or before any person referred to in sub-clause (a),

 

shall be deemed to be illegal or void or ever to have become illegal or void merely on the ground that the appointment, posting, promotion or transfer of such person was not made in accordance with any law, then in force, providing for any requirement as to residence within the State of Hyderabad or, as the case may be, within any part of the State of Andhra Pradesh, in respect of such appointment, posting, promotion or transfer.

 

(10) The provisions of this article and of any order made by the President thereunder shall have effect notwithstanding anything in any other provision of this Constitution or in any other law for the time being in force.
Simplified_Description: The President may by order made with respect to the State of Andhra Pradesh provide for equitable opportunities and facilities for the people belonging to different parts of the State. The President may, by order, provide for the constitution of an Administrative Tribunal for the State of Andhra Pradesh to exercise such jurisdiction, powers and authority as may be specified in this behalf in the order. The order relates to appointment, allotment or promotion to such class or classes of posts in any civil service of the State. It also applies to posts under the control of any local authority within the State, as may be specified in the order. The order also covers seniority of persons appointed, allotted or promoted. An order made under clause (3) may — (a) authorise the Administrative Tribunal to receive representations for the redress of grievances relating to any matter within its jurisdiction as the President may specify in the order. (b) contain such provisions with respect to the powers and authorities and procedure of the Administrative tribunal. The High Court for the State shall not have any powers of superintendence over the Administrative Tribunal. No court (other than the Supreme Court) or tribunal shall exercise any jurisdiction, power or authority in respect of any matter subject to the jurisdiction or authority of the Tribunal. No appointment, posting, promotion or transfer of any person. made before the 1st day of November, 1956, to any post under the Government of, or any local authority within, the State of Hyderabad as it existed before that date. No action taken or thing done by or before any person referred to in sub-clause (a) shall be deemed to be illegal or The provisions of this article and of any order made by the President thereunder shall have effect notwithstanding anything in any other provision of this Constitution. within any part of the State of Andhra Pradesh.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: Empowers the President to make orders providing for equitable opportunities in public employment and education for people from different regions of the state of Andhra Pradesh (now applicable to both Andhra Pradesh and Telangana).
Allows for the organization of civil service posts into local cadres.
Provides for the establishment of an Administrative Tribunal to adjudicate service disputes, with its jurisdiction overriding that of the High Court.
The provisions of this article override any other provision of the Constitution.
Historical_Context: Inserted by the 32nd Amendment Act, 1973, this article was the result of a political settlement (the 'Six-Point Formula') to address regional agitations and ensure balanced development and opportunities in Andhra Pradesh. After the bifurcation of the state in 2014, its provisions continue to apply to both Andhra Pradesh and Telangana.
Landmark_Cases: The validity and scope of this article, particularly its clause overriding other constitutional provisions, have been subjects of judicial interpretation. The provision excluding the High Court's jurisdiction was read down in the L. Chandra Kumar case.
Related_Articles: Article 371E (Establishment of Central University in Andhra Pradesh)

Title: Establishment of Central University in Andhra Pradesh
Original_Description: Parliament may by law provide for the establishment of a University in the State of Andhra Pradesh.
Simplified_Description: Parliament may by law provide for the establishment of a University in the State of Andhra Pradesh.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: Empowers Parliament to establish a Central University in the state of Andhra Pradesh.
This is an enabling provision.
Historical_Context: This article was also part of the package introduced by the 32nd Amendment Act, 1973, to address regional aspirations in Andhra Pradesh. The University of Hyderabad was established under this provision.
Landmark_Cases: This is a power-conferring article.

Title: Special provisions with respect to the State of Sikkim
Simplified_Description: The Legislative Assembly of the State of Sikkim shall consist of not less than thirty members. The Assembly was formed as a result of the elections held in SikKim in April, 1974. The State of Sikkim will be allotted one seat in the House of the People. The state will form one parliamentary constituency to be called the parliamentary constituency for SikKim. The Governor of Sikkim shall, subject to such directions as the President may, from time to time, deem fit to issue, act in his discretion. All property and assets (whether within or outside the territories comprised in the State of SikKim) which immediately before the appointed day were vested in the Government of Sik kim shall vest in the government. The High Court functioning The President may, within two years from the appointed day, by order, make such adaptations and modifications of the law, whether by way of repeal or amendment, as may be necessary or expedient. Neither the Supreme Court nor any other court shall have jurisdiction in respect of any dispute or other matter arising out of any treaty, agreement, engagement or other similar instrument relating to Sikkim Article 143: The President may extend with such restrictions or modifications as he thinks fit to the State of Sikkim any enactment which is in force in a State at the date of the notification. This article includes information that may have been validly done or taken under this Constitution as so amended. To see the full text of this article click here.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: Contains extensive special provisions for the state of Sikkim.
Sets the minimum strength of the Sikkim Legislative Assembly at 30 members.
Empowers Parliament to provide for reservation of seats in the Assembly to protect the rights and interests of different sections of the Sikkimese population.
Gives the Governor a special responsibility for peace and for ensuring the social and economic advancement of different sections of the population.
Validates all laws and actions taken during the transition period when Sikkim joined India.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 36th Amendment Act, 1975, which made Sikkim the 22nd state of India. The provisions were designed to accommodate the unique historical and social circumstances of Sikkim's integration into the Indian Union, protecting the rights of its various ethnic communities, including the Bhutia-Lepcha and Nepali populations.
Landmark_Cases: R.C. Poudyal vs Union of India (1993): The Supreme Court upheld the validity of the seat reservation for the Sangha (monastic) constituency in the Sikkim Assembly but struck down the reservation based solely on ethnicity as it violated the principle of 'one person, one vote'.
Related_Articles: This is a specific provision for Sikkim.

Title: Special provision with respect to the State of Mizoram
Original_Description:
Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, —

 

(a) no Act of Parliament in respect of —

 

(i) religious or social practices of the Mizos,

 

(ii) Mizo customary law and procedure,

 

(iii) administration of civil and criminal justice involving decisions according to Mizo customary law,

 

(iv) ownership and transfer of land,

 

shall apply to the State of Mizoram unless the Legislative Assembly of the State of Mizoram by a resolution so decides:

 

   Provided that nothing in this clause shall apply to any Central Act in force in the Union territory of Mizoram immediately before the commencement of the Constitution (Fifty-third Amendment) Act, 1986;

 

(b) the Legislative Assembly of the State of Mizoram shall consist of not less than forty members.
Simplified_Description: No Act of Parliament in respect of religious or social practices of the Mizos, Mizo customary law and procedure, (iii) administration of civil and criminal justice involving decisions according to Mizo law, (iv) ownership and transfer of land, shall apply to the State of Mizoram.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: Provides special protection for the cultural and legal practices of the Mizos.
No Act of Parliament concerning Mizo religious or social practices, customary law, or ownership and transfer of land applies to Mizoram unless the state's Legislative Assembly so decides.
Sets the minimum strength of the Mizoram Legislative Assembly at 40 members.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 53rd Amendment Act, 1986, as part of the Mizo Peace Accord, which ended two decades of insurgency. Similar to the provision for Nagaland, it was a political settlement to protect the distinct identity and way of life of the Mizo people and grant them a significant degree of autonomy over their socio-cultural affairs.
Landmark_Cases: This article is central to the legal framework governing Mizoram.

Title: Special provision with respect to the State of Arunachal Pradesh
Original_Description:
Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, —

 

(a) the Governor of Arunachal Pradesh shall have special responsibility with respect to law and order in the State of Arunachal Pradesh and in the discharge of his functions in relation thereto, the Governor shall, after consulting the Council of Ministers, exercise his individual judgment as to the action to be taken:

 

   Provided that if any question arises whether any matter is or is not a matter as respects which the Governor is under this clause required to act in the exercise of his individual judgment, the decision of the Governor in his discretion shall be final, and the validity of anything done by the Governor shall not be called in question on the ground that he ought or ought not to have acted in the exercise of his individual judgment:

 

   Provided further that if the President on receipt of a report from the Governor or otherwise is satisfied that it is no longer necessary for the Governor to have special responsibility with respect to law and order in the State of Arunachal Pradesh, he may by order direct that the Governor shall cease to have such responsibility with effect from such date as may be specified in the order;

 

(b) the Legislative Assembly of the State of Arunachal Pradesh shall consist of not less than thirty members.
Simplified_Description: The Governor of Arunachal Pradesh shall have special responsibility with respect to law and order in the State. The decision of the Governor in his discretion shall be final, and the validity of anything done by the Governor shall not be called in question.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: Assigns a special responsibility to the Governor of Arunachal Pradesh with respect to law and order.
In discharging this responsibility, the Governor can exercise their individual judgment after consulting the Council of Ministers.
This special responsibility can be ceased by an order of the President.
Sets the minimum strength of the Arunachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly at 30 members.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 55th Amendment Act, 1986, when Arunachal Pradesh was granted statehood. The special responsibility for the Governor regarding law and order was included due to the state's strategic location on the international border and its security concerns. The provision for a smaller assembly size accommodates the state's low population density.
Landmark_Cases: The discretionary power of the Governor under this article is a significant feature of the state's governance.
Related_Articles: Article 371A (Similar provision for Governor of Nagaland)

Title: Special provision with respect to the State of Goa
Original_Description: Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, the Legislative Assembly of the State of Goa shall consist of not less than thirty members.
Simplified_Description: The Legislative Assembly of the State of Goa shall consist of not less than thirty members. Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, the Legislative Assembly
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: Provides that the Legislative Assembly of the State of Goa shall have a minimum strength of 30 members.
This is an exception to the general rule of a minimum of 60 members under Article 170.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 56th Amendment Act, 1987, which granted statehood to Goa. The provision for a smaller assembly size was made to accommodate the small population of the new state.
Landmark_Cases: This is a structural provision for the Goa Legislative Assembly.

Title: Continuance in force of existing laws and their adaptation
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding the repeal by this Constitution of the enactments referred to in article 395 but subject to the other provisions of this Constitution, all the law in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall continue in force therein until altered or repealed or amended by a competent Legislature or other competent authority.

 

(2) For the purpose of brining the provisions of any law in force in the territory of India into accord with the provisions of this Constitution, the President may by order1 make such adaptations and modifications of such law, whether by way of repeal or amendment, as may be necessary or expedient, and provide that the law shall, as from such date as may be specified in the order, have effect subject to the adaptations and modifications so made, and any such adaptation or modification shall not be questioned in any court of law.

 

(3) Nothing in clause (2) shall be deemed —

 

(a) to empower the President to make any adaptation or modification of any law after the expiration of three years from the commencement of this Constitution; or

 

(b) to prevent any competent Legislature or other competent authority from repealing or amending any law adapted or modified by the President under the said clause.

 

   Explanation I. — The expression “law in force” in this article shall include a law passed or made by a Legislature or other competent authority in the territory of India before the commencement of this Constitution and not previously repealed, notwithstanding that it or parts of it may not be then in operation either at all or in particular areas.

 

   Explanation II. — Any law passed or made by a Legislature or other competent authority in the territory of India which immediately before the commencement of this Constitution had extra-territorial effect as well as effect in the territory of India shall, subject to any such adaptations and modifications as aforesaid, contiue to have such extra-territorial effect. 

 

Explanation III. — Nothing in this article shall be construed as continuing any temporary law in force beyond the date fixed for its expiration or the date on which it would have expired if this Constitution had not come into force.

 

Explanation IV. — An Ordinance promulgated by the Governor of a Province under section 88 of the Government of India Act, 1935, and in force immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, unless withdrawn by the Governor of the corresponding State earlier, cease to operate at the expiration of six weeks from the first meeting after such commencement of the Legislative Assembly of that State functioning under clause (1) of article 382, and nothing in this article shall be construed as continuing any such Ordinance in force beyond the said period.
Simplified_Description: All the law in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall continue in force therein until altered or repealed or amended by a competent Legislature or other competent authority. The President may by order1 make such adaptations and modifications of such law, whether by way of repeal or amendment.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: Ensures the continuity of all laws that were in force in India just before the commencement of the Constitution.
These 'existing laws' continue to be in force until they are altered, repealed, or amended by a competent legislature.
Gave the President the power to adapt or modify these existing laws to bring them into conformity with the new Constitution. This power was limited to the first three years.
Historical_Context: This is a crucial transitional provision that prevented a legal vacuum upon the adoption of the Constitution. It ensured that the entire existing legal framework (like the Indian Penal Code, Contract Act, etc.) continued to operate, providing stability and legal certainty for the new republic. These laws would continue as long as they were not inconsistent with the Constitution's provisions.
Landmark_Cases: This article has been cited in numerous cases to determine the validity and applicability of pre-constitutional laws.

Title: Power of the President to adapt laws
Original_Description:
(1) For the purposes of bringing the provisions of any law in force in India or in any part thereof, immediately before the commencement of the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956, into accord with the provisions of this Constitution as amended by that Act, the President may by order made before the first day of November, 1957, make such adaptations and modifications of the law, whether by way of repeal or amendment, as may be necessary or expedient, and provide that the law shall, as from such date as may be specified in the order, have effect subject to the adaptations and modifications so made, and any such adaptation or modification shall not be questioned in any court of law.

 

(2) Nothing in clause (1) shall be deemed to prevent a competent Legislature or other competent authority from repealing or amending any law adapted or modified by the President under the said clause.
Simplified_Description: The President may by order made before the first day of November, 1957, make such adaptations and modifications of the law, whether by way of repeal or amendment, as may be necessary or expedient. Any such adaptation or modification shall not be questioned in any court of law.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: Gave the President the power to adapt and modify laws.
This power was specifically for the purpose of bringing existing laws into conformity with the changes made by the 7th Amendment Act, 1956 (which reorganized the states).
This power was exercisable for a limited period, up to November 1, 1957.
Historical_Context: This was a specific, time-bound transitional provision required to deal with the massive legal adjustments needed after the reorganization of states in 1956. It empowered the President to make necessary changes to laws to align them with the new political map of India.
Landmark_Cases: This was a transitional provision with a limited time frame of operation.

Title: Power of President to make order in respect of persons under preventive detention in certain cases
Original_Description: Until provision is made by Parliament under clause (7) of article 22, or until the expiration of one year from the commencement of this Constitution, whichever is earlier, the said article shall have effect as if for any reference to Parliament in clauses (4) and (7) thereof there were substituted a reference to the President and for any reference to any law made by Parliament in those clauses there were substituted a reference to an order made by the President.
Simplified_Description: Until provision is made by Parliament under clause (7) of article 22, or until the expiration of one year from the commencement of this Constitution, whichever is earlier, the said article shall have effect. For any reference to Parliament in clauses (4) and (7), there were substituted a reference to the President.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: This was a temporary provision related to preventive detention.
For the first year of the Constitution (or until Parliament made a law), it gave the President the powers that Article 22 confers on Parliament regarding preventive detention.
This included the power to prescribe the maximum period of detention and the procedure for the Advisory Board.
Historical_Context: This article was a stop-gap measure to allow the government to operate the preventive detention system immediately after the Constitution came into force, even before Parliament had the chance to enact a specific law on the subject. It is now obsolete.
Landmark_Cases: This was a transitional provision and is no longer operative.

Title: Provisions as to Judges of the Federal Court and proceedings pending in the Federal Court or before His Majesty in Council
Original_Description:
(1) The Judges of the Federal Court holding office immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, unless they have elected otherwise, become on such commencement the Judges of the Supreme Court and shall thereupon be entitled to such salaries and allowances and to such rights in respect of leave of absence and pension as are provided for under article 125 in respect of the Judges of the Supreme Court.

 

(2) All suits, appeals and proceedings, civil or criminal, pending in the Federal Court at the commencement of this Constitution shall stand removed to the Supreme Court, and the Supreme Court shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine the same, and the judgments and orders of the Federal Court delivered or made before the commencement of this Constitution shall have the same force and effect as if they had been delivered or made by the Supreme Court.

 

(3) Nothing in this Constitution shall operate to invalidate the exercise of jurisdiction by His Majesty in Council to dispose of appeals and petitions from, or in respect of, any judgment, decree or order of any court within the territory of India in so far as the exercise of such jurisdiction is authorised by law, and any order of His Majesty in Council made on any such appeal or petition after the commencement of this Constitution shall for all purposes have effect as if it were an order or decree made by the Supreme Court in the exercise of the jurisdiction conferred on such Court by this Constitution.

 

(4) On and from the commencement of this Constitution the jurisdiction of the authority functioning as the Privy Council in a State specified in Part B of the First Schedule to entertain and dispose of appeals and petitions from or in respect of any judgment, decree or order of any court within that State shall cease, and all appeals and other proceedings pending before the said authority at such commencement shall be transferred to, and disposed of by, the Supreme Court.

 

(5) Further provision may be made by Parliament by law to give effect to the provisions of this article.
Simplified_Description: All suits, appeals and proceedings, civil or criminal, pending in the Federal Court at the commencement of this Constitution shall stand removed to the Supreme Court. The Supreme Court shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine the same, and the judgments and orders of the Federal court delivered or made before the commencement shall have the same force and effect as if they had been delivered by the Supreme court.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: Provided for the transition from the old judicial system to the new one.
Judges of the Federal Court automatically became judges of the new Supreme Court.
All cases pending before the Federal Court were transferred to the Supreme Court.
All cases pending before the Privy Council (in Britain, which was the highest court of appeal for India) were also transferred to the Supreme Court.
Historical_Context: This article ensured a seamless transition of the higher judiciary. It established the Supreme Court as the successor to both the Federal Court of India and the Privy Council, absorbing their judges, pending cases, and jurisdiction, and firmly establishing the Supreme Court as the apex judicial authority for the new republic.
Landmark_Cases: This was a crucial transitional provision for the judiciary.

Title: Courts, authorities and officers to continue to function subject to the provisions of the Constitution
Original_Description: All courts of civil, criminal and revenue jurisdiction, all authorities and all officers, judicial, executive and ministerial, throughout the territory of India, shall continue to exercise their respective functions subject to the provisions of this Constitution.
Simplified_Description: All courts of civil, criminal and revenue jurisdiction, all authorities and all officers, judicial, executive and ministerial, throughout the territory of India, shall continue to exercise their respective functions subject to the provisions of this Constitution.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: This is a general transitional provision.
It states that all existing courts, authorities, and officers (judicial, executive, etc.) would continue to function after the commencement of the Constitution.
Their functioning would, however, be subject to the provisions of the new Constitution.
Historical_Context: This article ensured administrative continuity across the entire machinery of the state. It prevented a collapse of the administrative and judicial systems by allowing all existing functionaries to continue in their roles, while making it clear that they were now bound by the new constitutional framework.
Landmark_Cases: This is a general provision for administrative continuity.
Related_Articles: Article 372 (Continuance in force of existing laws)

Title: Provisions as to Judges of High Courts
Original_Description:
(1) Notwithstanding anything in clause (2) of article 217, the Judges of a High Court in any Province holding office immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, unless they have elected otherwise, become on such commencement the Judges of the High Court in the corresponding State, and shall thereupon be entitled to such salaries and allowances and to such rights in respect of leave of absence and pension as are provided for under article 221 in respect of the Judges of such High Court. Any such Judge shall, notwithstanding that he is not a citizen of India, be eligible for appointment as Chief Justice of such High Court, or as Chief Justice or other Judge of any other High Court. 

 

(2) The Judges of a High Court in any Indian State corresponding to any State specified in Part B of the First Schedule holding office immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, unless they have elected otherwise, become on such commencement the Judges of the High Court in the State so specified and shall, notwithstanding anything in clauses (1) and (2) of article 217 but subject to the proviso to clause (1) of that article, continue to hold office until the expiration of such period as the President may by order determine.

 

(3) In this article, the expression “Judge” does not include an acting Judge or an additional Judge.
Simplified_Description: The Judges of a High Court in any Province holding office immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, unless they have elected otherwise, become the Judges of the High Court of the corresponding State. They are entitled to such salaries and allowances and to such rights in respect of leave of absence and pension as are provided for under article 221.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: This was a transitional provision for High Court judges.
Judges of the High Courts in the former British provinces who were in office before the Constitution automatically became judges of the High Courts in the corresponding new states.
It contained similar provisions for judges in the High Courts of the former princely states.
Historical_Context: Similar to Article 374 for the Supreme Court, this article ensured a smooth transition for the High Courts. It allowed sitting judges to continue in office under the new constitutional setup, preserving the continuity and experience of the higher judiciary at the state level.
Landmark_Cases: This was a transitional provision for the judiciary.

Title: Provisions as to Comptroller and Auditor-General of India
Original_Description: The Auditor-General of India holding office immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, unless he has elected otherwise, become on such commencement the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India and shall thereupon be entitled to such salaries and to such rights in respect of leave of absence and pension as are provided for under clause (3) of article 148 in respect of the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India and be entitled to continue to hold office until the expiration of his term of office as determined under the provisions which were applicable to him immediately before such commencement.
Simplified_Description: The Auditor-General of India holding office immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, unless he has elected otherwise, become the Comptroller and Auditor- General of India. He shall be entitled to such salaries and to such rights in respect of leave of absence and pension as are provided for under clause (3) of article 148.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: This was a transitional provision for the head of the audit institution.
The person holding the office of Auditor-General of India before the Constitution automatically became the first Comptroller and Auditor-General (CAG) of India under the new Constitution.
Historical_Context: This article ensured continuity for the crucial office of the supreme audit institution of the country, allowing the pre-existing head to transition into the new constitutional role of the CAG.
Landmark_Cases: This is a transitional provision.

Title: Provisions as to Public Service Commissions
Original_Description:
(1) The members of the Public Service Commission for the Dominion of India holding office immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, unless they have elected otherwise, become on such commencement the members of the Public Service Commission for the Union and shall, notwithstanding anything in clauses (1) and (2) of article 316 but subject to the proviso to clause (2) of that article, continue to hold office until the expiration of their term of office as determined under the rules which were applicable immediately before such commencement to such members.

 

(2) The members of a Public Service Commission of a Province or of a Public Service Commission serving the needs of a group of Provinces holding office immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, unless they have elected otherwise, become on such commencement the members of the Public Service Commission for the corresponding State or the members of the Joint State Public Service Commission serving the needs of the corresponding States, as the case may be, and shall, notwithstanding anything in clauses (1) and (2) of article 316 but subject to the proviso to clause (2) of that article, continue to hold office until the expiration of their term of office as determined under the rules which were applicable immediately before such commencement to such members.
Simplified_Description: The members of the Public Service Commission for the Dominion of India holding office immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, unless they have elected otherwise, become on such commencement the members. The members of a public service commission serving the needs of a group of Provinces or of a state or territory holding office before such commencement shall, notwithstanding anything in clauses (1) and (2)
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: This was a transitional provision for the Public Service Commissions.
Members of the pre-Constitution Public Service Commission for the Dominion of India became the members of the new Union Public Service Commission (UPSC).
Similarly, members of the Provincial Public Service Commissions became members of the corresponding State Public Service Commissions (SPSCs).
Historical_Context: This article ensured the continuity of the independent recruitment bodies at both the Union and State levels. It allowed the experienced members of the old commissions to transition into their new constitutional roles, ensuring that the process of merit-based recruitment to public services was not disrupted.
Landmark_Cases: This is a transitional provision.

Title: Special provision as to duration of Andhra Pradesh Legislative Assembly
Original_Description: Notwithstanding anything contained in article 172, the Legislative Assembly of the State of Andhra Pradesh as constituted under the provisions of sections 28 and 29 of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, shall, unless sooner dissolved, continue for a period of five years from the date referred to in the said section 29 and no longer and the expiration of the said period shall operate as a dissolution of that Legislative Assembly.
Simplified_Description: Legislative Assembly of the State of Andhra Pradesh as constituted under the provisions of sections 28 and 29 of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: This was a one-time special provision for the Legislative Assembly of Andhra Pradesh.
It fixed the duration of the assembly that was constituted after the creation of the state of Andhra Pradesh under the States Reorganisation Act, 1956.
It is now obsolete.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 7th Amendment Act, 1956, to deal with the specific situation arising from the formation of the new state of Andhra Pradesh by merging the old Andhra State and the Telugu-speaking areas of Hyderabad state. It was a purely transitional provision to set the term of the first assembly of the newly formed state.
Landmark_Cases: This was a transitional provision and is no longer operative.

Title: Power of the President to remove difficulties
Original_Description:
(1) The President may, for the purpose of removing any difficulties, particularly in relation to the transition from the provisions of the Government of India Act, 1935, to the provisions of this Constitution, by order direct that this Constitution shall, during such period as may be specified in the order, have effect subject to such adaptations, whether by way of modification, addition or omission, as he may deem to be necessary or expedient:

 

   Provided that no such order shall be made after the first meeting of Parliament duly constituted under Chapter II of Part V.

 

(2) Every order made under clause (1) shall be laid before Parliament.

 

(3) The powers conferred on the President by this article, by article 324, by clause (3) of article 367 and by article 391 shall, before the commencement of this Constitution, be exercisable by the Governor-General of the Dominion of India.
Simplified_Description: The President may, for the purpose of removing any difficulties, particularly in relation to the transition from the Government of India Act, 1935, to the provisions of this Constitution, by order direct that this Constitution shall have effect subject to such adaptations.
Subject: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
Key_Points: Granted the President the power to 'remove difficulties' during the transition to the new Constitution.
The President could, by order, direct that the Constitution would have effect with certain adaptations or modifications to overcome any transitional problems.
This power was temporary and could only be exercised until the first meeting of the duly constituted Parliament.
Historical_Context: This was a crucial enabling provision that gave the executive the flexibility to resolve any unforeseen issues that might arise in the initial period of implementing a complex new constitution. It was a necessary tool to ensure a smooth transition from the old colonial legal framework to the new republican one. This power is now no longer available.
Landmark_Cases: This was a transitional power and is no longer operative.

Title: Short title
Original_Description: This Constitution may be called the Constitution of India.
Simplified_Description: This Constitution may be called the Constitution of India. This Constitution may also be called
Subject: Short title, Commencement, Authoritative Text in
Key_Points: This article provides the official short title of the document.
The official name is 'the Constitution of India'.
Historical_Context: Every major statute has a 'short title' clause for ease of reference. This article formally names the foundational legal document of the country.
Landmark_Cases: This is a formal, non-litigious article.
Related_Articles: This is the concluding part of the Constitution.

Title: Commencement
Original_Description: This article and articles 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 60, 324, 366, 367, 379, 380, 388, 391, 392 and 393 shall come into force at once, and the remaining provisions of this Constitution shall come into force on the twenty-sixth day of January, 1950, which day is referred to in this Constitution as the commencement of this Constitution.
Simplified_Description: This article and articles 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 60, 324, 366, 367, 379, 380, 388, 391, 392 and 393 shall come into force at once. The remaining provisions of this Constitution shall come in force on the twenty-sixth day of January, 1950.
Subject: Short title, Commencement, Authoritative Text in
Key_Points: Specifies the dates on which the Constitution came into force.
A few articles (related to citizenship, elections, oath of the President, and some transitional provisions) came into force immediately on November 26, 1949, the day the Constitution was adopted.
The remaining provisions of the Constitution came into force on January 26, 1950, which is referred to as the 'commencement of this Constitution' and is celebrated as Republic Day.
Historical_Context: The two-stage commencement was for practical reasons. Provisions related to citizenship and elections were needed immediately to prepare for the new republic. The date January 26 was chosen for the full commencement to commemorate the Purna Swaraj (Complete Independence) declaration of 1930.
Landmark_Cases: This is a historical and formal article.
Related_Articles: Preamble (which states the date of adoption as November 26, 1949)

Title: Authoritative text in the Hindi language
Original_Description:
(1) The President shall cause to be published under his authority, —

 

(a) the translation of this Constitution in the Hindi language, signed by the members of the Constituent Assembly, with such modifications as may be necessary to bring it in conformity with the language, style and terminology adopted in the authoritative texts of Central Acts in the Hindi language, and incorporating therein all the amendments of this Constitution made before such publication; and

 

(b) the translation in the Hindi language of every amendment of this Constitution made in the English language.

 

(2) The translation of this Constitution and of every amendment thereof published under clause (1) shall be construed to have the same meaning as the original thereof and if any difficulty arises in so construing any part of such translation, the President shall cause the same to be revised suitably.

 

(3) The translation of this Constitution and of every amendment thereof published under this article shall be deemed to be, for all purposes, the authoritative text thereof in the Hindi language.]
Simplified_Description: The President shall cause to be published under his authority, — (a) the translation of this Constitution in the Hindi language, signed by the members of the Constituent Assembly, with such modifications as may be necessary to bring it in conformity with the language, style and terminology adopted in the authoritative texts of Central Acts.
Subject: Short title, Commencement, Authoritative Text in
Key_Points: Empowers the President to publish an authoritative translation of the Constitution in the Hindi language.
This includes the translation of all subsequent amendments.
This Hindi translation is deemed to be the authoritative text for all purposes.
Historical_Context: This article was inserted by the 58th Amendment Act, 1987. Since the original Constitution was drafted and adopted in English, this provision was necessary to fulfill the constitutional aspiration of promoting Hindi (under Article 343) by providing an official and authoritative version of the Constitution in the official language of the Union.
Landmark_Cases: This article provides for the official Hindi text of the Constitution.

Title: Repeals
Original_Description: The Indian Independence Act, 1947, and the Government of India Act, 1935, together with all enactments amending or supplementing the latter Act, but not including the Abolition of Privy Council Jurisdiction Act, 1949, are hereby repealed.
Simplified_Description: The Indian Independence Act, 1947, and the Government of India Act, 1935, are repealed. The Abolition of Privy Council Jurisdiction Act, 1949, is repealed.
Subject: Short title, Commencement, Authoritative Text in
Key_Points: This article formally repeals the prior constitutional laws that governed India.
It repeals the Indian Independence Act, 1947, which had created the Dominions of India and Pakistan.
It also repeals the Government of India Act, 1935, which had served as the interim constitution.
Historical_Context: This final article of the Constitution marks the definitive legal break from British rule. By repealing the Acts of the British Parliament that had previously governed India, the Constitution of India, created by the Indian people themselves, became the supreme and sole source of law and authority for the nation.
Landmark_Cases: This is a formal article marking a constitutional transition.
Related_Articles: Article 372 (which continues existing laws made under the repealed Acts, as long as they are consistent with the new Constitution)
